The bare-boned simplicity of 10 Items or Less is more a strength than a liability.
I have to hand it to Hardwicke: I was a lot less bored by The Nativity Story than I feared I'd be.
On the one hand, no one with a conscience should buy a diamond unless he or she knows where it came from. On the other hand, should Zwick really be using a glorified action movie to scold us?
Meyers' movies would be far less offensive if they were simply shiny, shallow entertainments. But they always read like pronouncements, monitor readings of how 'real' women think and feel.
Some people will see The Pursuit of Happyness as a glorification of capitalism, but the movie is much less about 'getting' than it is about 'not having.'
With The Good German, Soderbergh -- generally a terrific and creative filmmaker -- apes a style, and a way of seeing, that he clearly doesn't understand. It feels like a hit to the stomach.

Best of all may be the narration, by Sam Shepard: His voice, the kind of voice God might have if he'd ever smoked Camels, frames this gentle but potent little story with good-natured authority, making it feel modern and ageless at once.

Curran, his actors and screenwriter Ron Nyswaner have made an old-fashioned melodramatic epic that, as steeped as it is in the language and tradition of old movies, is never less than thrummingly alive.
Eastwood is so busy humanizing Japanese soldiers that he ends up rewriting history.
Even in a picture where the smallest gears all work perfectly and harmoniously, Emmanuel Lubezki's cinematography is a unifying and galvanizing force.

The movie pulls off a neat trick, using animation to show how, when Potter is alone with her animal creations, they leap around on the page or wink at her with unapologetic cheekiness. They're alive, and they're in charge.
It's a product that promises magic, and yet gives us nothing to live on.
De Niro seems to be good with actors but less successful at stringing a movie together, and keeping it together, scene by scene.

Cassavetes -- a sometime actor himself -- doesn't seem to understand actors at all. From the finished product, it looks as if his preferred method of guiding his actors is to egg them on rather than nudge them toward restraint.
The flaws in Flags of Our Fathers are at least partly attributable to Eastwood's attempts to do too much. Still, even when he overreaches, he somehow hits the mark.
It's not only one of the great fantasy pictures but one of the great end-of-childhood elegies.
A buoyant, passionately sympathetic dream-bio.

It's a comedy, a political thriller, a love story: Barry Levinson's Man of the Year tries to be all things to all people and fails on every count -- a little like the generic, ineffectual politicians it's pretending to excoriate.
Forest Whitaker shatters abstraction and replaces it with flesh, blood and unspeakable charm.
The Queen tears off the royal robe and suggests that, despite what Johnny Rotten said, she is a human being.

Kutcher and Costner have a kind of visual chemistry that's just as elusive as the other kind. And the connection and contrast between them remind us that Hollywood isn't as forgiving of older male actors as we like to think.

The movie is so open about sex, and approaches it with such affectionate bewilderment, that it feels like an anomaly in our so-called sex-obsessed culture: I've felt sleazier looking at ads for Captain Morgan's rum.
Maggie Cheung gives an astonishingly complex performance as a junkie rock star trying to clean up her act.
Comedies for grown-ups, period, are now in such short supply that a good-natured little picture like The Oh in Ohio feels like an anomaly.
Feels far too starched and clean to do its source material justice.
The picture is obviously a satire, but it has no sharpness, no sense of daring.
This is a movie about mothers and children that dispatches with the usual goopy sentiment. Volver reassures us that you can go home again -- if only in the movies.
As listless and phony as Failure to Launch may be, it does have one secret weapon in Zooey Deschanel.

Even though Niccol sometimes puts unnecessary homilies in the mouths of his characters, he mostly pulls off the tricky feat of being direct and breezy at the same time. "Lord of War" skims along like a dance routine.

The uncut Tears of the Black Tiger is more powerful than the cut version, not least for the way it shows that [director Wisit] Sasanatieng, even amid all the craziness, takes care to tie up even the loopiest plot details.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This somber action picture bravely defies expectations and gives us something wholly new.
"Transporter 2" is cheap, shiny, indefensible junk, a Hot Wheels hot rod encased in a glossy plastic blister pack. But come on -- you know you want it.
Even though these puzzles are mapped out with utmost precision -- and even though logic is an extremely useful tool for solving them -- they're still, somehow, objects of intrigue and mystery.
Nestled as it is amid the clamor of the late-summer blockbusters, it's the kind of small pleasure that can make you feel intensely grateful.
Scorsese has put together a fantastic ensemble of actors: Some of the movie's best performances are the ones tucked into the corners, like Alec Baldwin's beefy, arrogant state police honcho.
I couldn't look away, and neither could anyone else in the audience I saw the movie with. We hooted and hollered at the screen, captured by a single involuntary impulse.
The movie has a perversely unifying effect: Muslims, Christians and Jews may not be able to agree on exactly who the heck Jesus is, but they're fully capable of bonding in boredom.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Harrison Ford is outshone by his costars in this crisp, conventional thriller.
It's entirely possible that Gaghan just isn't an actor's director.
Anne Hathaway is Patricia Field's latest fashion victim in this limp semi-satire.
If it were 20 minutes shorter, it would be that much closer to perfect.
The plot is so convoluted that missing even five minutes at a stretch won't make any difference in your comprehension of the story.
This thriller about books, belief and betrayal covers topical terrain -- JT LeRoy and James Frey, anyone? -- but itself proves unbelievable.
Watching this buoyantly melancholy dark comedy, originally released in 1962, is like discovering a lost world.
I found Blood and Chocolate to be a lovely surprise, an imaginative and visually lush picture firmly rooted in the tradition of gothic romance and elegiac horror films about misunderstood monsters.

Breaking and Entering is so bloodless that even Minghella's best ideas come off as wan and pale. We're aware of the angst and confusion these characters suffer, and yet the movie shows us nothing so messy as real pain.
It doesn't have the momentum, the quick-wittedness, to keep us wondering what's going to happen next.
This, apparently, is the kind of stretch our contemporary great actresses have to look forward to as they near 60.
There are times when the spirit of a movie is enough to get you gliding over its obvious flaws. Waitress, which was directed by the late Adrienne Shelly, is one of those pictures.
Raimi at least manages to make it both huge and human.
Even if you think you know where Lucky You is headed, there's something pleasurable about watching it unfold.
It's Fonda who represents the movie's real lost opportunity. Now that she's back, which filmmaker is going to win the prize for figuring out how to put her gifts, and her looks, to use?
Everything about Once feels unforced and natural.
Feels sluggish and tired; its relentless, not-so-great gags hit with the soft thud of stone-hard bread crumbs.
A glazed, inhuman, cluttered piece of work, a storytelling mishmash that buries the considerable charms of its actors under heavy drifts of silt.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Supposed to be a serious psychological thriller, an unsettling little number designed to creep us out and make us think. But it's really just junk.
As I watched it, I found myself wishing it were just a little loopier. But the picture is still seductive and pleasing.
The picture is clever, somber, quiet: There's just no reason it has to be as deadly boring as it is.
Costner seems to be having some fun playing the respectable guy with an evil secret, but [director] Evans' murky storytelling just weighs him down. Cook has all the charisma of a misshapen mud pie.
Gracie is a gentle, easygoing picture -- it's not exactly dramatically gripping, but somehow, its spirit carries it through.

[Director Dahan's] approach draws more attention to the filmmaking than it does to the life. Dahan seems to believe that chronology is bourgeois: Pure storytelling is all fine and dandy, but he wants us to know he's making art.
It's time to send the Danny Ocean franchise out to sea, for good.

Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer is more ambitious than its predecessor. It's also more cluttered and less fleet: The light, pleasingly casual quality of the first picture has evolved into something forced and metallic.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: In many ways, it's steadfastly adult, a picture that admits, with every frame, a desire to hang on to everything we value about traditional modes of movie storytelling, instead of just trying to figure out what will win big at the box office.
For a movie that's supposed to be about reconnecting with God and ourselves, and cherishing the Earth we live on, Evan Almighty is a surprisingly dispassionate picture.
At the very least, he's raised a warning flag that shouldn't be ignored.
The movie attempts a false ending that doesn't quite work; the picture feels prolonged, dragged out, and its ennui lessens the impact of some of its more terrifying fillips.

Willis' John McClane, with that sly, sideways smile, is like an old acquaintance you don't mind running into. He may be older and balder, but he's none the worse for the wear. And he can still take a punch.
This delicious tale of a rat who cooks is pure joy, a grand achievement -- one of the most beautiful animated pictures ever made.
This is a gangly, confusing sprawl, and yet there are enough patches of beauty scattered throughout that it's impossible to reject it wholesale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Hilarious from moment to moment, but leaving behind both a warm glow and a sting. This is a picture that refuses to fetishize either the ability to conceive or the significance of our place in the universe once we've done so.
Hot Fuzz may not quite hit the same level of raucous mayhem [as Shaun of the Dead]. But I think it's even sharper and funnier, and Wright and Pegg never run out of ideas.
The O.C. may be over, but Adam Brody isn't.
The picture belongs to Salma Hayek.
If these are the only kinds of roles we can conceive for actresses who have grown into their faces, as Keaton has, it's no wonder so many younger performers are seeking the knife.
George Hickenlooper's impressionistic biopic Factory Girl is a strange little affair, and not a wholly successful one.
One of those movies where the small pleasures stack up high enough to dwarf the disappointments.

Venus belongs to O'Toole. This is, hands down, my favorite performance of the year, largely because I love the way O'Toole (and the filmmakers) refuse to yield to the all-too-pervasive idea that it's 'icky' for old people to even think about sex.
There are so many problems with Norbit that when you try to pin one down, another one splooges out elsewhere.
Moving and deeply satisfying.
If there's one thing Music and Lyrics understands, it's the apparent effortlessness of a good pop song, the way, particularly on a bad day, it can seem like a gift floating down from the heavens.
The picture is suspenseful where it counts, and at times, it's truly terrifying. There were moments that made my skin crawl.

I've never seen a picture quite like Days of Glory, which not only illuminates a forgotten patch of history, but also broadens and enriches the idea of what it means to be both a patriot, in the best sense of the word, and a citizen of the world.
Let's cut to the chase: Movies don't get much more dunderheaded than Joel Schumacher's semi-psychological thriller The Number 23.
[Apted's] picture, openhearted and enthusiastic, is partly an ode to Wilberforce and partly a love letter to the simple act of taking action.
Zodiac is all about Fincher's personal enthusiasms and obsessions. It takes a mighty big ego to steal the show from a serial killer. Apparently, Fincher's just the guy for the job.

The picture is very obviously crafted as a fable. Its characters are stereotypes at the beginning, but our focus sharpens as we watch them: They sneak out of the roles we've assigned to them and become people instead.
300, even with its impressive vistas of computer-generated soldiers, is just a throwaway epic.
This sweet, but not cloying, adaptation of Jhumpa Lahiri's delicate novel brings us some wonderful moments.
The picture can't decide between cheap scares or deep thoughts, so it goes for both.
I Think I Love My Wife is first and foremost a sex comedy. But Rock is sharp enough to set it in a world where people of all races share the same dreams and desires -- if not the same real estate.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Reign Over Me is a very gentle picture, intended to soothe us, not to jolt or shock us. But it's so gentle that it lacks any discernible energy.
Shooter is far more complicated than it needs to be, taking more crazy twists and turns than it should.
A sure-footed, restrained picture, in which the characters are allowed to drive the action -- not the other way around.

It asks the rhetorical question, 'So what's wrong with the idea of a guy-guy pairs team?' On the other hand, Jimmy's butt-strutting in that peacock suit, his mincing walk, play right into the stereotypes that boneheads everywhere love to laugh at.
Desperate times call for desperate measures, and Hallström and Wheeler have a great time setting up and embroidering Irving's increasingly elaborate scheme.
Love it or hate it, you sure get your money's worth.
There's a vast, possibly bottomless pit reserved for thrillers that are neither good nor bad enough to be truly entertaining, and James Foley's Perfect Stranger tumbles right into it.
Aqua Teen Hunger Force is clearly designed to appeal to fans of the show. For the rest of us, its appeal may be something of a stretch.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: We never quite know what Willie Stark does stand for, aside from the fact that we're repeatedly told he's a man of the people. Penn's performance has the opacity of solid brick.

Even though Fearless is laced with stunning fight sequences, none of them have lingered in my memory as vividly as Li's face has: His body may begin the story told in Fearless, but his face completes it.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Jacques Audiard's The Beat That My Heart Skipped is a distinctly modern picture with its heart in the '70s: It has the nervous, kinetic energy, and the swaggering pioneer spirit, that marked '70s American filmmaking.
movie_title: De Battre mon Coeur s'est Arrêté (The Beat That My Heart Skipped) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Syndromes and a Century is beguiling and confounding, and I hope to see it again soon: When I do, I suspect I'll understand it even less and yet love it more.
The three stories here are satisfying in a novella-like way. These are vignettes with smudged edges, snapshots of feelings, and yet they feel emotionally complete.
movie_title: Three Times (Zui hao de shi guang) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The movie works neither as a comedy nor as a lame melodrama -- its entertainment value is embarrassingly feeble.

Has so much going for it -- including intelligent performances that mesh beautifully, and a keen understanding of how seemingly small moments can rattle the foundations of families -- that you walk away from it feeling it should add up to more.

The picture is an exercise in exploitation joi de vivre, and your enjoyment of it will depend on your tolerance for shameless, reckless, unredemptive violence with relatively little artistic or spiritual value.
Elizabethtown never quite feels like itself, whatever that self might be; it's as if another, subtly but significantly different movie were desperately trying to break through its skin.

Dave's self-involvement is so extreme that he can't see that the bluntly human weaknesses of the people around him aren't his fault. We both pity him and want to shake him; eventually, though, we just become bored by him.
As hard as the actors work, Jarhead feels false right down to its seductive visuals.
This isn't Sheridan's most complex or richest picture, but there's lots of life to it: This is an unapologetically glossy pop product, powered by a strong, old-fashioned sense of B-movie melodrama.
As historically authentic-looking as Pride & Prejudice is, it has far more invested in emotional authenticity -- you feel engaged every moment.

The movie lures us into that forbidden garden where the funniest things are precisely the things we're not supposed to laugh at, only to yank us out of that paradise and draw our attention to the things it desperately wants us to laugh at.
It balances the exhilaration of independence -- one of the great joys of growing up -- with the sobering realization that being a grown-up means there's no one around to protect you.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit is lively and boisterous, but it also has a quiet heart.
movie_title: Wallace & Gromit: The Curse of the Were-Rabbit (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If Walk the Line isn't the full story of Johnny Cash, it's at least a crucial corner of it, a way of coaxing a legend down to a human scale, without shrinking that legend away to nothingness.
It's magic, but not the loud, shiny kind: It has the texture of worn velvet, or a painstakingly hand-knit sweater stored away for years in tissue paper.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Slowness doesn't necessarily equal beauty or power or profundity.
Brokeback Mountain takes great pains to be a compassionate love story; but the filmmaking itself, self-consciously restrained and desiccated, is inert and inexpressive.
By the end of the picture, you're left marveling at how [Director] Frears has kept the whole thing so crisp and so fun.
Good things do come in big packages. The trick for any filmmaker is to find the small movie within the big one, which is exactly what Peter Jackson does in King Kong.
This is a family, and a movie, where everyone talks at once -- and more often than you'd think, its characters actually come up with something worth saying.
Watching The Producers is simply exhausting.
Terrence Malick may not care much for people, but he never met a tree he didn't like.
Casanova works because it gives in to its nuttier impulses instead of fighting them. It's an absurdly joyous bit of fluff.
... from the casting to the dialogue, "Match Point" just feels pickled in artificiality.
The Intruder ... is exhilarating and exhausting, the kind of picture you don't bounce back from immediately.

Transamerica, the feature debut of writer-director Duncan Tucker, never lets us forget that it's a nonmainstream story about a nonmainstream subject, when ideally, it should simply be a story about a person.
The movie is both ruthlessly critical of its subject and unabashedly affectionate toward him, and Hoffman hits every note so it rings true.
Serenity is a trim little picture of epic proportions.

Even though Prize Winner ultimately asks us to swallow that golfball-size happy pill, Anderson and her not-so-secret weapon Moore are actually clawing their way toward something deeper and far more complex than a cheerful, embroidered slogan.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: It exists largely to entertain and delight, which used to be precisely what summer blockbusters were engineered to do.

Like so many recent thrillers of this ilk, many of them in some way exploiting the 'innocence' of childhood -- the dumb and unpleasant Hide and Seek springs to mind -- Dark Water falls apart in the wind-down.

Wedding Crashers may be the most optimistic Hollywood comedy of the year, because it restores at least some dim hope that directors, writers and actors with actual brains in their heads can somehow triumph over unimaginative studio execs.
In its best sections, it's magically deranged in a way no other filmmaker could even come close to pulling off.
Happy Endings is the kind of self-conscious puzzle picture in which characters behave in ways that serve the plot but in no way resemble things that actual human beings would be likely to do.

The fun and pleasure of sex are relatively easy to put on film. But subtler shades of feeling and doubt, which sometimes change almost from night to night in the early stages of a relationship, are harder to capture, and that's what Winterbottom gets.
Hustle & Flow suspends you in its spell of mood, of feeling, of climate. It's a pop picture that finds its richness in peeling down to the essentials of good storytelling.
The Island is nothing so dull as a total failure. But it has enough surprises up its clingy white sleeve to make you wish it were better.
At least Linklater isn't just picking the bones of his forebears; he honors them as they deserve.
It's ostensibly about adults, but there's nothing remotely adult about it.
Sometimes the profane is sacred.
Like most movies based on old television shows, Dukes is all concept, with a few jokes written into its crevices.
Duma, and the sort of intelligent, visually rich filmmaking it represents, are endangered species.
[A] well-meaning but remote picture.
Red Eye doesn't just stick to the basics -- it reminds us why they still matter.
El Crimen Perfecto is a joyride that leaves you feeling drunk and dizzy and swearing that you haven't touched a drop.
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Meirelles clearly trusts his actors, particularly Fiennes and Weisz: The plot of The Constant Gardener is fairly intricate, but in the end, the story is told mostly in their faces.
The picture is outrageously predictable and somewhat poky, but there's also something admirably bold about the way it so adamantly demands we swallow its hokum.
Schreiber leaves the whimsy faucet dripping for far too long.
Those who didn't see the theatrical production (myself among them) might be left wondering if the material looked this phony on stage.
Tim Burton's Corpse Bride is a lush, modern valentine to old-fashioned sentiment, and to old-fashioned moviemaking, too.

Just Like Heaven is really nothing more than your standard love-from-beyond-the-grave squishfest (even though the heroine isn't actually dead) done up in the dumb bonnet-and-bloomers get-up of contemporary romantic comedy.
If you bring an eye mask and a few sleeping pills, you should get through it OK.

This is serious grown-up entertainment with a sense of history and a sense of style, the kind of picture almost no one knows how to - - or, perhaps more accurately, can find the means to - - make anymore.
This is that rare movie version of a great novel in which watching is reading.

The problem with Munich is that Spielberg has made a beautifully crafted, intelligent picture that raises some very complicated, and not easily dismissed, moral questions -- only ultimately to find the easiest way to dismiss them.

...a movie that perfectly captures the vibe of a person, a place, a time and a way of being, and even gets, indirectly and without a whiff of sanctimoniousness, to the heart of what being an American ought to mean.
The Ringer, for all its glaring flaws, pulls the rug out from under us.
Sometimes it takes a sports movie to remind us how far we've come as a country -- and to marvel at how we got here at all, in our awkward combination of leaps and baby steps.

The problem with contemporary Hollywood isn't that so many of the movies it's churning out are based on formula; it's that so many directors take perfectly good formulas and wreck them with bad filmmaking.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Cohen's songs are both universal and deeply personal. Even when we're listening to him alone in our room, we still feel like part of the world.
Superman, born in 1938, is still very much alive in 2006. The Man of Steel has so skillfully bent the bars of our imagination that he seems real to us. And in a sense, he is.
Calling a summer movie 'action-packed' is supposed to be a compliment, but there's nothing so tedious as nonstop excitement.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Heading South is a seemingly straightforward and simple picture that's really defiantly complex, sexually, politically and emotionally.
You, Me and Dupree seems to have been made by people who don't know the difference between a light comedy and an inconsequential one.

Lady in the Water challenges us to believe in the power of myth. But the big challenge here is surviving the tedium of Shyamalan's meandering inventiveness. What's supposed to be fanciful storytelling is really just audience punishment.
Smith, an inherent optimist, has made a movie full of crude humor that also manages to explore the enduring qualities of friendship.

Little Miss Sunshine isn't the kind of movie you want to beat up on: It's sweet-tempered at its core, and even when it's trying too hard to reinforce its own quirks, the charms of its actors filter through effortlessly.

Essentially a string of gags loosely looped together, a set of absurd situations for the actors to clown their way through, Talladega Nights is an affable entertainment, both a celebration and a satire of lowbrow pleasures.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Even when Stone is clumsy, he at least seems to recognize that he can't possibly re-create the experience of these policemen: The best he can do is put it onstage, reminding us that this happened to someone else and not to us.
I couldn't spoil the plot if I wanted to, since I have no idea how it all ties together.

I have vague recollections of some of the actors' trying too hard, and of places where the story dragged like a tired peacock's tail. But ultimately, by God, I succumbed to the picture's faux-laudanum haze.

Between the gangsters and the showgirls, the gorgeous costumes and the wowser production numbers, Idlewild has just about everything a popular entertainment can offer. It also has a soul, and that comes free with the price of a ticket.
There's a danger in reducing pictures like this to the sum of their lessons, at the expense of recognizing them as satisfying, if flawed, genre exercises.
The picture, deliciously, catches MPAA representatives in one lie after another, picking up on their backtracking and doublespeak about their motives and modes of operation.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ... even though parts of the picture don't quite hold together, in the end, it sticks with you.
The Black Dahlia feels wobbly and uncertain.
It's a stunt more than a movie, and if this is what's passing for intelligent liberal thought in this (or any other) country, we're really in trouble.
Shut Up and Sing is a shout of defiance, a chronicle of the price we have to be willing to pay to stand up for what we believe in.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Part historical fantasy, part lovers-separated-by-death weeper, part New Age fever dream, The Fountain isn't truly horrible, just very, very silly.
Crisply made and highly entertaining.
Even though there were moments in The Magic Flute when I wondered if Branagh hadn't truly gone off his rocker, I found its audacity exhilarating.
Borat is an astonishingly entertaining picture, and it's a testament to Cohen's gifts that he can pull off a feat as extravagant and as fully realized as this one is.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Snakes on a Plane could have been great, good-bad fun. All it had to do was live up to its name.
Whatever A Prairie Home Companion has to say about aging, about death, about the mutability of art, is never stated outright: And yet it's all there in the picture's rambunctious collage of moods.
None of the characters in Cars feel like flesh and blood. None of them feel like family. Instead, they're just a means to an end -- vehicles and nothing more.
The Break-Up doesn't know whether it wants to be a facile, enjoyable date movie or an unnerving examination of the dark, pockmarked underbelly of everything we expect out of romantic relationships.
Annapolis is less like a movie than a virus -- one that clings so tenaciously to its host genre that it begins to take on the characteristics of a real movie, even though it's just faking.
There's nothing offhand or spontaneous-feeling about Nanny McPhee; it's a highly mechanical piece of work, and its potentially delightful details are wasted.
The movie's delights unfold like an intricate, exotic puzzle: Winterbottom has built a detailed, miniature universe inside a sugar egg.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Charming and surprisingly sharp.
A love letter to the consistency, and the familiarity, of that voice.
There are places where you can see a subtler, angrier picture trying to kick its way out of the one you're watching.

This is one of those lazy, lukewarm pictures that's even more disappointing than a purely bad one, and for one glaring reason: How could Marshall, his writers, and even his actors have let these dogs down so badly?

It's lower on the food chain than a mere exploitation picture because it clings so desperately to the notion that it's a serious movie about violence; it doesn't even have enough integrity to serve up cheap, sick thrills for their own sake.
It's a defiant act of optimistic patriotism. This is what Dave Chappelle's America looks like, and now that we get the idea, there's no reason we can't live in it too.

This is a sturdy little cop thriller, and even when it stretches the bounds of plausibility, you go with it, partly because you believe -- almost against your better judgment -- in what the characters are doing.
With Inside Man -- an ostensibly straightforward, old-fashioned heist movie -- Spike Lee brings together the old New York and the new.
It's fun, for a while, to hang out with the temperamental rock star. But in the end, we can't wait to get away from the man.
As its title suggests, the picture is something of a ballad, an ode to an elusive character who's both quintessentially human and so outlandish he almost seems unreal.

If you're trying to reinvigorate the art of the stylish thriller, the movie you come up with needs to be stylish and it needs to be thrilling. Basic Instinct 2, written by Leora Barish and Henry Bean and directed by Michael Caton-Jones, is neither.
Our curiosity about the answer to the question 'What's a nice kid like you doing in a joint like this?' may be the only thing that keeps us watching.
While we may be able to pretty much guess everything that's going to happen in Take the Lead, its considerable charm lies in the way it fulfills, rather than bucks, our expectations.
Mol's portrayal of Bettie Page is likely to at last earn her the recognition she deserves.
Even in light comedy, Ejiofor is a commanding presence. As queen or king, he rules.
The jokes in American Dreamz whiz by with speed and grace, and Weitz maintains control of the material every minute.

I've never had a more excruciating moviegoing experience in my life, and as brilliantly crafted -- and as adamantly unexploitive -- as the picture is, it still leaves you wondering why it was made in the first place.
Watching Mission: Impossible III, I kept wishing I was at home watching episodes of Alias instead.
The last third of the picture drags along listlessly -- by the end, we feel dusty and worn out, a little too tired to see Harlan for the romantic, tragic figure that he is.
Poseidon, which cost some $160 million to make, certainly qualifies as a big movie. But it's the kind of 'big' that you forget almost as soon as you've left the theater.

Howard doesn't move the story along as quickly or as smartly as he should. (It's a sad state of affairs when Hanks' character is actually asked to utter the words 'We have to get to the library, fast!')
The Last Stand is a hugely ambitious picture, and it would have been far more successful if Ratner had scaled it down to focus more on the interaction between the characters.

There are some funny gags interspersed among the undistinguished ones, but Wang's direction has little snap or wit, and the movie overall is too fixated on the laborious task of massaging our universal self-esteem.
Dong, at just 66 minutes, is filmmaking that feels expansive and compact at once. And it makes just a half-day of moviegoing feel incomparably rich.
John Travolta is no Divine. And this shiny musical just doesn't have the crazy, messy charm of John Waters' original.
Sometimes movies make sense in a logical way; sometimes they make only emotional sense. No Reservations makes no damned sense at all.
Synecdoche, New York strives to be a work of greatness. But Kaufman's overarching vision is a lot less interesting than the small insights he gathers along the way.

The jokes are forced, almost mechanical, in their crudeness. They're so carefully placed that they feel a little precious rather than spontaneous, which ends up defying that impulsive, animal thing inside us.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The only good reason to see the otherwise dismal comedy Soul Men is to have a look at the late actor and comedian Bernie Mac in one of his final screen roles.
The equivalent of trying to sneak an issue of Newsweek into the house, rolled up inside a copy of Mad magazine.

Not everything in life, or in history, needs to be framed in terms of things children can relate to. I'm not talking about shielding kids; I'm just saying that some ideas are so horrific that they shouldn't be framed in childish terms.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Quantum of Solace is best when director Marc Forster allows his star the latitude to explore emotions that, until Craig stepped into the shoes of the character, we didn't know Bond had.
Bolt, with its numerous winks and nudges, reminds us how attuned we are to the falseness of pop culture, which isn't the same thing as connecting us with its truths.

Twilight is, by its very nature, all about unfinished business, the story of a brooding, caring romantic hero and the woman who cannot -- although she wants to -- yield to him. Only his eyes penetrate her. For now, that's enough.
Calling a Baz Luhrmann movie a crazy mess isn't necessarily a damning statement. But it isn't an automatic compliment, either.
The Transporter movies are considered by many to be a guilty pleasure, and maybe I'd feel that way, too, if I ever felt any guilt at the movies.
Howard has made a picture for grown-ups, a well-constructed entertainment that neither talks down to its audience nor congratulates it just for showing up.

Normally, Jolie is an actress capable of both intensity and subtlety, but her performance here is too amped up to register as anything more than a star turn. Did nobody notice that the real Angelina had been snatched?

Martin, who also wrote the script, takes liberties with the Chess story, most notably dispensing altogether with Phil Chess. But "Cadillac Records" is such an exhilarating, spirited piece of work that its embellishments and omissions cease to matter.
Gran Torino, whatever its flaws are, is a movie about what America looks like now, and it posits that the work of living amicably together is sometimes hard but always worth it.
Nothing in Doubt -- which Shanley directed, adapting his own Pulitzer Prize-winning stage play -- is certain, definitive or clear. Least of all the filmmaking.
As holiday heartwarmers go, Seven Pounds is so unintentionally ghoulish, it makes Black Christmas look like It's a Wonderful Life.
With Yes Man, Carrey has bled the well dry, doing everything he knows how to do, over and over again, just to prove that he still knows how to do it.
The style is willing. But the spirit is weak.
The movie is ultimately less about the pain of loss than about the way families often take shape around a pet.
Even if you can get past the boneheaded premise, the picture feels halfhearted in its construction.
Notorious is surprisingly and pleasantly unflashy, a straightforward picture that makes a distinction between classiness and bling.
Over and over again, characters in Inkheart wax eloquent on the power of books. But there's nothing in the movie as haunting or as compelling as the sound they make when they speak for themselves.
[Director] Morel keeps Taken moving swiftly. It's never dragged down by excess feelings; instead, it's powered by the potency of the right ones.
[A] drearily cheerful little picture that isn't nearly as funny or as heartwarming -- or even as topical, given the economic climate -- as it thinks it is.
The Reader comes off as a movie that doggedly follows some dull, preordained text. It's Winslet who dares to read between the lines.
A horror-thriller that's neither horrifying nor thrilling.
Since when shouldn't it be fun to spend 90 minutes or so watching good-looking young people, singing and dancing relatively well?
Latifah is, as always, pure pleasure to watch.
Stern and his lead actor do manage to pull it all together at the end.
Tomb of the Dragon Emperor is more of the same -- and yet less.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's a relief to go to the movies and see teenage girls acting like teenage girls, as opposed to grown women acting like teenage girls.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is so wayward and fuzzy that, for the unbaked, at least, there's very little pleasure to be had in trying to follow it. The thing is so desultory and aimless that it seems like work to try to laugh at it.

Tropic Thunder is ridiculous and deeply enjoyable, but it also flashes a mercilessly polished mirror at the "prestige" products that the movie business so glibly feeds us in order to reflect glory back on itself.

The movie gets more cluttered and confused as it moves along, though it's dotted with so many generic battle scenes and paint-by-numbers light-saber combat sequences that you can see how it's at least attempting to mimic the illusion of excitement.
Death Race is cartoonishly brutal and pleasantly disreputable.
No matter how many jokes you pack around it, arrested development doesn't make for a very compelling dramatic arc.
The House Bunny gets the difference between being openhearted and empty-headed.
Traitor is an earnest, efficient, serviceable thriller that makes a valiant effort to untangle some of the moral complexities of the post-9/11 world.
It's high time for the western to be resuscitated as a genre; a picture that just pokes along amiably isn't enough to get the job done.
Maybe even Rivette himself is a little too delicate for this ferocious, intensely focused pair. But he's fascinated by them, and ultimately, he loves them.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Leoni and Gervais are wonderful together, as much for the ways in which they wobble against each other as for the ways they ultimately mesh.
At the very least, Eagle Eye gives us two principals who are appealing enough to keep us interested in them.
The movie around Lane and Gere is unreal, a tortured construct, but they open a breathing space in its center.
A lovely, exhilarating work about the ways in which failure and frustration can open the pathways through which we make sense out of life.
The movie around them may not have enough shape, contrast and texture. But at least these characters are always moving forward, even if the only sure thing they've got to look forward to is dawn.
With Rachel Getting Married, Demme has once again scaled back, making a picture that has some of the ease and warmth of his earlier movies.

It's like a lumpy, overworked, useless 'objet' that someone who doesn't know you very well might give you as a gift, a thing that sits around the house serving no unearthly purpose other than reminding you, none too subtly, that it's completely hollow.
Body of Lies is excessively intricate and extremely dull, the latest example of a filmmaker giving us a disjointed, overlong movie that's unnecessarily confusing to follow.
Aronofsky pulls all the usual strings in The Wrestler. But in the end the movie works, maybe because the best things about it are things that Aronfsky isn't even conscious of.
A picture so seemingly light that it might be hours (or even days) before you realize how deep and rich it really is.
Stone may not lead the charge against George W. Bush as viciously as he might have. But he doesn't misunderestimate him, either.
If truth is stranger than fiction, it's also, quite often, a lot more boring.
Knightley is up to the task. Her Georgiana is history with a human face.
Nearly everything in Coraline has been painstakingly handmade.
Somewhere along the way, He's Just Not That Into You starts taking all the wrong forks in the road of romance and ends up nowhere.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What is our reward for the collective effort of this prestigious assembly? One of the most dreadfully unnecessary movies in recent memory.
The Hangover is a cut above the typical contemporary guy-friendship comedy.
Land of the Lost is harmless enough. It just isn't, with the exception of a few odd air pockets, particularly funny.
The main sin of Away We Go is simple dullness.
It ambles along uncertainly, hobbled by the lack of chemistry between its two lead actors, and by gags that either try too hard or suffer from being barely there.
A romantic comedy doesn't need to be original to be enjoyable, and yet The Proposal still falls way too short of the mark.
A belabored trifle that's occasionally amusing but often just bewildering, beginning with the movie's intentionally outlandish setup.
Bay seems to think that just showing us a bunch of brightly clashing metallic limbs (accompanied by lots of noise) is enough to make us faint in our seats with excitement.
In the end, Bigelow's point of view is what's most interesting about The Hurt Locker. The picture's strength lies in the details she focuses on.
Chéri is a perfect example of a movie that gets many of the details right and the vibe all wrong.
I Hate Valentine's Day is a horror show masquerading as a romantic comedy. Maybe Vardalos is just in the wrong line of work.
Ultimately an odd blend of frustrating and satisfying.

The looseness Raimi allows himself here results in an especially joyous kind of filmmaking, the sort where the filmmaker's delight in scaring us (and making us laugh) becomes part of the movie's fabric.
Cohen has come up with some marvelous satirical motifs; elsewhere, he's just showing how far he'll go to get a laugh.
The Half-Blood Prince is a beautifully paced feat of filmmaking, one that navigates potentially choppy shifts in scale with grace and ease.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Everything that's wrong, on the surface, with (500) Days of Summer pales in light of everything that's going on beneath its surface.
Until that final, inevitable kiss, we have to listen to them, and the clatter of their crude, brainless exchanges is unbearable.
The jagged rhythms of the movie's dialogue are entertaining in themselves, and it's fun to watch the actors keep their lines spinning and bouncing off each other.
Funny People is an ambitious, misshapen picture that feels like two, maybe even three, separate movies uncomfortably jammed into one.
Cold Souls works precisely because its ambitions are somewhat mellow; this isn't a relentlessly high-strung picture.
Ephron does the smart thing in Julie & Julia and lets Streep carry the day, with a minimum of embellishment.
There's not much [McAdams] or Bana can do to rescue this dreary piece of romantic hooey.
Ponyo hasn't changed my mind about Miyazaki. But I'm willing to accept and enjoy this little window into the dream life of fish.
My One and Only is an affectionate picture, set in the early 1950s, that coasts breezily on its charm and style.

R.J. Cutler's vibrant and mischievous documentary The September Issue is only partly a movie about fashion. At its heart, it's really a movie about work, about the ways individuals compete with, grate against and inspire one another in the workplace.
I Love You, Beth Cooper moves along, taking two steps backward into crassness for every clever or just plain sweet moment it offers.
Its charms appear to have been applied with surgical precision; by the end, I felt expertly sutured, but not much else.
Whatever its flaws may be, it at least refuses to be a stiff, lifeless relic.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Terminator Salvation is so programmed, so impersonal, that it practically dares you to warm to its characters.
The International is so self-assured, so assertive in its devotion to craftsmanship, that it proves Tykwer is continually building on his promise as a filmmaker, not squandering it.
As an alternative to the Hollywood mainstream, which doesn't provide many good roles for African-American actors, Perry's movies are at least a stopgap solution. It's just too bad they're not better.

An interesting failure, a movie that at least strives to be about something, entangling itself with the question of what it means to be an American -- or, more specifically, what it means to deserve to live here.
The refusal of Tokyo! to proffer even the most perfunctory air kiss is what makes it so intriguing.
Miss March is, to use the vernacular of the escapist moviegoer, the biggest pile of crap I've seen in ages.
Although Adams and Blunt work hard at giving dimension to their characters, they can't overcome the fact that the story is essentially a greatest hits of family trauma.

The marvelous thing about John Hamburg's new comedy, I Love You, Man, is that rather than conforming to fit into some preexisting trend, it recognizes and even exalts in the reality that close male friendships can be a source of confusion and awkwardness.
I started out loving Duplicity; by the end, I wanted to strangle it.
If Alex Proyas' Knowing were reasonably entertaining -- instead of just dour, pointless and tedious -- it would be a camp classic.

MvA isn't, and isn't pretending to be, as ambitious a project as Pixar's almost universally lauded Wall-E was. But does it have to feel like something that's just rolled off a conveyor belt, made according to an exacting but dull set of specifications?
There's enough sweetness, and enough just-under-the-surface intelligence, in "The Education of Charlie Banks" to suggest that Durst may have a future as a filmmaker.
Fast & Furious spends a lot of time advertising how exciting it is, without actually being exciting.
The whole thing is calibrated to wow us with its weirdness, even as it assumes an air of 'Who, me?' guilelessness. I've seen slick, glossy Hollywood thrillers made with less knowing calculation.
Assorted conflicts and adventures ensue, and the movie overall is painless if not exactly electrifying.

State of Play does get a little creaky in its last third -- at that point it needs to be more streamlined, more concise. But Macdonald and the screenwriters manage to weave their ideas through a sturdy-enough plot, so we never feel we're being preached to

17 Again takes a while to get cooking, and at times it just feels like a pale imitation of 13 Going on 30. Still, it's often breezily entertaining, partly thanks to Efron, who certainly knows how to be cute.
In Crank: High Voltage, Statham just looks miserable, as if appearing in this lousy picture just sucked all the heart right out of him.
In the end, The Soloist is about how unknowable other people really are -- an idea that's terrifying until you step back and see the wonder of it.
Obsessed takes far too long to get cooking, and it works so hard at not being exploitation that it loses sight of its reasons for existing in the first place.

The problem with Wolverine isn't that the mythology is detailed and potentially confusing. The bigger issue is that "Wolverine" is so uninvolving that you might not care whether you remember what happened 10 minutes ago.

With Star Trek Abrams honors the show's legacy without fossilizing its best qualities. Instead, he's whisked it off to a planet where numbing nostalgia can't kill it, and where the future is still something to look forward to.
Objectified is so straightforward, sensible and thought-provoking that it alleviates that design noise instead of adding to it.
Ron Howard's follow-up to the stiff, stately 2006 The Da Vinci Code, might have been classy, entertaining junk -- if only it were entertaining.
The magic of Summer Hours is that even in its elusiveness, it gives us something to hang onto.
Management is ultimately undone by its own bland idiosyncrasies. It's nothing but a mismanaged opportunity.

Carter doesn't try to meet or exceed fans' expectations so much as create an intimately scaled dramatic universe for his fiercely beloved characters, Dana Scully and Fox Mulder, to inhabit, circa 2008.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stupid, crude and hilarious, Step Brothers works by sneaking past our better judgment.
Before I Forget is, in the broad sense, 'gay-themed'. But it's also one of the loveliest, most direct and most devastating pictures about aging that I've ever seen.
When Brosnan opens his mouth, the wrong sounds come out. And yet they're among the few things in Mamma Mia! that feel anything close to right.

Instead of painting a tiny, cramped picture intended only for the elite, it opens up one small corner of the world for everybody. Control is proof of the way the music of someone else's life can suddenly and magically become your own.
The Golden Age is frustrating because Kapur does seem to have a taste for nutball pageantry -- he just won't let himself go all the way with it.
This is a sturdily poetic movie, rendering in black-and-white a world where nothing ever is.

If these new, allegedly topical movies are to make us feel anything -- to move us toward any action or even just toward any fresh realization -- they need to at least seem alive on the screen, instead of just courting our polite, measured applause.

Reservation Road is all about the darkness that lurks in the hearts of men, and although it's dark in there, all right, the power of redemption is always a possibility. This dour, ponderous picture just can't show the way.
There's nothing groundbreaking about Dan in Real Life -- it's a picture that could have been made 10 or 20 years ago -- and yet its easygoing, affable nature is exactly what makes it pleasurable.
Before long, the story's conceit -- a loud-and-clear metaphor for the ways in which we all sometimes feel alien when it comes to human relationships -- just becomes wearying.
As a piece of storytelling -- built on the foundation of a great story -- it's an epic that's been sliced and diced into so many little morsels that almost nothing in it has any weight.

Bee Movie just lacks spirit and energy. Part of the problem may be that, as far as I'm concerned, any animated movie released this year (and possibly in years to come) suffers in comparison with Brad Bird's Ratatouille.
Even though Vaughn knows how to build a pretty good performance out of little more than exasperated eye-rolling, he's just coasting here, and his scenes with Giamatti have no weight and no energy.
The movie may use a lot of words, but it doesn't mince them, and its very directness is a relief.
Gratingly unfunny, mean-spirited Farrelly brothers flick.
Forget the heat of passion: The movie never breaks a sweat.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's bad enough that the movie is about uninteresting people's problems. What's worse is that it's about snobs, and Baumbach buys into their snobbery.
Of all the war-themed pictures that have been released so far this fall, it stands apart, and it stands alone: Redacted is confrontational, rough, immediate and confounding.
one of the most inventive and joyous movies of the year.
The picture feels both intimate and immediate, a model for what smart young filmmakers can do with good material.
The picture is so beautiful to look at that it's practically buoyant.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is the kind of movie that was made by throwing dollars at stuff, as opposed to using imagination, thought or even just common sense.
Wright has made a film that honors the imaginative responsibility of an adapter.
The Perfect Holiday is so modest and good-natured that its flaws are hardly glaring.
I Am Legend is a blockbuster like no other, one that finds its grandness in modesty. It's a star vehicle with a star who knows his place in the universe.

While a movie doesn't have to make literal sense to be good, a filmmaker can't be so lost in his own universe that he forgets his job is to open it out to the rest of us. And that, apparently, is what has happened to Coppola here.
A terrific tale of political wheeling and dealing.
Beowulf is ambitious, overbearing and hollow; it goes overboard to impress, yet it never feels truly inventive or imaginative.

Feels less like a breathing, thinking movie than an exercise. That may be partly because it's an adaptation of a book by a contemporary author who's usually spoken of in hushed, respectful, hat-in-hand tones.
The sex scenes -- intense, affecting and emotionally raw -- are the best thing about this frustratingly limp movie.
The picture is made with a degree of care, and what's surprising about it is the way [director] Berg actually resists making rah-rah jingoistic proclamations instead of relying on them.

The picture works because, despite the fact that it took nearly six years for the filmmakers to bring it to the screen, it doesn't strive for greatness. It's fleet, concise and clever in a nut-ball way.
El Cantante disintegrates into a stylized jumble -- even a straightforward jumble would have been preferable.

Was Austen really a smarter, feistier Carrie Bradshaw in more sensible shoes, longing for love even as she failed to hang onto it? Becoming Jane would have been more honest if it had been called No Sex in the Country.
A great action movie, exhilarating and neatly crafted, the kind of picture that will still look good 20 or 30 years from now.
This luminous, magical movie will dazzle even the fantasy-film phobic.

There's no doubt that Rush Hour 3 is anything but a mess. And yet there were moments when I found myself laughing giddily at the inanity of it all, and other moments when the picture was so beautiful to look at that I almost forgot its faults.
Self-consciously quirky on the outside, this gentle teenage fable has an affecting, openhearted core.

The movie doesn't need any superfluous redeeming qualities: Its pleasures and charms lie in its very crudeness, in the way the characters' thoughts begin in their dicks and spill out of their mouths, completely bypassing their brains.
Whatever its faults are, The Nanny Diaries is hardly the disaster that the gossipmongers -- including, perhaps, even the studio that made it -- want us to believe.
Atkinson's Mr. Bean, a man of few words, carries their memory in his rubbery bones. When it comes to knowing where he came from, he's got the beat.
Ultimately, it's a hollow enterprise, all ping and no pong. It doesn't bounce; it splats.
I'd put [Johnnie] To's Exiled into the category of Hong Kong movies that even people who think they don't care about Hong Kong movies should see.
The sum of the movie's exploding parts adds up to nothing -- not even just good, sick fun.
[Director] Mangold succeeds on his own terms, largely because the actors he's working with here, Russell Crowe and Christian Bale, so comfortably inhabit the movie, and the genre that cradles it.
Captain Mike Across America is a shameless act of self-promotion even for a shameless self-promoter like Moore.
It feels like a movie in search of prestige, not truth.
The Mother of Tears is wild and untamed, a celebratory feat of gonzo artistry.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The year 1980 may seem like a long time ago, but Grant's picture is so immediate, and so alive, that it may as well have been yesterday.
This is an indie crowd pleaser that's much more enjoyable -- in other words, not nearly as horrifying -- as Little Miss Sunshine.
George Clooney's subtle, affecting performance is the chief reason to see this super-sincere social drama.
There's a lot to admire in The Brave One. It just doesn't cut as deeply as it needs to.

If nature -- if life -- is as wild and precious as the movie makes it out to be, Hirsch needs to give us something, someone, to watch on-screen. We need to feel a presence before we can take the measure of an absence.
The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford represents a breakthrough in the moviegoing experience. It may be the first time we've been asked to watch a book on tape.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The picture would be nothing, an incomplete Venn diagram, without Murphy.

Anderson is still a maddeningly cool filmmaker. He's remote from his characters, which makes him remote from his movies. There's also a way in which he uses race as a novelty, suggesting an assertively white-kid view of the world.
Walk Hard is funniest in its first half, when you're not quite sure where it's going, and drags in the second, by which time you realize it's going nowhere.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry works hard at not being offensive. It just doesn't work hard enough at being good.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This Sweeney Todd is all subtext and no substance. It starts off large and swaggering but doesn't know where to turn next: Burton seems fixated on serving up an event, to the extent that he neglects to dig into the story.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There Will Be Blood strives for boldness, instead of just being bold. It doesn't cut, and it doesn't bleed.
When Chan and Li match wits, each celebrates the other's presence. This isn't just a martial-arts display; it's generosity and camaraderie in motion.
Even if the picture is softer than it needs to be, it still resists devolving into something warm and squishy.
To his credit, Langenegger keeps things relatively simple instead of resorting to lots of fast cutting and fancy camera angles. To his detriment, the picture he has made barely moves at all.

Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay embraces America's capacity for decency and kindness. The possibility that we could actually be that great country isn't just a pipe dream. Only sometimes you need a pipe to truly believe in it.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Although Downey spends a certain amount of screentime inside that suit, his face still carries the movie, giving it emotional weight.
Even its clichés -- including a dashing rescue on horseback -- are trotted out with bland indifference.
So bereft of intelligence, style and excitement that I can't figure out who in the world it's supposed to appeal to.

Andrew Adamson's The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian is a much more elaborate, ambitious picture than the 2005 The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe, and it adds up to far less.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A marvelously rich visual, intellectual and emotional experience, one that I expect will grow deeper with repeat viewings.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: At his best, Spielberg is certainly capable of tapping, to almost unnerving degree, collective moods and fears and longings, both emotional and cultural.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The show was at its best when it offered, without a great deal of extraneous examination, these glimpses into the nature of friendships between women. The movie needs more of that.
Avnet lays all this stuff out before us with a straight face -- the picture is humorless and witless.
You can tsk-tsk Sandler's penchant for dumb, crass humor all you want, but there's some meaning behind his madness. Is there nothing more human, more humbling, than the idea of smelly feet?
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Get Smart could have been smarter. But like the show that inspired it, it's still smarter than it looks.

The picture, written by Myers and Graham Gordy and directed by Marco Schnabel (no relation to Julian), is listless and pokey, chiefly because watching Myers in this particular guise is almost completely joyless.
Kit Kittredge is a gentle-spirited movie that also acknowledges the fact that we can't -- and shouldn't -- protect kids from everything.
Wanted is fast-moving and bloody, enjoyable even within its unapologetically generic limits. But McAvoy is its real secret weapon.
The picture feels weirdly, and disappointingly, disjointed, something that starts out as poetry and ends as product.
As gorgeous-looking as the picture is, you could never accuse Breillat of anything so banal as good taste.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's the sort of role Smith ought to be able to pull off easily. But even his superpowers apparently have their limits.
A movie that's faithful to an idea, and to a sense of adventure, more than to a specific work.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Poetic, funny, darkly romantic and beautifully structured.
Meet Dave alone may not radically change the course of Eddie Murphy's drooping career. But it is, at least, a little olive branch held out to his audience. And that's better than Nil.
[Ledger gives] a fine performance regardless, and I wish the movie around it were more deserving.
All action and no storytelling.
Forgetting Sarah Marshall follows the Apatow formula faithfully enough. All that's missing is charisma -- the je ne sais quois that makes us fall in love in the first place.
This is a small picture that explodes the boundaries of what size really means. Sometimes it's the smallest gesture that makes you feel most alive.
Memo to the Miramax marketing department: You might want to think about changing that title.
The movie is designed to be uplifting and inspirational, but everything about it is tired and listless. It doesn't so much make you feel the spirit as drain it out of you.

This movie is designed to be fun, and its intentions are signaled to us over and over again, as when the women jump around on a bed, giggling and flinging old, dirty money around in a wanton display of pure idiocy.
Maybe we now live in a world where we record the moment first and feel it later. If that's the case, Cloverfield leaves us waiting to feel.

The picture is unfocused and indistinct; there's a noncommittal quality to the filmmaking. Teeth hinges on one strong idea but doesn't know quite where to take it, wobbling awkwardly between going for laughs and making its semi-delineated points.
This isn't filmmaking; it's thesis defending.
Over and over again, Hoblit misses opportunities to make an engaging picture, instead giving us a merely pedestrian one.
The movie is neither cathartic nor entertaining.
Over Her Dead Body may be the worst romantic comedy I've ever seen, although I hesitate to make such a resolute pronouncement about a movie that's so barely even there.
A semi-adventure and even less of a romantic comedy, only pretends to whip up excitement.

There isn't enough going on in Semi-Pro, comically or otherwise, to sustain the movie even through its first half-hour. This may be one of the most sluggish sports comedies ever made -- even the supposedly rousing final sequence feels belabored.
A genteel soap opera in which the sex and intrigue are so muted, so tasteful, that they practically blow off the screen in a scattering of dust.
The picture has a hapless, meandering quality that's tolerable at first but ultimately becomes maddening, as if it were a cartoon narrative recounted by a distracted 4-year-old.

You need the right actors to make a movie as intelligent and as engaging as this one is, and [director] Donaldson knows how to make each character in this rather complex ensemble seem whole and distinct.
10,000 BC would be much better if it allowed itself the freedom to be kitsch.
Miss Pettigrew is one of those rare cases where a filmmaker's good intentions, and the enthusiasm of his actors, are enough to fill in the cracks.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The performances in Love & Mercy are key to its power: Dano can be a dispassionate, affected actor, but all his arty coolness slips away here.
Works both as a celebration of Bernstein, whose spirit is at once gentle and boldly generous, and as a way of exploring creativity and the meaning it can have in our lives.

There's so much to take in here that at times I almost felt as if I were absorbing it through my skin.
Baumbach's eighth feature isn't just sharp, it's serrated - its jokes, and there are lots of them, come at you with rows and rows of tiny teeth.

The movie Wenders and Juliano have made is a tribute that feels both grand and modest in scale: Just as Salgado's photographs do, it extends the notion of friends and family to include every citizen of the world.

You can feel the good intentions vibrating off the screen, but it's still a listless affair, one that takes forever to go almost nowhere.

For long stretches, it's dull and plodding, chugging along on the fumes of its earnest intentions. Still, there are worse ways to kill two hours than watching Hardy work his sturdy magic.

movie_title: Don't Think I've Forgotten: Cambodia's Lost Rock And Roll (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Everything is just a little off: The plot is resolved too tidily, and Lively appears ill at ease - she's stiff and self-consciously ladylike, as if she were a little embarrassed by the material.
Iris is more than just a movie about an amusing lady who likes clothes an awful lot. It's also a celebration of the revivifying power of creativity ...

Tom Sturridge is too numbly featureless to channel the cruel but sexy Sergeant Troy; they don't call them wooden soldiers for nothing. Sadly, his performance is perhaps the perfect counterpart to Mulligan's.

[Witherspoon] seems unafraid to cut loose, and she and Vergara make a terrific team.
It's hopeful and realistic in equal measure, and it's anchored by a quietly resplendent performance from Danner, who brings a featherduster touch to everything she does.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_title: The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from a characteristically nuanced lead performance by Chiwetel Ejiofor... it's a picture that stays more than a few safe steps away from anything so dangerous as raw feeling.

The remake that came too late, so benign and unmemorable that not even people who loved Park Chan-wook's 2003 original will be able to muster much outrage.

The picture is earnest to a fault, coming off like an exploration of how "the little people" live, so carefully written that it veritably trumpets how remote it is from the grittiness of its subject matter.
The charm of the whole enterprise wears off even before this movie's trim 80 minutes are up.
The sexual politics of Ms. 45 are blunt and easy to read, and the picture is riotously cathartic.
There may not be much behind the sparkling tinsel curtain of David O. Russell's extraordinarily entertaining American Hustle. But what a curtain!

With those eyes that are a little too close together, and that confident swagger that looks as if it could disintegrate into a pratfall at any time, Ferrell makes a grand ringleader for all this nonsense.

movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

A modestly scaled but potent film version of the adaptation, which hews closely to Ibsen's original - except when it doesn't.

The story matters only in that it creates opportunities for heaps of ridiculousness, and writer-director James Bobin (who also directed The Muppets), along with co-writer Nicholas Stoller, mines them skillfully and breezily.

Othello came together in defiance of any unifying principle beyond the scrappy vision of its director. It's a work of seat-of-the-pants grandeur.

movie_review_blurb: The Other Woman doesn't give these actresses much to do except look ridiculous, if not sneaky and conniving.

movie_review_blurb: Every so often there comes a movie so tasteless, so nakedly pandering, so bodaciously ill conceived that you've got to see it to believe it. This year, that movie is Collateral Beauty.
Assassin's Creed is very confusing. No, scratch that: It's a mess.
