There are enough under-the-radar subtleties, rendered with a refreshing lack of smart-aleckiness, to make Zootopia feel current and fresh. It's a modest, unassuming entertainment that's motored by a sly sensibility.
Cumberbatch, both a natural comedian and a subtle one, knows how to get a big laugh from nothing more than an arched eyebrow.
A Monster Calls isn't so much for kids as it is for grownups. It's a reminder of the time when we, too, thought only of ourselves-and found it too much to bear.
Both a dazzling piece of entertainment and a window into history ...
Driver is turning out to be one of the finest actors of the moment, an understated star with a great, non-movie-star face.

Shyamalan's skill as a filmmaker-his instincts for crisp editing, his knack for navigating shifting points of view-have always been stronger than his ideas. That's true here, too, yet Split is compulsively watchable.
All that reincarnating is hard work, and watching it unfold is a slog too.
Kelly and his actors seem anxious not to judge Glatze, but they can't downplay the cutting nature of his betrayal.
Chelsom tunes it to the wavelength of Gardner's isolation.
A compelling document that works as a mini-history of black racial identity in America from the mid- to late-20th century and beyond.
After that kick-ass opening, the picture devolves into an action-action-plot-action-plot-action monotone. Where have all the gags gone?
The pleasures of John Wick: Chapter 2 may be even greater than those of its predecessor-itself a symphonic achievement in scrappy, balls-out, action filmmaking ...
The picture's pleasures are bountiful, particularly for cat lovers ...
If millions of girls or guys go out to see Fifty Shades Darker with their friends for a giggle or two, then the world is a happier place.
My Life as a Zucchini is so warm, so alive, that we forget we're watching cartoon figures.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: So gorgeous to look at, and so effective at layering diaphanous tones of queasiness and anxiety, that you sometimes forget to think about what you're watching, which, in this case, is a good thing.

You might call it The Not-Bad Wall. But as a showcase for Damon's considerable talents, and as a canvas for the gifted Chinese director Zhang Yimou, this ostentatious mythical epic isn't quite the movie it should be.
The story's aims are noble, but it works too hard at scoring its points to succeed as either entertainment or lacerating social commentary.
Its story and dialogue are so straightforward and comforting that even when you think you can hear the next beat coming-and you will-the finale still comes as a cathartic surprise.
I wouldn't want to watch Trey Edward Shults' It Comes at Night alone. Unless you're a particularly sturdy soul, I wouldn't recommend that you do so either.
As Hangover-style dumb entertainments go, it's certainly good enough. Which isn't to say it's anything close to what women want.
It's easy to say, "You've come a long way, baby." Here's someone who walked, or sprinted, every mile.
Lucky was written by Logan Sparks and Drago Sumonja specifically for Stanton, and director Lynch and cinematographer Tim Suhrstedt do him justice in every frame.
Cruise plays Barry as an aw-shucks raconteur, and the routine is amusing at first. But midway through American Made, even Cruise devotees might decide enough is enough.
Green's film has a tense, nervy energy, most of which seems to glow from Gyllenhaal's very core.
You may not be able to afford the shoes, but Michael Roberts' documentary Manolo: The Boy Who Made Shoes for Lizards may bring you almost as much delight.
movie_title: Manolo, The Boy Who Made Shoes For Lizards (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Florida Project is both radiant and unsentimental.
[A] fascinating and admirably adult true-life drama about the creation of the feisty Amazon we think we know so well.
Dense with layers of biblical lore and Greek tragedy, it's like a cake that's impressively tall but also unpalatably dry.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Campillo, who co-wrote the script with AIDS activist and educator Philippe Mangeot, captures the mood of an era with a specificity that's by turns somber and joyous.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Square is both outlandishly funny and biting-and features a fascinating and sometimes disturbing performance by Terry Notary.

Thor: Ragnarok is packed tight with zooming space vehicles and noisy thunder battles, but the movie's extravagant excess is more narcotizing than energizing. Even poor Thor seems lost in all of it, and he's supposed to be its star.
Bodaciously entertaining ...
Lady Bird is both generous and joyous, but when it stings, it stings deep.

[Director Rian Johnson's] movie has a sense of humor about itself and a sense of joy, but its emotional generosity, even in the midst of all the extravagant green-screen work, is its best special effect.
For sheer, go-for-broke nuttiness, The Greatest Showman stands alone in the landscape of this holiday season's crop of movies, and I urge you to give it a chance.
The movie is a surprise, the good kind, an instance of a filmmaker zigging just when you're expecting him to zag.
Streep is revered for her great-lady acting, but she's always freshest, and most alive, in comedy. Her performance here is terrific because it's a whirlwind eddy of both.
This is a beguiling, somewhat grisly drama, based on something that happened to one genuinely unhappy, messed-up family.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, the feat these characters pull off is rousing, but 12 Strong never gathers the momentum it needs.
By this point, the franchise has come to rely less on suspense and more on high-speed chases over rugged terrain, generic zombie scare moments and ho-hum virus fixes.
Fanning [is] a performer who never chomps down on a role-she plays Wendy as a person and not a condition.

Black Panther is set largely in Wakanda, with a detour to South Korea. Still, there's no shaking the feeling that this is what America looks like when it's allowed to be its truest, freest self. That's a superhero challenge if ever there was one.
The very averageness of these conscientious, gutsy guys is precisely the point.
Johnson has a sense of Anastasia not just as part of a pristinely arranged tableau but also as a sensualist, with all the attendant nerve endings and complex emotions that that implies.
Justice League is no magic carpet ride, no matter how hard it strives for multi-superhero awesomeness.
First They Killed My Father is a sensitively rendered account of one child's real-life experience, but its broader implications are noteworthy too.
Doesn't cut very deep and isn't very scary.
School Life is a bit woolly in its pacing, but the picture's easygoing structure is part of its charm-it mimics, perhaps, the passage of time at Headfort itself.
Wright has orchestrated every swerve and near smashup -- and one glorious foot chase -- with precision, a rarity in action filmmaking these days.
Looking for a break from the Black Death, or even just the summer heat? The Little Hours is just the thing.
The Minions have proved they can't headline a movie, yet they pretty much carry this one. How do they do it?

There's ape betrayal, ape bravery, ape joy and lots of ape action in War for the Planet of the Apes. Yet the picture's plot mechanics aren't nearly as significant or as memorable as its characters are.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is an intricate, high-reaching piece of film-making, and there are places where the mechanics don't run as smoothly as they should. But the film's beauty runs so deep, it doesn't matter.

It's a relief to see a superhero engaged in deeply human activities, like getting ready for a date... This Spider-Man is still just a kid, after all, and he has no energy for existential angst -- just dealing with hormones is enough.
Like a wild, sonorous piano chord struck by someone or something in the middle of the night--where did that come from?--the contemplative aura of A Ghost Story sticks with you.
This is a grand spectacle, not an empty one, a rare example of the Hollywood blockbuster dollar well spent.
The plot is beside the point. Besson loads the picture with enough loopy visual splendor to keep us pleasurably distracted for long stretches.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The actors are all terrific: as Ali, Quinn has a radiant wildcat sweetness--there's fragility behind all that hissing. And Slate, with her marvelous, helium-tinged voice, is a pure pleasure to watch.
Girls Trip is just fun, a movie that-even within the context of its broad, exaggerated humor-never seems to be trying too hard.
A sweet-natured picture with an undercurrent of prickly energy.
Glowering from beneath the bangs of her moonbeam-platinum bob, Theron's Broughton is equal parts air, light and iron. We're just the moths clustering around her flame.
It could use more magic, more dread, a more staggering sense of wonder. It's wholly inoffensive, but it's unmemorable too. This is a fantasy that runs like a business.
Realistically, it's probably not possible to dance your cares away. But the determination of these girls makes you believe in it.

Pattinson is the real reason to see it: his Connie, wiry and intense, with beady, cracked-out eyes, is the kind of guy you'd cross the street to avoid. But by the movie's end, you realize that his desperation veils a rush of longing.
It represents the spirit of something more powerful than a bullet, the seed of something good springing from a terrible and unjust event.
Keep your eye on Brydon: He has some great tips for you.
Independently financed and distributed by Soderbergh, Logan Lucky is a magnificent movie that comes disguised as a modest one. Or, as I like to call it, a Joe Bang.
Patti Cake$ motors along steadily on Macdonald's unsentimental charisma.
Anyone who loves machines, poetry or, better yet, the poetry of machines should see it ...
Good-looking people may seem to have it all, but Frankie, with his cushiony lips and guarded eyes, is a vision of male beauty in turmoil.
There's enough magic, and extraordinary visual imagination, to smooth the edges of the movie's problems.
The filmmakers never let us forget how hip they are to humanity's dark side, and their hyperawareness is more wearying than it is illuminating.

It tries so desperately to be crazy and disturbing that all we can see is the effort made and the money spent. No wonder there's an exclamation mark in its title. Aronofsky just doesn't know when to quit.
While all Pixar movies are fine-tuned to keep adults as well as kids engaged, it's still fascinating to see workaday grownup fears addressed so openly.
Forster moves the action forward deftly scene by scene, yet the movie ends up feeling sprawling and empty, a "zombies invaded the world and all I got was a lousy T-shirt" enterprise.
Storytelling efficiency is one of Miss Sloane's most effective calling cards-that, and Chastain.
Lion ... becomes ordinary, even as it moves toward a climax that's moving for all the predictable reasons.
The majesty of nature is Embrace of the Serpent's true star, and Guerra captures the glory of every leaf, every inch of sky, in pearlescent black-and-white as luminous as the lining of a clamshell.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Where is Owens in all of this? By the end of Race, we don't know much more about him as an individual than we did when the movie began.
Should a movie about reporting from such a deeply troubled country really be this entertaining?

The family-in-peril motif is a disaster-film staple, but don't hold that against The Wave. Uthaug isn't trying to buck convention, he's just embroidering over it, on a small scale that ends up feeling surprisingly expansive.
Not an outright Cloverfield sequel but rather, as Abrams has put it, a "spiritual successor." It's also a better movie, one with a sense of humor about itself and its genre.
Gold shows us that the real work of a writer happens far from the keyboard: mostly it involves being alive to the world around us. But there's no reason to set out on an empty stomach.

As superhero spectacles go, Zack Snyder's Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is a grand one, with a mondo-operatic climax and a final shot infused with quivering, exhilarating molecules of grace. It's also not much fun.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Everybody Wants Some!! captures the essence of all sorts of youthful desires, both those that are easily identifiable and the more aching, unnameable kind.

Fairchild's performance is key to the movie: Krisha is witty and chatty one moment, shut down like a deserted fairground the next. We see dazzling warmth in her eyes but also the terror of total system failure.
As a showcase for its star, the Danish actress Paprika Steen, it's still rewarding in its own quiet, jarring way.
McCarthy deserves better than this. She can aim higher.
The Witch has been made with extreme care, and part of what makes its supernatural elements so terrifying is that Eggers is also in tune with the more ordinary challenges of just being human ...

Vallée, working from a script by Bryan Sipe, packs in too many symbols and potent signifiers-some are harmless, others are literally sledgehammer heavy. The movie doesn't need all that when it's got Gyllenhaal.
You've seen every element of Sing Street hundreds of times before-it's Carney's knack for assembling them that makes the difference.
This Barbershop is simply a place where we can all laugh together, sometimes at ideas that veer close to being explosive.
Hawke makes this sweeter, gentler Baker believable in a schoolgirl-diary way-this is the Baker we want to believe in when we lie back in the embrace of his trumpet sound.
Sadly, the movie is a snooze, but see it just for the magnificent Hiddleston, who honors Williams' greatness but also wriggles beyond it.

The story has too many moving parts, and Cheadle can't keep them all in play gracefully-but his portrayal of this fantasy Miles seems to strike an almost cosmic connection with the spirit of a man we could never really know.
The pleasure of watching Shannon and Spacey-together and separately-is key.
Gowns aside, this thing's a snooze: Events unfold tediously, and there are many scenes in which extras with dirty faces, playing demoralized townsfolk, mill about in a desultory fashion.
A Nina Simone novice seeing this picture would have no idea who this complex, magnificent artist was, or why she mattered.
Once you settle into Keanu, it works. And in many ways, it's of a piece with everything else Key and Peele have done.
Civil War, at its best, is blessedly light on its superhero-booted feet.
Foster navigates the tonal shifts with ease, and her actors follow.
This Jungle Book works, because Favreau has both a sense of humor and a sense of spectacle.
Deadpool, intended as a spiky antidote to superhero oversaturation, ends up impaling only itself.
The novelty of Pride and Prejudice and Zombies wears thin in the last third, but Riley and James help carry it to the finish line.
Hail, Caesar! doesn't completely hang together. But Johansson in a mermaid's tail? Really, why else make movies-or go to them?
Silverman shows us a person we've never seen before. She's playing a character, not stroking her own neuroses; she's too much of a pro for that.
The Wonders has an intimate, subtly buzzing power.

Screenwriters Steven Knight and Michael Kalesniko pack as much stuffing as possible into this rubbery squid of a film - and then jam in yet more, and the movie gets duller and less focused as it wears on.
In the end, Spectre is just too much of a good thing. Though each scene is carefully wrought, there's little grace, majesty, or romance in the way the pieces are connected.
Spotlight feels both timeless and modern, a dexterously crafted film that could have been made anytime but somehow feels perfect for right now.
Tender and low-key ...
The picture stumbles, and it may not completely be the fault of the filmmakers. Unless you drastically alter the details of real life, they don't always translate meaningfully to the screen.
When James White really digs in, it's an affecting portrait of grief and of feeling lost in life. So often the two go hand in hand.

If you've been wishing and hoping for a movie in which June Squibb - here playing a dementia-riddled relative named Aunt Fishy - shows her underpants yet again, you'll love Love the Coopers. For the rest of us, to know them is to hate them.
For me, it's a movie that's easy to admire but hard to hold close.
Coogler keeps everything moving so gracefully that by the end of Creed, we almost don't know what hit us.
McKay approaches this adaptation of Michael Lewis' book with wit, energy and a surprising degree of clarity. But if the movie is a crackerjack entertainment, it's one with a conscience.
This is a jewel box of a movie for anyone who loves either Hitchcock or Truffaut-or better yet, both.

Who cares anymore about the sea, or sailors, or whales who decide, with an almost biblical vengeance, that it's payback time? Howard cares, and his movie, flawed as it is, is so unfashionable that it's almost gallant.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's messy in places, as Lee's movies tend to be. But there isn't a moment that Chi-Raq isn't alive. This is a deeply serious, biting picture that also has joy in its heart.
Somewhere along the way, Abrams begins delivering everything we expect, as opposed to those nebulous wonders we didn't know we wanted.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Iñárritu may have fashioned The Revenant as the ultimate endurance test, but as Glass, DiCaprio simply endures. He gives the movie a beating heart, offering it up, figuratively speaking, alive and bloody on a platter

People do terrible things in The Hateful Eight-no matter what you make of the movie, the title doesn't disappoint. But its glorious, snow-capped visuals aside, The Hateful Eight comes off as haggard and atrophied.
Once you start reckoning with Anomalisa's obsession with self-absorption, the novelty of this one-man pity party begins to wear off. A little puppet pain goes a long way.

In the end, Joy is more slender and inconsequential than Russell probably intends it to be-it wears its ideas rather than embodying them. But Lawrence keeps the channels of communication open, every minute, with the audience.
The devastating truth of 45 Years, so beautifully wrought, is that even the most devoted couples are made up of two people who are essentially alone.

For all its intensity, Son of Saul is never ponderous. It moves so quickly, and relies so little on dialogue, that you need to race a little to keep up with it, and to keep your eyes open every second.
Monahan's sense of humor is as dark and bitter as a burnt espresso, and he has a taste for grim violence. But he still has a great deal of feeling for his characters, and that's the key to Mojave.
Mostly, Kung Fu Panda 3 is just fun.
[Pine is] the movie's finest special effect-not because he plays Webber as mindlessly brave but because he lets us see how scared he is.
The Lobster is a droll piece of work lashed with grim humor. For every moment that makes you laugh, there may be another that leaves you with your mouth hanging open.
This is a picture Beatty has wanted to make for years, and if the movie isn't the achievement it should be, it's at least entertaining in fits and starts.

Though Spielberg and screenwriter Melissa Mathison-with the permission of the author's estate-have somewhat expanded and changed Dahl's story, The BFG honors the author's whimsical, waggishness impropriety.
This is purely an exercise in style, and what style!

In the end, Nocturnal Animals barely feels like a film made by a human being. You could just dub it a "stylish exercise" and call it a day. But I just can't shake the fact that Ford somehow wants it to be more.
Both gentle and staggering, an examination of the way our personal experiences can spur creativity-or render it inconsequential.
The Birth of a Nation isn't a great movie -- it's hardly even a good one. But it's bluntly effective, less a monumental piece of filmmaking than an open door.

Leaves you feeling both stripped bare and restored, slightly better prepared to step out and face the world of people around you, with all the confounding challenges they present. There's not much more you can ask from a movie.
Was I supposed to be scared by this thing?
If the best westerns have always been, in some way, studies of contemporary manhood, it's worrisome to think about what this Magnificent Seven says about men today.
Harmlessly enjoyable ...
What's happened to Burton's gift for storytelling? In the movie's second half, it's impossible to follow the story's gnarled-vine logic.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Over and over, American Honey calls attention to how observant it is, rather than just being observant.
The picture is methodically constructed, to the point that it's sometimes dull. But here and there it sets off a mini charge, building up to a subtly satisfying conclusion.

Berg succeeds in balancing Deepwater Horizon's unnervingly believable special effects with the human element: when the rig first erupts in flames, it's as if some grim beast were gnashing at it with fiery teeth.
Morgan is an unassuming little thriller, nicely put together and engaging enough while you're watching, though its memory is likely to vaporize hours, or even minutes, after you've seen it.

Blunt gives Rachel multiple dimensions -- we could never view her as just a stewy mess. But the movie's surprise (or perhaps not-so-surprising) twist doesn't serve its lead character well, at best merely justifying her stalkerish behavior.
Sometimes raw but mostly just raucous, Hart generally pulls it off in his third concert film ...
Certain Women burns slow, but it leaves behind a mysterious, shimmering aura. You feel you know these women-even if their feelings are at times elusive even to themselves.
13th ... is dense with information, and it moves fast. But it's also a story told in images, and the ones DuVernay has chosen ring not just with sadness and horror but also cautious optimism.

Christine has every chance of going wrong-of courting, wittingly or not, the interest of gruesome curiosity seekers. But this is a case where one performance can make all the difference-and Rebecca Hall's does.
As long as there's suburbia, there will always be movies about near-middle-aged couples reckoning with their dull lives.
West, making his first foray into westerns, doesn't control the tone. Its somber, bone-dry gruffness crumbles to dust, only to be replaced by adolescent jokiness.
Part thriller, part obsidian-black comedy, part cerebral firebomb, it's confrontational, terrible and glorious.
Visually, the picture gives us almost no room to breathe, which leaves us only a few tight corners in which to feel.
There's so much going on in Fantastic Beasts that after the first act, you almost can't be bothered to care what happens next.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Craig and her actors, all of them wonderful, have freshened up the genre: As familiar as the basic story may be, it also hits some raw, nuanced notes.

If you open yourself to the experience, Lonergan's movies allow you to live with characters until they feel like people you know. Sometimes they're people you don't like very much. But somehow, by the end, they're your people.
Modest but devastating ...
A movie that reaches out toward the idea of goodness in the world. And whether you or I like Gibson as a person or not, it's no one's place to deny his reach.
Arrival gives us a lot to take in, and the picture is big, somber and grand, if in the end somewhat sterile.
It's a movie with the potential to make lovers of us all. All we have to do is fall into its arms.
A harmless enough entry in the "adorable mite tames surly masculine beast" romantic-weeper genre, hitting all the right beats with the clink of an expertly struck cowbell.
Samberg's Conner swaggers through it all, but he never lets us forget he's just an overtattooed white guy riddled with self-doubt.
The Fits riffs on the power and mystery of adolescent beauty, and on the joy of what it means to move.
Almost worth watching, if you still find yourself at loose ends after you've given the dog a bath, organized 10 years' worth of tax returns and completely moth-proofed your closet.
Although DeGeneres' Dory, with her breathless stream-of-consciousness patter, is unavoidably likable, the cast of supporting characters here may be even better.
The film's contrived quirkiness grows wearisome, and essentially the movie is really just two guys talking in the wilderness for 90 minutes.
The movie works as a quasi-historical ramble, thanks largely to Matthew McConaughey as Knight and the quietly valiant Gugu Mbatha-Raw as his second, common-law wife, the freed slave Rachel.

No one can steal the show from Johnson and Hart. Their dual rhythms, alternately laid back and hyperactive, end up in a glorious and ridiculous kind of syncopation, unicornlike in its rarity and oddness.
You can forgive Independence Day: Resurgence for being ridiculous -- its predecessor was too. But you can't forgive it for being boring.
Even though its conclusion feels rushed, the movie still works as a portrait of an unorthodox family that's well adjusted in its own odd way.
The cranky charisma of the performers, plus the cheerfully idiosyncratic rhythms of Waititi's filmmaking, keep it clicking.
You have to laugh a little at its audaciousness, but it's so completely irony-free that to deride it would only be cheap. Why not just enter its CGI-heavy bubble of wonder?
The movie's real value is that it's crude and funny for no defensible reason.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Feig's Ghostbusters is its own definitive creature, an affable, inventive riff on Ivan Reitman's proton-packing caper that exists not to score points, but only to make us laugh. For a summer comedy, there's no nobler purpose.
This is a summer movie for grownups, the kind that reminds you how gratifying it can be to sit down uninterrupted and watch actors work on the big screen.
Lin keeps this tense adventure ... from stumbling over its own excess: he knows that any good Star Trek needs wit as well as spectacle.
Damon, his eternal boyishness finally settling into the inevitability of middle age, brings the personal touch this movie needs. Its action is generic, but he's always special.

You don't need to be a woman working in finance to get a shivery thrill-and possibly a few chills-from watching Equity, a modestly scaled but perceptive drama about an investment banker who just happens to be a woman.
So much happens in David Ayer's DC Comics adaptation Suicide Squad that by the end, it's as if you've seen nothing.
It has a distinct hippie-folktale aesthetic, riffing on the idea that the natural world holds breathtaking secrets if we just know where to look.
The plot is clever, and its intricacies are beautifully worked out.

War Dogs is based on a true story, and even if you think you can't believe it, you sort of can. Efraim and David seem just ordinary enough, and just under-the-radar smart enough, to make their jaunty little schemes work.
[Ramirez's] performance works as a miniature study of machismo, which can be both a show-offy radiance and a kind of shade-a safe, sheltering rock for a man to hide behind.
As a work of imagination inspired by fact, the film shimmers with warmth.
You could treat it as a casual primer on suspense-film craft, or you can just watch through splayed fingers, like the women who sat next to me at the screening I attended.
Nichols ... tells the Lovings' story in a way that feels immediate and modern, and not just like a history lesson.
There's almost a story here. And the actors, including the picture's quietly dazzling star, Henry Cavill, do their damnedest to draw it out.
What Angio captures, beautifully, is that the Mekons make great music because, together and apart, they're so alive to the world around them.
It's a delightful, informative, and suitably contemplative study of the bee world and the bee-population crisis, though in the end it does offer enough dewdrops of hope to fill up a bluebell or two.
Even so, The Illusionist shifts gears too abruptly into an aggressively dour ending. It's as if the movie's grudgingly fanciful quality must come with a punishment.
The Coens' makings, maybe, were just a little too dry. But the thing still smokes.
Coppola is a filmmaker who fills up a big canvas with small moments.
Quote not available.
Bardem is the only reason that Biutiful is impossible to fully turn away from -- he's the beacon who lights the way in this otherwise overmanipulative, overreaching mess of a film.

In the battle between claustrophobic, showily indie filmmaking and the raw openness of the lead actors, the latter wins by a long shot. The faces of these performers -- particularly Williams' -- are the key to Blue Valentine.
You'll want to spend lots of time checking out those costumes, because, Perlman and Lee aside, there's not much to watch in the acting department.
Wells touches on so many problems of the modern workplace, as it's affected by corporate greed and thoughtlessness, that it's almost a wonder The Company Men is as entertaining as it is.
Nearly all the performers here seem to be having a good time, and their easy-going congeniality keeps the movie putting along, even through some extremely rough patches.
Im has a flair for highly controlled melodrama, and his visuals show a knife-edge precision: You could cut yourself on all these crisp shadows.

Mostly, The Mechanic creaks and groans as it goes through the motions, and not even its lavish violence -- which includes much smashing of heads and a nasty screwdriver stabbing -- is particularly electrifying.
The movie also hints that it's OK to be a hypocrite as long as you point out the hypocrisy of others.
If The Rite isn't exactly good, it's also surprisingly not-terrible.
Gregg Araki's Kaboom may be the most cheerful movie ever made about the impending apocalypse.
It's true that great visuals, or a great story, or deeply unself-conscious acting can be enough to make us look past awkward dialogue. But Sanctum is skimpy on those attributes.
In terms of storytelling sophistication, his latest feature, Cold Weather -- despite the fact that it falls down cold in the last act -- feels like a step toward something bigger and better.
It's cute, all right. But even as Shakespearean tragedies aimed at kids go, Gnomeo & Juliet is a slender conceit that stretches itself way too thin.
It's a movie that needs to look down its nose for its laughs, which generally isn't the best place to find them.
There's a lot that works in Heartbeats -- so much that its flaws stand out in disappointingly sharp relief.
I sure do admire Lussier and Farmer's go-for-broke ingenuity.
The key is to let yourself go with the meandering current of its narrative.
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing that happens in Take Me Home Tonight is surprising or affecting, and none of it is funny, either.
Verbinski has made an animated feature unlike any other on the current mainstream landscape: For a big-budget animated picture, Rango sure is an odd little varmint.
The picture is rambunctiously affectionate; Guiterrez may go for the broad joke, but never the cheap one.
If your idea of a great Valentine's Day is to ring up your secret beloved and breathe heavily into the phone, this is the movie for you.

Watching Jane Eyre, I envied those who have never read the book: What would it be like to watch this movie without already knowing all of the story's secrets? Miraculously, Fukunaga preserves much of the book's spooky mysteriousnes.
Even the name seems crass, as if some Disney marketing exec figured that all the studio had to do was slap "Legacy" at the end of the old title and the thing would be good to go.
It's the kind of espionage caper that doesn't get made anymore, a visually sensuous picture made with tender attention to detail and an elegant, understated sense of humor.

In its full-length version, Carlos stretches out to a languorous yet surprisingly taut five and a half hours, though it has also been cut down to an equally effective -- though not as detailed -- two-and-a-half-hour version.
Why is it I cannot resist the Jackass clarion call?
Paranormal Activity 2 sinks much lower than it needs to in order to get a rush out of us - and in the end, the rush isn't even that great.

Paul and Sandra Fierlinger's My Dog Tulip is a double rarity: An adaptation that wholly and faithfully captures the spirit and mood of the book it's based on, and an example of computer animation that shows the human touch in every frame.
If it's possible to make a completely gentle movie about boxing, Frederick Wiseman has done just that.

Unsettling, energizing and more than a little mystifying, Amer is the kind of movie that may leave you feeling indifferent or puzzled at the end. But damned if it doesn't return, days later, to visit -- kind of like a killer in black leather gloves.
A relaxed, enjoyable little documentary whose central figure emerges as a figure rendered in half-precise, half-diffuse pointillist dots
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is a movie where the drama is shaped more by quiet conversations than by noisy confrontations -- kind of the way things happen in real life.
As the end credits of this last dour Swedish snooze-a-thon started rolling, I clapped my notebook shut as if it were the last day of school. Huzzah! Bring on David Fincher. Please.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The problem with Megamind is that it wants to remind us, every minute, how smart it is -- and that sets it a world apart from Despicable Me, which is courageous enough to revel in its own silliness. Megamind tries too hard and ultimately achieves less.

Whatever the flaws of Four Lions may be, the movie neither coasts on multicultural smugness masquerading as openness (of the "They have their reasons" variety), nor does it reach for any cheap philosophical answers.
Rabbit Hole is a spare, carefully made picture, but it's not a bloodless one. And it's just good enough to make you wonder what Mitchell will tackle next.
As long as you have an idea of what you're in for, 127 Hours is more weirdly entertaining than it is grim.

Scott doesn't get hung up on those specific clichéd details -- he and cinematographer Ben Seresin treat them with a wink and move on, devoting most of their energy to building not-so-subtle layers of tension and suspense.
Skyline is a piece of junk, even in a movie climate littered with expensive -- though sometimes fun -- junkiness.
The plot is worked out with care, and it takes its time, unapologetically, in a manner that's perfectly suited to thinking adults. The whole enterprise reeks of class.
There are a number of touches that aren't just magical but also deeply moving.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A love letter written in rhinestones, feathers and glitter glue.
Love and Other Drugs is a sort-of romantic comedy about erectile-dysfunction drugs and Parkinson's Disease. Because Lord knows you can't make a romantic comedy that's just about erectile dysfunction.
A direct and heartfelt piece of work.
In Black Swan all is not as it appears -- in fact, everything is hokier, more obvious, more hilarious than it's intended to be. There's hardly a dull moment here.

This is a wry mini-epic, the sort of movie that grapples with big subjects -- issues of Jewish identity; the sliding scale of one man's morality; the devastating effects of losing friendship and love -- one sardonic joke at a time.
There's plenty of sweetness at the core of Glenn Ficarra and John Requa's bold, bleak little comedy I Love You Phillip Morris.
Whenever it should bounce backward, it lunges forward; it jabs instead of feints, and stomps down hard when it needs to dance.

Todd Phillips' Due Date is a massive wedgie of a comedy, which is to say it's a comedy of extreme discomfort -- it's so unnerving, in fact, it sometimes seems more like an experimental theater piece than a mainstream entertainment.
Aside from a few arresting visuals, Red Riding Hood is just a slog through the woods.

Cunningham has spent some 60 years out on the street, listening, he says, for what it has to say to him. Press' movie shows Cunningham leading by example, urging us not just to look, but to really see.
The secret to making a great, or even just a good, thriller these days seems to have been lost. Maybe the key is not so much feeling invincible as knowing what your limits are.
The picture is cluttered and convoluted and big, and Marshall - taking over the reins from Gore Verbinski - doesn't seem to grasp how exhausting nonstop action can be.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Not much happens in The Kid with a Bike, but it leaves you grateful that the worst doesn't happen - with these characters, you might not be able to bear it.
Strong visuals don't necessarily equal strong visual storytelling. If Malick could tell a story mostly with pictures - and faces - why would he need so many voice-overs?
If it's true that misery loves company, maybe this is von Trier's way of reaching out. Melancholia may be as close as he'll ever come to wrapping us in a bear hug.
The Skin I Live In isn't quite as el sicko as I'd hoped it would be, but the depraved gleam in its eye its nonetheless irresistible.
Drive not only met my hopes; it charged way over the speed limit, partly because it's an unapologetically commercial picture that defies all the current trends in mainstream action filmmaking.
This Must Be the Place is a bewildering piece of work, a picture that may have initially been guided by a sweet impulse but takes a sharp left turn into crazytown.
It follows the same essential pattern as its predecessor, but the ingenious loopiness is gone; the mechanism behind it grinds instead of whirrs.
As a portrait of a charming rapscallion and entrepreneur, Mr. Nice serves admirably.
While the picture sometimes groans under the 200-pound whimsy of Mills' filmmaking, it's also often touchingly direct.
I marvel at the way Winterbottom and his actors have captured the essence of your garden-variety midlife crisis in this lively and often bitterly funny two-hour distillation.
The big problem with Habemus Papum is that Piccoli (historically a wonderful and charming performer) just looks shell-shocked every minute. There's no texture to the performance.
Super 8 is such an authentic homage to the glory and excess of Spielberg that it barely has its own identity. It's been body-snatched by its own influences.

No matter how drastically the news-delivery model changes, anyone who cares about journalism needs to care about newspapers; and anyone who cares about newspapers needs to see Page One: Inside the New York Times.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The whole enterprise is surprisingly painless, albeit in an icy-cool, numbed-out way.
Reynolds is almost good enough to stand up to the gargantuan tower of emptiness that is Green Lantern, but he's fighting a losing battle.
Captures in entertaining and sometimes excruciating detail the trauma that live performers willingly put themselves through, partly to entertain us but also to fuel some drive in themselves.

Bad Teacher is hardly a perfect picture, but in the context of every other comedy on the summer movie landscape - from the faux empowerment of Bridesmaids to the neurotic frat-guy heteromania of The Hangover Part II - it feels revolutionary.
It does just about everything but tell an actual story.
Bay doesn't care about your soul, he just wants your money -- but he at least makes sure you go home feeling exhausted and spent rather than vaguely dissatisfied. It's a fair exchange.
Please, shoot me now.

This is a modest film that doesn't reach too high, instead spreading out in some interesting ways, exploring what it means to be a reasonably emotionally secure person when everyone around you is busy projecting their own insecurity onto you.
The melodramatic flourish that ends The Ledge feels unearned and unclean: It's the sort of ending that ought to hit hard, and yet it comes off as perversely inconsequential.
It's a lovely, and loving, survey of many of the girlhood-to-adulthood motifs Breillat has been exploring throughout her career. It's awake, alive and ageless at the same time.
Quote not available.
Bridesmaids obviously strives to seem modern, but too often it mistakes crassness for freshness.
So fluttering and tender, so guileless, that you almost can't believe it was made by an old hand like Van Sant. Then again, maybe you can.
Instead of trying to do a soft-shoe around the hallowed bond between mothers and sons, Ramsay treads fearlessly into some scary, unspoken territory.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Matthew McConaughey should always play lawyers. There's something smirky, cocky and untrustworthy about his demeanor -- he slides through every movie like a greased weasel, but in The Lincoln Lawyer, it works.
While it's nice to see TV actors get a crack at the bigger screen, Peep World barely seems like a movie.

When it comes to structure, pacing and even comic timing, Rodrick Rules doesn't let its audience down. I felt a lot less shafted by it than I do by some movies made for allegedly discriminating adults.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Schnabel is out of his element here. His movie comes off as a stiff lesson plan; his gift for subtlety seems temporarily lost.
The chief reason to see Potiche -- maybe the only reason -- is Deneuve.

Dupieux's idea, apparently, is that movie audiences are so stupid they'll consume anything, and the more tickets he sells for this arch little piece of junk, the more he'll be proved right. If I were you, I'd refuse to give him that satisfaction.
Hop is spectacularly charmless -- there's no spring in its step. The last thing we need is an Easter movie that comes limping down the bunny trail.

Bier has a sense of how everyday people get by in the real world, but maybe she's too forgiving of their faults and foibles. Sometimes a little harsh light is just what you need to see things clearly.
The surest way to kill comedy is to protect your audience, in advance, from being offended by it. And that's among the least of the problems with this new Arthur.

Meek's Cutoff is an ambitious feat of visual storytelling that's alive to both its landscape and the actors who people it. This is a big movie masquerading as a small one, fully awake in even its quietest, slowest moments.
Soul Surfer is the kind of sturdy, satisfying family drama that doesn't get made very often anymore. But even beyond that, at crucial moments it shows there's actually a brain behind the camera.
In the end, The Conspirator stumbles under the moral weight it's trying to carry. What matters, maybe, is that Redford didn't take the easy way out and lighten the load.
Facile documentaries like this one, no matter how sincere their intentions may be, don't help the case.
It's a little disconcerting at first when Blu opens his mouth to speak and Mark Zuckerberg's voice comes out.
Spurlock's movie isn't nearly as daring as he thinks it is, and for sheer audacity, it doesn't come close to a stunt Dana Carvey pulled on his short-lived (and brilliant) mid-1990s TV show.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: African Cats doesn't quite do justice to its strange and remarkable subjects. It gets them ready for their close-ups, all right. But it stops short of seeing through to their souls.

Although screenwriter Richard LaGravenese has streamlined it considerably, he and Lawrence have preserved the book's spirit: This may be a love story, but it's also a snapshot of a lost era and a strange, exciting, rough way to make a living.
It's a special disappointment when a movie takes a great subject and lets us down.
It isn't quite summer-movie season yet, but Fast Five is already peeling down to its proverbial, sweat-sodden muscle shirt in preparation. It's ready for anything.
Doesn't bring 3-D to dazzling new heights. Instead, it uses this relatively new technology to burrow a little deeper, both literally and figuratively, into history - into the nature of mankind, even.
Takashi Miike's samurai adventure 13 Assassins is so beautifully made, it could serve as a model for contemporary American action films.
Foster has crept out on a limb here, showing us a grown-up human being who's in terrible pain, and for whom there are no easy answers.

Hardly romantic and barely a comedy, Something Borrowed hovers in that damp gray region of movies that are often characterized as "cute," though it has barely enough character to stand up even to that bland adjective.
Branagh was meant to work on this scale. And even if ambition doesn't always equal vision, with Thor Branagh brings the two pretty closely in line.
For my money, the best Allen movie in 10 years, or maybe even close to 20...
The filmmaking choices Eastwood has made here range from merely misguided to numbingly dopey.
Tamara Drewe starts out as the kind of movie you think you might be able to send your friends to, and ends up one you're not sure you'd send anyone to.
The picture is directed with such a loose, slack hand that you'd think Craven had never directed a slasher-thriller before: I didn't jump once; I never even felt vaguely scared or creeped out.
For those looking to, or through, Secretariat for a deeper, more sinister meaning, all I can say is, there are worse places to look for God than in the nostril of a great horse.
With his garish, pointless and downright inept rendering of Alice Sebold's 2002 novel, The Lovely Bones, Peter Jackson has hit a new low in the annals of movie adaptations.
Gyllenhaal and Bridges are marvelous together, playing their characters' cautious affection for each other as an alluring winding path that's actually laden with minefields.
Quentin Tarantino seems to be hanging on to a lost world of moviemaking. He may be nuts. But he's a nut who cares.
It's a remote-control movie experience, a high-tech "wish you were here" scribbled on a very expensive postcard.
Watching the slow, cautious courtship between Victoria and Albert is so pleasurable, so surprisingly not-boring, that it doesn't matter how much of the ending we already know.
It's hard to get too bent out of shape about Sherlock Holmes, partly because the actors seem to take so much pleasure in the act of giving us a crazy spectacle.
It meanders and jaywalks according to its own confused rhythms, and the suggestion is that if we don't get it -- or if we get bored -- we're just not clued in to Gilliam's genius.
Meyers has dropped something a bit more subtle than her usual anvil. This one is more like a mere tire iron, but at least we've got Baldwin: He's the pixie dust that chases away the ensuing headache.
The picture has enough charm to make us feel something for its shy, gangly protagonist, and enough bite to keep us from wanting to kill him.
If only Leap Year were an anomaly, the kind of picture that comes along only once every four years. Instead, it's yet more evidence that romantic comedies are only getting worse.
Hawke gives his all here -- or maybe just half his all -- and it isn't quite enough: He's trying to be soulful, but he really just looks a little tired. The real delight is Willem Dafoe.
For a picture with so much invested in its staunch sense of social justice, Invictus ultimately goes down not as medicine but as entertainment.
Chan's strong suit now is his skill as a comic actor, and Levant and his writers don't know how to tap it.
Some questions just can't be answered by science, and the quandary of why Creation is so poundingly dull is one of them.

It's about as dramatically taut as your garden-variety board meeting. And it makes you realize that jerking a tear or two isn't necessarily a bad thing for a filmmaker to do, if it at least keeps your audience awake.
When in Rome may fall flat in places, but at least it hasn't had all the personality manicured out of it.
Gibson's character here is a man crazed with grief. But it looks as if Gibson is just using that as an excuse to act crazy, period.
Seyfried's performance is lovely. Her character may be sweet, but she's also marvelously direct, two qualities that Seyfried holds in balance perfectly.
From Paris With Indifference is more like it.
It doesn't know whether it wants to be dark and moodily glamorous or ridiculous and gory -- it's a creature feature suffering from extreme class consciousness.
Smith and the screenwriters keep trotting out one limp gag after another, including a foul-mouthed child car thief and a parkour routine that ends in a splat.
This is a movie that recognizes there's no straight line to the truth, which is part of what makes it vaguely unsatisfying -- though it's also what keeps it honest.
Greenberg is all about that halting, forward movement. Maybe there's no happy ending for Roger Greenberg, but there's no going back, either, and that counts as progress.
The predictable plot mechanics aren't what make it insufferable. The big problem is Miley Cyrus.
The Hughes Brothers may want us to think they're giving us a few deep, quasi-spiritual ideas, but what they're really serving up is earnestly shallow, machete-and-bow-and-arrow entertainment.
A Single Man, un film de Tom Ford, is all art and no direction -- it's a picture made up of visual choices with almost no filmmaking sandwiched between.
Another actor might have greedily milked the story's pathos quotient (believe me, there are plenty of opportunities). But De Niro hangs back, and the approach works.
The picture is brushed with a fine glaze of slickness, a product sealed in a blister pack. It's like airplane air -- it has a packaged freshness that isn't really fresh at all.

A limp romantic drama that occasionally lifts its drowsy head to attempt a wan smile, a picture that starts out being harmlessly dull and ends, somehow, in a place that feels insultingly manipulative.

Campion -- who also wrote the screenplay, inspired by British poet Andrew Motion's biography of Keats -- tells the story of Keats and Fanny in delicate, painterly colors, layered in such a way that they're vividly vital.
The movie substitutes calculation for brains, and the filmmakers seem to think we'll all be too stupid to notice.

This is a love story, all right, but it has less to do with the flaws of capitalism than it does with Moore's unwavering fondness for the sound of his own voice, and for what he perceives as his own vast cleverness.
Surrogates stays afloat by not taking itself too seriously, but also by recognizing that a movie about robots shouldn't look as if it were made by one.
Zombieland is a romance, a comedy, a road movie and a freewheeling schlock horrorfest, all in one.
There's no hope that Gervais' performance in The Invention of Lying will open up new hope for a different kind of leading man -- and that's what makes his resoluteness so great.
Whip It has such a sweet spirit that it's easy enough to let its flaws sail by.
Couples Retreat is neither funny nor honest. The exact opposite of a retreat, it's merely exhausting.
Chris Rock's Good Hair is one of those rare documentaries that works on two seemingly incongruous levels at once: It's both social commentary and pure delight.

Jonze's ideas, visual and otherwise, spill out in a faux-philosophical ramble that isn't nearly as deep as he thinks it is; at best, it's a scrambled tone poem. Even the look of the picture becomes tiresome after a while.
Cirque du Freak is disjointed and disorganized, and it meanders when it needs to gallop.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Jackson's mystery deepens, even as it dissolves between our fingers.
The House of the Devil is really a romance: a love letter to the kind of gal we thought had given up the ghost.

Kelly tries to gather so many ideas under this movie's umbrella: He has strong ideas about the necessity of compassion in everyday life. He wonders what awaits us after death. But he can't flesh out all of these ideas properly, or even haphazardly.
There's no doubt we need more movies for grown-ups, with jokes that don't hit us over the head, but The Men Who Stare at Goats doesn't fit the bill. At best, it might hypnotize you into a stupor.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Fantastic Mr. Fox is possibly the finest picture about family, community and poultry thievery ever made.

The effects are expensive-looking and impressive enough while you're watching them, although whatever awe they inspire doesn't last long: When you've seen one Washington Monument fall to bits, you've seen them all.
Despite Curtis' bumbling, Pirate Radio manages to stay afloat bravely enough -- at least until the climax, which comes off as a confused marriage between Top of the Pops and Titanic.
Cruz doesn't coast on her beauty in Broken Embraces, and she has the kind of role that can be difficult to flesh out.
New Moon offers few of the juicy, go-for-broke romantic pleasures of its predecessor, and the movie is so badly shaped that it's hard not to blame Weitz as a director.
There's a valuable lesson to be learned from Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans: Two wrongs don't make a right -- it takes at least three.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ninja Assassin lives in the moment, a visceral gouge of a picture, and sections of it move so fast -- and are so intriguingly, dimly lit -- that you have to use your imagination a bit to discern what's happening.
This is a standard coming-of-age story set in a milieu that's anything but standard, and that's what keeps the picture's motor running.
Sheridan shapes the drama so casually that he succeeds in making it feel naturalistically unshaped.
The truth is often slippery, although no amount of signage should stop us from seeking it.

Even its most reprehensible characters - like Farrell's superbly nasty autocrat, whose first act upon taking over the company is to order Sudeikis to fire all the fat people - brim with perverse joie de vivre.
An imperfect comedy, but as a movie with a mostly black cast, made by a white director, that isn't being marketed strictly according to color lines, it's a step forward.
Quote not available.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: There's nothing so frustrating as a small movie, made by a clearly gifted filmmaker, that flies close to magic only to be sternly jerked back to earth.

It's everything a modern action movie should be, a picture made with confidence but not arrogance, one that believes so wholeheartedly in its outlandish plot twists that they come to make perfect alt-universe sense.
A movie so desperately unfunny it makes you want to slit your wrists ...

Though there's a lot of ricocheting dialogue about Grigoriev's penchant for keeping secrets and telling lies within the household, Carion effectively maps the emotional minefield that stands between radical patriotism and family harmony.
Ambles along waywardly for the first half hour before losing steam altogether.
Henry is a man who knows how to live, and Kline welcomes us into the Russian Tea Room of his mind.

So what if he passes the Herculean he-man test the story puts him through? He still has all the sexual charisma of an untied shoelace. And even a woman who likes the soft touch can't do much with that.
It's not just the characters who are expendable: The actors may as well be tossed out with the garbage, too.
Roberts is precisely the right actress to play this character: She adamantly refuses to be adorable -- she'd rather just unleash that crazy, unladylike cackle.
Like the dance floor of a great club on a good night, it's gorgeous, unruly and exhilarating all at once.
A slow, steady rumble of anger and dismay at what the U.S. military, and the government, can get away with in the name of public relations.
If the career of Christopher Nolan is any indication, we've entered an era in which movies can no longer be great. They can only be awesome, which isn't nearly the same thing.
There's a degree of gruff integrity at work for at least two-thirds of Alexandre Aja's grindhouse piranhapalooza Piranha 3D.

Takers is a sterling example of how a movie can take a basic, appealing idea and turn it into something that you could easily watch while brushing your teeth, clipping your toenails, plucking your eyebrows.
Anton Corbijn's The American looks and feels like a movie made by a filmmaker who hasn't been to the movies since the '70s -- and I mean that as the highest compliment.
Such a gentle picture that at times it threatens to drift off the screen.
There's lots of talk and very little true wisdom which, come to think of it, is also a defining characteristic of the overinflated bubble world the movie is so desperately trying to puncture.
Paul's life is treated as a novelty. Out there in the audience, we're treated as suckers.
A picture that's by turns inventive, tender and boring, and one that uses a variety of novelty point-of-view techniques.

Fincher and his screenwriter, TV writer-god Aaron Sorkin, have made a seemingly modest picture that achieves something close to greatness the old-fashioned, slow-burning way: By telling a story with faces, dialogue and body language of all types.
The love scenes between Scott Thomas and López have a believable, animalistic tenderness.
It's a remake that surpasses its predecessor in depth and vision.
Quote not available.
movie_title: All My Friends Are Leaving Brisbane (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In a culture where children and their feelings often seem to run roughshod over the adult world, it's a relief to get a snapshot of a mixed-up middle-class kid who comes to realize just how manageable his problems really are.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: In The Switch, Bateman plays a not-so-romantic lead who sometimes makes you want to shake him. And still, he's never been so appealing.
The idea floating behind The Sorcerer's Apprentice, and it's a marvelous one, is that in the city, magic is both everywhere you look and everywhere you don't look.
If nothing else the racing scenes -- which look terrific, crisp and colorful, like the rest of the film -- will help the childless get in touch with their inner hysterical mother.
Such a low-key feat of filmmaking that the scope of its offhanded generosity -- toward its characters, its story, its actors and its audience -- may not hit you until days after you've seen it.
Not since Antichrist has a man suffered so greatly at the tiny, grabby hands of God's creatures. Nature is not our friend, kids, and it's not to be disrespected or underestimated.
Quote not available.
The big problem with Iron Man 2, maybe, is that it so dutifully gives the people what they want, instead of giving them what they didn't know they wanted.
Loach is trying to be jaunty here, and every once in a while his efforts pay off.
Gallenberger has an astute visual sense, and he's good at transmitting lots of information with a single image.
It treats its characters as individuals and not as strange folk who are willfully lost in time.
Once in a while a funny line or absurd sight gag will amble into the foreground, only to recede immediately in the rear-view mirror of memory.
Even in the context of that lumpy, overpriced Birkin bag of stuff we call Hollywood product, Sex and the City 2 hits a new low of idiocy and crassness.
Unapologetically crude and shamelessly silly.
Jordan acknowledges the world as a flawed place. But he also knows that the cracks in everyday life, even the ones so fine that sunlight can't get through, are exactly where the glamour creeps in.
It's so ineffectual and unfocused that after it's over, you're not even sure you watched a movie.

This A-Team isn't about charismatic personalities or teamwork or even, really, about cartoony violence. It's simply about blowing stuff up -- which is great as far as it goes, but maybe it's time we asked a little more from our action movies.
A Piece of Work is about an individual and about a career, but it's also about the nature of work, and about our fears that when the work stops coming in, we've outlived our usefulness.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Winter's Bone is one of those movies that can't quite make a distinction between profundity and plain old bleakness.
It winds its way gently toward its big themes instead of grabbing desperately at them, and because its plot is so beautifully worked out, getting there is almost all of the fun.

Thompson's novel is elegant in its bluntness and cruelty, as efficient as a closed fist -- you can turn away from it, but you can't escape it. But there's no subtle way to put this: Winterbottom's version goes too far.
Tom Cruise is no longer cool, a truth he just can't face -- if he could, he'd be cooler.
The unspoken idea behind Restrepo is that we can't just measure the effects of a war in terms of lives lost. The lives remaining count, too.
It's nice that they're so supportive of one another; too bad the whole exercise is so tedious for us.
Now that we've hit the third picture in the franchise, it's clear the studio behind it, Summit, actually prefers that the movies be programmed and predictable.

Spector's weirdness is pretty much off the charts, and Jayanti's approach confirms our worst hunches while failing to illuminate any of the more intricate nooks and crannies of this brilliant, troubled soul.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The Last Airbender, for all its Shyamalan-style grandiosity, is completely harmless and inoffensive, and at the very least, Shyamalan appears to be having a little fun here.
The picture never looks fussed-over or flattened -- it breathes, as opposed to just looking merely pretty.
Jonah Hex could be bigger, louder and longer, with more special effects and faster cutting, but it errs on the side of simplicity. And to that, let's all raise a shotglass.
Holofcener writes, and helps to shape on-screen, characters we often don't even like, and what do we do? We invite them home with us. Talk about a soft touch.
The Back-Up Plan is either someone's idea of a joke or simply what passes for mainstream romantic comedy these days. I'm afraid it's the latter.

Director David Yates and screenwriter Steve Kloves guide the story to a graceful and satisfying end. The movie's final moments are the equivalent of the half-jubilant, half-mournful thrill you get when you close the cover of a book you've savored.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: McAdams is a great screwball actress working, sadly, in an age when there are no great screwball roles. But Morning Glory at least has some pizzazz, and suggests an awareness of the way serious journalism has one foot in the grave.
Compared with Morris' best and most provocative documentaries, like The Fog of War, Tabloid is just a trifle. It's a silly little thing that goes down easy and is forgotten almost instantly.
The screenplay - which was written by Delpy, Landeau and Nahon - has a jittery kind of honesty about it, which Rock and Delpy sometimes push to its limits.
The spirit of great stop-motion animators like George Pal and Ray Harryhausen lives on in ParaNorman, and not just as a ghost: It's so real you could almost reach out and touch it.
The Expendables 2 is reasonably cathartic in a fall-down-go-boom way, and if the picture's self-conscious riffing becomes tiresome after a while ... it's still much wittier than its predecessor.
"The Awakening" takes so many unnecessary twists and turns that the final one, which should be a biggie, ends up feeling inconsequential.
Matt's learning curve is probably supposed to be entertaining, or endearing, or something, but mostly it just sends the movie lurching into inertia.
Hit and Run lures you in with its jackalope rhythms. There's nothing else like it on the current landscape.
[Lawless] is both too obvious and not direct enough, and its shapelessness dilutes its power.
The trick is to let yourself swoon into the picture's visual embrace and not get too hung up on its myriad sticky plot points.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The first half of The Possession is suitably atmospheric and reasonably creepy.

movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps not quite as painful as you might be expecting, though probably not as enjoyable, either.

Piranha 3D was ridiculous, gory and fun, everything Piranha 3DD is not.

movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Inside Llewyn Davis is the warmest picture [the Coens have] ever made, and though it will never attract the cultlike adoration of The Big Lebowski and Fargo, or earn the serious-lit-adaptation accolades of No Country for Old Men, it's possibly their best.
This is a superb, engrossing picture, strange in all the right ways, and one I long to see again.
