Pixar, the undisputed heavyweight champion of the animation world, retains the title with this winning tale.

A glasses-required experiment that pushes the boundaries of the concert doc yet keeps one foot planted in the conventional concrete. Rarely has a film attained such moments of exhilaration while also leaving the viewer with some level of disappointment.
As a chance to watch a gaggle of Serious Actors ham it up in an intricately plotted (though easy to follow) yarn, it's a well-executed diversion.
This charming documentary follows Ivan Thompson, the self-proclaimed 'Cowboy Cupid,' as he finds Mexican brides for American men who feel they've exhausted their options on their side of the border.
The film pokes fun at teen movies, but it also adopts many of the same clichés and stereotypes, resulting in a high-school flick that is both knowing and formulaic at the same time.
A fascinating biopic could be made about Brian Wilson, but this isn't it.
If you're looking for a harmless crowd-pleaser, this will fit the bill.
The Salt of the Earth certainly won't be for everyone, but it offers a haunting, reflective, thought-provoking portrait of a remarkable individual.
The performances are commendable and the zippy, back-and-forth dialogue is consistently enjoyable.
Black comedies are difficult to get right, of course, but despite a handful of positive attributes, The Legend Of Barney Thomson doesn't quite cut it.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While the events aren't particularly funny or dramatic, the characters are engaging.
There is little inspiration to be found and the end product is serviceable at best.
A naturalistic, insightful, heartbreaking film that deserves to be celebrated.
This bromance-flavoured comedy has more edge than you might expect.
Theron is solid enough in the lead role, and the central mystery is reasonably intriguing before the beans are spilled.
Every scene is filled with striking imagery and rich, descriptive language, but the whole thing grows relatively exhausting after a while. Perhaps you can have too much of a good thing.
A film that is smart, funny, likeable and entertaining. It is, quite simply, a thoroughly enjoyable piece of work.
All of this is superbly acted by Deyn, Mullan and Guthrie, and it is beautifully crafted by writer/director Terence Davies.
A likeable, thought-provoking film about friendship, community and kindness.
This engaging, low-key drama is a film about family, business and success.
Moving, sobering and heartbreaking, providing us with a non-judgemental film about a young woman who endured more than her fair share of judgement.
A gripping, smartly crafted film that deserves to be seen.
The film is pleasantly enjoyable throughout, combining likeable characters with knowing gags and lively set pieces.
The four leads are superb, but Fiennes steals the show, dominating a scene whenever he appears. His dancing, in particular, is a joy to behold.
The film itself doesn't generate much suspense, but it does engage as a morally ambiguous tale about loss and obsession.
Disappointingly flat and undercooked.
A must-see for cinephiles.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Numerous fight sequences are staged with a great deal of skill and style in this lean, propulsive, action-packed revenge thriller.
All of this plays out in a way that is restrained and understated to a fault, but Hoss is quietly devastating and there are one or two affecting moments.
As much a family drama as a crime thriller, Blood Ties is character-driven, so sparing in terms of action, although the regular eruptions of violence pack a genuine punch.
Life After Beth is one or two re-writes away from where it needs to be.
The Calling isn't so much an awful film as a flat and unremarkable one ...
A Northern Saturday Night Fever? Oh, go on then.
This dreamy tale of wasted youth provides a familiar yet authentic portrait of the teenage experience.
An ageing academic embarks on a journey of self-discovery in this old-fashioned European thriller.
Set Fire to the Stars benefits from crisp monochrome cinematography and two solid lead performances, but the end result feels somewhat flat, and it's difficult to see who the film will appeal to.
The Skeleton Twins follows a fairly predictable trajectory, but it is littered with affecting moments and joyous sequences.

As much about existence and the passage of time as it is cinema and criticism, this affectionate testament offers a reflective and surprisingly profound journey. Hopefully, the man himself would have given it the thumbs up.
Fans of fast-paced action movies will find much to enjoy in this bruising thriller from promising French filmmaker Fred Cavayé.
The end product rarely feels like a documentary, but Petrov's story is fascinating, and there's no doubt that it deserves to be told.
movie_title: The Man Who Saved the World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The story's plausibility is stretched in places, but it is held together by Bening and Harris, both of whom are wholly convincing at all times.
Testament Of Youth won't convert those who are fundamentally opposed to British period dramas, but it is beautifully shot and elevated by a striking lead performance.
Sombre and understated to a fault, but it also contains several quietly affecting moments, most of which are complemented by a beautiful score by Rachel Portman.
The picture's main asset is Ferdinando, who delivers a strong lead performance as the strung-out narc whose world is crumbling around him.
The film is uneven, but it's fairly effective as a portrait of sexual awakenings during adolescence, even if there's nothing in it that you haven't seen before.
Highly recommended for anyone feeling wistful about their youth.
The film isn't nearly as stilted as the set-up might suggest. In fact, it's rather charming.
The Salvation isn't just for those who love westerns ... it's a solid revenge thriller in its own right.
The tone is uneven and the various plot twists aren't as effective as they need to be, resulting in an underwhelming experience that fails to live up to its early promise.
The end result isn't always gripping, but it's a solid piece of work that deserves to be seen.
The story becomes increasingly messy and disjointed. It's hard to care about any of the characters ...
The Fault In Our Stars is unlikely to win over the cynics, but Woodley has a smile that lights up the screen, and you believe in her even when the film's plausibility is stretched.
The scenery is striking, and Negga is impressive as a woman who is haunted by events from her past. Regrettably, though, the film itself isn't worthy of such praise.
The White King only springs to life when Pryce is on screen, which isn't often.
Higgins and Dickie are superb as they combine to help create a haunting, downbeat film about two people who have been consumed by sorrow.
Prevenge won't appeal to everyone, but Lowe deserves plenty of praise, given that she directed the film while playing the main character, not to mention the fact that she also wrote the script.
The team's story is inspiring, uplifting and infectious. Happily, the same can be said about the film.
Tukel's feisty film won't be for everyone, but it's worth a look if you like your satirical comedies to combine scathing dialogue with contemptible characters.
The Age of Shadows is perhaps too long, but there's no doubt that it is a sumptuous, elegantly crafted piece of cinema.
This quietly absorbing Brazilian drama features an outstanding performance from Sonia Braga, who is so natural and authentic that you forget you're watching an actress performing.
Schwarzenegger delivers an impressively understated performance, portraying a broken man desperate to take back control of the situation in whatever way he can.
So grim and downbeat that it may just be too bleak for some viewers.
The story may be slow and uneventful, but it's peppered with moments that are quietly devastating.
Mara ensures that we feel for Rose, and James is surprisingly effective as the man who ruins Rose's life, but The Secret Scripture isn't as moving or intriguing as it should be.
My Life as a Courgette could be described as slight, given that the running time is just over an hour, but it is a beautiful, heartfelt film that deals with some difficult subjects.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is a bit slow to start, but it gradually evolves into a riveting, tension-soaked thriller that will keep you on tenterhooks until the very end.
Evans is likeable and engaging. Happily, the same can be said about the film as a whole.
Song to Song might be nice to look at, but it is a chore to sit through.
Tommy's Honour could be described as unremarkable, but it is a solid, well-acted, perfectly enjoyable film that doesn't do much wrong.
But here, the various power-plays and shifting alliances feel like musical chairs, while [Ray] Burdis's attempts to make [Paul] Ferris sympathetic are undercooked.

[James] McAvoy is sensational - utterly convincing as the manipulative bully who's racist, sexist and practically every other kind of 'ist' you can think of, while managing to elicit sympathy during rare moments of humanity.
The film may be slight, but there's plenty of charm and wit to engage and amuse.

Don't expect 90 minutes of action. Instead, writer Glenn Standring and director Toa Fraser take a different approach, providing us with a taut, detailed thriller that re-creates a significant chapter in the history of international terrorism.

Inevitably, some viewers may find certain scenes are unpleasant and distasteful. But if you like films of an unusually dark hue, you'll find an intriguing revenge thriller here that has the ability to get under the skin.
The Marker is entirely predictable, but it is worth watching if you enjoy dark, brooding crime movies that occasionally erupt into violence.
Quietly heartbreaking.
This is, essentially, a very long outtakes reel.
American Pastoral is a flawed film that lacks inspiration, but it has its moments, and the story might strike a chord with parents.
The whole thing is frustratingly slow and drawn-out, but this is the kind of film that seeps under your skin, and there is no doubt that it is beautifully crafted.
The film rarely rings true, and there are very few laughs along the way.
Cheadle deserves plenty of credit, but his performance veers towards caricature, and the film doesn't quite hit the high notes that it aims for.
If you like thoughtful, cerebral sci-fi films that are driven by ideas, you will be in for a treat.
A timely documentary that examines economic inequality in the modern world.
This delicate, mournful drama follows a family that is haunted by loss.
If you're looking for a globetrotting espionage thriller to pass the time, you could do worse.
In short, it may have been a long time (12 years) coming, but Barbershop 3 is much better than expected.
The Meddler isn't especially funny, but it is charming and quietly moving, and it's the sort of film that will make you want to call your mum.
A solid, impressively realised slice of fantasy adventure.
For those who don't mind unusual films that refuse to provide all the answers, Remainder offers a haunting, intoxicating experience that will linger in the memory.
A watchable but clearly fictionalised account.
Moss and Waterston are highly impressive, but be warned: this is a challenging watch.
The plot might suggest a large-scale epic, but These Final Hours emerges as an intimate film about the end of the world.
While the game itself never feels credible and the climax is weak, the whole thing moves fast enough that many viewers will be swept along.
All of this is entirely predictable, but it is funnier than you might expect, with Cox grabbing numerous laughs along the way.
You don't need to love Oasis in order to enjoy the film, but if you are a fan, you'll be "mad for it".
The film itself is relatively slight, but it's warm, engaging and likeable. In fact, it's a perfect choice for a first date.
For cinephiles and De Palma fans, this is essential viewing.
Radcliffe is convincing in the lead. There is very little action, but Imperium has some intense sequences and offers more complexity than you might imagine.
This isn't completely terrible, but if you want entertaining kickboxing thrills, watch the original.
This charming comedy combines endearing characters with generous helpings of deadpan humour - and the result is quite wonderful.
Poulter remains likeable and engaging throughout. Undoubtedly, his performance is the main reason for watching Kids In Love ...
It's Cameron Crowe's finest hour.
There are times when you feel as though very little is happening, but this is a bold, uncompromising film that gradually takes a hold.

Might be just another instalment in another big dumb multiplex franchise, but it's a beautifully designed and crafted one with much to admire, drawn from the joyful karma of animation ninjas rather than sucked from soulless executive spreadsheets.
Though elegantly staged, Silk is badly written and indifferently cast.
Fortunately for first-time director Alison Eastwood, Rails & Ties is populated by three sensitive actors who tread carefully through Micky Levy's anachronistic script.
The original Saw was crafted with thought and precision. Saw IV is an orgy of blood.
Fred Claus ends up closer in spirit to Eugene O'Neill than it is to Dr. Seuss.
Darfur Now is effective pamphleteering, but only an occasionally compelling documentary film.
Thornton never cracks a smile... His gloom is infectious.
Admirers of Gabriel Garcia Marquez's novel Love in the Time of Cholera will be heartbroken to see how dull translators have drained the magic from his worldly romance.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Never, not even in the aftermath of Pearl Harbor, has Hollywood depicted Asians with more prejudice. To what end?

Frequently gorgeous, occasionally dull, always fascinating.
The Duchess of Langeais benefits from many New Wave innovations -- long, fluid takes and loosely organized improvisational scenes. Still, it feels like a curiously static entertainment.
movie_title: The Duchess of Langeais (Ne Touchez Pas La Hache)(Don't Touch the Axe) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Though a presentation of 20th Century Fox, Shutter has the look and feel of a proper J-horror film.
If Under the Same Moon is formula melodrama, the film is well acted and its lead character perceptively drawn.
A sour, disenchanted war comedy that affects a breezy style, The Hunting Party was originally called Spring Break in Bosnia.
That Ellroy delivers a crude, undistinguished script here is a pity.
Enchanted manages the trick of recasting sugar spun Disney fairy tales of old into a winning, modern-day comedy. Walt Disney would be impressed.
The film is another example of how talented TV performers often lose their way in movies.
When we get to the top of the roller coaster, the film stalls and slows down.
There is no wisdom or critical acumen in evidence in Shoot 'Em Up, however. Just 100 or so cool scenes masquerading as a movie.
A more than satisfactory scare fest.
What makes Match Point, a coolly deliberate murder mystery from Woody Allen, so startling is that it feels as if the director himself has been done away with.
Why bother suffering through 90 minutes of bad company for a few moments of holiday cheer? Especially when you can still stay home alone and watch A Charlie Brown Christmas somewhere on TV.
An entirely serviceable night out for buddies looking to locate hidden feelings.
Alpha Dog is a commanding ensemble piece.
Heavier than an anvil, more bleak than a foghorn's call ...
The result is a 105-minute cringe-a-thon that reduces the Katharine Hepburn of her generation to a sitcom harpy presiding over a brood of Valley Girl chicks.
The results can be messy.
Like most modern action films, Shooter is too explicit, more interested in mayhem than motive.
Most TV wrestling matches are better scripted than The Condemned.
Is it possible to get mad at a film that has its heart and soul in the right place?
Here's hoping Lars von Trier's retirement will be brief. Cinema needs meddlesome provocateurs. An occasional stone in the shoe keeps us alert.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An unconvincing replica of the dizzy situation comedies that Hollywood poured out in double and triple bills in the thirties and forties (and went on making in the guise of TV sitcoms well into the nineties).
It lets you off dizzy and confused, whereas the best documentaries leave you feeling that you've come to a settled perspective on a subject.
The film steals one of the best laughs of Jon Heder's surprise 2004 hit, the scene where Napoleon nosedives over a bicycle jump, and stretches the gag into an 86-minute movie.
There is no getting around that the film is as dry as an unpaved country road.

Careers are funny, unpredictable things, and Ice Cube wouldn't be the first charismatic, threatening entertainer to don a chastity belt for a safe ride in Hollywood. Think Elvis Presley or Eddie Murphy.
An accountant's sex fantasy, Deception is the story of an audit gone deliciously bad.
Anyone who likes pop music or wonders how bands like the Rolling Stones got rolling will enjoy the ride.
Few movies have captured the intoxicating effect of pop culture on kids better than Son of Rambow.
Journey to Mecca is sure to gladden the hearts of spiritual-seekers. Mere popcorn enthusiasts will like it too.
Despite an evident appetite for mayhem, however, Bay is not the right guy to produce slasher movies. Horror requires intimacy.
Pontypool is ultimately a testament to its frequently besieged director's audacity and vision.
A couple of 10-year-old boys all hopped up on concession-stand soda would be ideal companions for Disney's latest: Race to Witch Mountain.
A deliberate, underplayed horror movie that is truly shocking.
movie_title: The Last House on the Left (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It is a film that is just good enough to keep you hanging around to the end, at which point you leave the theatre feeling vaguely let down.
Like Brian and Dom, Fast & Furious would benefit from more female company. And Vin Diesel's mumbling sulk gets to be a drag after a while.
A miraculous, American-made Hindi film that is every bit as tranquil as the blue-green reservoir that serves as its abiding metaphor.
As a spectacle Disney's Earth is right out of this world.
Obsessed is a safe, dull morality play. The most that can be said on its behalf is that, unlike Fatal Attraction, no bunnies were boiled in the picture.
Here's something you don't see every day: a high-school comedy for old poops.
Ay carumba-blimey, what a mess.
Every Little Step is an uncommonly tender and observant documentary.
Filmmaker Hamer isn't being cruel here. He's trying to tell us that conquering the ridiculous is one of life's necessary joys.
At no time does the film turn into a satisfying mystery where the audience feels compelled to guess along with our racing detectives.
The last third of the film is a 50-year-old's little-boy temper tantrum.
In fact, at two hours and 34 minutes, CC2C is too much by a half: too much dancing and fighting and too much footage of the Great Wall of China.
It's like flipping through five years of dog calendars.
Characters are stiff; there is little variety in movement. It's a cheapo product ideally suited for a Saturday-morning pyjama vigil in front of a small screen.

movie_title: Le Voyage du Ballon Rouge (The Flight of the Red Balloon) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Too much of the...film is bombast and street noise.

It's a howl and amazement for anyone under 12. As is often the way with middling kids' movies, parents who grow tired of the film are treated to a satisfying consolation prize: watching their children have fun.
It's kind of sweet, innocent almost -- kid-friendly in the best sense.
An amused and affectionate look at the writer who formed a crucial link between the New Journalism of the 1960s and today's blogosphere.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A meagre, occasionally funny affair.
Strictly one-dimensional in terms of characters and storytelling.
Helen Hunt deserves better.
Yes, Death Race is as brutal as a punch in the face. If you have a hankering for B-movie grime and gore, it can also be a lot of fun.
This could have been good.
An ugly, strictly-for-meatheads comedy that can only be recommended to couples who wear matching Tie Domi Toronto Maple Leafs jerseys out on a date.
Beverly Hills Chihuahua is hardly Best in Show when it comes to Disney dog movies.

movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

David Cronenberg might have made a great movie with the plot to Repo! The Genetic Opera.
The miracle of filmmaker Courtney Hunt's tense, carefully understated debut is that it is made better by its few flights of fancy.
As warm and comforting as a scarf knit by Grandma.
What makes the photographer's story so compelling is that her life's work actually does come alive onscreen.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As the audience moves from feast to feast, watching all the screen characters grow, glow and have fun, we can't help but feel like we're the only ones at a party who aren't drinking.
Feels as forced and sentimental as one of those disease-of-the-week melodramas that were once the mainstay of U.S. television.

Best of all, it doesn't star Ashley Judd, who has made a wearying specialty out of playing tough-tender female cops. Danger-prone Angelina Jolie is on the case here -- an improvement that pays big dividends throughout.

The only good thing about Never Die Alone is its rap-retro soundtrack.
Nowhere amidst all the frantic clutter do we find anything resembling the sweet, nutty playing that elevated The Whole Nine Yards.
An overemphatic revenge fantasy devoid of even a trace of excitement or wit.
Fails to provide enough tension to draw us into what, at first, seems a properly chilling crime drama.
The film appears to have been assembled by agents with stopwatches on their clients.
Other than McKellar's bright cameo, the remaining players seem trapped in a mean, deadening satire.
Such are the dangers of teaching foreign cultures to yelp like Reservoir Dogs.
A third of the way into Soul Plane, maybe earlier if you're in the right mood or with the wrong company, you might actually start to enjoy disliking the movie.
An amiable film comedy that leaves you feeling good as opposed to feeling for your wallet.
Buday is coolly persuasive in the seesaw role of an unbalanced housewife who jerks from despair to anger.
The script is terrible -- a confounding mish-mash of action-thriller chases, sci-fi travelogue and phony political intrigue.

A good stupid movie.
The film more than earns its heartwarming finale by virtue of the skilled performances of the leads.

The film can be recommended to parents of headstrong children who are up for a wild, frequently entertaining, but not always coherent ride. Everyone else might want to download the Disney screensaver.
A knowing, affectionate and often enjoyable film.
An enjoyable, hugely impressive cinematic accomplishment.
Where last time jokes flowed out of Cho's life story, which provided an engrossing dramatic through line, here the comedian hides behind obviously constructed routines.

It's hard to care about a film that proposes as epic tragedy the plight of a callow rich boy who is forced to choose between his beautiful, self-satisfied 22-year-old girlfriend and an equally beautiful, self-satisfied 18-year-old mistress.

Though Bullock and Grant more than pass their chemistry test, Two Weeks Notice isn't much of a movie.
Knights of Columbus! Wouldn't it be great if TV-based comedians weren't afraid of making movies that were funnier than they are?
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Kids attending Agent Cody Banks won't need candy. The film itself is a 90-minute sugar rush.
Despite extra scoops of action, Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life isn't nearly as much fun as the original.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A film full of phony swagger and dialogue so awful you hope for once-distracting conversations to break out in the theatre around you.

Frequently a stone bore.
Meadows has complained that financial backers forced him to cut a third of his Midlands script. The suspicion persists that he cut the wrong third.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in the Midlands (2003)

There is no acting or character development here -- just shouting, shooting and calisthenics.
A stylish, sharply observed erotic mystery.

movie_title: Between Sweet and Salt Water (Entre la mer et l'eau douce) (1967)

movie_review_blurb: A triptych of unrequited romantic tales.

movie_review_blurb: The miracle of the filmmakers' work would seem to be the perfectly struck performances of the leads.

... a curiously listless affair.
A British docudrama that is as provocative as it is timely.

Give the new college comedy Accepted half credit for having the gumption to marry two previously unrelated, seminal classics in American arts and letters.

There is not a scary scene in the whole movie.
Perhaps predictably, the final work in Li's on-screen martial-arts career won't be the film to remember him by.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

For all North Country's blockbuster elements, the film remains a curiously uninvolving affair.
Although flawed, the film is obviously successful in bringing to life what has been called the 20th century's 'forgotten war.'

We leave this movie hoping to see Miller and Lewis together again soon.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Short's fans should wait for the DVD, where they can skip to the good scenes, which amount to 24 minutes of ace material -- perhaps not coincidentally, the same length as an old SCTV episode.

What a disappointment then to report that Just Like Heaven is more like purgatory.
Modestly engaging entertainment.

Black, white and clunky.

Where a Hollywood film of a family feuding over a fabulous estate would surely end with a slapped face and an infantry charge of lawyers, Assayas's work concludes with a smile and a shrug. Life goes on. What else can it do?

movie_review_blurb: As well as unearthing flavourful clips from films only determined cineastes have seen (War Is Menstrual Envy, You Killed Me First), French filmmaker Céline Danhier has reassembled many of the era's crucial players.

A cheerfully offbeat Aussie take on superhero movies.
Continuously shocking and often painful to watch, the New Zealand horror film Wound should challenge its audience, many of whom believe the genre is best enjoyed as camp entertainment.
Warrior is a weirdly affecting hybrid, a 100-proof melodrama that's two-thirds Sylvester Stallone and one-third Eugene O'Neill. Think Rocky's Long Day's Journey into Night.
