Detective Dee is the action flick of the year, a two-hour epic that blows the Pirates of the Caribbean to the Bermuda Triangle.
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An ingratiating comedy based on the premise that it takes a village to raise an adult.
A routine, if rather gruesome thriller with attractive leads ducking in and out of danger.
Gatien's story is worth telling. Which makes it all the more unfortunate that director Billy Corben presents it in such a methodical fashion.
The kinder, gentler Kung Fu Panda 2 will surely try the patience of older children and fun-seeking parents.
What prevents the film from being a real crowd-pleaser, the Philadelphia Story that it clearly wants to be, are the marrying couple.
Always preposterous though never actually silly, knowingly funny without ever being self-conscious, Fast Five is a passable action flick that will more than entertain its core audience.
What pop spectacle!
Mozart lovers will be intrigued but dissatisfied.
If you yourself are stoked for a lurid, oversexed, stupid-with-Freud Midnight Movie extravaganza -- a trip to El Topo via Mulholland Drive -- there are worse ways to spend 2 1/2 hours.
The engrossing story of a Palestinian infant with a rare and deadly disease who can only be saved by a Jewish doctor in the Tel-Hashomer Hospital in Jerusalem.
Patricio Guzmán's documentary, Nostalgia for the Light, pays equal attention to the astronomers and searchers, regarding their quest as the same -- a search for life.
Although his first film is only a partial success, Yang Ik-june is a filmmaker worth watching for.
The Eagle makes for an okay parent-and-young-son film outing. But you'll want to get your youngster the Sutcliff paperback.
Sandler and Aniston easily pass the only important test of romantic comedies: We like them and want them to like each other. If only the other cast members were as good.

The most gripping war movie you'll see this year, We Were Here tells first-hand the story of how AIDS attacked San Francisco, killing more than 15,000. Whole peer groups were happy, healthy, and then dead in months.
STMS succeeds as an Ontario Gothic mood piece, a story of alternately repressed and exploding passion.
Even though Mars Needs Moms isn't female-friendly, mothers looking for quality time with 6- to 12-year-old boys could do worse than book group passage there soon.
At the same time overemphatic and insecure.
It's a slight, charming, thoughtful movie; one that can be recommended to fallen idealists of every persuasion.
It's a great act that makes for a spry, likeable movie.
The Diary of a Wimpy Kid series might more aptly be titled Diary of a Wimpy Family.. The film sequel is more engaging than the original was because it spends more time at home.
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Director Jones and screenwriter Ben Ripley also deserve credit for expertly shuffling the plot.
While we have much to admire here, there is no way around it: Exit 67 is a thumpingly dull, pulp-free meditation on gangsta movies that comes with way too much earnest, self-conscious chatter.
[Morris's] new comedy has a provocative, ticklish premise -- five North England Muslims become suicide bombers, but can't decide who or what to take with them.
he half-dozen songs here, performed mostly by Davis, are lovely bits of music-hall camp, reminiscent of the English band Beautiful South's sharp-witted ditties.
A Matter of Taste does an admirable job demonstrating how much body and soul go into a good restaurant.

Though hardly indispensable, Trespass is an agreeable time-waster distinguished by one good performance and enough clever twists to keep you, if not on the edge of your seat, at least happily alert, guessing along with the plot.
If only there was more of Dustin and his colleagues' back story in Fightville, the fight film might have been a real knockout.
The Three Stooges weighs in at about 15 howlers over 90 minutes. Not bad, about the same ratio of hilarity to hokey as the Stooges' old shorts.
A surprisingly tender look at San Diego Comic-Con...
movie_title: Comic-Con: Episode IV - A Fan's Hope (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The big-budget South Korean film is a mash-up of Chariots of Fire and Saving Private Ryan linked together with pounding orchestral swells. The film too often gets stuck in a shooter video game groove upon entering Spielberg domain, however.
Adolescent boys will savour My Way's bombast and solemnity. Cringing adult audiences will more likely beat a retreat before final call.
A sharp little cult thriller with a do-it-yourself ending.
Dark Shadows' only meaningful relationship is between Depp and his audience. He's a persona now, no longer an actor.
Watching Jesus Henry Christ sometimes feels like being trapped in a building with a faulty fire alarm.
The Intouchables works as a crowd-pleaser not because it's true, but because it's a plausible enchantment.
Like so much adolescent, made-for-guys comedy-horror, Piranha 3DD is so weirdly uptight about women you figure exhibitors should hand out teen health guides as well as 3-D glasses.
What could these women see in a dreary sack of mutton like Ricardo?
Bourne fans will find much to enjoy about The Bourne Legacy, even if they are forced to do without the title character.
Here Comes the Boom will probably connect like a haymaker with most of its intended audience. The leads are likeable, and the plot, though beyond incredible, is at the very least distracting.
Seen again a quarter-century later, we marvel at how the filmmaker generates so much tension and sweat with a bare minimum of moving parts.
In his new work, Lucas often forgets his story to linger on sets. Perhaps more accurately, this is a film about sets and mythologies that come out of the cheesiest sci-fi tradition.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Confirms the perception that only losers attend high-school reunions.
It would be interesting to see what Guez, a director who clearly knows his way around a camera, might be able to do with a few charismatic actors.
Though only 85 minutes, the film captures an entire, bewilderingly extended family and way of life inside a sturdy frame.
movie_title: Family Portrait In Black And White (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Greenwood is excellent, as always. And a carefully measured performance by Sonja Bennett as Maggie's confused, protective mother contributes to a sense of stampeding panic.

The Revolution will not be televised, Gil Scott-Heron once sang. Nor should it be filmed, we might add -- at least not as a costume drama with stirring speeches, an inspirational love story and gloriously heroic military charges.
Though beautiful to look at and graced with moments of ticklish camp, The Skin I Live In is also sluggish, arbitrarily conceived and, especially in its sagging middle, unaccountably dull.
Peterson's frantic, charismatic performance captures the giddy, hallucinatory velocity of war.
Spacey is mesmerizing as Sam, a weary, aging lion losing his appetite for antelope. And Irons plays the villain with magisterial ease.
The Mill and the Cross may thrill you. But be prepared for a fight. Twenty minutes in, your companion may throw up his or her arms and complain, "This is like watching a painting dry."
Though often fascinating and beautiful to look at, Surviving Progress falls into the adapting-a-book-into-a-movie trap. Trying to do too much too fast.
Quote not available.
Funny in both official languages, French Immersion is the story of career-conscious English Canadians who flock to a small Quebec town to meet a Tremblay and learn French.
Though it never quite has us by the lapels, the film is a solid, workmanlike action flick.
Tediously overwrought and drably made, with scenes punctuated by synthesized drums out of eighties American TV drama.
Unfortunately, Moon Point's fresh, interesting ideas are compromised by an often mean and shallow script.
The Mysterious Island is everything a 12-year-old boy could want - endless adventure involving a reckless adolescent hero, with a pretty girl in a clinging T-shirt around to watch him struggle.
Hallucinatory, elliptical, with dialogue as rich as chocolate cake, this is the self-proclaimed Demon Dog of American crime fiction at his fevered best.
Vince Vaughn is nowhere in sight, so you know it can't be a Valentine's Day offering from the Western world. It tries though. It tries.
Good Deeds is more proof that Perry is a crude dramatist.
What a disappointment.
Some films need script doctors. A slow, unconvincing cable-TV movie, Not Since You requires script hospice workers.
Guy and Madeline is a decidedly modern film, whose frightened, impulsive, charming characters could walk into our lives tomorrow.
movie_title: Guy and Madeline on a Park Bench (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like many good documentary filmmakers, Tristan Patterson is a talented eavesdropper who lets characters articulate overriding themes.
The Killer subplot looks and feels like it was grafted on with Krazy Glue. Thornton's character never adds up. And the film's big whiplash surprise ending is a real you've-got-to-be-kidding groaner.
Imagine Quentin Tarantino if he got his brow lowered.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What a drag that, one year into Obama's presidency, American films remain so careful about depicting black actors.

This one is simply a diverting, uncommonly violent action flick. No need for an extended critical postmortem. Except to say the Wachowski brothers' trademark seems to have turned into a designer brand dedicated to producing inexpensive knockoffs.
It's a historical war movie with impressive sweep, strong characterizations and the kind of idiosyncratic flourishes that made Woo such an irresistible storyteller.
The film might succeed as a travelogue were it not for writer-director Majmudar's treacly narration.
High Life is filled with surprising, artful flourishes.
At first glance, it feels like one of those inspirational weepies TV used to churn out, with a seasoned actress like Elizabeth Montgomery playing the flinty heroine.
Tooth Fairy makes the mistake of having too many anxious hockey players remain on the ice after their shift has ended.
A surprisingly unruffled tale of love, thievery, murder and revenge.
Another date movie-horror flick designed to scare tentative couples into each other's arms.
Unfortunately, everything the neo-Vikings say is unchallenged.
The resulting reconstruction is a triumphant realization of Clouzot's vision.
The film is agonizingly slow.
Too soon though -- maybe 30 minutes in -- audience laughs turn to chuckles, fading to worn smiles.
This dog can hunt. On the ground. Way-way up in the air. Swimming through clouds breathing fire. Imagine Old Yeller on a hundred pep pills.
We never get under the skin of anyone here. Freaks never become characters. They're objects of derision.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Throw in enough symbolism to choke an English-lit major and you have a film challenge that too often feels like a chore.
The film succeeds as a vehicle for Rock's personality.
There are six new songs in the remake, but not one makes any impact, or is likely to end up as the ring tone of 2010.

Director Alison Reid's film is too content to play the kooky in-laws for easy sitcom chuckles. Nor does Reid really make much out of the film's mockumentary format, dropping the premise in the film's final reel.
Watching Moon is kind of like seeing a booster rocket thrust seventies' sci-fi films deeper into orbit.
[Columbus'] new film feels curiously outdated.
Though The Stoning of Soraya M.' s heart is in the right place, its head is lost in storm clouds of anger.
Yolande Moreau is a revelation in the title role; a part she plays without vanity and sneaking humour.
On an adult fun meter, it would rate somewhere between a parent-teacher meeting and a trip to the orthodontist to outfit your kid with braces.
A Perfect Getaway is the rarest of film treats -- a B-movie that knows where it's going and how to get there.
Like all true filmmakers, Demme also has an eye for telling details.
You wear a smile right through the surrealist spoof Cold Souls, but leave the theatre feeling somehow under-entertained.

While Coppola seems revitalized by quoting from movies he studied at UCLA film school, what ultimately makes Tetro so compelling is the filmmaker's return to the motifs that made his 1970s films powerful.
It would be a shame if the most exciting and thoughtful CGI action movie of the year didn't find an audience because the film's heroes fail to pass the suspiciously high superhero-fitness test.
Hang in there Jen. You can do better.
No comedy should come bogged down with so many Important Life Lessons.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Pour Elle is a smart, startling thriller; a perfect date movie for couples who like to smoke afterwards.

Alvart's cynicism about the current state of mankind helps make futuristic Pandorum interesting, but what makes it fun is his evident enthusiasm and talent for exploring the conventions of sci-fi films.
Every new zombie movie, however, has to be a little bit different than the one that came before it. Otherwise, it wouldn't be horrifying or much fun.
The new G.I. Joe movie cost $175-million (U.S.) to make and is as cluttered as a nine-year-old's bedroom.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Raymond de Felitta understands that a proper farce, like a good campfire, needs plenty of friction to get started.
Make no mistake, they're becoming Trailer Park Men, demonstrating sure signs of maturity
movie_title: Trailer Park Boys: Countdown to Liquor Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film exhibits another flaw common to film biographies: Directors Espen Sandberg and Joachim Roenning seem more interested in making a shrine to (as opposed to a biography of) their war hero.
Sorry, mis amigos, wrong decades. The modern B-movie would seem to be devoted to self-conscious fun. More laughs, but fewer real chills.
Piché remains effective melodrama.
A wickedly funny noir.
None of this is the least bit funny. Or in any way entertaining. It's just another teenage-clown-in-a-dunk-tank flick. Everyone fire away.
After preliminary special-effects high jinks -- wolves bobsledding a hollow log down a twisty mountain run -- Alpha and Omega kicks into An Important Life Lesson.
A Woman, a Gun and a Noodle Shop is great to look at. It's just not much fun to watch.
movie_title: A Woman, A Gun and a Noodle Shop (San qiang pai an jing qi) (A Simple Noodle Story) (The First Gun) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The result is a harrowing, unsettling journey -- a terribly moving document.
For all of Solondz's mischief, we sense he likes his unhelpable characters, and that they maybe like each other. A little bit, anyway.
A mesmerizing talk-a-thon with smart, useful things to say about life, love and rock 'n' roll.
Hey, I might be flunking Calculus, young viewers tell themselves, but at least I'm not letting someone swing a dead mackerel in my face.
A 1930s-style, boy-meets-girl, boy-loses-girl songfest. With sticks, skates and a puck.
The film is achieved with a rare tenderness and grace by 29-year-old French actress-filmmaker Mia Hanson-Love.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, there are almost no film or storytelling skills at play here.
A coming-of-age drama so Irish you'll want to take out your Pogues' lyric sheets beforehand to brush up on Gaelic mumbling.
The movie is badly made, meandering and overemphatic in the way of much left- or right-wing pamphleteering.
An okay thriller with lots of smart flourishes, The Next Three Days has us hooked early on but never quite gets us in the boat

This portrait of a Beatle as a young man also gives filmmaker Sam Taylor-Wood, working on a thoughtful script by Matt Greenhalgh, creative room to manoeuvre, introducing us to John just as he and rock 'n' roll discover one another.
Even Romero's staunchest fans might conclude their hero is going through the motions here. Yes, almost like a zombie.
A splendid adventure sure to thrill children and fantasy buffs, while leaving everyone else passably entertained.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The new documentary on Joan Rivers is so in your face, so fraught with harrowing, oversized personal stuff, you might want to get a theatre seat a couple of rows behind where you normally sit, to safely take it all in.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Fitfully charming and sitcom cute.
And unlike many filmmakers who make movies to take pictures, Blakeson is interested in his players. His three principals deliver convincingly messy, ambiguous performances.
As you might guess, after a great deal of sniping Sophie and Charlie supposedly fall for each other. But the audience never buys it.
The shout line on the Shrek Forever After poster says it best: It ain't ogre till it's ogre.
Although often charming, Micmacs seems so pleased with itself that it hardly needs an audience.
Maybe filmmakers should shoot what Ashton's up to off-camera, because not many laughs are making it to the screen.
Dunn and McFadyen have done Geddy Lee, Alex Lifeson and Neil Peart the service of resolving their eventful, four-decade career. It's a smart, lyrical, often funny movie.
Cheerfully profane in the manner of a dormitory bull session.
A bracing survey course on the mystery genre set in a Scandinavian landscape as cold as a killer's kiss.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There are audience rewards for sticking with the herd and its lonesome cowboys.
A bluntly effective media campaign as opposed to a well-articulated documentary.
A vampire movie without enough sharp teeth.
It's Duvall and Murray who make Get Low a small, wonderful thing.
The Expendables isn't as much fun as it should be.
Calling Jonah Hex a waste of time requires qualification, given the action flick weighs in at 82 minutes.
In the cookie-cutter world of movies, it's a pleasure to come across a story you've never encountered before. Or ever will again. A film for which there can be no sequel.
movie_title: The Immaculate Conception of Little Dizzle (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This polished Danish thriller about a sensitive female werewolf is full of restrained horror and tastefully Scandinavian carnage.
A slick, witty, fast-moving blend of sports story and history lesson with clear appeal beyond the hockey-fan demographic.
A Life in Dirty Movies is a celebration of an unusual talent, but also an elegy for an unfulfilled life.
Serena only has one key flaw: it is difficult to believe a single word of it, still less to care about these relentlessly selfish and short-sighted characters.
A witty, warmhearted, imaginative documentary about the British rock band Pulp's farewell hometown show.
movie_title: Pulp: a Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets (2014)

movie_review_blurb: For Those in Peril is a strikingly original feature debut from the 31-year-old Scottish writer-director Paul Wright that resists simple categorization.
A fresh and original debut that is purely pleasurable.
Filmage offers an entertaining history lesson about how the alt-rock geeks did not quite inherit the earth.

All champagne and strippers, conspicuous consumption and witless machismo, Plastic is a contemporary British heist movie that already feels dated, as if it were made before the bubble burst on Guy Ritchie's comic book gangster voyeurism.
Dolan's fifth feature feels like a strong step forward, striking his most considered balance yet between style and substance, drama-queen posturing and real heartfelt depth.
Once the action heats up, Bong delivers a rich feast of political allegory and bloodthirsty carnage. Snowpiecer is no masterpiece, but an agreeably unorthodox, impressively arty blockbuster.
A partially successful hybrid of social-realist drama and escapist revenge thriller.
A fairly gripping thriller, and Rasoulof's most angry work to date.

An ingenious micro-budget science-fiction nerve-jangler which takes place entirely at a suburban dinner party, Coherence is a testament to the power of smart ideas and strong ensemble acting over expensive visual pyrotechnics.
Beautifully shot with an acute eye for crisp composition, this intimate mood piece explores the subtle intricacies and low-level power struggles of long-term love in forensic detail.

The characters are cartoonish, the pacing is bumpy and the plot illogical. Does this matter? Probably not to the film's target demographic, assuming there is still an audience for knowingly trashy semi-spoof horror comedies.
The film's emotional and psychological threads resolve themselves less convincingly.
It is almost perversely impressive how Dahan misses almost every target and squanders almost every opportunity.
An overwrought experiment in cerebral slapstick that misses more targets than it hits.
In fairness, Kidman has a radiant screen presence, even in chocolate-box tosh like this. But everything else about Grace of Monaco feels leaden and laboured ...
Aside from a few lines of juicy bad language, Gomez plays the innocent in this fast-paced screwball farce, which is full of cheerful vulgarity but dangerously low on wit, charm or narrative logic.
[The film] has much to recommend, including gorgeous New Mexico landscapes, sumptuous digital cinematography and -- as we might expect from Klein -- virtuoso editing.
Dowdle delivers enough adrenalized tension to maintain his track record of profitable, populist pulp.
For dystopian future-shock fans who can look beyond its basic design flaws, Garland's feature debut functions just fine as superior pulp sci-fi.
Fast and furious on the surface, shallow and conventional beneath, Diesel's bid to carve himself another billion-dollar franchise is off to a good start with this mainstream crowd-pleaser.
Robust and compassionate.
movie_title: An Episode in the Life of an Iron Picker (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A sensitive dramatization of a highly contentious topic, Three Windows and a Hanging examines the hidden scars left behind when rape is used as a weapon of mass destruction.

This project was clearly a labor of love for Constantine, but it is hard not to conclude that her original documentary idea might have had a lot more passion than this flat-footed fictional treatment.
A dazzling stylistic experiment which largely pays off.

Hawke and Ejogo are both extremely easy on the eye, and share a agreeably warm sexual chemistry. But the movie around them looks a little flat and televisual: too clean, too bright, too period-perfect, too Mad Men.
A harsh history lesson leavened by bawdy humor and classic western elements.
As gripping onscreen as it was onstage, London Road remains a work of great finesse and originality.
Jack Strong is a solid addition to the ever-growing canon of films in which former Eastern Bloc nations reflect on their troubled Communist past.
A cautionary true story about online romance, gay rights and Middle Eastern politics, The Amina Profile is both topical and compelling.
movie_title: A Gay Girl in Damascus: The Amina Profile (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Kim Seong-hun's A Hard Day offers a masterclass in throat-squeezing, stomach-knotting suspense.
This inferior sequel finds the Hollywood journeyman Jeff Wadlow replacing the original director Matthew Vaughn, ditching much of the first film's ironic -humour and unhinged charm.
Amy is an emotionally stirring and technically polished tribute, its sprawling mass of diverse source material elegantly cleaned up, color-corrected and shaped into a satisfying narrative.

The film has an engagingly zippy and colorful visual style, evoking the splashy Summer of Love motifs around the Roses, with allusions to their music videos and paint-splattered, Jackson Pollock-esque sleeve artwork.
A grisly multiple murder case opens up a broader inquisition into racial and social inequality in Tales of the Grim Sleeper.
Do not expect blazing emotional fireworks, just finely calibrated performances and deep reserves of inner torment.
Effie Gray is an exquisitely dreary slice of middlebrow armchair theater which adds little new to a much-filmed story.
A playful blurring of fact and fiction.
Incorporating echoes of the Hans Christian Andersen fairytale that gives the film its name, Powell and Pressburger include visionary flashes of surrealism and magic realism.
Mortdecai is an anachronistic mess that never succeeds in re-creating the breezy tone or snappy rhythm of the classic caper movies that it aims to pastiche.
While Avery handles the kinetic action set-piece with impressive swagger for a first-timer, his self-penned screenplay is a major weak point.
Joy of Man's Desiring touches on questions of alienation and despair in the workplace, but offers no clear insights and reaches no firm conclusions.
As an exercise in retro pastiche, it impresses. But as a postmodern genre reinvention, it fails to deliver.

A sumptuously orchestrated love story about a transsexual man's decade-long struggle to maintain a passionate romance with his female soulmate in the face of creeping hostility from friends, family and society.
Visually impressive but ultimately unrevealing.
It will not teach you very much about either autism or Metallica, but you will leave the theater smiling.
Scafaria and her two likeable leads have made a witty, warm-hearted and impressively original addition to the rom-com ranks.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This is an impressively mature and technically assured work.

An interesting twist on a classic plot, Dangerous Liaisons is essentially a deluxe soap opera. But with its beautiful cast and gorgeous production design, it is still a highly enjoyable way to waste two hours.
A ponderous trudge at times, it is ultimately worth the journey.
Miss Lovely sets out to prove that Indian cinema can be as rambling, pretentious and frustratingly opaque as a European art movie. It succeeds rather too well.
There is love, laughter and whisky galore in Ken Loach's unusually joyful comedy drama about delinquent Scottish youths defying the odds society has stacked against them.
With its universal theme and life-affirming message, it has some of the easy, breezy, warm-hearted charm of golden-era Woody Allen.
This universal story could easily serve as a dramatically gripping primer on topical immigration issues to schoolchildren across the globe, from Arizona to Afghanistan.
Dredd 3D constantly impresses on a visual level, with a gritty style more akin to cult hits like District 9 or 28 Days Later than to standard Hollywood comic-book blockbusters.
One of the joys of The Wild Ones is its formal purity, moving to its own elastic rhythm, enhanced by bold sound design that includes fizzing radio static and disembodied animal growls.
Unfortunately, Omirbaev fails to invest either the murder plot or its political subtext with much suspense or conviction.
Despite some impressively gritty street-level action, Safe plays it far too safe.

An amusing little farce inspired by some genuinely hair-raising true stories. But it loses its nerve in its second half as the need to impose conventional narrative closure eclipses the wacko subject matter. Fun, but forgettable. Burn after viewing.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A highly original portrait of a sociopath in a corrupt, festering, morally bankrupt society, this bleakly funny psycho-horror movie makes for clammy, compulsive viewing.
This is a warm, moving, non-preachy and surprisingly funny slice of contemporary history.
Corbijn has done his research during 30 years as a photographer, striking a realistic balance between farce and tragedy.
An intelligent, provocative blockbuster that succeeds on its own merits.
The director has always been at his strongest on the cusp between anger and humour, but there are simply too few such inspired episodes here.
In pure action adventure terms, Spectre delivers the goods, with plenty of revved-up supercar porn and several kinetic high-speed chase sequences on road, river and snowy mountain slope.

It maintains the movement's stylistic roots in no-frills naturalism and long single takes, but it makes a definitive break in terms of subject matter, tackling a timeless human drama in a contemporary setting.
Triple shot of apocalyptic weirdness from South Korea.
Fortunately, these Mount Rushmore-faced rock icons still have sufficiently supercharged charisma and brilliant music to carry off such a transparently commercial exercise in self-promotion.
Even with a script by the Coen brothers, and a classy international cast led by Colin Firth, this contemporary London caper movie falls far short of its potential even as a lightweight comic romp.
This low-budget found-footage horror debut from British director Elliot Goldner has plenty of chilling atmosphere but lacks bite.
Chen's interest has a tighter domestic focus, gently probing the unspoken fault lines of class, race and age that run through modern, multicultural Singapore.
Sharply scripted character comedy meets shotgun siege thriller.
This rich historical documentary chronicles the emergence of the teenager as a distinct social and cultural group.
Sorcery meets swordplay in powerful low-budget horror movie.
First-time writer-director revisits her bittersweet Tblisi childhood.
Weekend of a Champion begins as a motorsports movie but ends up a portrait of two wily elder statesmen who have survived into their seventies by skill, stealth and sheer luck.
Rufus and Martha Wainwright host an all-star tribute concert for their late mother, folk singer Kate McGarrigle, in this old-fashioned but engrossing rock-doc .
movie_title: Sing Me the Songs That Say I Love You: A Concert for Kate McGarrigle (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The funny side of navel-gazing narcissism.
The film's facile message of cross-cultural unity owes more to fairy tale than reality, but the action is slick and the story gripping.
Detective Bruce Robertson is a diabolically unpleasant anti-hero, but somehow McAvoy and writer-director Jon S. Baird makes us feel sympathy for the devil.
However mindless and heartless it may be, Through the Never succeeds as pure sense-swamping spectacle.
Royal with cheese.
A classic story competently told, Thérèse Desqueyroux is chocolate-box heritage cinema at heart, but a perfectly respectable and emphatically French epitaph to Miller's long career.
There are just enough laugh-out-loud moments here to excuse the lurches into shameless, tear-jerking sentimentality.
Crime but no punishment in remarkably revealing film about Indonesian death squads.
Haroun previously won the Jury Prize in Cannes for his 2010 drama A Screaming Man, and this low-key crime story unfolds with the same kind of thoughtful, resigned fatalism.
Director Frank Pavich's entertaining documentary makes the case for this overblown epic as a legendary lost masterpiece.
Highly original and delightfully unorthodox.
Pulpy prison yarn lacks conviction.
Leviathan is an immersive examination of a highly mechanized industrial process, the men who work at it and the thousands of poor fish who cross their path.
A classy slice of cerebral sci-fi with a literary-cinematic heritage stretching back through Blade Runner and Metropolis to Frankenstein.
This is bleak material, but also a compelling human story with just the right amount of soapy melodrama lurking beneath its frosty surface.
Nostalgia and narcissism from a cinematic Grand Master.

The Girl King really should have been an old-school epic full of palace plots, sword-plunging duels, fiery feminist polemic and bodice-ripping raunch. Sadly, it looks and feels more like a middlebrow TV miniseries, stagey in setting, flat in tone.
[A] rich banquet of mind-bending weirdness.
A potent cocktail of hilarity and vulgarity.
An emotionally absorbing ensemble drama full of dramatic swerves and chronological loops.
An elusive, allusive, classy psycho-thriller debut.
Salama ... uses playful juxtapositions and time-jumping plotlines to make serious points about compassion, generational friction and family dysfunction.
Its noble intentions [are] hobbled by a trite script, flat characters and a relentlessly saccharine tone that eventually starts to grate.
The central drama is deadeningly flat, a chessboard of mono-dimensional ciphers arranged across a schematic grid of good and evil.
A lean 91 minutes long, Cult of Chucky is part self-spoofing slasher, part lowbrow bloodbath and all guilty pleasure.

Fiennes rejects rock-doc conventions like talking heads, archive footage and linear narrative. Which is commendably bold on one level, but may leave some viewers scratching their heads and craving a little more context.
Ghost Stories is a witty and well-crafted love letter to old-school horror tropes.
West aims for a kind of Jason Bourne or Mission: Impossible feel, but he falls short in budget, star power and explosive spectacle.

Puts a smart contemporary spin on lurid giallo-style ingredients, minimizing the voyeuristic violence and maximizing the feminist revenge elements. This stylish, fast-moving exercise in hard-boiled pulp noir punches way above its weight.
The gory carnage is sparingly but vividly staged, the suspense-driven plot twisty enough to tax the brain.
Pavlu's prize-winning performance is the key bright spot here. Brooding and haunted, he conveys a stoic air of quiet desperation with minimal fuss.
movie_title: Meda or The Not So Bright Side of Things (Meda sau Partea nu prea fericita a lucrurilor) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As serious sci-fi, Attraction barely leaves the launchpad. But as superior bubblegum spectacle, it easily blasts into orbit.
[A] formulaic adolescent male button-pusher ... witless and brainless but not entirely joyless.
Tunley confirms his mastery of macabre moods here. Now he needs a bigger budget and a broader canvas.
A ploddingly pedestrian dramatization of Tupac Shakur's brief, tumultuous life.

An Insignificant Man is journalistically fuzzy and unashamedly partial. But it also has the appealing zeal of an idealistic passion project, and has generated an impressive amount of newsworthy buzz for a first-time feature.
A dry and sometimes depressing film, but informative and humane too.
A low-budget British vampire comedy with more bark than bite, Eat Locals feels like a school reunion project for survivors of Guy Ritchie's early gangster films.
A spooky, stylish, spellbinding debut.
For all its high-caliber talent mix, The Snowman is a largely pedestrian affair, turgid and humorless in tone.
A superior B-movie shocker set in the hinterlands of northern Sweden.
A timely and engagingly personal reminder of recent European history.
Banal adventures of a bland superstar.

A lyrical portrait of emotionally damaged misfits sharing a soulless working environment in contemporary East Germany, In the Aisles is full of tender observation and humane empathy for its downtrodden protagonists.

This is a concert movie, but unusually intimate and intense, with ultra-sharp high-end acoustics to capture every textural glitch and microtonal quiver in Sakamoto's deluxe minimalist sound paintings.
movie_title: RYUICHI SAKAMOTO: async AT THE PARK AVENUE ARMORY (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Calls for justice mostly fall on stony ground in The Silence of Others, a stirring documentary about the victims of Spanish dictator Gen. Francisco Franco and their ongoing fight to extract some kind of legal payback.
A single knockout performance does not make a compelling film, and Atef's intimate psychodrama ultimately lacks the imaginative verve and narrative meat to fill its overlong running time.
movie_title: 3 Days in Quiberon (3 Tage in Quiberon) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Horizon unspools at an unhurried, lyrical pace. While the two leads both give crisp, naturalistic performances, the otherworldly setting is arguably the real star presence here.
A polished snapshot of Beck's well-rehearsed shtick, as fast-moving and entertaining as the man himself.
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Piano (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Black 47 feels more like a small screen misfire than the grand cinematic epic that this rich story deserves.
Uninspired biopic sheds little light on unfathomable maritime mystery.
Winchester draws on a fascinating true story but then simplifies and sensationalizes it to fit creaky, clunky horror conventions.
Weak script and amateurish direction sink this dead-on-arrival debut.
While not exactly a fun viewing experience, Repond's somber psychodrama is a compelling piece of work, with a chilly candor and forensic eye for detail that recall Euro-gloom maestro Michael Haneke.
Brichta gives a compellingly wired performance, his fast-talking energy recalling the inspired intensity of vintage Robin Williams or Jim Carrey.
movie_title: Bingo: The King of the Mornings (Bingo - O rei das manhãs) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Pass the bong, dude.
Chilly but stylish homage to vintage film noir.
If Andrei Tarkovsky had grown up in rural Ireland, he might have made a biographical cine-memoir as luminously beautiful as Song of Granite.
With a tone more celebratory than elegiac, this is a worthy screen memorial that should interest serious Bowiephiles and casual fans alike.
movie_title: David Bowie: The Last Five Years (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Darling ... has a gripping obsessive-compulsive energy and an attractive cast of alluringly amoral, sharp-edged Nordic beauties.
As a rousing rebuke to patriarchal power, Masud's assured debut mostly hits the target, even if the overall package feels clumsy and simplistic in places.
A robust, atmospheric suspense thriller that shows how politics and personal ambition can have a toxic effect on justice.
Cox aside, this pedestrian drama is hobbled by too many monodimensional characters and too much overly explanatory dialogue that feels like a dry high school history lesson ...
This compassionate character study strains to hit the same kind of female-centric heights as vintage Pedro Almodovar, but it falls short and ends up something of a soapy hot mess instead.
Decor is a stylistically bold mix of self-referential love letter to vintage Arab cinema and bittersweet social commentary on post-revolutionary Egypt
A fable-like story about a young African girl banished from her village for alleged witchcraft, it blends deadpan humor with light surrealism, vivid visuals and left-field musical choices.
A visually and sonically striking ensemble piece that plays mischievous games with audience expectations ...
Seemingly torn between more refined art house pretensions and knowingly pulpy schlock, The Autopsy of Jane Doe ultimately feels like an unsatisfactory compromise between the two.
A modestly gripping debut which never quite musters the dramatic gravitas that such an emotionally charged true story should.
Even if the message is a little muddy, United States of Love is plainly the confident work of a fast-maturing young filmmaker with a strong voice and a sharp visual sense.
movie_title: United States of Love (Estados Unidos de Amor) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A lightly gothic murder ballad made with great finesse and a fine cast.
movie_title: I Am the Pretty Thing That Lives in the House (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The man and his motivations remain oddly elusive in this blankly heroic, clunkingly predictable portrait.
The jokes are uneven, the caricatures often overly broad, and the plot almost nonexistent.

Lady Macbeth mostly operates within established period conventions, but draws fresh blood from antique material thanks to a sparky cast, subtle nods to contemporary race and gender issues, and a hefty shot of gothic melodrama.
Alas, for all its stellar talent, Free Fire is a scattershot exercise in genre homage that ultimately misses the target.
There is a goldmine of rich material here, all beautifully shot, but fatally lacking in focus or momentum.

Director Wes Orshoski, who previously co-directed a laudatory 2010 profile of Motorhead frontman Lemmy Kilmister, builds a solid case for the band's historic importance in this funny, fast-moving, fan-friendly documentary.
movie_title: The Damned: Don't You Wish That We Were Dead (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A genial study of fleeting fame and its aftermath.
Under The Sun is a fascinating study in state propaganda and the darker truth that hovers just outside the frame.

Aiming for the same kind of affectionate comic tone as The King's Speech, this gentle musical farce from director Stephen Frears hits more than a few flat notes, but still delivers gentle laughs and classy star performances.
[A] charmingly offbeat rom-com.

Billed as the first-ever action movie filmed entirely from the hero's first-person viewpoint, Hardcore blasts along like a supercharged computer-game shoot-em-up, bursting with sick humor and splatterpunk violence.

Take a pinch of Top Gun, stir in a generous dollop of The Right Stuff, add a light sprinkling of Mad Men and you have the formula for this uplifting documentary portrait of former Apollo astronaut Eugene Cernan.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Entertains at a TV sitcom level, with its pithy dialogue, its chorus of thinly drawn caricatures and its cozy sense of mockery towards the failed social experiments of past generations. But as serious cinema, it feels limited for the same reasons.
Misfiring buddy-cop comedy is a less than lethal weapon.
The Merciless is a superior slice of hardboiled pulp fiction in the blossoming "Korean Noir" style.
Swedish writer-director Sanna Lenken's debut feature breathes warmth and humor into a potentially dry topic thanks largely to its terrific young cast.
There is something much more playful and affirmative going on below the surface here, a stifled scream of defiant humanity against a mercilessly cruel universe.
movie_title: Requiem for Mrs.J (Rekvijem za gospodju J) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This genial farce deals in familiar and occasionally glib material, but with a redeeming undertow of self-deprecating humor.
For fans of the original TV series, this reboot will feel like a disappointment. For everybody else, a pointless and easily avoidable misfire.

Let down by its frustratingly disjointed and diffuse narrative, Inflame is very much a debut film. It feels like Ozcelik has important things to say, but has not yet figured out the cinematic language to articulate them.
Chadha has distilled a fascinating and epic true story into a starchy, stuffy, sanitized period piece that never fully engages on an emotional or educational level.
A Cinematic Life ultimately serves as a comprehensive and absorbing primer on a century of Australian cinema.
Boasts a few pleasingly poetic flourishes, but it suffers from some common first-time director flaws, notably a listless narrative, thinly developed characters and a relentlessly somber mood.
Okja is peppered with lost-in-translation lines and clunky tonal shifts.
Even blessed with such a rich subject and vast reserves of archive footage, It Was Fifty Years Ago Today! still has the threadbare feel of an unauthorized cash-in.
movie_title: It Was Fifty Years Ago Today... Sgt Pepper and Beyond (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A minor but touchingly human subplot to the financial crash, Abacus: Small Enough to Jail is both an affirmation and an indictment of the American Dream.
Absolutely Anything is a good idea but is executed poorly, with a lame take-home message about great power demanding great responsibility.
Urban Hymn unfolds in predictably schematic steps and flat, stilted dialogue.
Apted ... brings nothing fresh to the formula besides the minor innovation of dropping an action heroine into a male-dominated field.
Heavy on glib generalizations but light on sharp insights or juicy revelations.

Scholarly cinephiles and punk-rock purists who fetishize a certain kind of old-school bluesman authenticity may find engaging material here, but the shapeless home-movie feel and sketchy lack of context ultimately borders on self-sabotage.
Mad to Be Normal boils a fascinating subject down into a slightly clunky, simplistic bio-drama.
Dozens of documentaries have been made about the repressive Communist regimes of the former Eastern bloc, but few have been as visually striking or as deeply personal as Karl Marx City.
Throwing together multiple characters in a single luxury hotel, this Altman-esque ensemble drama has lofty aims, but misses the target.
While the fuzzy take-home message of peaceful coexistence is something most viewers can get behind, it is also too simplistic and banal to sustain an entire movie.
Pays obvious dues to Hitchcock, Polanski and Lynch, but is too stylish and self-aware to fall into the trap of mere pastiche.

Erase and Forget manages to botch the mission, getting lost in arty ambiguities and lofty political aspirations instead of attacking its juicy target with the required amount of laser-guided military discipline.
After 90 years and more than 50 films, Wajda has earned the right to make stagey period pieces like Afterimage, minor codas to a gloriously symphonic career.
Gigineishvili strikes a careful balance between nerve-jangling action yarn and forensic procedural, even if this methodically non-judgmental approach sometimes risks slipping into aloof detachment.
Over 71 crisp minutes of fast-paced verbal combat, Potter tests the age-old theory that it's all fun and games until somebody gets knocked unconscious.
Although devoted Deadheads will be the prime target audience, Long Strange Trip also provides a detailed primer for curious rock fans who never bought into the cult around the band.
movie_title: Long Strange Trip: The Untold Story of The Grateful Dead (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Exodus frequently feels like it is running down a checklist of scenes and events rather than telling a natural story.
Reminiscent of German Expressionist horror films-The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari in particular-Mister Babadook himself is a masterpiece of design and implementation.
The film looks great and its heart is in the right place, but it ultimately falls into a rut of cynicism and brutality that feels unearned and unnecessary.
If you are an action film fan, you'll like John Wick.
Although the film is relatively faithful to the plot of the book ... missteps in casting, tone, structure and editing leave Horns a barely functional mess of a film.
Coming quickly on the heels of its 2013 predecessor, ABCs of Death 2 maintains the same formula, but steps up its game in several ways.
Spy is elevated by Feig's greatest talent ... his ability to assemble an unconventional, but winning ensemble.
Despite its clever premise, Open Windows never quite gets around to addressing any of the interesting questions it raises.
The film combines the most common tropes of war films and biopics, giving it a whiff of staleness before it really gets going.
Wiig is effortlessly charming as always, despite playing a deeply disturbed narcissist.
Salma Hayek remains as captivating as ever, gracefully pivoting from desperate, trapped mouse to machine-gun-wielding angel of death, often in the same scene.
Although it fumbles with several obvious twists ... Faults makes for an interesting debut and a compelling two-hander between a pair of generally under-served actors.
Although it picks up a bit of steam in the third act, the film will feel like a waste of time much earlier in the runtime.
Director Ekachai Uekrongtham strands Lundgren and Jaa in a series of poorly edited, confusingly shot gunfights that make little use of either man's talents.
Mad Max is a straight forward fusion of two B-movie genres popular in the 1970s: the car chase film and the vigilante revenge film.
Influenced as much by Wes Anderson as by Sergio Leone ... The genre is often presented as myth; this is the Western as fairy tale.
The film lacks the granular realism of the earlier installments, but Miller renders that unnecessary by magnifying the weirdness and insanity that always lurked beneath the series' surface.
Jamaica Inn, while no classic, seems undeserving of its reputation as a failure.
[The script] reduces some of the more complex themes of maturation to something resembling an R-rated after-school special.
[Feels] like a period exercise in the modern, Liam Neeson-led trend of grim revenge films.
However successful [the film] may be at capturing hearts and minds when it comes to social and political issues, it has the early indicators of being a small-scale cult classic.
Swerve plays out like a down under version of No Country for Old Men, sapped of any sense of tension, logic or charm.
The Drop is a pleasant reminder that the days of the quiet 70's crime drama are not completely gone.
Creep is interesting as a disturbing character sketch, but any jaded horror fans will likely scoff at its inclusion in the genre.
Brendan Gleeson gives a career-best performance.
Although it is based on the French graphic novel Le Transperceneige ... Snowpiercer is the best video game movie ever made.
David Wain has created a playfully bizarre takedown of the [romantic comedy] that just barely manages to not wear out its welcome.
Beyond the endless ambiguity of the plot, the film also leans heavily on the relationships between the three leads, which are thin at best.
The film's pat, unsatisfying resolution ultimately doesn't detract from it's minute-to-minute pleasures.
[Aubrey Plaza's] physicality and vocal work alone make for one of the most memorable zombie performances in recent memory.
Do yourself a favor and stick with the original.
The everyday suburbs and wilderness of Virginia come to life as places of rustic beauty and grim reality.
Some viewers of Whiplash may find it morally suspect, but after a final act that grips you by the throat and doesn't let go, it's doubtful they'll mind.
Being about 70% romantic-comedy and 30% quirky underdog sports movie, to call the plot of Cuban Fury predictable would be an understatement.
Based on the YA novel by Meg Rosoff, How I Live Now finds itself hindered by its source material, even as it seeks to surpass it.
The film builds to an effectively tense climax, but spends much of its runtime bogged down by tonally incongruous sub-plots that alternate between boring and nonsensical.
The film's not-so-secret weapon is its lead actress, the late Zoe Tamerlis Lund.
The fights are visceral and gruesome without going too far, but by the sixth or seventh bout, the lack of variation becomes noticeable.
24 Exposures filters its lurid subject matter through the low-key, DIY aesthetic which Swanberg and his collaborators have cultivated over the past decade.
If nothing else, the directors have assembled an impressive, if underutilized cast.
The film makes the most of its premise and small cast, zipping from low-budget drama to sick black comedy to gruesome thriller.
Essentially a gender-swapped riff on the Taken films, the film is as by the numbers as they come.
The last half hour alone ranks it as one of the best martial arts films ever made.
Dom Hemingway lives or dies by the audience's identification with its protagonist.
Shadows seep into nearly every frame of the film, but true darkness never coheres.
While the final climax provides some modest thrills, the hour and change leading up to it is not worth the price of admission.
Director Craig Zobel is less interested in sex or thrills than he is in what people value when their past and future have ceased to exist.
Given how easy it is to pander to cat lovers, Kedi deserves credit for never stooping to outright mawkishness or cheap emotional manipulation.

It seems unlikely that, in an America ravaged by police shootings and generally teetering on the edge of authoritarian dystopia, audiences will be endeared to a pair of gleefully corrupt cops who resort to violence for kicks.
Definitely worth the time of any martial arts fan eager to see Uwais in action while they await the inevitable third entry in The Raid series.
A unique and compelling take on a pulpy, well-worn subgenre of horror.

Fans of Hathaway will likely enjoy seeing her in something that isn't a dopey rom-com or an obvious Oscar plea, but Colossal ultimately feels more likely to be remembered as a flawed curio than a cult classic.
It's hard not to feel bad for Armie Hammer through all of this. ... he's asked to do little more than endure suffering, like Leonardo DiCaprio in The Revenant, except less interestingly shot.
Where the film really misfires is in its action and thriller elements.
Funny and irreverent as well as visually interesting and thoughtful.

On paper, it sounds over-the-top wacky and saccharine, but The Big Sick treats its subject matter seriously and mines humor from the characters realistically reacting to awkward and extreme situations.
While The Salesman forgoes the expansive, knotty moral tapestry of A Separation for a simpler narrative, it maintains the same sharp focus on the complexities of human interaction and moral dilemmas.
To the Bone never quite succeeds ... The direction is too pedestrian, the script too generic and the film as a whole is more concerned with reassurance than with confrontation.
Wind River fails to clear the incredibly high bar set by [Sheridan's] previous films.
Ingrid is a toxic blend of insecurity, FOMO and Terminator-like perseverance ... Plaza has found the ideal vehicle for deconstructing her persona in Ingrid Goes West.

These characters are the detritus left behind by a 21st-century America with increasingly less room for the poor and undereducated. The Florida Project never looks at them with pity, only understanding and sympathy.
For all the murder and mayhem that ultimately ensue, Lady Macbeth is a quiet, measured film.
Super Dark Times appeals to the tactile and sensory memories of anyone who grew up in a middle-class suburb around the turn of the century.
There's nothing inherently wrong with ambiguous endings or obscure motivations in art, but film's ultimate moral question seems to suggest a purpose that is clearer than the one the film presents.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sadly, a few quality gags can't save the film from its flat direction, dull characters and eye-rolling morals about life and love.
M.F.A feels less like a throwback and more like a fresh part of the zeitgeist.
Splitting its time between stoner comedy, violent spy action and indie romance, American Ultra executes its varying aspects well but never successfully synthesizes them into a singular vision.
Unfortunately, The Incredible Jessica James isn't quite as incredible as Jessica James.
After a thirty-year career and four Oscar nominations, Annette Bening seems to have found her magnum opus in the form of Dorothea.
For all its messy tonal whiplash, Okja is an entertaining and occasionally thoughtful adventure tale that will hopefully find an audience on Netflix, if not the theaters.
All the fine actors, narrative subversions and dusty landscapes in the world can't save a film that thinks it's saying a lot without saying much at all.
Combines the city-folk-besieged-by-rural-horror of Straw Dogs with the dark fairytale appropriation of Pan's Labyrinth and the grotesque practical monster effects of The Thing and Alien.
[The film] nicely intertwines the reverence Bergman's fans will have for the icon she was on the screen with the fact that she was a very real person, extraordinary but far from perfect.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Revenant is as gripping as film can get.
Deadpool is arguably the most faithful and entertaining cinematic interpretation of the character that fans are likely to see.
Triple 9 would have had a much greater chance of success as a season of a cable drama than as a two-hour film.
Purely a stylistic exercise.
The endgame [feels] slightly over the top compared to the painstaking screw-tightening of the first hour, but the film remains purposeful and specific even when it finally lets loose.
It's terrifying how little modulation it takes for [Stewart's] comforting baritone to convey utter hopelessness.
Watson has come a long way from her cartoonishly broad performances in the early Harry Potter films, but still feels a bit stiff as Lena.

Although it frequently traffics in cliché, The Autopsy of Jane Doe is an effective horror film, using many familiar elements -- mirror scares, creepy old-timey music, eerie sound design and lighting -- to great effect.
Anyone with any appreciation for small-scale crime stories or the two leads would do well to give it a look.
Maggie's Plan reads like indie dramedy filmmaking 101 ... It's unfortunate then that film plays like a stiff, awkward parody of the genre.

Desierto seems destined to be a historical curio for future generations, an artifact of a dark chapter in American history that will hopefully seem distant and strange.
A work of art all its own, thoughtfully made and deeply affecting.
The Eyes of My Mother regards atmosphere and dread both as its engine and its endgame.
Turning his recent slide into middle-aged paunch to his advantage, Travolta allows a glimmer of the charisma he wielded in Pulp Fiction to shine through.

Every performance seems calibrated to wacky, yet pitiful, which keeps the film entertaining even if you're not actually rooting for any of the characters.
Joséphine Japy and Lou de Laâge are painfully genuine as two very different but equally lost young women.
His visualisation is a joy on the eyeballs.
This powerful film is often harrowing to watch, but it can also be shockingly entertaining as it deftly mixes macabre humor, pathos, and horror.
Stiles's character is finally too opaque, and the mind games she plays on Channing aren't clever or cruel enough to produce a satisfying denouement.
Directorial style triumphs over a nonsensical script (by Scott Frank).
While the antiwar message is familiar, it gains power from the deeply felt performances.

The love story (which features Jason Scott Lee and Anne Parillaud) that means to add pathos to this cultural collision doesn't generate enough heat. But the theme tantalizes, and many of the images soar.
This adaptation is a sleek, smartly plotted entertainment, thoroughly engrossing.

The movie may well make money, but no matter how many zillions it grosses, Tom Cruise will forever after be something of a joke.
There's absolutely no emotional or sexual heat between Maguire and Jewel; they seem like kids playacting at grand passion.
Richard Farnsworth brilliantly embodies a man who combines cantankerousness, tenacity and wisdom.
[The Coens'] most entertaining movie because it's explicitly about old Hollywood, their one true passion.
Chock-full of funny, raunchy dialogue.
A clever and satisfying comedy that comes as a blissful relief from more high-minded festival fare.
The director's strong visual imagination and the fine performances keep us riveted.

movie_review_blurb: Resurrects the manifold pleasures of a polished tale brightened by a glittering array of classy British players.

Because of its superior craftsmanship, In the Bedroom conjures a searing vision of a well-scrubbed American family that lives perilously close to catastrophe.
An impressive achievement on the part of the writer, John Sweet, as well as the director, Charles Shyer.
That rare movie that can be called adult -- not because it incorporates a few frank sex scenes, but because it respects the complexity of grown-up relationships.

Technically primitive but still enjoyable raunchfest.

A modest but pleasingly adult entertainment at a time when even the most promising American films ultimately revert to Pollyannaish platitudes.
Capraesque without being cloying.
Part fairy tale, part travelogue, and part kindergarten lesson in Eastern religion. Not a single part is persuasive or compelling.

movie_review_blurb: The brillance of Downey's performance is that Tony Stark is more of an impenetrable, unstoppable force than Iron Man.
If you're really, really high, you might think that H&KEfGB suggests that we are only truly free when we transcend our own racial identities.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The difference between Apatow and Hornby is that Hornby has written at least one compelling female character.
Clooney tries to Flags of Our Fathers if directed by Preston Sturges.
Jackie Moon is every other Will Ferrell character in John Stockton shorts.
The metaphysical angle is too awkward: Horton comes off like a Giant Flying Spaghetti Monster.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like "Terabithia," willfully darker than most children's fare.
Will Hayes' only flaw is that he's too idealistic--in the same way that John Edwards cares too much for poor people.
Like your high school's production of "Grease": A musical about sex with a chastity belt strapped to its waist.
Paul Giamatti is forced to play Santa like a socially awkward version of Vince Vaughn
Even Martin Sheen is keepin' it real.
Nicole Kidman hasn't been in a movie this bleak since "Dogville."
Completely inauthentic in every detail--the cinematic equivalent of an apple pie from Perkins.
"When We Were Kings" for dorks.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: To Ridley Scott, Frank Lucas is less Superfly and more David Glass.
Like a well-done Produce Pete sketch, Carell peels back layers of banality covering the bitterness underneath.
Tries to be "The Big Lebowski" of the War on Terror.
If, say, Tom Hanks had been cast in the lead rather than Rickey Gervais, "Ghost Town" would be "Wings of Desire" for the "You've Got Mail" crowd. Thankfully, it's more cantankerous.
A journey into Hollywood's heart of darkness.
As for Meryl Streep, you sense that she's thinking what you're thinking: That she can't actually be in this movie.
Julia Roberts damns a paint-by-numbers kit of Van Gogh. Who is she trying to kid?
A Central Station flashmob of a movie.
The only way to understand this movie's argument about performance pay is to imagine Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker watching it.
Harry Potter isn't about the wand choosing the wizard; it's about what education should be about: transforming imagination into reality.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Will Ferrell isn't stunt casting--his size and deadpan are essential to the character.
Jodie Foster invites us to laugh at this guy who talks through a puppet, then scolds us for doing so.
More a horror than a comedic film, as if Todd Phillips is making a kind of "Heart of Darkness" argument with Bangkok as his backdrop.
By filling the plot hole of Lillian's cluelessness with explosive diarrhea, the film undermines the whole "Apatowian Female Comedy" idea.
"Midnight in Paris," a parable about romanticism and nostalgia, recalls Early Owen as much as Early Woody.
"Larry Crowne" is made precisely for people like Larry Crowne.
Ocean's Eleven if conceieved by Tony Scott.
Polanski creates a sublime image of Tony Blair: A man who traps himself in a storm-battered glass house because he lacks the courage of his convictions.
Superbad makes cultural statements that should be every bit as disturbing as blaxploitation's were.
Samantha does everything but draw a picture of the Prophet Muhammad on a pair of crotchless panties.
Perhaps a satire of Nicolas Cage's Jerry Bruckheimer movies.
Asking Juliet Capulet for relationship advice is a little bit like asking John McCain for campaign consulting, isn't it?
It's deeply immoral to turn a ten year old girl into The Bride from "Kill Bill" and pretend it's just a cartoon.
Instead of shooting for 'It Happened One Night,' it opts for being 'The Hangover' for married people.
John Cusack's response to the canonization of John Hughes.
'This is It' is tied together by an aesthetic that can only be called Synthetic Intimacy.
To say 'Precious' is exploitative because it's bleak is to argue that Jonathan Kozol shouldn't have written 'Savage Inequalities' because it shows urban schools in a bad light.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If Molly Ringwold had taken a shot at 'respectability' in a Merchant Ivory Oscar-bait film, this might have been the perfect screenplay.
The difference between 'Crazy Heart' and 'The Wrestler' is the quality of the female characters.
A western bromance.
Kevin Smith sees homemade porn as the end of the empire.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Josh Brolin develops an ingenious physical tic that encompasses the President: He talks with his mouth full, like a man who's bitten off more than he can chew.
Tony Stark is Dick Cheney's foreign policy driven by Grover Norquist's fiscal policy, sold to the public by Ari Gold. Very confusing.
Imagines what might happen if Rod and Todd Flanders grew up and decided to have a surrogate child together.
Linklater shows how Welles' hubris take him from the Caesar of his own theater to playing Falstaff on 'The Dean Martin Show.'
Russell Crowe plays his role as Ethan Edwards for the post 9/11 western.
Spielberg turns a kinder, gentler Minority Report into a tedious, maudlin homage to the New Wave.
Frank Oz has made a career of making comedy out of on-set tensions and his actors' personal anxieties.
Troy proves that Brad Pitt has the nicest rump of any man to ever hail from Springfield, Missouri.
This is why Liberals are losing the environment debate
The lesson of Soul Plane: Being white is so much less fun than being black.
Rowling's prose unwittingly resembles the monster books that try to eat the students.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: If Antonio Banderas would have played Zorro more like Puss 'n Boots, that movie might have been a lot better.
If this is family entertainment, why do the Olsen twins spend 25 percent of the movie naked?
Why does Tina Fey insist on taking off her shirt and showing us her bra? That's very, you know, like, Plastic.
Find one stereotype and stick to it. Don't confuse the audience by trying to be Wayne Brady and Bernie Mac in the same movie.
Hellboy is sort of a Denis Leary Catholic: Snarls a lot, tromps around in a grungy coat, and chomps on tobacco products continuously.
Moviegoers have a duty to admonish Hollywood for turning the multiplex into a Two Hours Hate, asking us to cheer the fascist aesthetic of movies like Man of Fire.
Who knew back in 1981 when Ellen Sandweiss was raped by that tree that this would be the future of Hollywood?
Tries to be the "Ulysses" of exploitation films.
There's nothing more wacky! than teenage porn stars!
The Rock, as if bidding for another appearance at the Republican National Convention, stars in this parable of neo-con justice.
Would the producers please just get out of the way and let Todd Phillips direct the darn movie?
General Jesus Christ is reborn, awarded the most earned Purple Heart in history, and summons his Christian soldiers to march forth and fight whatever battles He calls us to.
Gavin O'Connor takes a potentially jingoistic movie and makes it into a challenging little politcal statement--hey, you get the *puck* out of Afghanistan!
Tim Burton turns a gothic fairy tale into a Steven Spielberg movie.
Why didn't Kimberly Peirce rescue this movie?
I am scared of Ben Kingsley. And for that matter, Jennifer Connelly.
Jackson's movies are a triumph of cinematic voice, much like Tolkien's books are a triumph of literary voice.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The Farrellys most personal film since Dumb and Dumber. Is that a compliment?
A close reading of Mr. Woodcock reveals a dark, depressing film about small town decline. I think.
A Never Never Land Slightly Less Creepy Than the Neverland Ranch
A direct hit on Jesse Jackson.
Resembling Bill Murray's early career, Ron Burgundy is a Peter Venkman/Carl Spackler type performance which will be remember fondly during Will Ferrell's 2020 Oscar run.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Hollywood kids the Democrats because the love the Democrats.
Lieutenant Josh Rushing emerges as a voice of reason, a moral arbiter between al-Jazeera and Fox News.
The story of some nice lawyers who give dozens of pro bono hours working to adopt puppies for orphans before Christmas. George Clooney plays the headmaster.
Benicio is the heroine addict with a heart of gold!
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Linklater's method, in an age when critics celebrate the egomania of M. Night Shyamalan and Quentin Tarantino, distinguishes him as Gen X's most literary director.
A direct rebuke of the pro-torture "24," arguing that torture isn't just cruel to the tortured, but to those who are asked to torture.
Another Frank Oz comedy with a mean streak, this time with such delights as an old man defecating in his wheelchair.
Would be less offensive with a title like "Ladies and Gentlemen, The Bronx is Flaming."
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Gives us the most evil EPA agent in movies since William Atherton unleashed the minions of Zool on New York City.
Moore effectively vents our collective rage, but his Cuba is like the Buena Vista Social Club, but with better benefits.
Yates' vision for Delores Umbridge is simple: She is to leave no wizard behind.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For all the talk of "morals" in the American cultural dialogue, stoner Ben says the only thing that really should matter: "I just want to do right by you."
If This Pays For Another Darfur Benefit, Then So Be It.
It has a Before Sunrise vibe, but the aphrodisiac is music rather than pseudo-philosophical Gen-X ramblings.
As Captain Sparrow himself observes: "The immaterial has become.....immaterial."
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: But how would the rat match up against Iron Chef Morimoto?
The director of Three Kings asks: If all people want is cheap oil and Wal-Mart convenience, should liberals just give up?
Harold and Kumar discover that the American Dream is not to be Doogie Howser; it's to be Neil Patrick Harris.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Antonio should use his Puss n' Boots voice in the Zorro sequel.
Like dadaist art, Baby Geniuses challenge the artist-audience contract: We *hear* the babies talking, but we clearly *see* that they aren't.
John Waters' "The Passion of the Christ."
Why puppets? The form meets function.
The subtext of this film is about John Kerry: The Manchurian Democrat.
In a year where cinema played a crucial role in the Culture War, Kinsey is the only film to dig at the roots of both sides. Best film of the year. Without a doubt.
This should have been an episode of "Curb Your Enthusiasm." Larry David would spark nuclear conflict.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most interesting concepts in American movies this year: The French Nascar driver who is just a compilation of American stereotypes of "Frenchness."
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Understands that a kids movie that's "For Adults Too" means "Mature, Complex Themes," not "Fart Jokes and Sexual Innuendo."
"Music and Lyrics" argues that pop songs are poetry, and in the tradition of Walt Whitman, the film proceeds to celebrate itself.
None of the character of, say, a Will Ferrell movie, or the cyncial wit of Harold and Kumar.
Although its tone is more dreamy than steamy, this film oddly seems a product from the same heated template as a William Inge or Tennessee Williams drama of the early 1950's.
movie_title: Springtime in a Small Town (Xiao cheng zhi chun) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Kate Hudson stars in this mildly ingratiating comedy as a selfish fashionista whose career stops short when she is granted custody of her late sister's three children.
The fizz of playful sexual anarchy bubbles like spiked ginger ale through the comedy, whose two stars are veterans of recent Pedro Almodóvar films.
movie_title: My Mother Likes Women (A mi madre le gustan las mujeres) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This muddled drama begins as a high school soap opera, segues into a boys-to-men military drama and peters out as a feeble answer to Girl, Interrupted.
Only the French, those self-proclaimed sages of 'l'amour fou,' would dream of concocting a surreal romantic allegory like Yann Samuell's grown-up fairy tale.
A vivid and affectionate portrait of Jackie Curtis, the drag personality who cut a speed-driven swath through New York's downtown bohemia in the late 1960's and 1970's.
Just below the sitcom surface of this smart-talking comedy seethes a bitter critique of the sportive sexual habits of Southern California's babes-and-hunks culture.
André Téchiné's taut, swift wartime drama portrays the panicked mass exodus from Paris in 1940 on the eve of the German occupation.
Hector Babenco's sprawling portrait of Brazil's criminal class exudes a throbbing flesh-and-blood intensity so compelling that it's impossible to avert your eyes.
A tender tribute to Nick Drake, the English singer-songwriter who died in 1974.
movie_title: A Skin Too Few: The Days of Nick Drake (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This remarkable if overlong Korean film strips away much of the sentimentality and goody-two-shoes attitudes that the movies traditionally display toward disabled people.
A high-minded, lethally dull biography of the legendary golfer Bobby Jones.
Anne Reid stars in this extraordinarily clear-sighted drama as a recently widowed grandmother who pursues an affair with her daughter's hunky, unhappily married boyfriend.
Jamie Foxx floats gracefully through this screwball sex comedy with a cocked eyebrow and the playful smirk of an overgrown adolescent.
So broad and relentlessly raunchy that it makes a spoof like Airplane seem as demure as a vintage drawing-room comedy.
Diverting (if eccentric) wisp of a movie that doesn't come close to exerting the primal force of something like Cocteau's Beauty and the Beast.
In bodybuilding terms, this overmuscled sequel to Pitch Black is all bulk and no definition.
How young do you have to be before you want to be older? With this wispy pubescent comedy, Hollywood has come up with a number: 14.
Bulgarian Lovers observes the interplay of sex, power and money with a cool, amused attitude and a fine sense of social detail.
The waves get progressively higher in Stacy Peralta's overlong but entertaining historical surfing documentary.
This relentlessly morose movie from Denmark is a sleek, desolate fable about the conflict between corporate values and human needs.
You have the creepy sense of watching adult children (with the singular exception of Mr. Kline, who can surmount any disaster) dressed up in period costume at a school pageant.
Against your better judgment, you root for the pair to beat the odds against them.
Without straining, this definitive, deeply engrossing film biography makes a strong case for Charles Bukowski as a major American poet.
Not even Janet McTeer, one of the world's most resourceful actresses, can rescue this movie from deteriorating into a clanking melodrama.
Strong but muddled Brazilian documentary.
This lush, surreally flavored immersion in voyeurism and romantic dreams muses on many of the same themes as Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window and Vertigo.
Ben Stiller plays a pumped-up fitness guru in a consistently funny sports spoof that unapologetically roots for the über-nerds.
A satisfying slice of old-fashioned storybook entertainment.
The best way to approach Broadway -- The Golden Age (and the movie is fun, despite its messiness) is to enjoy it as a fan's worshipful notes.
As a personality study Imelda is a devastating portrait of how power begets self-delusion.
A family-friendly movie made for the same audience that likes to imagine talking animals.
Barry Levinson's attempt to match the Farrelly Brother in adolescent goofiness has its laughs, but it's really a movie that's afraid of itself.
This musical documentary, which offers a musical mosaic of Afro-Cuban styles, could be described as a basic course: Afro-Cuban music 101.
Most of this weird-for-weird's-sake film is set inside a cluttered store for movie props where a pathologically shy young clerk (Michael Pitt) lives and works.
Nir Bergman's aching domestic drama concerns an Israeli family of five shattered by the recent death of the father.
An intimate scrapbook of the memories of several firefighters who survived the horror.
Isabelle Huppert, an actress incapable of making a mawkish gesture, fights tooth and nail to keep this soft-boiled story of an embittered prostitute from turning to mush.
An incoherent documentary about the annual Burning Man arts festival in the northern Nevada desert.
Amos Gitai's acidly comic study of life in a flimsy Tel Aviv apartment complex is a sour urban mosaic whose seedy characters, try as they might, can't get out of one another's faces.
A sweet little nothing of a romantic comedy that has all the edge of an overstuffed cream puff.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A passionate but messy home movie that looks back at the multicultural, mostly gay underground dance movement in New York that coalesced in the early 1970's.
This flat romantic comedy fails to provide any reason why a spunky girl-next-door like Jennifer Aniston's character would give Ben Stiller's uptight nerd the time of day.
Nick Broomfield's documentary, which chronicles the events that led up to the execution of Aileen Wuornos, is an absorbing film, partly because its subject exudes a scary charisma.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This remake of the 1950 movie is a bubbling crockpot of farcical mush to warm the tummies of anyone who really and truly misses The Brady Bunch.
Geoffrey Enthoven's dour little pseudo-documentary explores the effect of divorce on three children.
As Aileen Wuornos, the notorious Florida murderer, Charlize Theron pulls off the year's most astounding screen makeover.
Its combination of psychological insight and emotional restraint helps it transcend sentimentality.
Frustrating lack of context leaves you wanting a lot more in the way of texture.
A stark moral fable told in the language of the sort of western that Hollywood has stopped making, this Australian film could be viewed as a companion piece to Rabbit-Proof Fence.
Pearl Gluck has made what may be the first movie to evoke in equal measure the attraction of Hasidic Judaisim and the equally compelling reasons she abandoned it.
Bon Voyage, a rich, teeming French farce set in and around Bordeaux in 1940 on the eve of the German occupation of Paris, is a triumph of narrative ingenuity.
Wants to be both a realistic family drama and a mythical odyssey but lacks the substance to be much more than a vignette.
movie_title: The Middle of the World (O Caminho das Nuvens) (2004)
