movie_review_blurb: Hypnosis in the movies has always been synonymous with hocus pocus, and the tradition continues in this flashy, mildly tingly British thriller.
The brassy cross-dressing farce Connie and Carla shows that Hollywood still gets the jitters about gender-bending.
Enduring this black-and-white mood piece from Mexico is like putting up with an acquaintance who drones on and on about the pain of an unrequited love.
A clever hide-and-seek game of reality versus fiction that reveals itself as not the movie you thought it was when the final credits roll.
Although this visually dazzling movie from Italy takes on many of the characteristics of a conventional thriller, it refuses to go for cheap, vicious shocks.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The sustained force of Bruno Dumont's vision of existence as a swirl of brute instincts may not be easy to absorb, but it marks him as a major filmmaker.
This grueling Israeli documentary filmed in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip leaves you infuriated and mystified.
This soggy contemporary fairy tale is a cinematic cream puff with a melted marshmallow inside it.
Xavier Giannoli's film is an anguished contemplation of life, death and sex in the face of potential tragedy.
The weary acceptance of violence in an atmosphere of perpetual siege is the subject of the Israeli journalist David Ofek's small, chilly documentary.
At its most absorbing, Salvatore Mereu's handsome film slows time and observes the procession of life without comment.
John Henderson's gentle World War II comedy dilutes its soft-bellied sentiment with a steady infusion of whimsy.
Annette K. Olesen's women's prison drama, like so many Scandinavian films, is heavily shadowed by the titanic influence of Ingmar Bergman.
Kevin Smith has made a movie so false and blatantly icky that it's the film equivalent of making goo-goo noises and chucking a baby under the chin for 103 minutes.
While you watch the movie, it can seem ridiculously long-winded. But once it's over, its characters' miserable faces remain etched in your memory, and its cynical message lingers.
This Imax documentary, a hymn to the harmony of nature, is a seductive visual tone poem that portrays a world without pain, pestilence or aggression.

Sustains a documentary authenticity that is as astonishing as it is offhand. Even when you're on the edge of your seat, it never sacrifices a calm, clear-sighted humanity for the sake of melodrama or cheap moralizing.
The young director David Gordon Green's first film with a conventional plot is a moody gothic thriller drenched in myth and superstition.
The only real touch of class in the rickety little romantic comedy is Kyle MacLachlan's dead-on impersonation of Cary Grant's ghost.
In the wake of Saving Private Ryan, The Pianist and the mini-series Band of Brothers, this pulpy, sex-drenched wartime epic seems frivolous, quaint and foolishly prurient.
When Sky Captain remembers that storytelling and characters matter more than design and special effects, it charms as well as impresses.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A likable, formulaic sports movie.
Testosterone, a shaky comic noir larded with soft-core sex, is a movie for connoisseurs of male eye candy. It wants to be much more.
Those who fret that Woody Allen's finger is no longer on the pulse of New York City can take cold comfort in James Toback's smudged postcard of a city in thrall to sex and money.
John C. Reilly stars as a gimlet-eyed con man in this clever and diverting adaptation of the Argentine thriller Nine Queens.
From its flickering, inky cinematography to its wavering late 1920's-style sound track, to Veronkha's kohl-eyed vampish look, the movie is an expert parody of a period movie style.
Haunting internal dialogue between grown-up longing for a return to innocence and a child's yearning for its loss.
If this movie is any indication, middle-class urbanites in Italy are even more crass, old-age-phobic and obsessed with body-image than their counterparts in the United States.
It is a chilly study of an uncomfortably common breed of male paranoia.
With its diminished gravitas, this Becky comes across as a lightweight schemer about as formidable as an aspiring trophy wife on a daytime soap.
Far from being a random sequence of oddball occurrences, Cold Fever, under its jokey surface, has a steady allegorical resonance.
A choppy, unsuspenseful succession of chases, melodramatic showdowns and routine special effects.
A free-for-all comic spoof that brings the 'hood' genre of Hollywood films full circle.
movie_title: Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in The Hood (1996)

movie_review_blurb: Wants to be an outdoor, barbecue-grilled Barbershop but lacks the pungency and honesty of its prototype.
[It] may be trash, but it has a maniacally farcical sense of humor, and Tromaville's evildoers are dispatched in ingenious ways.
By treating the genre as a joke, this satire, whose title plays off George A. Romero's 1979 golden oldie, Dawn of the Dead, yields ironic dramatic dividends.
In this tale of karmic payback, a humiliated job applicant lays a curse on a corporate snake that leads quickly to ruin.
This nonsensical Dutch movie musical rides on the dubious assumption that camp and infantilism are the same thing.
movie_title: Ja zuster, nee zuster (Yes Nurse! No Nurse!) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: James Wan's sadistic, Halloween-ready gore fest suggests a reality television competition like Fear Factor, carried to the nth degree of cruelty.
The characters in Happy Hour are stick figures from a musty old teleplay that might be titled The Days of Wine and Malarkey.
This remarkable concert film documents the blues legends who gathered at Radio City Music Hall in 2003 for a historic and joyous musical summit.
The woozy, sinking sensation this Christmas comedy produces suggests a movie slapped together after the consumption of far too many gallons of spiked eggnog.
Christian Bale's 63-pound weight loss makes this bleak thriller one of the few movies to scale the barrier between chilly fantasy and authentic cinematic nightmare.
Offers a fascinating historical look at the technological side of the 60's revolution in pop music.
Shall We Dance?, an Americanization of a popular 1996 Japanese film, is an old-fashioned feel-good fantasy that piles on the euphoria.
The sort of mordant ensemble comedy that Robert Altman pulled off with A Wedding appears to have been a prototype for this flat, funereal farce.
Robin Williams, looking like the world's most constipated mortician, stars in a chilly sci-fi fantasy saddled with distractions and cheesy subplots.
Not a movie of ideas but an emotional and tactile experience of economy-class travel.
Almodóvar has toyed with film noir before, most memorably in his 1997 film Live Flesh. But his newest movie, Bad Education, is a delirious, headlong immersion and re-invention of a style.
Has the good sense to take a large step back from the emotional debate surrounding the issue and scrutinize the history of marriage itself.
A star-watcher's guilty pleasure.

Ingmar Bergman has said that Saraband, his bleak made-for- television epilogue to Scenes From a Marriage, will be his final statement on film. For the great Swedish writer and director, final turns out to mean unbendingly severe.
The movie strains to bend the fairy tale to accommodate another coarse high school comedy of air-headed teenage vixens ganging up on a meek little angel.
A dreary, overstuffed hodgepodge of poorly edited martial arts sequences and often unintelligible dialogue.
[It] may be the silliest episode yet in the popular Karate Kid series.
Because it is a convoluted meditation on the guilt that often accompanies personal wealth, Valeria Bruni Tedeschi's wistful, self-effacing comedy is a movie that will push your buttons.
Includes many fascinating anecdotes about the creation of some of the most famous modern rock and soul recordings.
movie_title: Tom Dowd and the Language of Music (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Only a trifle, but it has its charms, most of them residing in the low-key performances of Mr. Ifans and Ms. Otto, who make an attractive pair of shy soul mates.
Offering few laughs and a climactic scene of breathtaking cruelty, this sour comedy draws you against your will into its malignant force field.
Allusive, and enigmatic, this Thai film is a wistful mood piece whose contemplative tone is periodically punctured with eruptions of violence.
This true story is an unsettling character study of a man self-destructively addicted to flouting authority.
This absorbing documentary by Michael Gramaglia and Jim Fields traces the history of the seminal punk rock band in exhaustive detail.
movie_title: End of the Century: The Story of the Ramones (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Attacks of hunger and indigestion, comic hallucinations and episodes of flat-out insensibility are scrambled together on this goofy roller coaster ride of dope.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: In Patrice Leconte's sardonic psychological thriller, Sandra Bonnaire portrays a Gallic answer to one of Alfred Hitchcock's sleek blond women of mystery.
Zach Braff's small, smart, off-kilter comedy is too self-conscious by half, but its struggle to revitalize a cliche; by turning it inside out is a worthy one.
Lee carries his political exasperation beyond outrage into chaos.

Pits a substantial actor like Mary McDonnell, playing a New York madam, against a bogus story that crossbreeds noirish affectations and romantic comedy into an unpalatable mush that suggests strawberry ice cream slathered with beer.

Mr. Zinn delivers a challenge when he says, 'To be neutral and to be passive is to collaborate with whatever is going on.' Democracy he defines as 'not just a counting-up of votes' but a 'counting-up of actions.'
movie_title: Howard Zinn: You Can't Be Neutral on a Moving Train (2004)

movie_review_blurb: In the wake of 9/11, this globe-trotting post-cold-war melodrama full of standard cloak-and-dagger intrigue has the reassuring aroma of a home-cooked meal served while riding the world's smoothest roller coaster.
Thunderbirds wants to be two things at once: a live-action gee-whiz kiddie flick and a nostalgic spoof of 60's England when it swung like a pendulum.
A Midwinter's Tale" packs together so many characters and ideas that they crowd one another out, leaving enough room for plenty of chuckles but none for belly laughs.
movie_title: In the Bleak Midwinter (A Midwinter's Tale) (1996)

movie_review_blurb: The homosexual panic instilled by Deliverance fuels the running joke driving the uneasy laughs evoked by this loathsome comedy.
Slap an ill-fitting dress on an ugly man and you have instant guffaws. That surefire vaudeville tactic guarantees this chaotic French farce a fair share of laughs.
There are sights in the film that once seen cannot be forgotten.
movie_title: Landscapes in the Mist (Topio stin omichli) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: By deliberately blurring the distinction between highbrow and trash movies, the director mocks his own inclinations toward a Wellesian grandiosity. The strategy allows him to flaunt a liberated cinematic imagination with nose-thumbing glee.
The film is so beautifully acted that you barely notice the staginess of some of the speeches.
Although the series has obviously run out of steam, the ending leaves the door open for Michael's return. Really, it's about time the masks were removed once and for and all.
movie_title: Halloween - The Curse of Michael Myers (Halloween 6) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: When Mr. Leguizamo isn't doing third-rate ethnic parody, he is wallowing in scatological jokes that are so poorly prepared and executed that they make similar antics by Mr. Carrey play like classic routines.

In this likable fable about growing up, learning teamwork and developing courage, three small creatures who dwell in Dapplewood, an idyllic forest, go on a far-flung quest for healing herbs to save the life of a dying friend.
This politically damning profile chronicles the rise to power of Karl Rove, the brilliant, nerdy chief aide to President Bush.
Too much of the film...is taken up with stiff, mechanical chitchat.
Kieslowski conveys the sadness of a world-weary sage.
Benoit Jacquot's small, dazzling film A Single Girl is so buoyant, sharp-eyed and casually sexy it comes closer than any recent movie to capturing the essence of youth itself.
Its picture of a world where people spy on one another reverberates with a post-cold-war paranoia, evoking the chilling notion that privacy, like love, may also be just an illusion.

In the latest episode of the series, which seems to have nearly run out of steam, he is portrayed by Robert John Burke, an actor who bears some resemblance to Mr. Weller while lacking his forerunner's tongue-in-cheek glint of authoritarian machismo.
Although well acted, with early scenes that deftly sketch the atmosphere, the movie, written by Carol Heikkinen, never takes off.

Anyone with the misconception that the spirit of a particular music is not a direct reflection of the souls of the musicians who created it must see A Great Day in Harlem, Jean Bach's small and very moving documentary about the jazz life.
It wants to be at once traditional and morally ambiguous. The two visions don't quite harmonize.
To describe this supernatural soap opera as inept and mawkish doesn't really begin to evoke the awfulness of The Singing Forest.
Its digressive screenplay lacks focus and momentum and is too oblique to connect many of the dots between its characters and their behavior.
Superbly balanced and organized documentary.
Had The Endless Summer II stuck to its subject, it would be a pleasant diversion. But it is weighed down with frivolous travel vignettes that are as dull as they are cute and contrived.
Because all of this looks blatantly unreal, and because the timing of the shock effects is so haphazard, Dead Alive isn't especially scary or repulsive. Nor is it very funny.
A chaste teen-age love story with an ecological sensibility and some terrific scenery.
For all its patness, the movie also has a gritty realism that is not found in many higher-priced versions of the same thing, and its happy ending is not the typical Hollywood leap into fantasy.

It's not hard to view "The Ballad of Little Jo" as an allegorical critique of sex and power and men's-club values in America. In its disdain for those values, the film is as focused and cool-headed as the remarkable character whose story it tells.
Drop Dead Fred wants to be an offbeat cross between Harvey and Beetlejuice, but it is more like a shrill, interminable episode of I Dream of Jeannie.

The conviction of the performances overrides the rough spots in this spare, rather short film. From the moment the doctor begins to awaken from his moral blindness and to connect with others, the film radiates a deep and sorrowful sense of shared humanity

The most intriguing is a glassy-eyed follower whose right hand shoots out a hissing reptile that can extend itself for miles. Exotic creatures like these make watching Mortal Kombat feel like being in a high-tech fun house.

When the movie is concentrating on the book, it is a creepily enthralling document that illustrates the susceptibility to breakdown of what we think of as sanity and civilization. But the film stumbles in its color sequences.
Until it succumbs to one cliche too many, Screamers, which was directed by Christian Duguay, does an efficient job of generating a stomach-knotting tension.
If My Boyfriend's Back is an irredeemably silly movie, it has an engaging lightness of tone and uniformly impeccable performances by a cast that maintains just the right attitude of deadpan parody.
Even being the most sensitive parent, the film reminds us, has its limits. No matter how hard you try, you can't live your children's lives for them.
Because the speechifying lacks the cutting comic edge that distinguishes good satire, Floundering too often blubbers when it should be viciously funny.
Watching the film is like leafing through a giant sketchbook crammed with intriguing ideas that can't all be comfortably fitted into the same master plan.
movie_title: The City of Lost Children (La Cité des Enfants Perdus) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: "Mistress" abounds with sharp comic performances that never stray into caricature or sentimentality.
What Son of the Pink Panther doesn't have, in addition to Mr. Sellers, is a screenplay that is even semi-coherent.
Mr. Van Damme's Gibson is so opaque that he makes Mel Gibson's Mad Max seem weepy by comparison.
Overacted, underwritten, murky (some scenes appear to have been filmed by candelight), and essentially implausible, it succeeds only in churning up an atmosphere of ghoulish sentimentality.
A film that would be twice as funny if it tried half as hard.

Together may not be overtly political, but its vision of contemporary Beijing, where brazen, fashion-crazed gold diggers like Lili bait their hooks to snare arrogant, slippery wheeler-dealers who end up playing her for a sucker, has bite.
Its emotional climate is too extreme to invite identification, and its characters are too single-minded in their revenge to evoke pity, terror or even much interest.
Visual imagination and sophisticated wit raise Finding Nemo to a level just below the peaks of Pixar's Toy Story movies and Monsters, Inc..

With its impeccable timing, steady kinetic drive and superbly choreographed chase sequences through the canals of Venice and the streets of Los Angeles, the movie, directed by F. Gary Gray, feels a like smooth, exciting whoosh down a ski slope.
Forrest Gump has the elements of an emotionally gripping story. Yet it feels less like a romance than like a coffee-table book celebrating the magic of special effects.
If Menace II Society is terrific on ambiance, it is considerably less successful in revealing character.
The movie offers a generous helping of rock 'n' roll but no sex or drugs on the side, unless you count buckets of coffee, the group's stimulant of choice.

Between scenes of splattering gore in which severed heads literally roll across the floor, the movie has a good time spoofing itself and a gallery of mostly sleazy characters who confront a crew of blood-thirsty demons.
movie_title: Tales from the Crypt Presents: Demon Knight (1995)

movie_review_blurb: One of those comedies that might sound like a zany hoot when pitched to a movie studio but that in execution emerges virtually laugh-free.
movie_title: Mom and Dad Save the World (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Most of the time, Richie Rich is too busy oohing and ahhing over the junk that money can buy to relax and have a good time.
Mr. Lemmon and Mr. Garner are such pros that they carry the movie smoothly over its dull patches.
Sends a chill that extends from the cheekbones through the eye sockets to the back of the skull.
Mr. Daniels's luminous performance as the heroic colonel dominates ... half of the film. And when the actor all but disappears in Part 2, he is sorely missed.
Rambunctiously funny.
Loses tension (and ultimately credibility) as it wanders through three possible endings before grinding to a halt.
The film can't seem to make up its mind whether it wants to be a comedy, a fantasy or an adventure film.
Inept in almost every respect.
The actor's voices may suit animated television characters, but on a large screen Kevin Conroy's Batman, Mark Hamill's Joker, and Dana Delany's Andrea sound flat and one-dimensional.
The movie is shameless in exploiting the father-son connection to try to make the star, who exudes a bored, dead-eyed cool, seem sympathetic.
Made up of fragments of dreams, autobiography, documentary footage and re- enacted interviews in New York, this personal collage-movie doesn't add up to very much.

If much of this previously unseen work seems simply frivolous, every bit of it is entertaining. Even when he wasn't being serious, Welles, like all really good magicians, had the ability to mesmerize.
movie_title: Orson Welles: The One-Man Band (The Lost Films of Orson Welles) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Painfully earnest.
By the end of the film, Selena has been all but canonized.
A sleek, amusingly nasty screen debut by a film maker whose television credits include an Amy Fisher docudrama.
A bit more refined in its details than the conventional horror movie.
movie_title: Halloween 5: The Revenge of Michael Myers (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Through it all, Mr. Kiser, who says not a word, exudes the foolish amiability of a partygoer who is beyond plotzed and is living in a private world of his own.
The film takes us so deeply into this shabby, transient world that we feel its texture -- both its scary thrills and its bleak, fatalistic uncertainty.
The film, which was made with only natural light, draws the viewer into its spiritual mood with one breathtaking shot after another, as the camera draws back to contemplate Yumiko from afar.
Offers above-average pyrotechnics, a body count that steadily mounts, and plenty of hand-to-hand combat.
The lifeless music and dance sequences in which the rapper performs with his crew have the feel of low-budget video clips that have been inserted almost by mistake.
It is the unusual film comedy in which the humor springs as much from character as from situation.
The movie's reflective moments belong to Mr. Lundgren's sweaty chest.

Were it not for John Travolta's big-hearted portrayal of an unemployed white factory worker driven to commit a desperate act, the movie would be an emotionally frozen exercise in cautious high-mindedness.
The film is so contemptuous of its audience it doesn't even bother to present a surface resemblance to reality.
A movie that fully lives up to its name, right down to an opening credit sequence rife with intentional misspellings and grammatical errors.
Only a child could love Mr. Carrey's character, but that may be the point. The movie has the metabolism, logic and attention span of a peevish 6-year-old.
More so than the exuberant movie miracles that came before it, this latest animated juggernaut has the feeling of a clever, predictable product.
How could an action-adventure film that cost $34 million, most of which clearly went into pyrotechnics, computerized special effects and scenic locations, end up looking cheap, silly and lifeless?
movie_title: Highlander III: The Sorcerer (Highlander: The Final Dimension) (1993)

movie_review_blurb: One moment, ''Head Above Water'' plays like a clanking melodrama, the next like a gallows comedy of corrupt yuppie manners.
As cartoonish as its star.
Wagons East! has the distinction of being Candy's final film, and it is dedicated to his memory. That, unfortunately, is its only distinction.
A comic meditation on desire, disguise and inherent bisexuality.
It is a strange piece of work.
Mr. Wayans is an agreeable screen presence, but he makes a surprisingly bland action hero.
When Bob Rafelson decides to get nasty, he really means it.
A witty, extravagantly picturesque homage to Sergio Leone.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in China (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The impressive acting can cover up only so many glaring holes in a film that doesn't really know what it wants to say.
Careful is one long and amusing pun on German Expressionistic film imagery, Freudian psychology and quasi-Wagnerian storytelling, all carried to absurdist lengths.
Instead of exalting physical grace and virtuosity, this film's slapdash action sequences resort repeatedly to the old trick of accelerating the action to the speed of a silent-film chase.
Under the direction of Andy Tennant, the Olsen sisters lay on the icky-poo cuteness with several trowels, often delivering their lines as though they were reciting the alphabet.
Led by Ms. Bettis's discreetly campy May, the performances are a cut or two above what you would find in the average slasher film. But in the end that's all it is.
As an aching meditation on the power of beauty, this hits home.
Despite its messiness, Tycoon is a movie wired to the moment. Like certain Spike Lee films, it is a cinematic newspaper whose alarming headlines cry out not to be ignored.
Since Otar Left sustains a perfect balance of pathos, humor and a clear-headed realism.
Although the supporting performances are carefully shaded caricatures, Die Mommie Die! is really Mr. Busch's show. Within the cramped limitations of drag, he exudes a genuine screen charisma.
If there's one movie that ought to be studied by military and civilian leaders around the world at this treacherous historical moment, it is The Fog of War.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Hard-headed documentary.
A synthetic mush of molasses-soaked pablum.
[David Zucker] still has the eye, ear and metabolism of a hyperactive child weaned entirely on candy bars and educated by Mad Magazine.
More than a scary close-up look at the raw mechanics of a power grab, the film is also a cautionary examination of the use of television to deceive and manipulate the public.

If Brother Bear aspires to be The Lion King Plus, that plus is the infusion of ethnographic kitsch recycled from earlier Disney hits like Mulan and Pocahontas that adds moral tone, but no extra entertainment value.
At once too densely populated and too clinically detached.
Ms. Gershon's hot-wired performance infuses Prey for Rock and Roll with a bracing charge of authenticity.
What distinguishes Raja from every other movie to contemplate the treacherous intersection of passion, avarice and power is its unsettling emotional honesty.
A very funny for-kids-of-all-ages delight that should catapult Mr. Black straight to the top of the A-list of Hollywood funnymen.
[A] moving documentary.
A dawdling affair that never finds its own rhythm.
Bright Leaves leaves you feeling invigorated by the boundless curiosity, humor and high spirits of its creator.
As the film veers uncertainly between meticulous historical recapitulation and shameless hokum, it brings enough characters to populate a mini-series.
An occasionally savvy farce that suffers from attention deficit disorder.
An oddity that takes itself much too seriously.

What Alice Found, a small, finely wrought drama about a naïve young woman who gets lost on the American highway, gives that wonderfully salty New York stage actress Judith Ivey one of the chewiest roles of her career.
A fascinating but disorganized documentary.
movie_title: Forget Baghdad: Jews and Arabs - The Iraqi Connection (2003)

movie_review_blurb: An unforgettable experience.
Without pushing too hard, the film makes a case for Bowery as a significant artistic catalyst blazing a glittery trail at the intersection of fashion, pop music and surrealist performance.
Suggests a particularly wretched episode of Star Trek tricked out with fancy fireworks and weighed down with a score that grinds away like a cement mixer.
[A] powerful sweat-stained swatch of Argentine neo-realism.
Is as unrelenting an exploration of isolation and dissociation as Roman Polanski's Repulsion.
Does a fine job of building up a sense of dread as its adulterous relationship gathers steam. So it's all the more disappointing when the movie ultimately collapses.
Little more than a vignette elongated into a feature-length movie. Moody and slow moving, it depends on the truthfulness of its performances to carry it.
If Mail Order Bride, a strained, incoherent farce, accomplishes anything positive, it will be to drive another nail into the coffin of that exhausted subgenre, the mob comedy.
This wistful, soft-edged portrait of Rodney Bingenheimer, a social impresario of the Los Angeles rock scene, keeps its claws carefully retracted but still leaves a bitter aftertaste.
If the movie ... has loads of nerve, its ambitious fusion of cartoons and live-action comedy is only fitfully amusing.
For all the grimness and desperation on view in Mango Yellow, the characters emerge as robust, full-dimensional people in touch with their explosive feelings.
A crude but stirring video documentary.
movie_title: Steve Earle: Just an American Boy (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Despite its crudeness, the film has a number of scenes that are so real they hurt.
Too fragmentary and too devoted to its self-referential ethos to transcend its insular vision of rock's lunatic fringe.
movie_title: Southlander: Diary of a Desperate Musician (2001)

movie_review_blurb: An unusually subtle and convincing study of group psychology and fluctuating morale among professionals under stress in close quarters.
The entrancing visual imagery goes a long way toward filling in the screenplay's gaps in logic.
The images of the land... exert a nostalgic tug for a Norman Rockwell dream of which this family, in better days, seemed to have found a piece.
This story of a shy Canadian professor who weds a younger Mexican woman he has met online is not content to be a feel-good intercultural idyll.
Tasty French souffle.
A sleek-looking film with intense performances by its cast, Confusion of Genders has nothing to say that wasn't put much more succinctly in a minor 50's pop hit for Sarah Vaughan ...
Madame Sata is no exotic tour of the slums of Rio. It takes you deeper into the soul of its title character and his desperate world than you imagined a movie could go.
For all its oversights, absurdities and unconnected dots, Tattoo succeeds in getting under your skin.
[A] standard variation of the princess myth.
A cautious, digressive expose of the girls' exploitation by their families and by the managers of the Great Rayman Circus.
Watching On_Line is a dispiriting experience that leaves you with a nagging 'Is that all there is?' feeling about sex in general.
The movie's disparate voices coalesce here as an emotionally charged microcosm of the conflict and suggest how difficult it would be to sustain any peace.
If you're attracted to pure, exquisitely photographed cinematic depictions of the world, you could almost lie down in Hukkle as if it were a meadow and soak in its sun-drenched atmosphere.
The motion picture equivalent of Cheez Whiz.
Is The Heart of Me tasteful? Yes. Is it compelling? No.
A peppy romantic trifle from France that rises above the mundane on the strength of its beautifully detailed lead performances.
Tautly acted, fairly sexy and atmospheric.
Far too much of the movie's energy is devoted to rampaging hormones and irritable bowels.
When focusing on its four main subjects, Catching Out is an absorbing, picturesque group portrait.
A skillfully organized account of Mr. Rogowski's life and of the sport's boom period.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The movie ultimately belongs to Mr. Dorff, whose villain is as frightening as any human reptile to have slithered onto the screen in quite some time.
The movie's even-handed portrayal of two cultures uneasily transacting the most personal business resonates with truth.
May be pure hokum, but at least it knows how to spin a yarn.
A meticulously structured portrait of a complicated man who remains elusive even after key elements of the puzzle have been pieced together.
This remarkable woman has no messianic illusions, despite her celebrity.
An unusually potent blend of dread, gore and gallows humor.
A feel-good romantic comedy without a shred of credibility.
A piercingly poignant then-and-now portrait of five friends who worked as summer guides on the Colorado River in the 1970's.
May be the nadir of the subgenre that produced The Exorcist (at its high end) and Stigmata (at its middle-to-low end).
At 133 minutes, Home Room is sluggishly paced and refuses to lighten up for even a second.
A dramatically compelling clash.
A nauseating bowl of treacle about a man who discovers heaven in his own backyard.
A satire of contemporary sexual warfare that leaves you smiling but also stung.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Bed (2003)

movie_review_blurb: This is the kind of comedy in which the characters are construction-paper cutouts whose abrupt changes of heart are dictated entirely by the preposterous plot and not by psychological or social reality.
Ms. Khoury, often filmed in close-up, gives a deeply sensitive, unsentimental performance.

As much as these wonderful actors invest their performances with psychological nuance, their efforts go mostly for naught in a movie that gives character development a distant back seat to the grinding mechanics of its formulaic plot.
A lip-synching hall of mirrors, it is essentially a piece of highbrow karaoke.
A film that takes in the topsy-turvy world of contemporary Tel Aviv through an adolescent's distracted glances.
Pierce Brosnan and Salma Hayek play partners-in-crime in a jewel-heist frolic so stale it feels like a retread of a retread.

Clean is one of the few fiction films to evoke realistically the grubby texture of existence for second- and third-tier rock celebrities crumbling under a combination of fading renown and drug addiction.
The ailing title character in this thorny masterpiece by the Romanian director Cristi Puiu suffers a late-night descent through circles of medical hell.
Somersault is a movie about the looks on people's faces and the disparity between the surface and the roiling chaos beneath.
The recipe for this silly, quasi-inspirational British comedy comes from the same cookbook that gave us The Full Monty.
Amos Gitai's long-winded essay revolves around the interaction of three women, an American, an Israeli and a Palestinian, on a car trip from Israel to Jordan.
A dance teacher turns students at a South Bronx high school from gawky ducklings into gliding swans in this sloppy but mildly endearing pop fairy tale.
... a romantic epic manque that swoons across the screen for nearly two and a half hours without saying much ...
This star-studded jigsaw puzzle of revenge and mistaken identity thinks it's terribly smart, although it amounts to an empty, self-satisfied imitation of Pulp Fiction.
Rian Johnson's flashy cinematic stunt grafts the hard-boiled argot of Dashiell Hammett onto an upscale Southern California high school.
Matthew Barney's visually spellbinding film is a work that might be described as the artist's Moby-Dick.
Robeson radiates the roguish charm and dangerous looming ferocity of a master con man with a scary streak of violence. Like his singing, Robeson's acting has stature. It is larger than life.
Stoned, Stephen Woolley's convoluted docudrama examining the final weeks in the life of the guitarist Brian Jones ... stalls in its own laborious accumulation of detail.

The 27-year-old protagonist of Steve Buscemi's deadpan comedy Lonesome Jim lives out the worst nightmare of every bushy-tailed go-getter who moves to New York to Be Somebody (in his case, a writer) and fails miserably.
This stridently sorrowful polemic against the proliferation of handguns in the United States consists of three fictional vignettes.
Who said mainstream Hollywood has a monopoly on dumb, gross-out farces? The gay, independent comedy Adam & Steve is as crude and nonsensical as any number of B-list studio equivalents.
Don't Tell, which was unaccountably nominated for an Oscar for best foreign language film, is no better than a second-tier candidate for the Lifetime Channel.
An allegorical neo-Western with dreams as big as the fantasies that consume its protagonist, a suburban cowboy (Edward Norton) who is not what he appears to be.
Cédric Klapisch's Russian Dolls has not much on its mind beyond updating the lives of the characters in his 2002 comedy L'Auberge Espagnole.
More than a decade after Larry Clark scandalized the movie world with Kids, he is still pushing buttons with his lubricious insider's view of teenage life.
Lian Lunson's wonderful documentary portrait combines pieces of an extended interview with Mr. Cohen with a tribute concert at the Sydney Opera House in January 2005.
Robert Edward's satirical allegory shamelessly borrows ideas from Orwell's 1984, then tramples them into the dust.
Loverboy, the shaky second feature directed by Kevin Bacon, stars Kyra Sedgwick as a single mother whose possessive instinct runs amok.
The feverish libidos wreaking emotional havoc in Oskar Roehler's infantile sex comedy are a quintessentially Germanic mixture of kinky, obsessive and sentimental.
When all else fails, pump up the thunder and lightning. That seems to be an operating principle behind the supremely unnecessary remake of the 1976 horror fest.
What gives the film a chilly authenticity is the creepy performance of Arno Frisch in the title role.
Enough of the ingredients for a sultry downscale noir are in place in Coastlines, that once the film turns perversely goody-good, it leaves you feeling vaguely disgruntled.
Alison Murray's chaotic, semiautobiographical account of a teenage girl's misadventures in a traveling cult, occupies its own stylistic niche: the movie as acid flashback.
Emmanuel Carrere's psychological mystery is a surreal reflection on perception, reality and memory.
This sketchy documentary portrait of a summer camp for teenagers with Broadway stars in their eyes remains a cool distance from its subject.
Terrorism and cultural identity are only two of the themes wound into a tight knot of fear and bewilderment in Cavite, a gripping no-budget political thriller.
The action -- especially the motorcycle chases through the marble government halls -- pack a fairly good visceral charge.
Keeping Up With the Steins begins as a growling, razor-toothed satire of carnivorous consumption in Hollywood. But after the first half-hour, those growls subside into whimpers.
Michael Cuesta's film 12 and Holding flashes a laser beam on ... the moment between childhood and adolescence when unguarded emotions and fantasies still rule, but adult experience beckons.
Rank is as thorough an examination of the sport of bull riding as you could hope to squeeze into 90 taut, well-organized minutes.
Visually majestic but dramatically inert.
The movie is as blunt as its title.
In the rarefied stratosphere of Eugène Green's film Le Pont des Arts, music, literature, philosophy and aesthetics, and the characters' engagement with them, are literally matters of life and death.

If it weren't for the fact that several of its characters die, Irving Schwartz's twisted, laugh-free comedy Perception might be the pilot episode of a low-rent imitation of the television series Arrested Development.
For many complicated reasons, fundamentalist Christianity in America doesn't look the same today as it did in 1972, when Marjoe won the Academy Award for best documentary.
Graced with a magnetic lead performance by Yolande Moreau, this French-Belgian movie follows the road tour of a middle-aged solo comedienne through northern France.
movie_title: When the Sea Rises (Quand la Mer Monte...) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Pierce Brosnan plays a gold-chain-wearing sleazeball in The Matador, a weightless, amoral romp about a professional hit man facing a midlife crisis.
Claire Denis's magnificent enigma of a film explores the troubled soul of a brooding loner who travels halfway around the world to begin a new life.
This fact-based story of conflict and resolution between a primitive warrior tribe in Ecuador and peace-seeking Christian missionaries is inspiring despite its sentimental excesses.
With its tentative pace, fussy, pieced-together structure and stuffy emotional climate, The White Countess never develops any narrative stamina.
In her small, witty autobiographical documentary, a Korean-American filmmaker named Grace Lee explores the personal and social ramifications of a name she finds oppressive.
Annie Proulx's heartbreaking story of two cowboys who fall in love has been faithfully translated onto the screen in Ang Lees landmark film.
This based-on-fact story of a New Zealand coot who defies age by racing his motorcycle competitively is a big mushy piece of ice cream cake for Anthony Hopkins.
A chore to watch, The Kid and I is self-congratulatory, excruciatingly sentimental and sloppily written and directed.
Margaret Brown has directed a tender, impressionistic film biography about the Texan singer-songwriter Townes Van Zandt.
movie_title: Be Here to Love Me: A Film About Townes Van Zandt (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This rich documentary proves that inner city boys have a better chance of thriving if removed from their poor neighborhoods.
This fanciful Chinese tearjerker wants to be an Asian Cinema Paradiso but doesnt quite live up to its prototype.
Find Me Guilty, Mr. Lumet's first feature film in seven years, catches him near the top of his game.
... the rare German movie calling itself a comedy that is actually funny, even if only in bits and pieces.

Annapolis is so gung-ho about the United States Naval Academy's ability to turn boys into fighting men and rebels into scrappy team players that it could easily be confused with a military recruiting film.
Set light years away from the real world, this tart, amusing piece of screwball fluff stars Matthew McConaughey as a 35-year-old who still lives with his parents.
A glossy French antiwar movie with melted snowflakes in its eyes.
This muddled cinematic ballad to American country music concerns a naïve, guitar-toting farm boy who leaves home to seek his musical fortune in Nashville.
Cuba Gooding Jr. sheds the halo that has threated to strangle his career by playing a corrupt cop in a nasty little genre film set in Los Angeles.
Michael Glawogger's glamorized documentary observes laborers from around the world going to hell and back, day after day, year after year, to eke out subsistence livings.
Cate Blanchett sinks into the role of a recovering drug addict in a thorny, compelling drama from Australia.
Set in Alabama in 1933, the movie lays out an excoriating examination of the legacy of slavery in the United States.
Adam Rapp's story of an embittered child's homecoming and confrontation with a parent throws off dramatic sparks, but they never flare into a blaze.
This gripping true story conveys what it must have been like to be a young, smart, idealistic dissenter in Nazi Germany, where no dissent was tolerated.
The director repeatedly places the viewer at the center of the crossfire and turns the gyrating camera into the next best thing to a lethal weapon.
Despite a witty performance by Steve Martin, much of The Pink Panther feels like trying on old clothes that no longer fit.
The message about race relations in America conveyed by this choppy and psychologically cauterized screen adaptation of Bernard Malamud's 1971 novel is dire.
This misbegotten adaptation of Oscar Wildes 1892 comedy Lady Windermeres Fan lacks Wilde's high-toned repartee.
... a movie whose twisted visual imagination is more forceful than its wobbly, zigzagging narrative.
A box-office phenomenon in Russia, the convoluted horror fantasy Night Watch might be described as Star Wars Meets the Vampires in Moscow.
Michael Kang's small, perfectly observed portrait of a Chinese-American boy captures the glum desperation of inhabiting the biological limbo of early adolescence.
Laurent Cantet's devastating new film contemplates the darker social undercurrents beneath a seemingly benign example of sexual tourism. examination of middle-age desire.
Every character in André Téchiné's rich, warmhearted exploration of cultural collision oscillates between two worlds and two ideas about the meaning of experience.
Nick Nolte dives beneath the blubber to bare the weary soul of an automobile junkyard operator pushing 60 who also umpires high-school baseball games.
An extraordinarily revealing documentary portrait of the Swedish director at his home on the desolate Baltic Island of Faro.
movie_title: Bergman Island (Ingmar Bergman - 3 dokumentärer om film, teater, Fårö och livet av Marie Nyreröd) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Had it taken a more hard-headed approach, 3 Needles might have been to the AIDS epidemic what Traffic was to the drug trade.
... much of what's on the screen feels like a creaky, tone-deaf classroom exercise in mechanical contrivance.
When Lauren (Emmanuelle Seigner) unwisely allows her biggest fan, Lucie (Isild Le Besco ), into her life, we know that little good can come of it.
The current of intellectual energy snapping through the ferociously engaging screen adaptation of Alan Bennett's Tony Award-winning play feels like electrical brain stimulation.
As its title suggests, this eccentric film written and directed by Isabel Coixet, contemplates the insufficiency of language to encapsulate traumatic experience.
For Your Consideration is by far the broadest comedy Christoper Guest and company have made. Despite its merriment, it is also the flimsiest.
The twin specters of Ingmar Bergman and Woody Allen hover over this talky history of a relationship between two New Yorkers.
In Come Early Morning, Ashley Judd delivers her most natural screen performance since Ruby in Paradise, the film that pushed her toward stardom in 1993.
The film builds to a melodramatic finale that would like to make you weep, but by then it has worn out your patience.
A Good Year, an innocuous, feel-good movie that reunites Russell Crowe with the director Ridley Scott, is a three-P movie: pleasant, pretty and predictable. One might add piddling.
... the film is an anti-soap opera in the trappings of an old- fashioned sudsfest.
Commune, a breezy, informal history of a long-running California commune begun in the summer of 1968 and still in existence, offers the fascinating spectacle of observing people then and now.
Harry Moses' entertaining documentary portrays the debate between connoisseurship and science as a culture war.
This modest, unassuming documentary about an illegal Mexican immigrant living in San Francisco is a case study of a life defined by poverty.
The kindest description of Home of the Brave, the first Hollywood movie to examine the experience of American soldiers returning from Iraq, might be that it is fueled by noble intentions.
Night at the Museum adheres to the current Hollywood philosophy that coherence doesnt matter if enough stuff is thrown onto the screen.
If you've ever stifled a bubble of rage while going through airport security, you will recognize the tensions in Close to Home.
Grbavica shows that even as you leave a war behind, you bring it with you.
The Freudian farce Unconscious is paced so breathlessly that it keeps you panting to keep up with each new plot twist.
Operation Homecoming is a spinoff from an anthology of essays, e-mail messages, poems and letters from soldiers in Iraq.
movie_title: America At A Crossroads: Operation Homecoming: Writing The Wartime Experience (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The documentary Fired! contains slivers of shtick that play more as diverting filler than prime comedy material.
Snappy repartee with the ring of real conversation is sustained through enough of Puccini for Beginners to make it a rarity.
Surprisingly, Rocky Balboa is no embarrassment. Like its forerunners it goes the distance almost in spite of itself.
Factory Girl, a biography of Edie Sedgwick, the most glamorous of Andy Warhol's so-called superstars, suggests a magazine layout masquerading as a film.
A handsome, old-fashioned western of few words and heavy meanings that unfolds with the sanctimonious grandeur of a biblical allegory.
God Grew Tired of Us is a sober, uplifting documentary that follows the resettlement in the United States of three young men uprooted as children by the civil war in Sudan.
This film is the cinematic equivalent of a delicate English tea cake whose substance is buried under too many layers of icing.
This delicate, bittersweet comedy prepares you for an eruption of high drama that never arrives.
The relentless emotional violence in this film, a compendium of five vignettes related to a young woman whose corpse is discovered on a hillside, is of a level rarely found in movies.
We Are Marshall is the kind of crassly formulaic movie in which everything hinges on a single play in the final seconds of a big football game.
The romantic comedy Catch and Release is refreshing for what it doesn't have. There is no whiny, spoiled golden girl and no baring of claws.
The five-minute movie, which is only a fragment of the program, has the feel of a manic silent-film parody.
This documentary about the Dixie Chicks offers a revealing case study of the relationship between politics, celebrity and the media in todays polarized social climate.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This eerie and indelible documentary about suicide juxtaposes transcendent beauty with personal tragedy.

What breaks your heart is the film's accumulated firsthand stories of New Orleans residents who lost everything in the flood after Hurricane Katrina, and the dismaying conclusion that a year after the disaster, the broken city has been largely abandoned.
movie_title: When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A grisly gangster movie with moral pretensions, 10th and Wolf never transcends mobster cliches recycled from The Godfather, Donnie Brasco and GoodFellas.
Neil Burger's screen adaptation of a short story by Steven Millhauser gives Edward Norton a role that perfectly fits his disturbing inscrutability.
Although the setting of this tiny, well-acted movie is contemporary London, it could be any European or American city where people mate and hope for the best.
movie_title: The Trouble With Men and Women (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This captivating romantic fairy tale for grown-ups could be described as a yuppie Bonnie and Clyde in which alienated corporate climbers break the rules.
You might be excused for speculating that it is really a high school romantic comedy whose teenage characters are played by their grandparents.
Although early scenes hold out some promise that this parody of Survivor could amount to something, the movie quickly runs out of ideas.
Quinceañera, a portrait of a Mexican-American family in Los Angeles, is as smart and warmhearted an exploration of an upwardly mobile immigrant culture as American independent cinema has produced.
13 Tzameti flaunts a grim sense of the absurd that suggests a French new wave film infected with a virulent strain of Eastern European nihilism.
Paul Yule's documentary wades through the seamy mess surrounding the estate of the Brooklyn-born photographer O. Winston Link, who died in 2001.
movie_title: The Photographer, His Wife, Her Lover (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Been Rich All My Life, an admiring portrait of the Silver Belles, a troupe of veteran Harlem tap dancers between the ages of 84 and 96, is a valuable historical document and a useful how-to movie about making the most of old age.

Shadowboxer, a gaudy thriller saturated in sex and violence, is an extravagance that leaves you with your mouth hanging open -- partly in admiration of its audacity and partly in disbelief at its preposterousness.
Edward Burns paints a scathing portrait of raucous high school buddies clutching at their rock n roll glory days as they push 35.
In this screen adaptation of David Mamet's play, William H. Macy is perfectly cast as a prim Manhattan businessman who heeds his inner demons and plummets into free fall.
This is a fake documentary that barely lets on that it's fiction.
Ric Burns' absorbing four-hour critical biography of the seminal pop artist is devoted to the proposition that Warhol was the greatest artist of the second half of the 20th century.
Saint of 9/11 is a touching elegy for the Rev. Mychal Judge, the much-loved New York City Fire Department chaplain who died at the World Trade Center.
Ahmad (Ahmad Razvi), the Pakistani immigrant who is the protagonist of Ramin Bahrani's Man Push Cart, goes through a Sisyphean daily grind.
This earnest documentary about assisted suicide plays like a stodgy promotional film for the Swiss organization Exit A.D.M.D., which helps terminally ill patients end their own lives.
movie_title: Exit: The Right to Die (Exit: Le Droit de Mourir) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This film paints a portrait of Mr. Jones, who died with his flock in Guyana, as a man with two faces.
The uncomfortable message sent by Bobcat Goldthwait's lean, subversive comedy Sleeping Dogs Lie is how easy it is to gross out people who think they're so swinging and cool.

Driving Lessons belongs to that hardy niche of British comedies designed as star vehicles for distinguished actresses (preferably Dames) of a certain age whose assignment is to win awards by devouring the scenery.
The documentary Black Gold tells an unresolved modern version of the age-old David and Goliath story.
As informative as it is, Wrestling With Angels doesn't have time to do more than scratch the surface of its fascinating subject.
Although four stories are folded together in Eric Khoos elliptical film, it's the true story of a deaf and blind Singaporean woman that gives the movie its backbone.

If there were more experimental films as entertaining as The Decay of Fiction, Pat O'Neill's luminous Hollywood ghost story, the notion of a thriving avant-garde cinema might not be so intimidating to the moviegoing public.
The grim, dystopian world in this animated French film is the product of a computer technique that evokes the sharp, linear style of a graphic novel.
This riveting documentary explores Kids on Fire, a summer camp in Devils Lake, N.D., that grooms children to be soldiers in 'God's army'.
This documentary chronicle of the hardcore punk movement in the first half of the 1980s imagines an underground culture that was more than a new generations style of hormonal eruption.

Anyone who has cringed while watching the home movies of newlyweds bumbling through their own corny, personalized nuptials will appreciate the comic potential of the British mock documentary Confetti.

Amid the continuing deluge of documentaries about the war in Iraq, Patricia Foulkrod's film The Ground Truth stands out as an especially pointed indictment of the American military's treatment of its own people on and off the battlefield.
The dark British comedy Keeping Mum exudes the comfy familiarity of a vintage episode of Alfred Hitchcock Presents stretched into a feature-length film.
This agreeable, lightweight movie, written and directed by Georgia Lee, turns the malaises of a suburban family into bittersweet farce that teeters between cheeky humor and surface pathos.
Just Friends hangs its crude, clobbering sense of humor on a dubious theory.
So snug, airtight and insulated from reality that the nice, well-scrubbed Cheaper by the Dozen seems almost rambunctious by comparison.
A midnight raid by Israeli soldiers turns the home of a Palestinian family into an occupied territory in Saverio Constanzo's politically loaded allegory.
Neil Jordan's picaresque fairy tale stars Cillian Murphy as an Irish transvestite who is arrested after the bombing of a London disco.
If this small, homemade movie offers some attractive views of the city and its canals, it lacks any sense of historical grandeur.
Slow, ruminative and dusted with wisps of folksy humor.
John Boorman's high-minded but hopelessly wooden film makes the fatal mistake of turning characters into mouthpieces.
A pile of blood-soaked toxic waste dumped onto the screen in an attempt to salvage Bruce Willis's fading career as an action hero.

Sir Ian McKellen is at his tweediest and most persnickety as the title character in Emile, the portrait of an eminent scientist who returns from England to his homeland, Canada, to receive an honorary degree from the University of Victoria.
A fraudulent yarn riddled with plot holes and improbabilities and topped by a cynical final twist that pulls the rug out from under the story.
This tweener fantasy of athletic glory frantically tries to balance a decent sense of values against a market-savvy awareness.
Almost every frame of this modest gem of a movie, directed by Carlos Sorin from a screenplay by Pablo Solarz, conveys the emptiness of the environment in which three interwoven vignettes unfold.
Ms. Montenegro's rough-hewn integrity is the one quality that ennobles The Other Side of the Street, an otherwise confused mixture of cat-and-mouse thriller and sentimental old folks' love story.
movie_title: The Other Side of the Street (2004)

movie_review_blurb: At its best, Philip Frank Messina's show business comedy plays like a less acerbic, less Jewish triple episode of Curb Your Enthusiasm.
Tyler Perry's movie is so oblivious to genre that it occupies its own special stylistic niche, if you can imagine such a thing as a romantic revenge farce.
movie_title: Diary of a Mad Black Woman (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There are brave, boundary-breaching movies, and there are mad, foolhardy ones. Harry and Max belongs to the latter breed.
Sky Blue teeters unsteadily between dystopian fable and Saturday-morning cartoon.
Schultze Gets the Blues rediscovers the world through the astonished eyes of a retired German salt miner on a musical pilgrimage to the United States.
At its best, it plays like a less acerbic, less Jewish triple episode of Curb Your Enthusiasm.
Judy Irving's affectionate documentary profiles a 50-ish San Franciscan who tends a flock of around four dozen wild parrots that live in his neighborhood.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Milk and Honey is the kind of nightmare- in-a-box you might expect if Neil LaBute remade Martin Scorsese's After Hours on a shoestring.
A heat-free pseudo-lesbian spoof of Charlie's Angels by way of Heathers.
The Danish filmmaker Suzanne Bier's gripping psychological drama is her second film to examine events worthy of Greek tragedy through a contemporary therapeutic lens.
Like so many science fiction fantasies, Hal Hartley's new film begins with a clever satirical premise, then stumbles all over itself trying to tell a coherent, original story.
Ladies in Lavender offers the opportunity to watch two beloved dames of the British Empire rattle around a house in Cornwall.
This dense biographical collage of images and memories of the Soviet dictator's second wife has a paradoxical quality.
Deft homage to the French New Wave.
The desperately unfunny kidnapping farce King's Ransom is the cinematic equivalent of trampled chewing gum on a subway platform.
One of Mr. Sayles's artistic strengths (and commercial liabilities) is his refusal to make movies that knock you over the head with larger-than-life characters and emotions.
The movie never recovers from its jarring turn into a rushed, unconvincing caper movie with a blasé, Robin Hood attitude.
Anyone who watches Yvan Attal's breezy, skin-deep sex comedy can identify with the grass-is-always-greener daydreams that haunt its characters.
Collectively, the dozen cases reveal a great deal about class expectations and the notion of entitlement in Parisian society.
movie_title: The 10th District Court: Moments of Trial (2004)

movie_review_blurb: If Dot the i, the directorial debut of Matthew Parkhill (who also wrote the screenplay), has a crass visual flash, it fails to give its characters any credible substance.
Michale Boganim's mournful cinematic poem follows the paths taken by emigrants from Odessa to the Brighton Beach area of Brooklyn and to Ashdod, Israel.
Ruth Leitman's documentary is more of a scrapbook than a coherent history of professional women's wrestling during its rough-and-tumble infancy.
movie_title: Lipstick & Dynamite: The First Ladies of Wrestling (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A film of spellbinding visual beauty.

It may not be Raiders of the Lost Ark, but Sahara, the screen adaptation of Clive Cussler's sprawling African adventure yarn, is a movie that keeps half a brain in its head while adopting the amused, cocky smirk of the Indiana Jones romps.
Bold on the surface, squeamish underneath and utterly lacking in erotic warmth, Unscrewed could well perpetuate the very dysfunction it purports to address so fearlessly.
While [the production notes] describe the story's Rocky-like outlines, they ignore the gripping, downbeat family drama at the movie's core.
The emotional climate of Bjorn Runge's harrowing drama, which eviscerates the rot of three middle-class marriages, is harsh enough to produce frostbite.
Takeshi Kitano's melancholy allegory is a meditation on the heavy ties that bind, of which love is merely one and not necessarily the strongest.
The barely watchable buddy comedy L.A. Twister is so sloppily put together it bungles its recycled movie-within-a-movie conceit.
The third installment of the Blade series is a choppy, forgetful, suspense-free romp that substitutes campy humor for chills.
A bluntly heart-tugging city-mouse, country-mouse fable from Iran.
The concept gets a weird but intriguing workout.
A whimsical romantic comedy served with a heaping tablespoon of sugar.
This featherweight spoof of closeted, Red-baiting Hollywood in the mid-1950's is played as such an exaggerated cartoon that its political outrage is dissipated by its stridency.
In retrospect the group's story is a painful example of the warped idealism of the radical left and its fateful romance with violence.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Lockstep suburban conformism enforced with fascist severity is the ugly (but admittedly sometimes funny) joke driving Joe Roth's family comedy.
With its ludicrous frisson of patriotism and a nod to The Da Vinci Code, a more cynical grab for Hollywood gold is hard to imagine.
A stirring, idealistic documentary that examines the grass-roots cooperative movement in financially devastated Argentina.
If Triple Agent is an impressive docudrama, it lacks the warmth and flow of this filmmaker's best, earlier movies.

So skillful at sustaining a chilly antiseptic atmosphere in which death stalks every gleaming corridor that it comes as a sharp disappointment to find its hygienic imagery wasted on a clunking cat-and-mouse game.
movie_title: Qui a tué Bambi? (Who Killed Bambi?) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Claude Miller's ingeniously freewheeling adaptation of "The Seagull" drags Chekhov's 1895 play into the age of cellphones, digital video and hip-hop.
English-language East-West domestic dramas usually tip the scales in favor of modernity... But A Fond Kiss is equally sympathetic to each side.
A moth-eaten stranded-in- the-desert yarn so manipulative that the involuntary jolts of adrenaline it produces make you feel like a fool.
The Sea Inside, the story of a quadriplegic activist fighting for the right to die, struggles to transcend the disease-of-the-week genre to which it belongs.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Sigourney Weaver creates a portrait of a taut, frustrated suburban mother of three whose complexity transcends the Mom as Devourer stereotypes who have prowled the movies since Mrs. Robinson stirred her first martini.
Elliot Greenebaum's hardheaded comedy has the guardedly facetious tone of a fake documentary.
A grandiose hybrid of undersea documentary and outer-space fantasy.
Grimly austere barely begins to describe the atmosphere of dread that seeps through Fear X like a toxic mist.
This horror film, spun off from an old Atari video game, is so inept on every level, you wonder why the distributor didn't release it straight to video, or better, toss it directly into the trash.
The familiar visual signposts of alienation are spiffily arrayed in Siegrid Alnoy's handsome but empty film debut.

Our turbulent political climate is so clogged with the instant hysteria demanded by the chattering class to keep its voice in shouting condition that a sedate documentary examining the long-term weather patterns is a welcome respite from the noise.
movie_title: With God on Our Side: George W. Bush and the Rise of the Religious Right in America (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A moving documentary that approaches the Holocaust from a fresh, intimate perspective.
Monsieur N, Antoine de Caunes's densely plotted costume drama, suggests that Napoleon's demise might have been an elaborate hoax through which he escaped into anonymity.
It is a dream of life in which everything is reduced to black and white. Or as the rhetoric used to go, you are either part of the problem or part of the solution. Nothing was ever quite that simple.
A grim Germanic variation on a classic theme that can never bear too much repeating: Can't buy me love.
movie_title: Ich will doch nur, daß ihr mich liebt (I Only Want You to Love Me) (1976)

movie_review_blurb: The movie, written and directed by Andrew Litvack, a protégé of Ismail Merchant and James Ivory, strains to be the ne plus ultra of arch, hyper-sophisticated fun, but the laughs are few.
You don't have to agree with its premise -- that middle-class marriage equals sadomasochism -- to respond to the bravura comic glee with which the director lays it out.
In the first feature directed by Shainee Gabel, John Travolta delivers a hammed-up scenery-chewing variation of the brainy good ole boy he played in Primary Colors.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Hotel Rwanda is a political thriller based on fact that hammers every button on the emotional console.
Kevin Spacey's biography of Bobby Darin is a mess, but it captures Darin's desperation, his braggadocio and his magnetism.
This frantic comic hodgepodge, built around Martin Short's Comedy Central character, tries desperately to flesh out a television sketch into a feature-length movie.
A wise, sweet-natured Spanish film.
Jane Fonda returns to the big screen in a comedy so one-dimensional and craven that it makes Meet the Parents look avant-garde.
Peter Raymont's film is a respectful portrait of Roméo Dallaire, the Canadian commander of the United Nations peacekeeping force in Rwanda in 1994.
movie_title: Shake Hands with the Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: If MirrorMask is a marvel of visual ingenuity, its monochromatic panoramas are too busy and flat to yield an illusion of depth or to convey a feeling of characters moving in space.

Going Shopping...has enough smart, knowing touches and enough easy spontaneity among its well-chosen actors to make you wish it added up to more than what it turns out to be: a flighty, motor-mouthed cinematic divertissement.
Jane Andersons bittersweet, satirically savvy film tells the true story of a 1950s housewife (Julianne Moore) who helps feed her family by writing jingles.
movie_title: The Prize Winner of Defiance, Ohio (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Phelan deserves points for chutzpah for daring to wallow in abject psychic misery in his debut film.
Even by the standards of its bottom-feeding genre, Dirty Love clings to the gutter like a rat in garbage.
Sleek, attractive and ultimately vapid, Novo applies to sex and love the concept of short-term memory loss used to such acute dramatic effect in Memento.
Propelled by astute, straight-faced performances, this deadpan fake documentary about a group of dorky frozen-food collectors succeeds in stirring up some maniacal laughs.

To observe the tenor Neil Shicoff's thrilling performance of the final aria from Fromental Halevy's 1835 opera 'La Juive' ('The Jewess') at the Vienna State Opera is to watch a singing actor shoot the moon.
movie_title: Finding Eléazar: Portrait of a Tenor and a Role (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Jem Cohen's visually haunting film deliberately blurs the lines between fiction, documentary and cinematic essay.
Deborah Koons Garcia's sober, far-reaching polemic against genetically modified foods poses many ticklish ethical and scientific questions.
Watching the featherweight French farce Côte d'Azur provides the oxymoronic sensation of looking at a pornographic movie with no real sex.
Beyond casting a jaundiced eye at the community's oppressive communalism, Campfire neither endorses nor opposes the settler movement that since 1981 has become an incendiary issue in Israel.
Robert Redford, Morgan Freeman and Jennifer Lopez star in a sentimental western that suffocates in its own predictability and watered-down psychobabble.
This impressionistic documentary is a mystical exploration of the sensory world as experienced by a musician who lost most of her hearing as a teenager.
Separate Lies, the directorial debut of Julian Fellowes, is so busy constructing its labyrinthine plot that it often forgets to plumb the souls of its characters.
Poorly plotted, suspense-free film.
A witless farce about working at a chain restaurant that belongs in a circle of gross-out hell somewhere below Porky's and slightly above Jenny McCarthy's Dirty Love.
An extraordinarily rich and satisfying suite of fleeting but intense moments in the lives of nine women.
Eran Riklis's tightly wound film is about a bride-to-be trapped between Syria and Israel.
An extraterrestrial fantasy, based on a children's book by Chris Van Allsburg, that feels both real and unreal, like a dream you could shake off at any moment.
Naomi Watts delivers a fearless, largely unsympathetic portrayal of the title character as a desperate, unstrung version of herself (an Australian actress with a knack for dialects).
A sumptuous screen adaptation of Jane Austen's 1813 novel that gathers you up on its white horse and gallops off into the sunset.
Craig Lucas's sublimely acted film stars Campbell Scott as a closeted bisexual predator who has an affair with an emotionally unstrung writer (Peter Sarsgaard).
Kevin Jordan's small family drama, set in Sheepshead Bay, is an unusually pure example of American kitchen-sink realism.
The desolate Western landscape through which the characters in Mark Milgard's promising debut wander in an introspective daze, defines their emotional life.
Greg Whiteley's small, tender documentary portrait looks at life after rock 'n' roll as experienced by the original bassist for the New York Dolls.
This taut, ingeniously calculated thriller fixates on the flashpoint where psychology and politics ignite in self-destructive martyrdom.
Josh Stolberg's mild-mannered satire imagines that teenage rebellion in the Bush era has gone soft.
Calm, deliberate and devastating, Jessica Sanders's documentary confirms many of the worst fears about weaknesses in the American criminal-justice system.
The groundbreaking film Ushpizin, a rare collaboration between secular and ultra-Orthodox Israelis, offers a warmhearted vision of marriage among Hasidic Jews.
If it isn't easy being any of the troubled people wandering through the film, Loggerheads makes it easy not only to believe in them, but to care about them as well.
Because this is history viewed through the eyes of a child, Innocent Voices gives you feelings and impressions, but few facts
Bigger, faster and more spectacular is usually the rule for sequels. Applied to The Legend of Zorro, that rule translates into busier, sloppier, less coherent and more frantic.
Keith A. Beauchamp's lean, harrowing inquisition into a murder that catalyzed the civil rights movement is an incendiary documentary.
movie_title: Untold Story of Emmett Louis Till (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Steve James's absorbing documentary follows a family to the rural Fijian island of Taveuni, where they showed free movies in the world's most remote movie theater.
Four Brothers has an elaborate plot, whose elements are unsatisfactorily pieced together between action sequences.
It's impossible to watch the emperor penguins in Luc Jacquet's sentimental but riveting documentary without feeling a tug of anthropomorphic kinship.
Herbie: Fully Loaded is a perfectly silly movie for a silly season that in recent years has forgotten how to be this silly.
The assembly and eventual destruction of the Kalachakra sand mandala is the cycle around which the German director Werner Herzog's absorbing documentary is structured.
Entertaining but muddled corporate thriller.
The flimsy new Hilary Duff comedy toys with the notion of mother-daughter role reversal.
How bad could a movie be that features talent as serious as Robert De Niro, Kathy Bates, Gabriel Byrne, Harvey Keitel, F. Murray Abraham and Geraldine Chaplin? That bad, alas.
movie_title: The Bridge of San Luis Rey (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The best and maybe the only use to be made of the catastrophic screen biography Modigliani is to serve as a textbook outline of how not to film the life of a legendary artist.
Murray Nossel's warm and fuzzy documentary is a portrait of two gay men and a female surrogate who join forces to create new life.
A meandering comedy that offers the pleasure of watching the great French actor Daniel Auteuil as the world's most overzealous, uptight good Samaritan.
Adam Bhala Lough's hot little melodrama rhapsodizes the lives of contemporary graffiti artists.
Alice Wu's amiable romantic comedy examines the lives of three generations of Chinese-Americans living in New York.
There's no escaping that Dominion is finally an act of commercial scavenging.
Compare and despair: that wise, useful adage popularized by 12-step programs could be the subtitle of Eric Weber's sloppy but smart-enough-to- make-you-squirm comedy.
This intimate portrait of the legendary octogenarian cinematographer Haskell Wexler is the richest documentary of its kind since Terry Zwigoffs Crumb.

The movie uses the competition for Caterina's loyalty to portray the school as a microcosm of Italian society under Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. Any way you look at it, it's not a pretty picture.
Strong stuff.
Short on laughs, if supremely inoffensive, this sleepy nonentity of a movie finds Mr. Lawrence in his huggable teddy bear mode.
... gripping sports documentary ...
A tedious World War II epic that slogs across the screen like a forced march in quicksand.
Any satire worth its salt should not be afraid to offend, and Pretty Persuasion flings mud in all directions with a fearless audacity.
This crude, inspirational tear-jerker is as sweet as a bowl of instant oatmeal smothered in molasses.
In this homemade documentary, the narrator-filmmaker moves heaven and earth to get a date with his childhood dream girl, Drew Barrymore.
Phil Morrison's wise, bittersweet, beautifully acted comedy about a Southern homecoming envelops us in texture of a world the movies rarely visit.
This zippy Disney adventure-comedy asks that age-old question, 'Is there life after high school?,' and answers it with a cheerful 'Not really.'
Must Love Dogs is an Internet dating comedy so weightless that it makes a trifle like You've Got Mail look like Chekhov.
The acrid fog of war is palpable in Pirjo Honkasalo's magnificent documentary, The 3 Rooms of Melancholia, one of the saddest films ever made.

Some revealing historical facts are scattered through Karen Kramer's documentary about Greenwich Village. Most of the film, however, is devoted to sound bites from celebrities who used to live or hang out there.
A cleverly assembled film, shot and edited on digital video for a pittance, November wants only to be an entertainingly squirmy mind tease.
Michael Winterbottom's film is a lyrical, graphically explicit chronicle of an ordinary love affair between two attractive people.
The lives of three desperate teenagers unravel in a docudrama based on actual case studies of young women who spent time in the Jersey City juvenile detention center.
Jim White, the songwriter and hero of alt-country music, conducts a highly selective back-roads tour of the rural Deep South in this richly lyrical documentary.
[A] sometimes savvy media melodrama.
A humane, lotus-scented documentary with a heavy spiritual agenda.
Ma Mere may be ludicrous, but its cast displays a commitment that deserves more than grudging admiration.
An earnestly well-meaning film whose adult characters have a refreshingly grown-up perspective on their choices in life.
Much of it plays like a confused, desperate rehash of [Meet the Parents].
That voyeuristic fascination with doomed glamour is one of the guilty pleasures of Susanne Ofteringer's utterly haunting documentary film, Nico Icon.
Awash in angelic choruses and panoramic scenery, the movie aspires toward a solemnity that Dana Stevens's prosaic psychobabbling screenplay cannot support.
In the end the movie cops out.
This sleek, Cliffs Notes version of a masterpiece is ... glossy and picture perfect on the surface and hollow at the core.
Danny DeVito is the only cast member who succeeds in making something out of the movie's nothing of a screenplay.
Quote not available.
Shamelessly manipulative and sentimental, but in an agreeably familiar way.
Quote not available.
[A] funny, gleefully offensive spoof of professional sports.
As smart as it is, 'Pi' is awfully hard to watch. Filmed with hand-held cameras in splotchy black-and-white and crudely edited, it has the style and attitude of a no-budget midnight movie.
An incoherent romantic comedy whose sexy title character (played by Ms. Smith) is an unbearable, unfunny pain in the neck.
The movie is sparked by more than half a dozen incisive performances.

The subtlety with which Mackintosh conveys her complicated mixture of vulnerability, defensiveness and pride makes [Kim] one of the most fully realized characters to be portrayed on the screen in a long time.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
A nearly laugh-free comedy!
Quote not available.
Quote not available.

Although the opening scene suggests a dark urban satire, Blade quickly turns into a cartoonish futuristic action-adventure yarn in which Blade is the only thing keeping humanity from being exterminated by vampires in a hematological holocaust.
Happy's tantrums, which the movie pretends are liberating explosions of self-expression, aren't nearly maniacal enough to reach comic delirium.
With The End of Violence Mr. Wenders has made a film as resonant as his most memorable work.
Impenetrable mess of a movie.
Offers a deeper immersion in that old '50s feeling than any other Hollywood film in recent memory.
You probably won't feel comfortable when Humanité is over, but as you leave the theater you will feel more alive than when you entered.
Ray lacks his father's eye for poetic detail and visual metaphor, but he is a confident director of actors. Agashe's landowner is such a convincing rat that you can almost smell his rancid breath.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
If this scenario sounds like stock film-noir plotting, Bill Bennett ... makes something utterly fresh and, for all its scent of evil, invigorating out of it.
You don't have to believe a word of the strained dialogue in A Perfect Murder to be seduced by the movie's chilly high-gloss ambiance and its skillfully plotted update of Frederick Knott's play...
Its shelf life may not be long, nor will it probably be a big hit, since the laughter it provokes is the kind that makes you squirm. But that's what good satire is supposed to do.
Quote not available.
For all the ideas it tosses around -- and many of them are useful and painful correctives to our rose-colored fantasies -- Treasure Island is too crude a movie to muster much rhetorical clout.

Next Stop, Wonderland isn't really much more than a beautifully acted, finely edited sitcom, but it creates and sustains an intelligent, seriocomic mood better than any recent film about the urban single life.
At the heart of the film is a star-making performance by the handsome Welsh actor Christian Bale.
[David Twohy] tweaks this formulaic escape-from-hell story with just enough original touches to give it a lift.
Quote not available.
Likable but muddled.
