A giddy triple somersault of a film that makes no sense whatsoever, although in its best moments it is as much fun to watch as a death-defying circus act.
Its mixture of biographical hype and social studies quickly curdles.
Quote not available.

The kind of manipulative, cliché-infested hokum that alienates moviegoers by its insistence on hogging all the tears.
Lorenzo, the bratty 14-year-old protagonist of Bernardo Bertolucci's "Me and You," is the quintessence of flailing adolescent angst.
"If You Don't, I Will" is a dour, acutely observed comedy about marital boredom that doesn't glamorize or overdramatize the characters' angst.
"Goodbye to All That" is very evenhanded in assessing its characters' flaws, and it never sentimentalizes.

"Into the Woods," the splendid Disney screen adaptation of the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical, infuses new vitality into the tired marketing concept of entertainment for "children of all ages."
Could Robert Duvall's incoherent melodrama "Wild Horses" have been salvaged by a skillful editor? Probably not.
Evokes the march of history with a balance and restraint exhibited by few movies with such grand ambitions.
Martin is as desperate to grow up as Nicole is reluctant to take the next step. Both are at a crossroads that this wonderful, lighter-than-air movie depicts as a major turning point.
Think of "Gemma Bovery" as an airy puff pastry, dripping with honey.
For its first two-thirds, the film, written and directed by Thomas Cailley, seems to be groundbreaking. Then it slides into comforting familiarity.
Its findings don't add up to more than a sardonic gloss on a provocative subject.
Filled with comic intrigue ...
For all its sensitivity to the subject, "The Farewell Party" makes a number of tonal missteps ...
A modest, quietly touching portrait of an older woman radiantly embodied by Blythe Danner.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Disregard the arguments for and against drone warfare advanced in "Good Kill," and the movie still makes a persuasive case that our blind infatuation with all-powerful technology is stripping us of our humanity.
This extremely personal and moving documentary has several layers.
Excruciating ... an unwieldy hybrid of high school dance competition movie and shameless flag-waver.
A feisty, passionate performance by the Irish actress Deirdre O'Kane gives the inspirational biopic "Noble" a serrated edge of defiance and gumption.
The lead performances are so perfectly in sync that Alex and Ruth really feel like an old married couple who know each other's foibles and cherish every tic.
An absurdist deconstruction of classic Hollywood westerns whose 21st-century view of frontier mythology is as sardonic as that of the Coen brothers.

This Canadian movie, from a screenplay by Jessie Gabe, begins in Winnipeg and ends in Vancouver and jounces along on the crackle of smart-aleck dialogue mouthed by its stars, Richard Dreyfuss and Tatiana Maslany.
"The Yes Men Are Revolting," their third film, has a personal poignancy that is missing in the forerunners, "The Yes Men" (2003) and "The Yes Men Fix the World" (2009).
"Saturday Night Live" deserves much better than the documentary equivalent of what a book editor would surely dismiss as a rushed, careless clip job.
A nasty, flawlessly acted little gem that goes deep inside its characters' psyches.
A story that you half-expect to turn into a melodrama stays true to the sensibilities of its immature, painfully sincere characters, who are faced with life-changing decisions.
"Unexpected" offers the satisfactions of a very good made-for-television movie. For all the unexpectedness endured by the characters, it studiously plays it safe.
"Alleluia" is a fever dream of sex, jealousy and murder whose intensity leaves you spellbound.
"Lila and Eve" deteriorates into a tawdry shoot-'em-up whose screenplay takes an ill-advised surreal twist that propels the movie deep into the ozone.
The film conjures an absurdist nightmare of bureaucratic incompetence, indifference and social inequity.
"Set Fire to the Stars" barely skims the surface of characters you wish had been given more dimension, but as a snapshot of postwar academia and its pretensions, it exerts a creepy fascination.
An austere, beautifully filmed and powerfully acted portrait of extreme religious fervor that slyly flirts with comedy.
It isn't especially well directed or incisively written, and its ending is frustratingly vague. The main attraction is Mr. Williams's relentlessly dour performance.
One of the pleasures of "Jimmy's Hall," a likable period piece directed by the social-realist British filmmaker Ken Loach, is its unswerving belief in old-fashioned populist heroes.
You anticipate a cheap, sentimental ending. But it is not to be, and the movie is much the better for it.
This film is a nasty piece of work.
The 90-minute movie is a tightly compressed exploration of forces that make it next to impossible to operate a small business when a voracious corporation moves in for the kill.
Mr. Rickman has found in the Sun King a character worthy of his imperious, reptilian charisma.
Mr. Thorpe's explorations of a painful subject are an exercise in healing. His discovery of how many gay men share his anxiety and discomfort leads him to greater self-acceptance.
As an instructional movie on the sport, "Ride" offers some useful tips, but beyond that, it feels like a slightly bizarre vanity project.
The kind of gory British policier from which you come away with the queasy feeling that the world is essentially a butcher shop ruled by greed, murder, cruelty and lust.
A movie that has the haranguing inspirational tone of a marathon Sunday-school lesson.
Songs that tell their story from both their points of view are among the smartest show tunes this side of Stephen Sondheim.

Mr. Grant, now 54, is facing the expiration date of his twinkly boyish act. And in "The Rewrite," as he plays a spoiled screenwriter and one-hit Hollywood wonder on the skids, you can feel the strain as he goes through the routine one more time.
Ms. Hamilton's straightforward documentary skillfully interweaves reminiscences by members of the group with re-enactments of the burglary.
"Black or White"... is notable for what it doesn't try to do. It doesn't assess America's racial attitudes based on the headlines of the day or use its story... to placate or to inflame.
This overlong movie loses its focus as the director piles on distracting, pretentious cinematic embellishments underscored by an insistent use on the soundtrack of Vivaldi's "Stabat Mater."
movie_title: Je m'appelle Hmmm... (My Name Is Hmmm...) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Mr. Depp's wizardly expertise at disappearing into a character is intact. But what if that character isn't funny and hasn't an ounce of charm?
As could have been predicted, "Hot Tub Time Machine 2" is vastly inferior to the first "Hot Tub," but it's not stupid so much as desperately frantic.
"Son of a Gun" adds to the mystique that Australian crime films are meaner, nastier and more brutish than their American counterparts. But it changes style roughly every half-hour.

The story loses credibility as it goes along, as the body count escalates, and Robinson's solutions to life-and-death crises grow increasingly far-fetched. Well before it ends preposterously, "Black Sea" has taken leave of its senses.
You may scold yourself for investing any emotion at all in hokum that even Mr. Marsan, for all his kindly gravity, can't begin to salvage.
For all its disorganization and lack of an ending or even a sense of direction, "Appropriate Behavior" is alive.
[A] low-key, beautifully photographed movie ...
With its dearth of substance and its wandering focus, this is a middlebrow bodice-ripper posing as an epic that hasn't the foggiest idea of what it wants to say.
"Li'l Quinquin" is a quasi-epic farce that mostly wears a poker face as it elaborates his continuing obsession with the collision of humankind's bestial and spiritual impulses.
The movie is too shrewd to qualify as a jeremiad, but underneath the comedy are boiling undercurrents of anger and despair.

On one level, "Bluebird" is a bitter slice of life about hardy, stoic New Englanders battling the elements and a crumbling regional economy. On another, it's a poetic meditation on the human struggle to make sense of a cruel and indifferent universe.
Explores interlocking themes of sexuality, immigration and power dynamics with a cleareyed sensitivity and refuses to demonize even its shadiest characters.

The director, John Madden, and the screenwriter, Ol Parker, who created the first film, try to compensate for the new movie's lack of coherence and narrative momentum. But with no real story to tell, only so much can be done.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Because I Was a Painter" maintains a funereal rhythm, alternating images of artworks with long-distance views of camp barracks as they are today, the camera moving slowly and stealthily.
Lurches along a wobbly line between salacious comic nastiness and nauseating sentimentality.
"Black Souls" is an ominous, well-acted portrait of an ingrown feudal society of violence, retaliation and deadly machismo.
You begin to wonder to what extent the film is a critique of an entire society in which the disparity between tradition and modernity is irreconcilable.
The central problem with "Cut Bank" is a screenplay by Roberto Patino that never achieves comic liftoff despite an abundance of facetious humor.

A legal fight over the struggle for ownership of an artwork is hardly the stuff of high drama. And the screenplay can't find a way to make that conflict, or the ethical and moral issues involved, compelling ...
I was drained and quivering with fury and disgust.
As a piece of storytelling, "A Wolf at the Door" may be a tawdry little shocker. But on a visceral level, it is a knife to the gut.
movie_title: A Wolf at the Door (O Lobo atrás da Porta) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Man From Reno" fascinates. It invites you to go back, decipher its clues and discern a grand design, if there is one.
[A] shameless piece of boomer bait, which peddles the highly questionable notion that it's never too late to get back to where you once belonged.
"She's Lost Control" sustains a mood of deepening alienation, but the attitude of the movie is too detached for it to be emotionally gripping, and its ending is botched.
Mr. Jacobs and Mr. Grodsky have an extraordinary ear for the rhythms and nuances of everyday speech, as voices overlap, conversations take random directions, and casual remarks carry loaded subtexts.

Rather than breaking new ground, "It Follows" recycles familiar teenage horror tropes - a girl alone in a house, evil forces banging on a door - but its mood is dreamy. Seldom do you feel manipulated by exploitative formulas.
The screenplay relies on so many mechanical contrivances to make the story gripping that you can hear the rusty machinery clanking.
With its casual deadpan attitude, Buzzard offers a nightmare portrait of arrested development and anomie for the age of inequality.
An earnest homage that also honors Mr. Crimmins's crusade to drive child pornography off the Internet.
The movie reminds you of the extent to which poetry has been marginalized as a cultural force since the early 1960s.

Judi Dench's portrayal of a stubborn, kindhearted Irish Catholic trying to discover what became of the toddler she was forced to give up as a teenager is so quietly moving that it feels lit from within.
An endearing curiosity that, at 125 minutes, is as badly in need of a trim as the hair of its comically coiffed dandies.

The blooming puppy love between Thomas and Jackie lends The Black Balloon a welcome strain of tenderness. Mr. Wakefield and Ms. Ward project the innocence of shy, sensitive young people for whom a tentative shared kiss is a very big deal.
Tightly constructed and fiercely one-sided.
When Sissy Spacek speaks her cliched lines in the mediocre screenplay of Lake City, her delivery lends them a resonance that is not in the written words.
Were the World Mine, an indie alternative to Disney's High School Musical franchise, is a small, endearing film.
A good scolding and a toke on a joint: that's all it takes to turn the curmudgeonly old folks in How About You into goofy pussycats.
The Dukes tastes like pasta sauce that has sat on the shelf long after the expiration date on the can.
Savage gallows humor might have substituted for pathos. But Adam Resurrected feels so detached that there is not a laugh, nor even a wicked smirk of nihilistic glee, to be gleaned.
That the movie is easy on the eyes (Melody's fetching silhouette against those sunset river views) doesn't make it any less bogus.
Role Models pours sugar and cream on everything and turns it to mush.
The fact that My Name Is Bruce knows what it's doing doesn't mean it's funny.
It is impossible not to be fired up by Kurt Kuenne's incendiary cri de coeur, Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Passengers is a supernatural thriller so mechanically inept and lacking in suspense that it doesn't even pass muster as lowbrow Halloween-ready entertainment.
Mr. Efron's athletic grace is Astaire-like in its casual authority. Ms. Hudgens's blissful smiles melt the screen.
Gonzalo Arijón's documentary Stranded offers an incontrovertible argument for the necessity of team spirit in the face of catastrophe.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gardens of the Night is a harrowing story of kidnapping and forced child prostitution that conjures a world entirely populated by predators and prey.
Mary is a convoluted, hysterical mess of a movie with grandiose spiritual airs and not a drop of humor.
An efficient home-for-Christmas ensemble comedy trimmed with plastic teardrops.
The steady attention to detail in Moscow, Belgium lends it a texture rarely found in films about domestic life.
No computer-designed animatronic invention can begin to match the beauty and grace of the oceanic life photographed in Under the Sea 3D.
A corporate crime drama that runs fatally amok.
Great Speeches From a Dying World is an unsettling documentary portrait gallery of nine homeless people living on the streets of Seattle.
movie_title: Great Speeches from a Dying World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Hoary slapstick routines, invariably rushed, are all there is in The Pink Panther 2.
An unwieldy hybrid of historical allegory and supernatural mystery.
The flat romantic comedy New in Town has no idea of how to play its cards.
Scott Walker: 30 Century Man, is the story of and oracular singer, experimental composer, British-based American expatriate and reclusive cult figure.
Will anyone finally escape this floating slaughterhouse? Do you even care?
Loaded with enough stupid pet and human tricks to satisfy David Letterman for years to come.
The teachers we remember most fondly are often the ones who entertained as they enlightened, through hyperbole seasoned with grains of salt. Mr. Zizek belongs in that company.
As Just Another Love Story zigzags between austere realism (the scenes of Jonas and his family) and surreal gore, you have the not unpleasant sense of being taken for a ride.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: For all its attention to detail, Yonkers Joe isn't half as tough as it pretends to be. The real story of these bottom-feeders and the sad young man they exploit is a lot uglier than the movie even begins to let on.
Good is an anemic screen adaptation of C. P. Taylor's play about a respectable 'good German' who passively acquiesces to Hitler's agenda.
At the end of Marley & Me you don't leave the theater with a sense that anything much has been learned, only that a fixture in the Grogans' comfortable suburban lives has been removed.
Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms is a depressing, scattershot survey of the spread of weaponry around the world, especially in Africa.
movie_title: Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Reveals the fundamental silliness of fashion.
Without forcing comparisons, Frontrunners finds parallels between the election at Stuyvesant High and the current national election.
For its courage to address a ticklish subject with warmhearted humor, Breakfast With Scot, adapted from a novel by Michael Downing, deserves a light round of applause.
The third installment of the Mummy franchise, Tomb of the Dragon Emperor, is by far the weakest.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The semi-improvised performances, which seem so natural that it is tempting to confuse the actors with their characters, bring Baghead into the realm of group therapy observed through one-way glass.
An ingenuous 24-year-old man-child is at the center of John Crowley's wrenching melodrama Boy A.
An unblinking portrait of a complicated, solitary gay man who has outlived his working years.
Written and directed by Ric Roman Waugh, and filmed at the New Mexico State Penitentiary near Santa Fe, Felon is one of the most realistic prison films ever made.
A handsomely remodeled variation of a cherished genre you might call the mystery-train movie.
The movie equivalent of being patted on the shoulder by an encouraging high school guidance counselor and assured that you are doing just fine.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In Julian Schnabel's grimly majestic concert film Lou Reed's Berlin, Mr. Reed wears the deadpan smirk of a Zen master who has endured punishing Buddhist training.
A brave film simply for daring to portray a nightmare lurking in the minds of middle-aged workers, people who might fear a film that addresses their insecurities this bluntly.
A film of tightly assembled bits and pieces that don't fit comfortably together despite clever dashes of magical realism connecting past and present.
In the recent epidemic of comedies about 30-something men in the throes of severe arrested development, he is one of the most pitifully incompetent losers.
Holding Trevor, a portrait of 20-something gay men and their straight friends, is a joyless exploration of middle-class deadbeats.
Guillaume Canet's delicious contemporary thriller Tell No One is Vertigo meets The Fugitive by way of The Big Sleep. That is meant as high praise.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Set mostly in Las Vegas, Finding Amanda offers a vision of confused Americans losing their already shaky bearings in the world's gaudiest honky-tonk.
A low-rent answer to Robert Altmanâ(TM)s Short Cuts.
At moments City of Ember suggests a mild satire of end-of-days ideology.
Once Avery's mission assumes a Freudian dimension, the allegory loses its moral force and changes from a meditation on justice, power and inequality into a gory melodrama.
The nymphs and druids who frolic through The Romance of Astrea and Celadon occupy mythological space between Shakespeare and Greek mythology.
A doggedly workmanlike variation of an old story: the lone crusader doing battle with the big bad establishment.
So much pot is smoked in the agreeable drama Humboldt County that you may come away from it with a contact high.
Religulous is a film that aims for laughs, not a scientific survey of the roots of faith.
An entertaining collection of vignettes strung together by a sarcastic loudmouth whose heart is breaking under his sophomoric bravado.
The sharp comic timing and the offbeat chemistry of Ricky Gervais, Greg Kinnear and TÃ (C)a Leoni keep Ghost Town afloat.

But a drama is only as convincing as its characters. The people awkwardly forced together in Battle in Seattle are rhetorical mouthpieces tied to the sketchy plotlines of a so-so Hollywood ensemble movie.
With characters named Esperanza, Dawn and Patience that signal Deeper Meaning, Henry Poole Is Here traffics in the kind of inspirational kitsch that only a true believer could swallow.
The suds that cascade through Tyler Perry's The Family That Preys more than equal the cubic footage from nighttime soaps like Dallas, Dynasty and their offspring.
As the movie inches along, its virtues turn into faults. Its elliptical style leaves unanswered questions, the pace begins to feel choppy, and the lyrical pauses become a recurrent tic.
The Pool takes a look at the lives of the haves and the someday might haves in Goa.
There is hardly a moment in this new film in which you are not aware that its absurdist view of the human condition was shaped by traumatic 20th-century events.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It all adds up to the kind of bad family entertainment likely to raise only a few eyebrows.
Watching Rainn Wilson gyrate in The Rocker, you can't help wondering if Mr. Wilson is inhabiting a role that was originally turned down by Jack Black.
The portrait of Anita O'Day that emerges in this documentary is of a woman who always lived by her own rules.
movie_title: Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A crude but scathing portrait of suburban life.
Subscribes wholeheartedly to the history-as-pornography school of thinking, in which all will be revealed if you can figure out who is sleeping with whom, when and where and what they do in bed.
In 12, the elements of the modest courtroom classic 12 Angry Men have been enlarged to operatic dimensions.
It leaves you frustrated and annoyed.
Like smog settling over Los Angeles, a creeping sense of anomie haunts the Hollywood power players and parasites sidling nervously through Shrink.
A frightening jeremiad about the effects of climate change.
Not the first movie to follow a victim of sex trafficking into a living nightmare.
How do you explain a movie as hermetic and perverse and ultimately repugnant as Death in Love?
Homecoming is coldly efficient for what it is. But what it is is trash.

In The Vanished Empire, Mr. Shakhnazarov, a prolific and under-recognized Russian filmmaker with a surrealist touch, views the collapse of the Soviet Union as an inevitable conflation of the younger generation's natural impulse to reject the past.
However streamlined, this consistently gripping, visually intoxicating film stands as a landmark of contemporary Turkish cinema.
[An] engrossing documentary portrait of a once-beloved radio and television star who died in 1966 and today is barely remembered.
You might blame Nora Ephron, whose screenplay for When Harry Met Sally established the formula that I Hate Valentine's Day runs into the ground. Compared with this, Ms. Ephron is Chekhov.
More than an indelible portrait of a sociopath with the soul of a zombie, Tony Manero is an extremely dark meditation on borrowed cultural identity.
Although it is not a comedy, Lion's Den is suffused with sense of life lived in the present. Even the grimmest moments are not exploited to instill fear and loathing.

The movie uses the talent show Afghan Star as a prism through which to examine the fragmented tribal culture of Afghanistan as reflected in the backgrounds of four finalists (two of them women) and the public responses to their performances.
Beneath its layers of sentimentality Local Color means what it is says.
The Stoning of Soraya M. thoroughly blurs the line between high-minded outrage and lurid torture-porn.
The movie's unblinking observation of a friendship put to the test is amused, queasy making, kindhearted and unfailingly truthful.
Scary enough to make the faint of heart decide never to venture into the woods or to lie on the grass again without protective covering.
Produces nightmarish horror and formal beauty in a surreal, Central European blend.
More skin is shown in Spread than in most Hollywood movies. But despite twitches of insight into its characters and their world, Spread refuses go more than skin deep.
A faithful, compelling screen adaptation of J. M. Coetzee's Booker Prize-winning 1999 novel.
Although Paris makes gestures toward being a top-to-bottom examination of the city's social fabric, its perspective is solidly middle class.
Sorority Row is an interminable mess of a film that juggles more characters and undeveloped subplots than it can handle and even manages to bungle the setup.
Choppy, high-energy documentary of the band's rise from a cult phenomenon to international acclaim.
The sexual temperature remains a safe, nap-inducing 98.6.

The film's rich performances, in which every shade of every character's emotions registers, can go only so far to camouflage the glaring lapses in a drama that often confuses hints and allusions with coherent storytelling.
The small, sometimes confusing movie is a knowing homage to Jean-Luc Godard.
Stands as one of the most accomplished recent films about a non-European immigrant coming to the United States.
So completely lacking in his eye for revealing detail and his ear for colloquial speech that it feels less like a movie than an incomplete first draft of a well-meaning if unsophisticated essay.
Given a subject that has become synonymous with overblown mythmaking, its modesty becomes it.
A good-natured screwball road film set in 1953.
With a merciless acuity this nihilistic comedy ridicules collective grief and the news media's cynical marketing of inspirational uplift after a death.
A streamlined, adrenalized thriller that is not as deep as it would like to appear, treads a retrospective political tightrope.
A full appreciation of Lucrecia Martel's elegant, rain-soaked film, The Headless Woman, requires the concentration and eye for detail of a forensic detective.
movie_title: La Mujer sin Cabeza (The Headless Woman) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The lesson of this story: if enough money is involved, greed trumps morality.

Until it implodes with preposterous plot manipulations, The Narrows can be appreciated as the film equivalent of a reasonably palatable pasta dish concocted from a familiar recipe and served in a no-frills restaurant.
The Windmill Movie is a version of the autobiography of Richard P. Rogers that might have been.
The movie jolts you with the realization that the AIDS epidemic and the public debate about such issues have retreated so far under the news radar as to be half-forgotten.
As operatic cinema, it ranks alongside the best of Martin Scorsese and Francis Ford Coppola.
Lemon Tree is a wrenching, richly layered feminist allegory as well as a geopolitical one.

What balances the movie is Mr. Caine's exceptional portrayal of old age as the accumulation of a lifetime's experience. In his performance the child, the youthful rogue and the forgetful codger all live at once.
American Violet, which is based on real events that took place in late 2000, has the quasi-documentary feel of a well-made television drama.
With its off-center dialogue and upscale industrial settings, Gigantic strains to be original. But beneath its indie affectations it is really another contemplation of generational misunderstanding.

As unabashedly sentimental as The Song of Sparrows often becomes, this simple fable of a righteous man's relationship to his family, his community and most of all his faith has the force of conviction.
When Ms. Sangare sings a heartbreaking lament of "a worried songbird" searching for her father, you don't need to know the language to be gripped by the force of her cry.
This movie adaptation of Rebecca Gilman's play is a methodical, not to say mechanical and plodding, exploration of identity politics and language.
The film's portrayal of farm life as a rugged pastorale lends The Country Teacher a foundation of visceral truth.
The matchmaking games in Emmanuel Mouret's romantic comedy Shall We Kiss? may backfire, but nobody is seriously hurt.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The Great Buck Howard is an agreeable show business satire with a warm heart.
Watching Valentino: The Last Emperor is a little like gorging on chocolate and Champagne.
Leaves you wondering why its subjects are not widely recognized as national treasures.
Superior acting elevates a small, overcrowded ensemble piece set in rural upstate New York into something a little deeper.
Although American Swing pointedly goes out of its way to include positive testimonials from several women who patronized the club, it leaves you feeling queasy.
Obsessed, a clanking, low-rent imitation of Fatal Attraction, lacks both the original film's imagination and moral ambiguity.
A road movie that poignantly juggles absurdism and melancholy.
I'll take a bunch of teenagers terrorized by chain-saw-wielding zombies any day.
Tennessee is an earnest, increasingly preposterous road movie about unhealed family wounds and fraternal bonds.
With stale 1970s-style sitcom humor, My Life in Ruins has none of the homey authenticity of My Big Fat Greek Wedding.
Unmistaken Child documents the four-year search of Tenzin Zopa, a gentle, baby-faced 28-year-old Nepalese monk.
A small Canadian horror film that makes the most of its minuscule budget.
Pressure Cooker belongs to the honorable genre of inspirational films dedicated to the proposition that one passionate teacher can make a difference in the lives of students.
Rashid Masharawi's film is a fleet, dark urban comedy that registers outrage in glancing jabs of absurdist observation.
May leave you with the impression that the spirit of modern New York was conjured out of thin air by its subject.
movie_title: Milton Glaser: To Inform and Delight (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In its cold-eyed assessment of the English aristocracy Easy Virtue has none of the lurking Anglophilia found in Merchant-Ivory movies.
Its belly laughs leave you feeling liberated and not guilty; I repeat, not guilty.
This minuscule indie variation of Saturday Night Fever moves only in fits and starts.

If it isn't half as good -- or as funny -- as its forerunners, it maintains its integrity as a small, sweet-natured comedy that refuses to obey the commercial dictates of Hollywood by allowing its characters to determine their own zany destinies.
Beyond that your response to the movie, which takes too conspicuous a delight in its own cleverness, is likely to be a shrug and a "so what?"
Adoration is a profound and provocative exploration of cultural inheritance.
As sleek and handsome as any of the new and improved household items it exhibits.
Portentous dreams infiltrate the Argentine director Carlos Sorn's film The Window.
Peter Askin's stirring documentary Trumbo gives you reasons to cheer but also to weep.
The candy-colored Full Grown Men wants to be a kind of anti-Wizard of Oz for a culture inundated with toys and toons.
In the deathbed drama Two Weeks, Sally Field creates an agonizing portrait of a middle-aged American everywoman in the final stages of ovarian cancer.
This fragmentary portrait of the British filmmaker, painter, set designer and writer Derek Jarman, is a cinematic scrapbook of the life and times of an iconoclast, aesthete and provocateur.

Ethan Hawke's earnest, talky film The Hottest State, which he adapted from his own semi-autobiographical 1997 novel, doggedly peels away the gloss to dive into the emotional swamp where two young people get lost in each other.
As The Nanny Diaries wobbles along uncertainly, it rests on the tense, squared shoulders of Laura Linney.
Resurrecting the Champ is a cautionary fable that every journalistic go-getter dreaming of front-page bylines would do well to heed.
A weird hybrid of political exposé and sensationalistic fluff.
Love for Sale has a deep sympathy for sexual free spirits in a rigid macho society.
Tom DiCillo’s angry comedy Delirious subjects modern celebrity culture to a microscopic examination that shows the toxic virus of fame squirming under its lens.
Tender and sad, it is a fully realized work of mumblecore poetry.
Though less reassuring and not as dramatically coherent as Hotel Rwanda, it still packs a hard punch.
Tender but hardheaded.
The movie assumes that its churning energy, lightened with whimsy, will carry the day. And, to an extent, it does.
This 75-minute film plays like a sketchy hybrid of a Columbo episode and Body Heat. It even includes a soupçon of philosophy.
Explicitly religious, intensely poetic meditations, filled with recurrent symbols and suffused with a spirit of divine apprehension. [It is] sad beyond measure.

Julie Gavras's wonderful film, Blame It on Fidel, is a deeply political movie that sidesteps strident polemics by viewing the ideological conflicts within a French-Spanish family through the eyes of a smart, willful child.
movie_title: Blame It on Fidel (La Faute a Fidel) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A triumph for Anne Hathaway, who brings to the young Jane the same jittery wide-eyed intensity she displayed in The Devil Wears Prada along with a secure British accent. She and Mr. McAvoy inject a keen intelligence into the couple's verbal jousts.
Julie Delpy's and Adam Goldberg's performances are so assured and spontaneous that they don't even seem to be acting.
Eartha Kitt stands out in this otherwise uneventful romantic comedy.
There is much more to be explored than this noble documentary, made on a tiny budget, has the resources to examine.
There is more raw vitality pumping through Romance & Cigarettes than in a dozen perky high school musicals.
Canvas is a movie that rings emotionally true, despite structural contrivances and dim, washed-out color.
This scattershot exposé of usurious banking practices examines why the most vulnerable segment of society is victimized by the lending industry and finds a simple answer: It's obscenely profitable.
If Broken defies basic credibility, it is at least well acted.
The comedy of male midlife angst dates back at least to The Seven-Year Itch, when it was sweet and innocent. Each time it is recycled, it gets more sour and joyless.
Like most documentary polemics, it simplifies the issues it confronts and selects facts that bolster its black-and-white, heroes-and-villains view of raw economic power.
Playing a canny old papa bear dispensing nuggets of advice to a flock of unruly cubs in Feast of Love Morgan Freeman has a role he could act in his sleep.
The Nines is a philosophical mind teaser with satirical fangs.

However authentic and heartfelt this film's depiction of life on the meaner streets of the Northeast corridor may be, it doesn't begin to match The Sopranos' epic vision of violence, class struggle and upward mobility in a barbarous culture.
An entertaining, carefully assembled piece of clockwork that imposes order on ever more complicated gender warfare.

Across the Universe captured my heart, and I realized that falling in love with a movie is like falling in love with another person. Imperfections, however glaring, become endearing quirks once you've tumbled.
Breezy, loose-jointed.

[Director] Girard confuses pretty scenery doused in ponderous music with epic visual poetry. Impenetrable musings intended to evoke ineffable romantic longing leave you scratching your head as you wait, ever more impatiently, for something to happen.
When F. Scott Fitzgerald remarked that the rich "are different from you and me," he might have been thinking of someone like the moody billionaire from Fierce People.
In the Shadow of the Moon is a morale booster. The power of its archival images hasn't diminished with familiarity.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A sumptuously illustrated but shallow fable of the grass-is-greener conflict between freedom and commitment.
How easy [the capitalist] appetite is to stimulate is demonstrated in the cheeky documentary Czech Dream.
A mood of cosmic desolation seeps like late autumn sunlight filtered through clouds in Aki Kaurismaki's Lights in the Dusk.

So convincingly acted that if it didn't include brief interludes in which the grown-ups suddenly break into musical-comedy mode or reflect out loud in video diary segments, you might not guess it is fiction.
If you love to hate the superrich, The Valet is a sinfully delicious bonbon.
Slow Burn is a wooden police thriller that is as dull as it is impenetrable and ultimately beyond ludicrous.

A beautifully photographed remake of 1970 cult B-movie The Honeymoon Killers succeeds better than many in balancing the philosophical with the visceral, although its villains' dirty deeds still trump its deeper strain of melancholy.
Even after it lurches from the far-fetched into the preposterous, Perfect Stranger leaves a clammy residue of unease.
If its portrait of hippie parents raising a misfit child has much in common with Rebecca Miller's Ballad of Jack and Rose, Whole New Thing refrains from going to the same extremes.
Summer in Berlin is a pointedly unglamorous slice of life that could be set in any urban neighborhood where real estate prices haven't gone through the roof.
Without standing on a soapbox Stephanie Daley suggests a tragic gender gap between men who judge and women who feel.
With Blades of Glory, Will Ferrell and Jon Heder stake an early claim to being the comedy couple of the year.
A pointed little thriller with metaphysical pretensions, First Snow is shrewd enough to approach basic philosophical questions in sneaky, offhand ways.
Tristan Bauer's film portrays the Falklands War in 1982 as a mismanaged, vainglorious spasm of nationalism.
movie_title: Blessed by Fire (Iluminados por el fuego) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Until everything collapses, and the filmmakers are left grasping at straws, it's absorbing in a sick way.
movie_title: American Cannibal: The Road to Reality (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Mira Nair's The Namesake conveys a palpable sense of people as living, breathing creatures who are far more complex than their words might indicate.
The sloppy, absent-minded Premonition is a step back in time and a giant leap backward for Sandra Bullock.
The documentaries Blockade and Amateur Photographer offer a devastating look at World War II-era atrocities.
Once the movie gets started, it doesn't know where to go or how to end. It more or less repeats itself.

The meek, mopey comedy In the Land of Women is the film equivalent of a sensitive emo band with one foot in alternative rock and the other in the squishy pop mainstream: a softer, fuzzier Garden State.
Snow Cake partly camouflages the banality of its concept with its meticulous performances.
Meticulously assembled, Diggers shuttles among several major characters with an ease and grace that don't waste a moment of screen time. But it doesn't feel rushed.
As this sad, shambling antihero swings from one pole to the other on the issue of capital punishment, you are inclined to follow every step of the way toward his tragic enlightenment.
Once you become accustomed to the mystical vocabulary describing a world without modern science and technology, it amounts to using different terms to describe universal experience.
If it is not as sadistic as the Saw and Hostel movies, it is as malignant in its insistence on the omnipresence of evil.
It won't hurt you, and it's easy on the eyes.
A cold, misanthropic work that places no faith in institutions and in humanity itself. But it's also very funny.
movie_title: The Boss of it All (Direktøren for det hele) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This shambling, good-natured comedy is a Wilson family affair.
Fay Grim gets so carried away with the intricacies of its plot that it gets lost in its own excessive cleverness.
Whether you like or loathe Mr. Dumont's movies, his unsettling vision of humanity stripped of cultural finery feels profoundly truthful. Beneath the facade of civilization, life is a barnyard.
So devoted to sustaining shock and awe that it doesn't bother to offer clues about the causes and treatment of gambling addiction.
Magic realism is a tricky thing to pull off in a movie, and Disappearances, the third of Mr. Craven's films based on Mr. Mosher's novels, only occasionally succeeds.
The best jokes in The Ex a scattershot screwball satire of job insecurity, upward mobility, political correctness and yuppie marital tensions, have claws that leave scratches.
In Allegro, the past is a shadowy night town whose geography is continually rearranging itself.
Day Night Day Night, a movie about a suicide bomber, may be serious, and it is certainly sure of itself. But it is also maddeningly, purposefully evasive.
For this kind of omnibus movie a success rate of two out of three is a pretty high batting average. There are no home runs, however, only doubles, singles and coy little bunts.
The movie's treatment of Mr. Obree's mental illness is so perfunctory that it might have been better not to address the subject at all.
John Malkovich has virtually cornered the market on portraying aesthetes in the thrall of demonic visions. Klimt adds to his gallery of elegant monsters.
Until it erupts in tears, Love Happens dawdles along uncertainly as though debating exactly how to season its morose story with enough attempted witticisms to keep the audience from dozing off.
A movie that, despite its fine acting, has the emotional impact of a general anesthetic.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Those seeking career advice about how to become an emperor of fashion will find little if any useful information in Lagerfeld Confidential.
A somber, brooding study.
An astonishing documentary of culture clash and the erasure of history amid China's economic miracle.
Then She Found Me, a serious comedy, is more impressive for what it refuses to do than for its modest accomplishment.
At once enthralling and troubling...does about as good a job as you could hope of distilling a 750-page historical examination of religious zealotry and power into 95 swift minutes.
As it plods along decorously, you have the sense of reading a poetic essay in which every image and metaphor is hammered too neatly in place.
While Never Forever lingers in the thick of sex, lies and anxiety, it is something to see.
The romantic comedy Made of Honor adds tart satirical flavors to a cotton-candy formula without sabotaging the sugar rush.
Dark Matter, with its view of cutthroat politics and competing egos inside a university, is also laudable in its refusal to soft-pedal the viciously petty side of the academic fishbowl.
The Monk music that courses through the film is extraordinary in its range of feeling.
movie_title: Thelonious Monk: Straight, No Chaser (Straight, No Chaser ) (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Tuya's Marriage finds an austere beauty in a landscape of scrub and grassland ringed by forbidding slate-blue mountains.
As the director of the documentary Shine a Light, Martin Scorsese is a besotted rock 'n' roll fan who wholeheartedly embraces its mythology.
Flawless is a mildly diverting period heist movie in which an odd couple conspire to loot an evil London diamond company, for which they both work.
Forget reality shows exalting American gluttony and savor the more refined amenities on the coasts of southern France in the cynical Gallic comedy Priceless.
Filmed mostly in winter, in browns, grays and soiled whites, Sleepwalking sustains a mood of unrelenting bleakness, wearing its aesthetic of desolation like a badge of integrity.
To observe a fluctuating group of about two dozen singers whose average age is 80 perform in the documentary Young@Heart is to be uplifted, if slightly unsettled.
Married Life, a period comedy of manners merged with a suspenseful psychological thriller, aspires to be a hybrid of the sort that Alfred Hitchcock polished to perfection.
The ingredients of the Indian director Santosh Sivan's period piece Before the Rains may be awfully familiar, but the film lends them the force of tragedy.
Noise, the second part of a projected 'fanatic trilogy', is shallow and loud.
Chris & Don: A Love Story examines a complicated and enduring relationship that raised eyebrows even in Hollywood.
Quid Pro Quo hovers in a noir-shaded twilight zone where repressed memories and guilt merge in an obsession with physical and emotional paralysis.
Think of it as a polite, tightly muzzled Clerks.
[A] small gem of a film.
movie_title: Le fils de l'épicier (The Grocer's Son) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Much of the dialogue is so quirky it sounds overheard instead of scripted. The performances are correspondingly spontaneous.
Bigger, Stronger, Faster* left me convinced that the steroid scandals will abate as the drugs are reluctantly accepted as inevitable products of a continuing revolution in biotechnology.
Until it crosses a shadowy line dividing serious comedy from distasteful exploitation, The Babysitters has the makings of an incisive satire of greed and lust in suburbia.
Stuck, while not strictly a horror film, is steeped in gore and carries a seam of mocking gallows humor as relentless as that of Sweeney Todd.
Enthralling documentary.
movie_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The problem with gonzo moviemaking, in this case, is that nothing really adds up. What initially appears whimsical eventually seems sloppy. And when the bleeding heart kicks in, you feel betrayed.
My Father My Lord has the glowing simplicity and force of a biblical parable.
Yella is the kind of movie that tantalizes the mind with possibilities without solving the puzzle.
Although it exhibits a heartfelt connection with the city's half-invisible population of illegal immigrants, its myriad inconsistencies and strained plotting are increasingly frustrating.
Turn the River is a finely observed portrait of a desperate working-class woman who refuses to play by ordinary rules.
Just under two hours, sumptuously photographed in noirish shades and slathered in spine-tingling music by Ennio Morricone, it twists every which way to sustain suspense until the final frame.
How light is this movie? So buoyant that even an air raid warning, signaling that this whole world is about to crumble under the blitz, can't dampen its giddy spirits.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: City of Men is a rootin'-tootin' gangster movie shot in the notoriously lawless shantytowns overlooking the beaches of Rio de Janeiro.
Cinderella meets The Ugly Duckling in Penelope, a muddled, charm-free fairy tale whose title character is a rich girl born with the snout of a pig.
The Perfect Holiday, directed by Lance Rivera, is that most dispiriting product, a formulaic movie that doesn't believe in itself.
By the end of The Walker a movie that begins as a dazzling round of charades has deteriorated into a plodding game of Clue.
Once its machinery is humming, it settles into a soothing fable of a last hurrah.
For most of its 85 minutes Grace Is Gone, a small, tender film about contemporary parenthood in wartime, carries off a delicate balancing act.
It is a small relief to discover that Chronicle of an Escape is relatively restrained in its depiction of torture. Despite its restraint, the movie is deeply unsettling.
Protagonist is an enthralling documentary exploration of people with obsessive needs for control and self-mastery.
Nanking is a swift, incisive documentary about one of the lesser-known horrors of the 20th century.
To describe August Rush as a piece of shameless hokum doesn't quite do justice to the potentially shock-inducing sugar content of this contemporary fairy tale.
War/Dance is an honorable, sometimes inspiring exploration of the primal healing power of music and dance in an African tribal culture.
Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 follows the painstaking yearlong process of building and fine-tuning a handmade nine-foot concert grand piano.
movie_title: Note by Note: The Making of Steinway L1037 (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Ends up stranded between two concepts.
A quiet, methodical call to action.
Bella is a movie that wears its bleeding heart on its sleeve and loves its characters to distraction.
Slipstream is Anthony Hopkins's third film as a director and his first as a quasi-avant-garde filmmaker working well outside the mainstream.
If the concept of Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium is ingenious, its execution is erratic.
A business course on cutthroat capitalism disguised as a slacker comedy: That's the kindest way to describe Michael Lehmann's Flakes.
Steep is an undeniably impressive visual spectacle that follows the sport of extreme skiing.
There are enough things to admire about The Great Debaters, the heavily fictionalized true story of The Little Debate Team That Could, that your impulse is to forgive the movie its shortcomings.
Two decades after Ferris Bueller, a new smarty-pants seeks popularity in Charlie Bartlett.
Ezra is a scorching portrait of an African child who is kidnapped and turned into a soldier for a rebel militia.
An 81-minute movie that runs out of ideas well before the halfway point.
Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show imagines itself a contemporary equivalent of rootin'- tootin' traveling entertainments like Buffalo Bill's Wild West Show. That's a tall comparison to draw.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Fundamental issues of ethnic and religious identity and the agony of exile are at the heart of Live and Become.
movie_title: Va, Vis et Deviens (Live and Become) (Go, See, and Become) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The beautifully acted ensemble film The Witnesses sidesteps most of its opportunities for high drama, political sermonizing and the jerking of tears.
Morally duplicitous torture porn: how else to describe Untraceable, a bleak, rain-washed horror thriller.
Teenage horror-movie spoof, John Waters parody, No Nukes protest movie: Mitchell Lichtenstein's clever, crude comedy, Teeth is all these and more.
This movie is awkwardly structured.
If the abysmal reception so far for films about the war in Iraq is any indication, Day Zero is the last thing movie audiences will want to consume.
The Business of Being Born is not overtly political. Its feminism is palpable but unspoken.
[A] transporting vision of life in a mountain village in northwest Turkey.
Andrew Piddington's devastating re-enactment of events leading up to, including and immediately after the murder is taken from interviews, depositions and court transcripts.
Honeydripper, directed by John Sayles, is a shambling fusion of pop mythology and social mosaic.
The Bucket List operates on the hope that two beloved stars rubbing their signature screen personas together can spark warm, fuzzy box office magic.
A potent exercise in art-world mythography.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Compacted into an 80-minute mishmash of interviews, confessions and sketches, melded into a shaky mosaic, the answers from a cross section of men are shallow, self-serving and ultimately unenlightening.
In The Monastery: Mr. Vig & the Nun, Jorgen Lauersen Vig comes across as a hybrid of quasi-Dickensian curmudgeon and modern grumpy old man.
movie_title: The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An enraptured fantasia of high times at the hotel, the film is so intoxicated with the Chelsea's bohemian mystique it virtually consumes itself.
Your religion or lack of one doesn't matter. At some point while watching the film, you may feel that music is God, or if not, a close approximation of divinity.
If "Mr. Nice," which was written and directed by Bernard Rose, is steadily watchable, it lopes along without building much tension.
"Beautiful Boy" tiptoes into a minefield, where it loses its nerve and remains frozen in its tracks, too timid to find a way back.
With minute facial movements, Ms. Onetto can signal feelings that run from rueful to sardonic, while remaining tantalizingly enigmatic.
Manages the considerable feat of creating six fully human characters who are quirky enough to transcend the stereotypes found in a typical indie film.
It is a touching, elegiac tale of the rise (and some would say fall) of a colorful New York neighborhood under the relentless march of gentrification.
movie_title: Florent: Queen Of The Meat Market (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The weepy story at the heart of "Bride Flight" is trumped by its sumptuous depiction of New Zealand in the 1950s and '60s. This lushness has the effect of a powerful fabric softener added to the wash.
Sam and Rasheen's icky pas de deux is coarsely shoehorned into a movie that juggles three tepid romantic mini-dramas.

Oh to live the exquisite life! A wistful sigh of longing was my initial reaction to "L'Amour Fou," Pierre Thoretton's tantalizing documentary about Yves Saint Laurent, the French couturier who died in 2008.
Not even Mr. Gordon-Levitt's unremittingly savage performance can begin to salvage such hokum.
"Daydream Nation" rolls elements of "Juno," "American Beauty," "Donnie Darko" and "Twin Peaks" into a potent blunt.
Clunk, clunk, squish. That is the sound of the dead language in Roland Joffé's screenplay for "There Be Dragons" as it tramples his would-be epic of the Spanish Civil War into an indigestible pulp.
Conjuring magic, it goes abracadabra and snaps its fingers, but nothing happens.
If this isn't "King Lear" or Chekhov, "Harvest" shows the truth of life as it is lived, growing messier and more complicated as the days dwindle and last chances loom.
I have a mental picture of the film's creators, stoned out of their minds on who knows what, cackling crazily as they outline a movie that would have more appropriately been titled "The Big Goof."
Mr. Harris's depiction of a saintly, soft-spoken, bow-tie-wearing middle-school teacher lends the movie a moral weight it probably couldn't have summoned had another actor played the role.
If Mr. Hellman's movie only partly fulfills its promise as a gripping neo-noir mystery, his stylistic hallmarks lend it a singularly haunting atmosphere.
"R" is not about justice or redemption. You couldn't even call it a protest film about prison conditions, but it is very well made and persuasively acted.
[An] melancholy rumination on time, love and decay...
movie_title: La bocca del lupo (The Mouth of the Wolf) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An exhilarating adrenaline rush with breakneck momentum so shrewdly calculated that you could imagine its French director, Fred Cavayé, standing by with a heart-rate monitor.
Time and again, "True Adolescents" resists the temptation to succumb to easy melodrama.
The screenplay is blunt and to the point, and the performances are subtly tinged with a surreal comic edge.
The movie is truly a tree-hugger's delight (I confess to being one such hugger) that makes the most of its metaphors without straining toward supernatural schmaltz.
We see the impostor's trickery but not the pain driving it.

Starting as a coldly realistic thriller, this film eventually loses its bearings as the director Miguel Ángel Vivas succumbs to a fit of nihilism, transforming "Kidnapped" into gruesome tit-for-tat torture porn.

It is a rich, beautifully organized and illustrated modern history of Eastern European Jewry examined through the life and work of the author, born Sholem Rabinovich in Pereyaslav (near Kiev) in 1859.
movie_title: Sholem Aleichem: Laughing in the Darkness (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Beneath a deceptive calm, it uncovers a core of fear and loathing as ominous as the backwoods world of "Winter's Bone."
Not even Mr. Pierce's best efforts can make sense of a character who by the end of the film seems to be a completely different person with the same name.
A rom-com fairy tale so tepid and well behaved that watching it feels like being stuck in traffic as giddy joy-riders in the opposite lane break the speed limit.
A movie that has the tone and structure of early-to-middle Woody Allen, but infused with a dose of Gallic identity politics.
movie_title: Le nom des gens (The Names of Love) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If "Conan O'Brien Can't Stop" is consistently watchable, it isn't especially funny, nor does it give any deeper insight into its star than you might get from seeing his late-night shows.
The film's sobriety and carefully balanced arguments make it an exemplary piece of reporting, although its emotional heat rarely rises to a boil.
movie_title: If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front (2011)

movie_review_blurb: What undoes it is its mechanical structure: a stale dramatic formula of the sort taught in elementary playwriting classes.
"Magic Trip" is the cinematic equivalent of a yellowed scrapbook whose pictures are accompanied by sketchy captions created after the fact.

These characters may serve an obscure metaphorical agenda, but they make no psychological sense. And as the movie contemplates the rewards and perils of giving and receiving, it winds itself into stomach-turning knots.

Short-circuits the novel's quirky charms and period atmosphere by its squeamish attitude toward gritty circus life and smothers the drama under James Newton Howard's insufferable wall-to-wall musical soup.
In any case, this intriguing, sometimes frustrating, in some ways amateurish movie is a work of vaulting artistic ambition.

The new movie confirms Mr. Dolan as a wildly talented, carelessly extravagant filmmaker nakedly in thrall to idols like Wong Kar-wai, Jean-Luc Godard, François Truffaut, Bernardo Bertolucci and Pedro Almodóvar.
Matt Porterfield's moody, elliptical fusion of fiction and documentary, slips back and forth between the forms with a stealth that dissolves one into the other.

Senes of Columbus's arrival and of his imperialist and religious sloganeering, and of the carnage he wreaks, have a grandeur and a force reminiscent of Terrence Malick films. The segments about the chaotic water riots have a documentary immediacy.
The Edge of Dreaming is not the confession of a true believer who has found the Answer but of an intelligent woman with an open mind and heart who embarked on a serious metaphysical quest.
Vidal Sassoon: The Movie isn't just the story of a brilliant fashion idea that swept the globe. It is a euphoric account of one man's strenuous self-invention.
A reasonably watchable immersion in nostalgia.
If the movie, which starts out shakily, improves in the second half, it is a discombobulated grab bag of jokes peopled with characters who have little emotional resonance.
In the end, as another talking head points out, "the music always wins." And it did -- by a landslide.
Above all How I Ended This Summer is a merciless contemplation of the fragile human psyche under siege.

Is it the devil's work or a psychiatric disorder? That is the spurious debate that sputters along in this dull, pretentiously verbose movie that (need it be said?) enthusiastically takes the devil's side.
If its message can be boiled down to one sentence, it is George's stoic observation: "There is a psychic risk in being an artist."
The paradox of aggressively pursuing intimacy and discovering the idiosyncratic chaos inside everyday people runs to the heart of Twelve Thirty.
Very well written and acted, Every Day feels like a glorified television drama softened with comic and surreal trimmings, with a mildly upbeat ending appended.
More often than not, I felt suffocated by the gaseous sentimentality and lightheadedness of a story that drops in subplots that it can't begin to develop.

Kitson, who plays CJ, the mouthy, forthright teenager at the center of the storm, illuminates a movie that is otherwise so studiously balanced an examination of teenage pregnancy that it deserves a medal for evenhandedness.
Despite its modernist sensibility, there is little reason to be intimidated, unless you find the character of James abhorrent.
Little is left to chance, and every detail contributes to a tightly schematic, microcosmic poetic concept.
A sad, lyrical reflection on the foolish worship of movie stars.
What would "The Greatest Movie Ever Sold" be with a different narrator-guide? It is hard to imagine. Mr. Spurlock has the gift of gab along with an undeniable star quality.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A multicultural vision of urbanity coalesces that is very different from that of a typical movie of impoverished immigrants trying to assimilate in an outer borough.

If, like me, you would rather get lost in a noir than try to second-guess its creators, "The Double Hour" is the best movie of its kind since the French director Guillaume Canet's hit from 2006, "Tell No One."
Throughout the movie, Ms. Thurman's facial expressions suggest a peevish spoiled child about to stomp her feet and throw a full-scale tantrum.
[Refuses] to soften the harsher personal truths faced by aging professional salesmen of erotic fantasy.
Has some scattered witty notions, but it is not funny.
"Super" rides on the carefully bent performances of its stars.
An incoherent hybrid of buddy movie, "Girls Gone Wild" episode and James Bond spoof that employs cheap cinematic tricks like multiple split screens for no apparent purpose.

Putting profane adjectives in front of every other noun in dialogue that wants desperately to sound streetwise doesn't make it feel authentic if the other words spoken by the characters are arranged into orderly little blocks of exposition.
There are no dry talking heads, no droning lists of Soviet leaders and events, just raw experience.
In many ways "Cracks" is lurid and rickety. But its gripping ensemble performances lend it an emotional intensity that outweighs its shortcomings.
The movie immerses you in the consciousness of a restless boy desperate for initiation into the rest of his life.
The film's passionate insistence on remembrance lends it a moral as well as a metaphysical weight. Mr. Guzmán's belief in eternal memory is an astounding leap of faith.
In small but significant ways, "Queen to Play" defies expectations.

"The Whistleblower" has a choppy, fumbling screenplay (by Ms. Kondracki and Eilis Kirwan) that lurches between shrill editorializing and vagueness while sorting through more characters than it can comfortably handle or even readily identify.
The body-swapping premise, which is stale to begin with, isn't explored with any depth, unless you find meaningful Freudian subtext in the movie's relentless anal fixation.
It strains to celebrate diversity and individualism, while its processed music exemplifies strict corporate teamwork.
"The Hunter" never declares who is good or bad or right or wrong. And the implications of Martin's decision when the moment of truth finally arrives are left for the viewer to unravel.
Digs deeply into the soil of working-class American life.
Despite several solid performances, the characters are too hazily sketched and too loosely linked to form a meaningful chain.
At its heart is an incandescent performance by Ms. Oduye, who captures the jagged mood swings of late adolescence with a wonderfully spontaneous fluency.
The screenplay isn't written so much as assembled in carefully slotted little blocks, following the rules of a screenwriting textbook.
By the end, you feel nothing, not even contempt.
"Norwegian Wood" registers less as a coherent narrative than as a tortuous reverie steeped in mournful yearning.
Demonstrates how great acting can infuse a banal, politically correct drama with dollops of emotional truth.
If the film's conspiratorial viewpoint makes sense and is probably accurate, its final judgment is so gloomy that your impulse is to throw up your hands and despair.
The visually snazzy film has stark, ominous, mostly black-and-white computer-animated sequences depicting Mr. Khodorkovsky's initial arrest.
A mug of warm cocoa with marshmallow topping that produces a comfy feel-good glow.
The heavy candlelit chiaroscuro paints the women as mobile Renoirs, Degases and Manets.
These are the same old, adorable Muppets, as sweetly innocent and likable as ever. Winking at itself, the movie is casually, amusingly self-reflexive.
Its refusal to adopt a single point of view may be conceptually ambitious, but it keeps the drama unfocussed, and slightly off balance.
Dr. Suzuki's upbeat tone is the spoonful of sugar that makes the bitter medicine go down.
movie_title: Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Both anguished and histrionic and in its strongest moments very, very good. But it is also overpopulated, strident and constitutionally unable to step back and scrutinize itself.
You really can't hang a drama on a mathematical theory and expect it to serve as a shortcut for storytelling.
A conventional, rather shallow up-by-your-bootstraps drama, but with a difference.
A mediocre gross out movie that barely pushes the envelope.
movie_title: I Hope They Serve Beer in Hell (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Danis Tanovic's scalding black comedy about the insanity of war...
Part character study, part crime thriller, "Bullhead" is the impressive but deeply flawed first feature written and directed by Michael R. Roskam.

This coldly compelling film doesn't try to explain Michael's behavior or analyze his disease. As if doing penance for Michael's sins, it eventually metes out unequivocal punishment, but it is small consolation.
If some of these shorts are stronger than others, there are no lemons among them, and a half-dozen are truly memorable.
You admire these characters for their considerable resilience while understanding that even the best-intentioned people can break under the stress.
A lower echelon of musical comedy hell (or heaven, if you love the hoariest musical comedy clichés).
Beautifully photographed, "The Dish & the Spoon" is awash in images of rain-soaked streets and gray wintry skies.
A solemn sci-fi parable set in present-day Glasgow, whose deepening sense of foreboding is sustained by the enigmatic, pseudo-biblical reflections of an unseen narrator.
Carol Channing is 91 going on 7. That is meant as a compliment.
A movie that doesn't realize that it should have been a comedy.
For all its quirks and tangents, "Declaration of War" feels entirely alive. This story of two people who transform fear into action is inspiring.
A movie that reserves its final sickening wallop for a grueling half-hour that leaves you as emotionally battered as the soldiers are forced to return to hell for one last senseless round.
A mildly entertaining classroom instructional about the Tuskegee Airmen.
The clammy chill that pervades "The Hunter," the fourth feature film by the Iranian director Rafi Pitts, seeps under your skin as you wait for its grim, taciturn protagonist to detonate.

About halfway through, the wheeling and dealing becomes so elaborate and the villains so numerous that the only way to enjoy the movie is to let its preposterous story wash over as you sit back and take in the scenery.
The carnage, although explicit and frequent, is not grotesquely overdone.

Like many of its subjects, Revolutions is fierce, lovable and scrappy.
An appropriately tragic yet surprisingly eye-opening documentary on the rise and fall of singer and actress Whitney Houston
Inversion feels like a neo-realist movie. The settings appear tangible and authentic. The actors disappear into their characters. There is no soundtrack, just the noise of radios and ringtones.
Suntan is further proof that people should sit-up and take notice of the Greek "weird-wave", a movement brimming with fresh ideas, tackling dark, social issues.
Rules Don't Apply doesn't hang together but for fans of Beatty there are glimmers of his now trademark stylish direction and witty dialogue.
... a work as heart-warming as it is gorgeous.
Earns its uplifting ending.
movie_title: The Son of Joseph (Le fils de Joseph) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A bleak crime drama.
The jokes frequently land and Wade and his co-stars (Percelle Ascott, Dee Kaate) are amusingly hyperactive.

Everything's held together by an authoritative performance from Sheehan, who does fine work keeping open the question of whether the ghosts are really there or just figments of his troubled imagination.

Protagonist Vivian (Shelby Young) may evoke memories of Natalie Portman in Black Swan or Suspirias Jessica harper. But shes a comparatively underwritten character, failing to convince as a trauma victim.

It feels somewhat apt that the story is as directionless as its protagonist. On the other hand, writer/director Rachel Lang's film lacks cumulative dramatic punch, its appeal rooted mainly in its easy humour.
Farrier doesn't overlook the amusing oddness of such a strange corner of the internet, but treats the subjects of the videos respectfully.
Think My Week With Marilyn but with Dylan Thomas and shot in luscious black and white and you've got some measure of Andy Goddard's debut feature.
There's an undeniable sweetness to the songs our hero pens in an attempt to win Amy (Lorna Anderson) back -- but his cause isn't helped by stock characters, leisurely pacing and crude contrivances.
Aesthetics go out the window with the opening night's self-absorbed celebrity fundraiser.
Hull's observations -- an audio diary -- provide plenty of insight and engagement.
A group of middle-Aged Belgian Muslim women of north African descent form a friendship attending a French writing class in this gently heartwarming doc.
movie_title: Patience, Patience, You'll Go to Paradise! (Patience, Patience) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film struggles to flesh out its running time, but such is its sincerity in honouring Fukumotos profession that witnessing him perform his samurai sword skills is genuinely touching.
Performed in Yiddish and shot in Brooklyn's Borough Park, this is a rare insight into Orthodox Jewish culture.
Researching others' experiences as well as recording her own, Brea turns an unflinching eye on the distressing details of those left bed-ridden.
Not even Octavia Spencer can redeem this one.
The complexity of the topic is well handled, and Brixton itself is full of vibrancy, but the film prompts more questions than it manages to answer.
The solemn score, plucky Brits and nasty Nazis are all familiar, but there's a lived-in feel that transcends cliché.
It moves from one traumatic event to another with the swiftness of a biopic thats trying to squeeze in all the major events of its subjects life so much so that none carry the weight they ought to.
This comedy-drama elicits chortles aplenty with its gently caustic humour despite the dark subject matter.
Likeable, but low-stakes.

Catherine Corsini's film highlights the successes of second-wave feminism, but it's when the lovers move to the countryside that the film really finds its theme: the difficulties of growing up gay in a conservative community.
[The Darkness] favours generic mumbo-jumbo about inter-dimensional demons.
The kind of film that serves only to add to YouTube supercuts of Cage freaking out.
It's this last half of the movie -- when Riley learns that Fear and Sadness are all part of growing up, especially when they work alongside Joy -- that really connects.
Moonrise Kingdom may be a light summer entrée, but it rewards us by serving up a rich romantic fantasy and isn't afraid to share its sweet, beating young heart.
Even when it threatens to fall apart at the seams, the movie's good will and heart save the day and, as for Moore, scene for scene, the guy's never less than right on time.
It's clear the stuffing was already pulled out of Ted in the first Ted, so here's hoping Seth MacFarlane grabs a clue and says goodbye to his little friend.
The special effects and action sequences seem like uninspired retreads of things done decades ago.
Schilling, as she's proven on Orange Is the New Black, sport a wicked sense of deadpan and she's genuinely touching opposite Scott.
The movie doesn't earn the darkness, nor the satiric jabs Flynn's novel sets up for it. It's just too bland to pack a wallop.
It's great to see an American movie that's gung-ho on sex and good times that it isn't afraid to tap the heartstrings as it pushes the G-strings. It's big fun.

The laughs come so hard and fast that you may need to watch it twice to catch them all. And that's a good thing because the way we see it, the more exposure to Schumer's canny, daring brilliance, the better.
Although less than amazing, The Amazing Spider-Man is still plenty good enough to deliver big grins, thrills and a welcome tug on the heartstrings.
It's an efficient, diverting entertainment delivery system, a gigantic theme park disguised as a movie.
As this summer's glut of superhero movies goes, let's just say that it's no X-Men: First Class but at least it's more enjoyably goofy than Thor.
The thing has got big laughs, a real heartbeat, and a modesty of scale that, next to the mega machinery of most Marvel movies, is kind of a relief.

Amy gives ample evidence of the brilliance of its subject's massive talent and it respects her by leaving her an enigma, allowing the viewer to decide whether the blazing star could have been saved from chaos and ruin. What a loss.

Love & Mercy is a strong, unconventionally entertaining movie about the mysteries of the psyche the creative process and it's graced by a knowing, charismatic, heartbreaking performance from a never better Dano.
The movie entertains, sure, but the real story behind the puff stuff is way more complicated.
Results wants to seduce and charm by roughing up the rom-com formula but, way too often, it drags and annoys.
Aloha feels thin, tonally weird, false, and undernourishing.
As a recruitment poster for dreamers and reformers, Tomorrowland falls short. As a movie event, it's the most dispiriting letdown of the season so far.
As a Hollywood satire of zero-budget horror flicks, Reality is never as fresh or savage as its needs to be.
If you're up for something slow, steady, muted, and nicely acted, Mr. Holmes might be up your alley.
For connoisseurs of unintentionally terrible movies, San Andreas delivers more than a few hearty belly laughs.

Good Kill is smart and provocative when it examines the bizarre-o world of drone warfare and the intersection of violence and gamesmanship. Unfortunately, it's much less good at exploring what drone warfare does to the men and women who practice it daily.
We're no fans of capital punishment but if any movie deserved to be put out of its misery, it's this one.
Utterly unhinged, magnificently inspired, hugely ambitious, deeply weird, emotionally resonant, and brilliant in every possible way, Mad Max: Fury Road is a mow-you-down masterwork.
Like the heroine it portrays, the whole thing is a curio: a queasy, unpleasant thing wrapped around a cry for help, and a self-indulgent one at that.
Nothing in Maggie connects or coheres. Still, there's talent here amidst all the missed opportunities and it could be interesting to see what might come next from Maggie's writer and director.
In the end, this Far From the Madding Crowd is a handsome but bloodless version of the Hardy classic.

Overall, though, for all of its cheesy fun mixed with doom-and-gloom observations on the plight of humanity, this Avengers leaves us with the nagging feeling that we've been here too many times before.

Crowe, who's been having a rough time finding his footing again for a decade now, underplays his role so self-consciously that when he wants us to feel his pain, all we feel is his ego. He fails to move us. And so does The Water Diviner.

It's got such energy, a sense of fun, and builds so much good will for McCarthy as its central character, don't be surprised if a Susan Cooper franchise happens - once Feig, McCarthy, and Kristen Wiig do a number on their Ghostbusters reboot, that is.
Inception is as wildly visionary as it is smart. If only all "big" movies could be this haunting. We can dream, can't we?

Okay, so maybe nobody expected Gangster Squad to be in the league of, say, Chinatown or L.A. Confidential, but even on the level of pure, bullet-spattered fun, this thing is so vaporous that it slides out of memory even while you're watching it.
It's as rousing, crowd-pleasing, and grandly old-fashioned an accompaniment to popcorn-munching as we've seen all summer.
As for all the stoner jokes, they were done better in other movies. But American Ultra may still turn up in future rotation as an amiable, fun, zero-pretensions living-room favorite.

Worth seeing for the opportunity to watch Robbie become a full-fledged film star, for the strong performances of Ejiofor and Pine, and for the fascinating stuff the movie has to say about race, religion, and the mixed blessings of scientific progress.

Despite a good opening section and some strong suspense sequences, No Escape is an ugly hearted and shamefully xenophobic B-movie directed with remorseless efficiency by brothers John Erick Dowdle and Drew Dowdle.
Wise, funny, sexy, The Second Mother has so much to offer, not the least of which is an ending that has to be one of the most satisfying, if neatest and all-wrapped-up, of any movie so far this year.
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This one is strictly a walk, don't run proposition.
A gritty, beautifully detailed, get-under-your skin slow burn.
It's not that anyone in the movie is terrible but it's not like anybody sparkles or charms, either.
Spotlight, even with its shortcomings, is high quality stuff.

The Visit's a spooky, so-so little fairy tale based on the premise that older people are inherently bizarre. Sounds legit -- so long as you're making movies for super young, slow, and gullible audiences.
The movie's knowhow is impressive and its politics are spot on.

Everest drags you close to the world's highest mountain, slams you down into an unworldly environment, and rams you through the wringer for a couple of hours while relatable, all too human members of a climbing expedition run into terrible luck.
Almost everything that could go wrong does.

Visual and emotional dazzlers finally pop and crackle in the last 20 minutes of The Walk, the new Robert Zemeckis-directed movie starring Joseph Gordon-Levitt as daredevil French aerialist Phillippe Petit.
If one thing's certain about director Ridley Scott's lightest, fleetest, least labored movie in years, it's that it's funny, hopeful, can-do, and aims strictly to entertain.
The funny, cutting, sexy -- and, yeah, even touching -- movie manages to make their relationship a blast to watch and a regretful look at the messed-up state of modern romance.
The End of the Tour may be a niche movie but for those willing to tunnel in, it's a thing of beauty.
The movie's ace in the hole is Tomlin, for whom Weitz wrote the movie, and she is quietly, authoritatively and award-worthy astonishing.
That generosity of spirit lightens and elevates Mistress America and accents the movie's nice sour-ball tang.

We don't even want to know how hard Jake Gyllenhaal trained and bulked up to play a down and out fighter in Southpaw. It's too bad all that obsessive Christian Bale-worthy physical transformation just wasn't worth it for Southpaw.
Although Marley's immense talent, drive, charisma, marketing savvy, and complexity are too big for any film or book to capture, here, at least, they emerge in vibrant glory.
Casa de Mi Padre is an amiable but eventually tiresome Spanish-language goof of telenovelas and floridly melodramatic, moustache-twirling westerns.
The movie goes wildly off the rails chasing so many characters, subplots, and complications that you may find yourself zoning out.
