As the pinched, ever-wary, heartbreaking Nobbs, Close gives a tricky, high wire, award-worthy performance yet she commendably resists any temptation to be showy, campy or spectacular in the least.
Wanderlust doesn't have much new to say but it's fast, vulgar, forgettable fun.
A brash, enjoyable nostalgic rush that also happens to be as timely as tomorrow.
If plot-wise there isn't all that much new being cooked up here, the invaluable, endlessly creative Rudd's interactions with a gallery of terrific actors carry the day.
Although his gear-loose, party guy style fits the role, Brand's stamp on Arthur is good for some mild laughs but not much else.
In a still young movie year, Win Win is already on the mat as one of the best.
For heat-ravaged late summer moviegoers, The Gift ought to do just fine.
The only thing fantastic about it is the miscalculation.
If you're in need of a good giggle, go rent The Temp right now.
You want a killer, cutting edge, thoroughly modern The Man From U.N.C.L.E.? This isn't it. But that doesn't mean it isn't bloody good fun.
Line for line, insult for insult, The Trip is the year's most addictively quotable movie.
Felix and Meira makes fascinating observations on forbidden love and as well as on the Hasidic community. Although its pace is sometimes pokey, it's a movie offering nice rewards to the patient.
Danny Collins isn't what it could have been but at very least the actors are terrific and some of the dialogue has a welcome, tart edge.
It's bananas -- a loud, crackpot joyride and you'll love every messed-up minute of it.
Edge of Tomorrow obviously cost a fortune to make, but it has a light, shrugging, tossed-off air that makes it all the more impressive, let alone enjoyable.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Happily, Wild is scrappy, impressive movie with trippy visuals, a respect for the transformative power of nature, a powerful strong central performance and a deep well of pain.

Cumberbatch does what he can to fill in the blanks and he is the real thing here -- all shyness, rudeness, acid comments, pathos, dazzling intellect and aching melancholy, while suppressing his velvety star charisma.
As an ode to jazz, to the single-minded pursuit of greatness, and to the agony and exultation of jamming to one's inner drummer, Whiplash hardly misses a beat.
Creepy, nasty, often hilarious stuff, Nightcrawler shows Gyllenhaal exactly where he seems to want to be and having the time of his life while he's at it.
Gone Girl is out of this world, a powerful reminder of what cool, crazy, dangerous, hugely entertaining things can happen when big studios let grownup filmmakers make movies for and about grownups.
Somehow, Kent takes these tried and true tropes, whacks them on the nose, and conjures something surprisingly eerie, Freudian and jittery.
Birdman is a raging, exhilarating howl of a satirical comedy.
It's state-of-the-art thrill ride stuff of the kind we hope for in superhero movies but seldom get. Bravo.
Les Mis is so bombastic, emotionally hollow and loud, let alone desperate to make us choke up, that we stagger out of the theater feeling like we've been stormed as mercilessly as the barricade.
Skyfall isn't just one of the best-ever James Bond movies. It's also one of the most rock 'em sock 'em, intelligent, witty, dazzling and best-acted movies of 2012.

Affleck, having now directed his third strong feature film after Gone Baby Gone and The Town, works in a solid, gritty, non-show-offy style. This is his very best movie yet, and it deserves to be a widely seen crowd-pleaser.
[Soderbergh] may be unpredictable but his command of movie making is exhilarating and lord knows he's never dull.
The bold, visionary film jolts us with its sense of scope, scale and social outrage that sometimes suggests novels by Charles Dickens and Victor Hugo.
Humorless, glossy, bland as milk, generic and instantly forgettable.

Mostly avoiding the trip-wires of illogic that tend to plague the gobbledygook of time travel, Johnson dodges the bullet by veering away from plot twists and special effects and instead focusing on relationships, character and emotions.
It's a skin-deep movie of skin-deep characters, but it's rowdy, beautifully made and good hearted.
The jazzy Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead is filled with talking heads you actually want to listen to.
movie_title: Drunk Stoned Brilliant Dead: The Story of the National Lampoon (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A powerhouse of a documentary from Oscar-winning writer-director Alex Gibney.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A shrewd, entertaining, fascinating and surprisingly touching documentary.
Here's a tough, twisty, relentlessly paced little indie in which a college frat hazing looks pretty much like a gang initiation.
Talk about jazzing up a tired-out franchise. X-Men: First Class does that and more.
What's best about Yates's direction of the adapted screenplay by Steve Kloves is that it never loses sight of the emotional interplay and struggles of its characters.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: We guess if you're up for a big, state-of-the-art, kick-ass 3-D giant monster movie, Godzilla gets the job done.
Unpredictable, richly detailed, terrifically acted, biting and funny as hell.
The movie doesn't want to bite the hand that feeds, it just wants to make nice.
Wiig, who's been underused in the past in movies like MacGruber and Paul, proves she's as good with a withering dialogue as she is with oddball characters and physical humor.
Adapted lovingly and good-naturedly from the comic, Thor gains some Shakespearean heft from its themes of sibling rivalry, epic emotions and touching Oedipal conflict.
The movie is one wonderfully, maze-like con game.
It's as big, funny, shiny, explosive, expert, rip-roaringly entertaining an action movie as we've seen in a long time.

Nowhere near as exhilarating as the first, a triumph compared to the second, Men in Black III offers one sci-fi alternative to a moviegoing summer front-loaded with caped avengers in tights. But not much more.

Things are on much firmer ground when the quietly powerful, watchful and intense Davis and the sour, hilarious Spencer mostly take over the movie and expose the painful consequences of the racism that to this day plagues and demeans us.
Directed flatly and with disappointing tone deafness by Michael R. Roskam (Bullhead), the movie's various plot threads never weave together convincingly.
Although it's narrow gauge and barely touches on Hawking's breakthrough theories about time, space and matter, it's really well made and spectacularly well-acted.
It's a modest movie, yes, but it's got style, know-how, hits the spot and knows enough to keep Reeves kicking ass constantly but saying little. Satisfaction pretty much guaranteed.
For landlubbers or the more adventurous, Humpback Whales is worth the journey.
In the end, Fifty Shades of Grey isn't so much terrible as it is timid and tame.
Kingsman: The Secret Service isn't for the politically correct or the faint of heart. But, if you're on its groovy, twisted wavelength, it's a stone blast.
Focus, nicely filmed and very competent, delivers come snappy dialogue and fizzy, forgettable fun.
Despite good stuff, the movie sputters, drags, and lurches from episode to episode, juggling way too many characters and plot complications without having much reason for existing.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You may find yourself wanting every character in this thing to die horribly. And quickly.
The Last Five Years is a small, bootstrap kind of movie, obviously a labor of love, and it works well because of the passion, charisma and Broadway belts of the two leads.
It isn't enough that the movie's heart and soul are in the right place. It needed edge and art to throw a punch.
The dark, grim Run All Night delivers the action goods while giving Neeson a chance to show us all over again what a great actor, and screen presence, he is.
The Wrecking Crew is breezy, intriguing, tuneful, joyous stuff for anyone. For rock and pop fans, though, it's absolute catnip.
It's all made more powerful and paranoia-inducing because the shuffling stalkers could be anyone, anytime, anywhere. They're as inexplicable as they are impossible to escape.
With such a promising premise at its center, Get Hard could have been scathingly, satirically funny, a kind of 48 HRS meets Trading Places for moderns, but, oh, man, it's not.
It's just another tourist salad bar of stale, limp man-on-the-run clichés with chases, hand-to-hand-combat, gunfire, and an hilariously pretentious sequence set during a bullfight.
The tragic sadness of a Victorian wife and the unraveling of her marriage might be a worthy subject but, as brought to the screen by so reverently and bloodlessly, Effie Gray is a bit of a drag.
McFarland, USA may not take us anywhere new but it gets us to the finish line with know-how and an aim to please.

Gleeson is terrific and Vikander, who stars in five other films this year alone, is a revelation. As is Ex Machina, a movie that looks like something destined to be savored, watched and re-watched endlessly over the years.
While the visuals dazzle, the storyline never grabs hold.
Kill the Messenger painstakingly makes the case that it tells a story which matters but fails to tell us why we should be outraged.

You go in to Interstellar hoping to be mind-blown, thrilled, and smartened-up. Although it's beautifully made, brainy and sometimes insanely gorgeous, you may find yourself wondering what the big whoop was all about.

This smart, lean, tough and, yeah, talky flick has been very shrewdly and knowingly directed/adapted by Scott Frank (who wrote The Wolverine), who knows the noir conventions -- rain, melancholy, tough, doomed characters, paranoid plotting.

There's no arguing the immensity of it or the beauty of its visual images. But what's around the many show-stopping moments is too generic to send us out of the theater properly awestruck, reverent and wowed.
The movie may not deliver every Sondheim fanatic's hopes for a perfect cinematic Into the Woods but it makes for at least a respectable, if not remarkable night at the movies.
Park is sharp, funny and oddly sweet as the dictator but, even with a toned-down assassination sequence, the movie is a throwaway, worthier of a few laughs than it is a full-on international furor.

The movie is just a hodgepodge of badly filmed chases, ridiculous capers and riff-y scenes in which talented comics looking as though they're having great fun talking over each other and drowning each other out -- just not loudly enough.
The Artist recreates a movie era so full of wonder and emotion that it may make you question whether the way we were wasn't a whole lot better than the way we are.
The Hunger Games: Mockingjay is just a long, slow teaser for next year's grand finale, Mockingjay - Part 2.
Foxcatcher gets under your skin and stays there. It's easily one of the best things we've seen this year.

There's no doubting the sincerity and passion of actor Bradley Cooper, director Clint Eastwood and screenwriter Jason Hall in bringing that saga to the screen. So, why is it a good movie instead of a great one?
Although the self-made hero Zamperini deserves every bit of the respect the movie shows him, Unbroken could have done much less noble idolatry and much more edge and insight.

By the time the movie ends, we don't even know very much more about these two than we did when we started: that they're a pair of privileged, great-looking people with a photogenic case of the oh-so-sads.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The moviemakers have created a unique portrait of a highly unusual, gifted oddball who is -- unlike his paintings -- a true original.
The Equalizer is empty and merely efficient but it's enjoyable as hell with Washington in solid, focused Man On Fire form.
The Homesman isn't dull. It's too peculiar for that. But neither does it make you want to saddle up and ride off with either of its two leading characters, either.
Boyle has serviced Sorkin's material well enough and he's got an ace in the hole with the shark-eyed Fassbender, who is miraculous, all hustle, energy, and scary grace.
Very few movies exert the emotional tug and pain of Anomalisa. It's almost a relief that the whole thing is done with puppets. Otherwise, it might be unbearable.
Bridge of Spies isn't a great movie but it's an awfully good and meticulously made one that sends the audience out feeling proud, reassured, and satisfied.
Here is entertainment and social commentary done big, bold and razor sharp.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You don't just leave this 112-minute movie smiling; you leaved so pumped and energized, you may just want to turn around, strap in and take the sweet ride all over again.
Transformers: The Last Knight clocks in at 149 minutes, most of them every bit as painful, childish, 'roid-raged and pointlessly bombastic as the last four movies would lead you to expect.
The Beguiled is fun, yes, and we're all for nuance. But for what is essentially a Southern horror movie, it's too hermetically sealed, wispy and careful to grab you by the throat the way it should.

If you're that hungry for a dark monster-o-rama universe... then, for the love of James Whale, Boris Karloff and Ernest Thesiger, go back and binge-watch the originals, then chase it with two seasons of Penny Dreadful.
So when are Jenkins and Gadot teaming up for the next installment? We can't wait.
Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales isn't just standard issue bad; it's mind-numbingly boring. Abandon ship, gang. Seriously.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It is Fassbender, in dual roles, who is the real focus of the movie, and he is the best he's been in years-perverse, haunted, magnetic, touching and unique.
It ought to be a riot. Instead, the odd-couple comedy -- a surprisingly violent and unsurprisingly crass play on Romancing the Stone -- runs the gamut from mildly amusing to dismal.
As a showcase for Smith's unique talent, original vision and deadpan humor-let alone as a study of a strange guy with a rich inner life-the movie is an art house-style fascinator.
How did a film so loaded with good intentions and talent on both sides of the camera go so badly off the rails?

Transcendently stupid, flat-out nuts and pretty damned irresistible, The Fate of the Furious is the eighth in the series of vroom-vroomers that started off as modest B-movie drag-race stuff ideal for triple-bills at old time drive-in theaters.

Part daikaiju-on-the-loose rampage, part quirky romantic comedy-drama a la 28 Days, the risky and occasionally thrilling Colossal doesn't always deliver on its gonzo promise but, hey, it's still got plenty of charm.

It takes a brave, even foolhardy, director to attempt a remake of anything made first by a master director of the order of Ernst Lubitsch, but that's precisely what Ozon has done with this beautiful melodrama.
Style is substance in Ghost in the Shell, a super slick and utterly empty live-action gloss on the beloved manga.
No, Life isn't Alien or Gravity. It's more like a jumped-up It! The Terror From Beyond. Take it for what it is, though, and it might give you a good laugh and jolt now and then.
Betting On Zero... repeats itself too often... But... the tale it tells of the struggle between Haves and Have-Nots tale is powerful, necessary and persuasive.

The resonant and entertaining Rogue One is about the persistence of hope and faith in the darkest of hours. As we stagger to the end of this epically turbulent year, the movie is all but guaranteed to strike a chord.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Passengers could have been big, shiny, quirky and heart tugging -- a cool holiday popcorn flick. Instead it's empty, anonymous and calculated.
Stay home and play the game instead.
Affleck should be commended for shooting high, but in the end, Live By Night turns out to be just a glossy, pretty, maddeningly generic fedora fest.
If you've got a thing about being seen crying in public, you might want to take a pass on catching A Monster Calls in a theater. But that would be a big mistake.
You leave the theater impressed, inspired and moved by the unique community spirit known as "Boston Strong."
The House isn't built on the strongest foundation but, for most of its 88 minutes, its terrific cast helps gloss over some of the glaring fissures.

Nicely shot by Mike Gioulakis, Split keeps us riveted, laughing, jumping out of seats and guessing right to the end. It's a nasty little piece of work, Shyamalan's best in forever, and a juicy, macabre pleasure to watch.

Lean, intelligent and leaving you wanting more at 95 minutes, I Am Not Your Negro is a less a portrait of the the towering, fiery James Baldwin than it is a chronicle of the life of a troubled, deeply flawed nation as filtered through his piercing eyes.

Although the second Lego movie doesn't deliver the surprisingly deep emotion or high-wire brilliance of the Phil Lord and Chris Miller-directed first -- let alone the relentless earworm "Everything Is Awesome" -- it will do very nicely.
The Great Wall is a visual stunner... But this one's a bloated, special-effects-heavy, supremely silly groaner, a leaden thing that's almost wall-to-wall Lord of the Rings-influenced awful.
A weird and delicious surprise, Get Out subverts the tired clichés and freshens up the horror game in all kinds of surprising -- and surprisingly stinging -- ways.
For what it is, Logan is strong stuff, and a classy sendoff to Wolverine. Let's just hope that Marvel and Jackman let sleeping wolves lie.

Unfortunately, the movie never comes close to touching the... 1933 original a flat-out masterpiece. But, hey, maybe that's too much to ask... at least Skull Island hits its marks hard and fast and paves the way for much better sequels.
This is ambitious, well-made stuff -- a quiet, well acted if overly schematic film that's stronger on moral ambiguity and psychological nuance than on fast paced, cat-and-mouse thriller trappings.

It isn't merely that Chazelle has made a film with eye-popping color and bold lighting, fantastical sets and characters showing their souls in movement and rhyme. He's made it feel revolutionary and brand new, even when it's as old as the hills.
This one's sweet, entertaining, consistently funny, humane, optimistic and eager to please.

Those who haven't read the Dark Tower books may wonder what all the fuss was about in the first place... those who have read the books are left to ponder how such a resonant literary work turned up on screen so undernourished and easily dismissed.

A socially progressive viewpoint, diverse casting and crew members, positive role models and hopeful upbeat messages are one thing, but a good time at the movies is another thing entirely. The movie isn't scary, suspenseful, gripping in the least.
Red Sparrow may not be as funny, grabby, tense or intelligent as it could have been...Still, it's a slick, well-appointed and surprisingly nasty piece of work for most of its 139-minute running time.
Game Night turns out to be a cool, clever surprise. The cast crackles-Bateman and McAdams are fast, easy and terrifically enjoyable together-and there's bright, sharp supporting work.
Unlike most simplistic, tidy, instantly disposable Hollywood sci-fi fare, this one doesn't spoon-feed. It Kubricks us.
Looking, sounding and feeling the way it does-wearing its anti-corporate, anti-fascist, anti-racist heart on its sleeve-it's a movie that, for sure, knows what's up.
This heroine has guts, a spine, a stoic presence that commands respect and empathy. As played charismatically, unsentimentally and exquisitely by Vega, it's impossible to write her off.

Cooper's reach may exceed his grasp with Hostiles, which is never as incisive or as profound as it often wants to be. But he's made a movie that says America can never come to terms with its divisive hate-filled present unless it finally faces its past.
It's January, and that means the pickings at the local multiplex are among the leanest and least ambitious of the year. Enter-loud, blustery, rousing, paper-thin-12 Strong.
Even for mid-January-traditionally the dog days of cinema releases-The Commuter rattles along like an unreliable train to nowhere.

Time will tell, of course, but right now, Phantom Thread feels like a masterwork. Imagine Anderson crossed with du Maurier crossed with Hitchcock crossed with Ibsen and Strindberg. It's that rich and strange.
Scott proves that he can still make us sweat and grab the armrests till our knuckles turn white.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The good news is that this one, a ghostly gothic romance, is at least a step up from Del Toro's killjoy kaiju would-be epic Pacific Rim. The less good news is that... this one is strictly forgettable.
Even with the warts, Star Wars: The Last Jedi feels like a big, dazzling holiday present most Star Wars fans should be able to tear into and enjoy.

Robbie may not be perfect casting as the rough and ready Harding, but her fierce and generous performance gives Harding a measure of sympathy and grace, even when the movie around her doesn't seem to want to.
It's a professional and personal triumph for the reinvigorated Franco.
Call Me by Your Name is one of the great movies of the year.
When Justice League mocks and kids itself, and the whole genre, it's way more effective than when it reaches for grandiosity and pathos.
The Trip to Spain hits the spot very nicely, thanks.
With Logan Lucky, Soderbergh, one of our most inventive and unpredictable directors, just wants to have fun and bring the audience in on it. That's going to be all right with a lot of us.

Atomic Blonde wobbles when it piles on layer upon layer of thorny, labyrinthine John Le Carre-style plotting. The rest of the movie doesn't pack the weight or the multidimensional characters necessary to justify it.
It's well worth a trip to your local cinema to check out Terminator 2: Judgment Day, again or for the very first time.
These tulips may be photogenic, but they are doomed by root rot.

The movie earns its R-rating less by bloodletting than by long, slow buildups, creepy shadows and half-glimpsed things that go bump in the night in sewers and derelict old houses. That's a good thing.
Watching Dunkirk, the word "masterpiece" comes to mind -- often and effortlessly.
Bravo, Mr. Aronofsky and bravo everyone who helped birth something as insane and personal as Mother! into our cookie-cutter world.
You may also find yourself wanting Marshall (but not Marshall) to keep going, but preferably in a much more incisive, truthful and dangerous movie than this one.
The brain freeze that is The Snowman should destroy any hopes of a franchise and that, considering how good the Nesbø series is, ranks as a damn shame.
The performances are uniformly first rate, with Kidman a standout in riding the line between the ridiculous and the sublime.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thor: Ragnarok might rub some humorless Marvel purists the wrong way, but for the less obsessive among us, it's every bit as silly and mocking as it ought to be.
McDonagh's movie is a four-course meal, with writing so sharp and performances so bold and sly that it's tough to leave the theater unmoved.

Lady Bird is easily one of the year's best ways to spend your time and money at the movies. It bounces by at 93 minutes and maintains a shoulder-shrugging tone that makes its truths land all the more powerfully.
As melancholy and bleak as Blade Runner 2049 is, when it ends, you want to see it over again, just to ease back into that mood pocket and savor its dark delicacies.
Although often gut-wrenching, the movie is supremely compassionate toward its subject. Yet Larrain and Oppenheim pull no punches when it comes to Jackie, who emerges as incredibly complex.
Serving as a mirror image of 2017, The Post is absolutely, punishingly timely, even when it too often tells us what's on its noble mind instead of making us feel it.
With Manchester by the Sea, writer-director Kenneth Lonergan has delivered a quietly devastating sucker punch of a film about the persistence of hope in the face of unfathomable loss.
The movie stays clear of jingoistic grandstanding or chest-beating. But the people who've made it have every reason to crow; this is by a mile one of the very best movies of the year.
A breezy memory film with period details as dead-on as anyone expect from Linklater and without a mean bone in its body, it's a twangy, loping charmer.
Midnight Special is a slow burner -- tense, somber and very sad.
It's a credit to director Trachtenberg, in a remarkably self-assured feature directing debut, that he lets the actors, including John Gallagher (The Newsroom), make a good script even better.
In the end, Whiskey Tango Foxtrot is too watered-down and formulaic to be what the source material suggests it could have been: a pitch-black surreal comedy on the order of Robert Altman's M.A.S.H.
Triple 9 is all pose, noise, flash and phony grit without a point, let alone a point of view.
The Witch is so diabolically good that it sends genre expectations -- and appreciative members of the audience -- straight down the booby hatch.
If Zoolander 2 were a high-ticket fragrance, it would be called Desperation.
For all its "Hooray for Hollywood" sparkle and highly welcome down-with-Hollywood bile, this dream machine blows its gaskets with too many flat non-scenes, stale jokes and pointless cameos.

[Deadpool] is filthy, degenerate and seriously pervy, and Reynolds -- decked out in red and black spandex, sporting two katanas and white canvas where eyes should be -- is every bit as flip, funny, nasty and self-deprecating as you'd want.
It's so criminally self-conscious that you might find yourself wondering why it turns out to be such a misery. Make that: an unintentionally funny misery.
It's only January, but Dirty Grandpa is so desperately unfunny and excruciatingly endless at 102 minutes that it's dead certain for a top spot on lists of the year's worst movies.
The film has heart, boundless chaotic energy, heartfelt sincerity and laughs that sting. Above all, it has the starry Lawrence, who puts the joy and pathos right up front where it counts.

Although his movie may be flabby in places, it's should also be an eye-opener, especially for blind proponents of American exceptionalism -- probably the people least likely to give the movie, and Moore, a fair shot.

Tarantino also rates big cheers for presenting The Hateful Eight... as a 70mm widescreen roadshow attraction, one with an overture, intermission, longer running time and exit music. Many more of these, please.
Abrams and company have brought Star Wars home again by reigniting the soul, spirit and sense of wonder of the three original films.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The makers of The Big Short want to wise us up. The question... is whether anyone will get the gist behind the glitz. Of course it helps that such good actors play these opportunistic lizards, the craven cheerleaders of Too Big To Fail.
As a tribute to old-time Hollywood genre moviess, Allied is the goods -- stylish, suspenseful, utterly artificial.
The fancy period costumes and bleak, lived-in settings may be strictly Britain in 1912, but the rage and passion feel strictly contemporary in the history-based Suffragette.
The best thing to do is to leave the theater, look the other way, and pretend it never happened.
If by the wholly unconvincing finale, the movie's brand is mediocrity, the constantly undervalued Bullock's brand is insane likability and knowhow.
Ronan's big talent, the sweetness and resilience of the characters, and the film's big heart, are almost irresistible.
Sure, the action sequences are thrilling. But the emotional intensity and gravitas of Skyfall are missing, and that makes the movie feel more like a string of highlights than a satisfying whole.
Despite welcome flashes of dark humor, Demolition is phony and shot through with clichés.

James White is a deeply moving debut for Mond, a gorgeously made, beautifully acted stunner that is especially painful because it's so obvious that it comes from a deep personal place. But the movie's worth every moment you give it.
In the hands of Cate Blanchett, who is wondrous and magnetic as always, and Rooney Mara, who has never been better or more touching, the movie becomes unforgettable.
Legend also boasts a top-flight supporting cast doing standout work -- including David Thewlis, Paul Bettany, and Taron Egerton -- but it's Hardy's show. And what a show he gives.
What a welcome surprise to find that Creed is so good, so satisfying that it gives Rocky -- and up-by-the-bootstraps sagas, in general -- a good name again.
One way to get the most out of Youth... is just to let its ravishing images and gorgeous soundtrack of Stravinsky and Florence & the Machine ooze over you.
The Revenant is a stunning, impeccably made, hauntingly poetic western. It's also long, immersive, demanding, spooky and metaphysical.

The movie's constant reminders -- this story inspired Moby-Dick! -- only emphasize that while Melville's novel charts hauntingly deep philosophical and psychological waters, In the Heart of the Sea navigates a shallow, if entertaining, pool.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Sure, things get warm and mushy at the finale as the guys do their growing-up-and-moving-on thing, but at least The Night Before is merry and bright enough to keep you from being sorry the morning after.
Barbershop: The Next Cut poses serious questions and-quite a feat -- even generates some big laughs while doing it.
As much as we admire Jolie Pitt's ambition and fortitude in getting an offbeat, grown-up and character-centric movie off the ground, her screenplay and gifts aren't up to the task.

Unlike, say, old comedy movie teams of the past, Key and Peele aren't joined at the hip; both act in and write other projects for other people. But when they do their next movie together (yes please), let's hope it growls rather than just purrs.

Through Adams and Renner's performances, we share dread, wonder, frustration, panic and transcendence as they begin to interact with the "Heptapod" aliens that evoke memories of the work of H.G. Wells and John Wyndham.
Glum, messy, dull and brazenly patched together from a dozen better [films].

Prometheus is so visually ravishing with stunning special effects... But the characterizations are thin and one-note, leaving most of its talented cast members without much interesting to say or do before they get [killed].
Doctor Strange is Marvel's most visually splendiferous movie yet.
Look, a Jack Reacher movie doesn't have to be great, but it does have to be better than other vigilante flicks like, say, John Wick or Blood Father. This one isn't.
Entertaining and preposterous.
At least Burton seems more in tune with the material than the director has in years. And when things get dull, there's Eva Green making it all worthwhile. When she's off screen, you're on your own.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As a look into the vagaries of the filmmaking process, as a peek behind the veil of a deeply unknowable cultural landscape, as a gripping thriller, The Lovers and the Despot is well worth a shot.

[Gordon-Levitt's] meticulously dialed Snowden voice sounds much less rangey and more matter-of-fact than his usual onscreen voice. You feel the painstaking weight of his efforts. It takes some getting used to -- but after a while, it works.
Sully won't just please crowds and evoke tears but, in an angry, ugly time in our national history, it should also resonate deeply with many.
Even with all the good stuff, The Light Between Oceans too often shines dimly.

It's a sharp and savvy thriller for an age in which more than half of Americans seem to feel less secure than ever -- a fear that politicians tend to stoke despite violent crime and violence being down significantly since the '90s.
The movie's not as lacerating or memorable as it has every right to be. Then again, it's a big studio-financed corporate thing, and it's still got a nice bite.
Although you can pretty much guess how things are going to play out in the finale, the ride is so satisfying, bleakly funny and well-acted, you almost wish the cat-and-mouse games would never end.
Little Men needs no explosions, no CGI, no dramatic pyrotechnics. It just sneaks up and wallops you.
Hanks can do lots of things beautifully, but even he stumbles over the script's eye-rolling contrivances, expositional dialogue and general dullness.
You keep pulling for The Infiltrator to break on through to something special, but it's largely an imitation of other, better movies.
Jason Bourne delivers plenty of red meat, no question. Now if Damon and Greengrass can only bring back the heartbeat and complexity.
Massive, overstuffed, overlong and yet fleet-footed, witty and terrifically entertaining.
Even with occasional flashes of edge, there's an unexpected coziness and sweetness about Neighbors 2 that may resonate a lot more strongly with the ladies than with dudes.
Me Before You is calculated and shameless, and it steamrolls its way over some pretty complex issues.
The Conjuring 2 is a great showcase for Farmiga and a pretty good excuse for an early-summer scare or two.
The Wailing is a grab-you-by-the-throat stunner, by far the best thrill machine of the year so far.
X-Men: Apocalypse isn't bad enough to kill a huge money machine franchise. But if any band of superheroes could stand a cinematic intervention, stat, it would be these freaks and geeks.
There's way too little danger and too much method in the cushy, tasteful, icy cool A Dangerous Method.

There's nothing new in Star Trek Beyond, the latest installment in the venerable 13-film series, but its least inspired stretches still manage to play like a crowd-pleasing and exceptionally well-acted Star Trek clip show.
With little dialogue but a world of emotion in his face, eyes and body, [Andy Serkis] not only keeps us on our toes but also has us rooting for the apes to trounce humanity.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Feig spends an awful lot of time on an awfully scant plot, and the digital effects-bloated flick is awkwardly paced and clumsily edited and rarely generates big enough laughs, scares or interest in the characters.
Wise and funny, it's got glorious photography by Stephane Fontaine and a tone shot-through with melancholy, loss and regret.
It's a well-made, well-meaning piece of entertainment, and it's grown up.
All the sped-up and slo-mo footage in the world won't disguise the weird attempt to morph the Lord of the Apes into just another comic book superhero franchise.
Finding Dory is charming, very funny, touching and more than a bit repetitive but never a bore.

The Conjuring 2 has a few slow moments and should be a bit shorter than two hours, but it's a technically dazzling, emotionally acted, scary film. Were I still a young teen I'd be having a few sleepless nights now.
It's an entertaining enough film, buoyed by the chemistry between good-looking stars Emilia Clarke and Sam Claflin.
It's a warm, enjoyable, funny and sometimes wise exploration of family, friendship, faith, fallibility and fatherhood in a double sense of the word.
Overall I found this less innovative than the first film. It's a bit over plotted and yet less energetic, and too long at two hours.
Their slapstick physicality (especially Gosling's) and wry dialogue is worth a laugh, but is that due to the script or because it's two serious stars being funny? I think it's more the latter.

The animation is touchable (it's good to see in 3-D) and there's room for an interesting discussion with younger viewers if you know a bit about, well, the solar system. It's light on jokes for the adult viewer and the plot is a bit thin.
When it comes to making us wonder, it's a bit predictable.
If you are not familiar with the X-Men story it may pay to read up before joining the ticket queue. But overall it's an enjoyable and fast-moving movie about mutants in all their mystery.
A drama lifted by an entertaining script, old-fashioned action scenes and a few surprising twists.
I laughed more during The Angry Birds Movie than I have at any film for a while.
Whether you want to take your mother to see it is something only you can know.
An imaginative and absorbing piece of filmmaking.
The result is average -- there's not much of a story beyond the question of whether love can conquer all -- but watchable.
There are lots of other laugh-out-loud moments: self-aware, comic book-aware ones for Marvel fans and straight-out ones for non-expert viewers.
Nichols is a director who isn't afraid to leave questions unanswered. I left the cinema thinking a lot about what I saw.
The Boss is not as clever or as funny as it might have been, but seeing it made me think about a few issues within the film and outside of it, which is not a bad result.

There are a couple of well-shot, exciting action scenes... but the overall effect is patchy in terms of plot and character relationships and unfulfilling in its intellectual reach and resolution of this world-changing story.
There are so many wonderful scenes.
Sherpa is different and arresting: it's an old-fashioned documentary that allows the participants to tell their stories.

This is a film that allows you space to think, to make connections -- and to wonder what is going on and why. The actors are often silent; they are like people we might meet at any time, and being with them is challenging and rewarding.
This is a high-quality superhero movie for adults, which is a pleasant, almost superhuman, development.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If you are looking for an immersive action thriller, this will do the trick.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: We will never know for sure but chances are Jane Austen would have approved of Pride and Prejudice and Zombies.
This is basically a two-hour battle between humans and orcs, one that owes The Lord of the Rings franchise and the television series Game of Thrones.
The story of Christ's resurrection is unlikely to take any sudden detours. But the Roman point of view adds real interest.
The script is intelligent and sharp, full of seriousness and humour.
The early attacks on Earth are successful but the computerised graphics of cities crumbling and oceans rising don't have a lot of oomph.
A gripping drama about a lesser known aspect of the civil war, with McConaughey as unknowable and absorbing as we have come to expect.

There are moments, especially towards the end, when Hank's behaviour comes across, to my eye at least, as a moving examination of mental illness, of isolation in the ordinary world.. I could have done with more of that, and less of a farting corpse.
How to Be Single defies expectations in a satisfying way.
This is an important documentary about a developmental disability that affects so many people.
The Red Turtle is about the importance of life, big or small, and its interconnectedness. It's a beautiful and thoughtful film.

Owen, with his hangdog handsomeness, brings a fragile sense of legitimacy to our hope that Walt is a good man. Lieberher is superb as his straight-talking and honest son. The scenes between the two are tender and sometimes funny.

Like recent children's films such as BFG and The Jungle Book, this is another sweet reminder that strong stories and spirited characters are what make good films, and that childhood is something we all have forever.
Overall the characters are cliched, the story predictable and the jokes, for me at least, not funny.
The reliance here is on jump scares rather than psychological horror and the result is less than spellbinding.
This third instalment is not as funny or as original as its predecessors -- and sorely misses Grant -- but it's an enjoyable enough entertainment for a Friday night at the cinema.
It's co-directed by Chris Renaud, who co-directed the Despicable Me movies. It doesn't rise to that level, but it's still full of fun for young children.
Girl Asleep is one of those films where I advise anyone interested in seeing it to read a bit more about it. It doesn't quite work for me.
This is an engaging documentary about a significant moment in recent history, told via one of the larger-than-life people who helped make it happen.
This is not a gore-fest like Evil Dead. It's a tight film about people messed up by the ordinary world and what happens when they walk further down the wrong path -- and collide.
This is Gervais's film, unlike the ensemble effort of The Office. The result is more poignant than comic and I like it for that.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: You can see the obvious social-political jokes being made, but it's so juvenile.
Bad Moms is an entertaining, girls-mainly comedy about the problems of parenting.
Overall, though, the final two-thirds of the film are less funny than should be the case. The villains versus villains confrontation is not well explained and the fight scenes are unspectacular.
Absolutely Fabulous walks a tart line between embracing celebrity culture and rejecting it.
Visually and emotionally stunning.
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If like many people you are glad Damon is back as Jason Bourne, you will be even gladder after seeing this.

This is the sort of reboot I like because it's there for everyone. Star Trek devotees will have their specialised views on its place in the 13-film universe, but average viewers will not feel marooned.
Austen did like to have fun with her characters to show the stranger sides we all have. Watching this classy adaptation of one of her lesser-known works will remind you of that, and make you laugh.

If you are in the mood for some neck hair prickles, this should do the trick. By the finely judged end, just who is causing all this horror is not clear, and that perhaps is the greatest fright of all.

While there are in-jokes for diehard Ghostbusters fans and cameo roles for Murray, Aykroyd and others, including a few of the original ghosts, it's also an enjoyable supernatural comedy for one and all.
It's an intriguing character study embedded in a spy thriller.
The Legend of Tarzan is a passable action adventure. I ended up thinking a lot about it afterwards, because I found it so odd. I'm not sure that's enough to recommend it.
Steven Spielberg's The BFG is a marvellous, mood-lifting, word-mangling adaptation of Roald Dahl's 1982 children's novel.
Black is in good form as the enigmatic Stine, but it is Minnette as Zach who impresses most.

The much-hyped film adaptation, in which James was closely involved, sticks closely to the novel, but is both strengthened and weakened by what director Sam Taylor-Johnson and screenwriter Kelly Marcel decided to omit.
There's no denying that Room starts from a dark place, but that does not necessarily make it a bleak film.
I still don't know what Jupiter Ascending is about but, wow, what a ride.
Laura Poitras's Oscar-nominated documentary Citizenfour is proof that you can make an espionage thriller without car chases, bikini babes or martinis.
This is a slick, fast-paced film that maintains its sometimes unbearable tension until the last roll of the dice.
It's hugely enjoyable.
This is not an easy film to watch but it's relevant, courageous and full of grace.
What I like most about Wild is its nuance, its sense of uncertainty and its willingness to leave unanswerable questions unanswered.

[Director Jeremy Garelick] doesn't stray too far from safe, squelchy ground here, but if you enjoy films such as The Hangover trilogy, then this one should go down like that third shot of Jagermeister.
While the action scenes are eye-popping, for me the film becomes something special in stiller moments, with the megalomaniac Thorin raving, questioning, justifying, swerving towards evil.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If anything, Cosmopolis is more timely now than when DeLillo published it almost a decade ago.
This is a beautifully shot, intelligently directed film that, as with former soldier Stephen Daisley's award-winning 2010 novel Traitor, shows us another side of the Gallipoli story.
Egoyan skilfully brings these story-lines together as the film builds to its disconcerting conclusion.
A foul-mouthed, sex-obsessed immature comedy that pushes the boundaries of decency. So, all in all, not a bad Friday-night flick after a hard week's work.
There's also a lack of suspense, with events following the predictable pattern of a much-played video game.
This gritty, claustrophobic film will not be to everyone's taste -- and if I say that phrase also has a double meaning, you have a hint of just how gross Ray's week gets before it's over.
Carell and Garner do the physical comedy with a lot of flair, the younger actors more than hold up their end and Megan Mullally of Will and Grace fame puts in a crisp cameo.
movie_title: Alexander and the Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad Day (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This film continues to linger in my mind. See it at a morning session with a strong coffee. You won't regret it.
Curtis commands our attention in every scene, not least because we are unsure of what he will do next.

At this point Let's Be Cops loses much of its humour and starts looking like a film Liam Neeson will turn up in any time soon. That's a pity because the first half, about two doofuses playing police, is funny and occasionally sharp.
A gangster film that is elevated above that genre by the presence of Gandolfini, just as he pushed The Sopranos beyond, well, everything that came before.
While it's good that Lance eschews the conventional, the question becomes, what does he have in its place? I was left unsure of the answer.
Mack Lindon's autobiographical prison drama Riseis one of the strangest films I've seen in a while, not always in a good way but not always in a bad way either.
This is a film that starts out being about an unknown artist and ends up being about something more complex and challenging: a person.

This is an intimate, poignant film that makes you feel a little sad. But there are lots of loving and funny moments - such as when Mason and his kids campaign for Barack Obama - and the overall effect is life-affirming.

This is a smart, sophisticated film, one without obvious heroes and villains, a fine addition to the honour roll of recent Australian crime dramas including Animal Kingdom, Snowtown, Last Ride and Mystery Road.
Unlike The Big Short, it's not so much the system that's busted here but the people, women and men. The ending is perfect, and all too true.
The final third of the film, which is directed by Rogen and Evan Goldberg, degenerates into a humourless and violent Rambo pastiche.
I didn't know anything about The 5th Wave before seeing J. Blakeson's film and assumed it would be a dystopian action thriller. It is, and a solid one at that, but it's also consciously comic.
Fans of the first film (of which I am one) will be pleased to know Madden and his terrific ensemble cast deliver more of the same. We are talking feelgood with a capital F.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This is the first English language film of the twice Oscar-nominated Russian director Sergei Bodrov and he delivers an action-packed, enjoyable piece of escapism without too many boring detours.
If you are looking for an agreeable and entertaining school holidays film for younger children, this is it. Fans of the comic strip should get a kick out of it, too.
This is a high-grade action thriller that -- dare I suggest it? -- redeems the Point Break brand. And, yes, there's definitely room for a sequel.
It's all a bit of a mess and just not funny. Anyone who hasn't seen the first film will wonder what on earth is going on.
By the end of Deadpool I was left with the feeling that it probably was more fun to make than it is to watch.
One of the most disappointing films I've seen in a while.
It's fascinating to watch -- not once was I bored -- and superior to most other offerings on the big screen at the moment.
As Vreeland's diligent documentary makes clear, Guggenheim was an artist of sorts, too: she created her extraordinary self.
Very good indeed.
The takeout for parents? Well, you'll probably realise you are doing a lot better than either of these bozos.
Story and spectacle are what count, and Abrams delivers the latter with deftly realised reprises of favorite scenes and thrilling set piece.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This one defies easy expectations, right up to its strange (in a good way) ending. The blues soundtrack is excellent, too.
It's essentially a two-hour conversation about life, love, selfhood, art high and low (Wallace was a television addict) -- and I did not want it to end.
A clever and funny animated romp that kids and adults will enjoy.
Love the Coopers sets itself up to explore some interesting if not original questions, but it baulks at probing too deep and instead retreats into schmaltz.
As with the appalling Pyongyang-set The Interview of last year, The Night Before relies on swearing, stereotypes, causing offence and adolescent sexual jokes for its laughs.
I left this remarkable film energised by the thought that we are not one thing but many things.

The rapport between Stallone and Jordan is fabulous, especially in the old-school training scenes, chasing chickens to improve speed and all the rest, that pay homage to the original, Oscar-winning 1976 film.
So much better than last year's plodding, aimless Part 1.
Sparks must be doing something right.
You don't need to be Einstein to see where this is going, but it's an enjoyable and occasionally very funny trip, with some smart observations about the yoof's addiction to technology.
It's good, clean, harmless fun.
The dialogue is clunky, and other than Tris the characters are one-dimensional. Moreover, it's all so earnest.
A film with serious potential marred by a reliance on cliche and a desire to make people happy.
Violent and disturbing, especially in the implications of its quite brilliant final twist.
[Collette] and co-star Thomas Haden Church elevate this no-frills but intelligent story into something well worth seeing.
My main problem with this documentary, which Gameau says is a quest for definitive answers, is that it is so one-sided.
Jerome Meyer and Maggie Naouri are terrific as Joe and Anu, heading a little-known cast that rises to grapple with this draining drama.
Beneath the action-packed game is another story, one about kids learning to come to terms with who they are and to value the differences in others. So there is educational value in this holiday film.
Even non-rugby fans will know how it ends but it's worth the nostalgic pain to keep watching until the final siren.
That's the lasting impression this movie left on me: there are good people in the world; ordinary good people, not superheroes.
Winslet and Elba are easy actors to watch and the landscape shots are beautiful, but this movie is just silly.
We all think about which films we should see from the current crop. Tom of Finland is perhaps an unusual choice but it's one I'm pleased to have seen.

The only redemption is seeing Elton John as Poppy's piano-bashing, singing, F-word-dropping hostage, but even he becomes tiresome before too long. If there's a Kingsman 3, I'll defect to Statesmen. At least they have whisky.
Flatliners, the remake, is a good example of how the gene pool doesn't necessarily become stronger with time.
This beautifully shot, thoughtful documentary has sent me to listen to the Go-Betweens and their contemporaries.
This is a must-see movie.
This is a clever, funny, perceptive movie that pokes its nose into the bizarre business of filmmaking, and the sometimes wacky world of sibling rivalry.
Full of nerves, laughs and love.
I liked It a lot. Its aftermath is so busy in my mind, that I'm tempted to award it four stars just for that. But based on what is on the screen I'll stick with 3 1/2.
It's not a great film but, once the preliminary scenes on terra firma are over and we descend to a place we don't belong, it delivers an hour or so of sustained physical and psychological terror.
This leading-man humour is a large part of what makes Thor: Ragnarok just about the funniest superhero movie I have seen.
The path to Elba and McConaughey's inevitable showdown is slick and fun to watch.
Gore's new position is the subtitle to this film: today, he thinks, it's even more important to speak truth to power.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Besson loves messing around with time and space.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While Kiki is an interesting movie the humour in the main didn't work for me.
movie_title: Kiki, Love to Love (Kiki, el amor se hace) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The fight scenes are gripping because they look real. It's not the stylistic biff and bash of a superhero film but up-close bareknuckled brawling.

This is an action adventure so viewers will expect a climactic confrontation between the two main characters, Caesar and The Colonel. It does come, but it is nothing like what we have come to expect from superhero films, and is outstanding as a result.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A war film that is not a war film and yet will immediately enter the ranks of the best war films made so far.
This is a charming, funny, coming-of-age story about a 15-year-old, Peter Parker, who has more power than he can handle and at the same time is frustrated that he can't show it off.

If you don't know much about Singh (as I didn't), you can follow this like a historical thriller. It is a carefully made film, sometimes to the point of slowness in plot development and over-explanation in dialogue.
I laughed a few times. But the up-close moments, the Ferrell and Poehler non-repartee and barely physical comedy, are embarrassing.
As Alfred Hitchcock understood, birds are from a different planet. This light-hearted, warm-hearted documentary shows them in all their glory.
All in all, it's harmless fun.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This horror-thriller set in a national park is one of the more brutal films I have seen.
This is a solid movie about man versus nature.
The action is exciting at times but the outcomes are predictable. Indeed, this often has the feel of a set-up movie, one made to kick off a series.
This is a movie I will see again soon.
It's a fine reminder that the impossible disaster is only impossible until it happens, and when it does it inverts the world we think we control.
This is documentary as beguiling storytelling.
The filmmakers talk to people on both sides of the argument, and people who are in-between. Everyone gets a fair say.
There is more character development in this movie than in some I could name that have received multiple Oscar nominations. It made me laugh a lot, too.
This is a cleverly scripted, well-acted and in its way timely movie, but not one for the squeamish.
Overall this is a predictable horror movie that relies on jump scares rather than mental darkness. Insidious may have run its course.

The clever American comic thriller Game Night is a bit like a matryoshka doll. There are stories within stories and, just when it looks like the final doll has been revealed, there is another twist to keep the game going.

It's about real adults living ordinary, important and sometimes difficult lives. Finding Your Feet is rightly billed as comedy-drama; yet, although it's full of rib-tickling dialogue, it's the drama that cuts deep.

Butler and Schreiber deliver commanding performances. They are men who could explode at any moment, at work or at home. That nonstop ticking beneath their calm exteriors fills the film with a gripping tension.
This finale is the weakest of the three. The two stars look like they are going through the motions a bit. The script is trite.

Even if you are not a fan of superhero movies you may find the issues explored thought provoking. It is also action packed, well acted, dazzlingly shot by English cinematographer Rachel Morrison and... full of humour and self-aware wisecracks.
It is seriously let down by an inability to put up the words The End. The final 40 minutes constitute the most drawn-out ending I have seen, almost unwatchable.
This is a movie that had an immediate effect on me and my co-viewer. We talked about it for hours. It's still on my mind.
The story is full of surprises and twists. It's also a sound reminder that this world includes some things that can never be harnessed.
Michael is ahead of this viewer when it comes to working out which passenger is the target, which is how it should be. Some of the action is heart-racing.
While the animation is Pixar perfect, I don't think the story grips the viewer.

As I've noted, a lot of capital-N names helped make this film. But the director, the bloke who wore a beanie to the red carpet premiere in Sydney, deserves our admiration. He is the showman who, like Barnum, has his name above the door.
Cena is excellent as a kind and gentle big boy who doesn't know his own strength.
A wonderful film for the young and the young-at-heart.
This is not an animated movie for young children. There will be loads of those in the next few weeks as the school holidays kick in. But In This Corner of the World is remarkable.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Star Wars: The Last Jedi is a spirited continuation - sometimes spectacular, often humorous - of the never-ending space saga.
As the plot develops it does lose momentum a bit and at times verges on cliche.
[Sweet Virginia] is a high-quality physical and psychological thriller.
This is a honourable film that has hits and misses. Watch it for the performances, particularly Redgrave's. Its most telling line is this: Bravery in the face of the enemy

The Man Who Invented Christmas, however, is a festive treat, in no small part because it's not about Christmas. It's about one of the most famous authors we know and how he overcame the writer's block equivalent of Santa being stuck in the chimney.
I have been a fan of Despicable Me from the outset and this third outing, directed by Pierre Coffin and Kyle Balda, doesn't let the side down.
McLaren is a fine documentary made by Ballarat-born NZ filmmaker Roger Donaldson.
This is an intense, serious war film.
By and large Aniello and the cast pull it off, with dramatic twists and amusing side stories.
A great strength of this film is a focus on extended scenes, some quiet, some explosive, ones that remind me of the best recent television such as True Detective.

You may come out of it agreeing with him, disagreeing with him, or somewhere in between. But it's a live issue that could change the world, could end the world as we know it, and this dedicated journalist wants to make sure we know about it.
The acting is first-rate, as is the script. The melodramatic music is less so.
Middle School is a treat for kids before they head back to their own classrooms.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The result is a film that is weird in a good way. It's engaging and funny and held together by fine performances.
As one musician says, a piece of music can't stop a bullet. But this engaging film is a vote for culture, a vote against xenophobia.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Iggy is the star of the show. He comes across, still lean and long-haired and handsome (and almost fully clothed), as intelligent, caring -- and still vexed by what he sees as the corporate corruption of rock 'n' roll in the 70s.
I have a soft spot for the gigantic, arrogant, avaricious crab named Tamatoa.
This is modern, old-fashioned fun, and I hope Franco keeps making films such as this.
A final warning: if you don't have a dog, and you take kids to see it, you may come under a lot of pressure to acquire one.
Rogue One does not extend the Star Wars story but there are times when it deepens it.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There are no cliches here.
As Christmas gifts go, a ticket to this movie sure beats a pair of socks.
That they are vampires and werewolves is almost secondary. Underworld: Blood Wars is fast-paced and fun at times, but it doesn't feel like a horror film to me.
Lee and screenwriter Jean-Christophe Castelli are faithful to Fountain's novel.
Bad Santa 2 is up there with the worst films I've seen in recent years.
Overall this is an enjoyable opening to what promises to be another popular film series about a world that, while not quite ours, seems close to it.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The two lead actresses are superb and Virzi keeps the plot road real and clear of cliched speed humps.
Unfortunately this one runs out of steam and becomes more of a shoot now, ask questions later (or never) flick.
For all its flaws, it's a strangely absorbing film.

Doctor Strange, the 14th film in the franchise based on Marvel comic books, is one of the funniest of recent times, lifted beyond the ordinary world, as befits the story, by a superb cast that includes Benedict Cumberbatch in the title role.
This is a film that grows on me the more I think about it.
Overall this is a slick action-adventure that has relevant reverberations from the American involvement in Afghanistan and Iraq, and touches on the complex nature of the war on terror.
This wonderful film is full of quietly funny moments.
I admit I didn't know much about Whitney Houston before seeing this documentary. I found it fascinating and unsettling.
Personally I think the three books and the two films to date are interesting in their way. They are not golden, but then they are not vanilla either.
This film has neither the humour nor the extreme violence of Snatch, but it is still catches the attention.
The secret to this movie is to accept it's all nonsense and enjoy the ride.
The characters do not have the brittle edge, the dangerous dynamism they did before. They're just not as interesting.
It's exciting, beautiful to watch and ends in a manner that leaves hope for just about everyone.
The Mummy is a solid start to a new series.
Weisz is superb as a woman who wants to assert rights her gender did not yet have, such as control over money.
Baywatch is a rare movie in one sense: it starts with a good plan, to spoof the 1980s and 90s television series on which it is based, and sticks to it.
It's disappointing because Wonder Woman deserves better.
This is a quiet film, but it will make a lot of noise inside your head, inside your heart.
This amusing buccaneering adventure, fifth time to sea, isn't ready to walk the plank just yet.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Damon is solid as usual but it's an oddly impassive role, beyond fight scenes.

Whiteley's art was landmark, and remains important. The life the artist lived doesn't change that. When this documentary considers the art and the artist, and blends the two into one complex life, it is at its best.
The result is several IQ points above the typical American comedy. The central dramatic scene involves no bad guys, just a mother and daughter. Hawn knocks it out of the park.
Free Fire offers up a lot to talk about in terms of filmmaking ideas and techniques, but whether it's an enjoyable movie in its own right is open to debate.
This film has drama, humour and pathos.
It builds to something quite remarkable.
[Ritchie] brings his distinctive 21st-century touch to a time-honoured tale.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is the human message of this amusing film: everyone's life gets messy at times. It's important to cut others some slack, even when it's not deserved.
Logan is a fine example of the superhero film where fantasy is tame and reality is wild.
Freeman and Arkin are spot on, but it is Caine who stands out.
Miss Sloane raises important issues but loses focus.
It's the inclusion of historical references, and literary ones, that make this film engaging, despite its faults.
Perhaps the director has fudged it a bit, but his intention was to make a beautiful film about one girl from a place and a culture we know little about. That he has done.
The songs are splendid and the camerawork is attractive but overall there's a lack of the tension that impels audiences to wonder what will happen next.
Amusing if overlong.
This is an exciting, fun, futuristic thriller that, like its main character, has a probing mind. It will make you think.
The result is an ideal movie for the school holidays, one that children of all ages will rock along with (Batman fancies his own singing) and adults will laugh at.
I liked the Emma Stone-Ryan Gosling song and dance romance-drama, but for me Dance Academy feels more real. It has something about it that is more dramatic, more emotional, more complex.
Verbinski's gothic psychological thriller is absorbing. It unfolds in a maze even Theseus would not escape. It will keep you guessing until the almost unbelievable ending.
As fate would have it, Rocket Science might prove to be the handiwork of a burgeoning cinematic genius.

Tyler Perry's latest conspicuously lacks his drag clad alter ego Madea %u2014 the star of his earlier hits Diary of a Mad Black Woman and Madea's Family Reunion %u2014 but it manages to be a drag nonetheless.

Krasinski and Moore are an adorable couple, but marriage material they aren't, especially since they're given a mere ten minutes to form a full-fledged relationship before Williams breathlessly barges into the picture.
Farmer isn't the radical reinterpretation of the kid's film genre that one might expect from the Polish brothers' previous credits.
Venus showcases all we have come to love about O'Toole - his facile wit, his commitment to a scene, and the same light in his eyes that he had when he played T.E. Lawrence.
The Holiday wears its Tinseltown credentials on its sleeve and provides the kind of escapist entertainment that's been so lacking thus far into the winter season.
A good horror remake needs to either be smarter than the original in this post-Scream era or about ten times as bloody. Unfortunately, The Hitcher falls into neither one of those categories.
A film that in spite of its shiny veneer actually hits all the high notes through its underlying rawness.

Curse of the Golden Flower may be one of Zhang's most erratic, even to major fans, but it still manages to also be a successful marriage of the storytelling that he built his career on and the large scale epics he's making now.
While Déjà Vu is appropriately titled, it's also an enjoyable mystery that ranks with the producer's [Jerry Bruckheimer] best.
The drama may be less pronounced, but the emotions are no less complex, creating a film that's quietly devastating and elegant in its understatement.

Director Sylvain White, whose last film was the equally unnecessary I'll Always Know What You Did Last Summer, manages to take the joy out of a dance movie by jerking the camera around and speeding up the dance moves so much.
A well-told parable about on the futile perpetuation of violence ... [Director Susanne] Bier may not believe in hitting back, but she's a big believer in hitting hard.

Cuaron's script, co-written with Timothy J. Sexton, is incredibly tight, Owen is palpably comfortable in Theodore's skin, and the issues of immigration and cultural ambivalence that the film centers on are more than compelling.
"Wild Target" bears all the hallmarks of [director Jonathan] Lynn's best films, despite being, even at a tidy 90 minutes, a bit too long.
A sturdy piece of entertainment that adds a wrinkle to the traditional underdog tale by having Ward's greatest battles come from within his own family.

That much of "The Last Mountain" actually is beautiful, with polished cinematography and deft editing, makes the medicine go down easier, but there's no doubt to some, it will still feel like medicine.

Bello and Sheen are equally fearless in their performances, though the limitations of their characters' circumstances and ultimately, the predictability of the story conspire to result in something stagey. Still, they set "Beautiful Boy" apart.
"Senna" is an interesting biography not only because it limits itself to 15,000 hours of video already on record, but also since it is far less about the man than the driver.
It's Cunningham's single-mindedness about his work that's so infectious as well as so strange.
"Bridesmaids" is first and foremost a showcase for Wiig, who surely doesn't play it safe here but still comes off as an affable everywoman with a twinkle of danger in her eye.
[Winkler] spins it fast and keeps it on track, delivering a pleasant diversion that's refreshingly free of cynicism, full of vibrancy and ultimately, a curiosity about what he will do next.
A brilliant, scrupulous breakdown of how giant egos and greed led to a disaster that would imperil the American public.
As filmmakers, Gervais and Merchant find a rhythm technically that makes the fact they never find the balance between humor and heart that they've achieved in the past even more of a disappointment.
Bar-Lev achieves no small feat in parsing out a complicated narrative and picking up on the family's outrage without turning it into a partisan or anti-military screed.
A crime thriller that is good more of the time than it's not, but suffers from the fact it should've been great.
Even if it never delivers the knockout blow usually crucial to films as suspenseful as this aspires to be, it's a testament to its director that it's engaging throughout.
[You can't say] "Loveless" isn't ambitious - just the opposite since it is hardly as easy as it looks to make a film as comfortable in its own skin as Serry's is.

This misbegotten, incoherent Mummy is a muddle of too much exposition, too many tired tropes from past Cruise movies and some of the worst plotting and dialogue this side of a creaky 1940s radio serial.
The underwater thriller 47 Meters Down works so well as a nail-biting example of nonstop tension for one reason: its matter-of-fact credibility.
Henry is both naturalistic and unabashedly fantastic.

England's Edgar Wright, already a critical and cult favorite, casts a glorious summertime spell with Baby Driver, a speed- and music-propelled gangster saga that transforms into a coming-of-age character study.
With director Michael Showalter's assured comic tone, The Big Sick rates as a fearless and fearlessly funny look at how cultural collisions can end happily.
If a bit too familiar with echoes of Final Destination and Carrie, Wish Upon delivers the gruesome goods.
Newcomer Haddish takes Girls and, like Melissa McCarthy in Bridesmaids, puts it in her pocket as scene-stealing sexually aggressive Dina, who is unfiltered, unfettered and unapologetically wild.
Clever, sweet, smart and sassy, the animated Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie is stuffed with many weird and funny elements.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If Kidnap is Berry's tour de force, Chris McGinn, as the scariest and most merciless kidnapper, manages a few moments in the spotlight.
Impossibly upbeat and as real as a movie can get, Step could not be more emotionally wrenching as it chronicles 19 inner-city Baltimore students' senior year.

While the English subtitles are splendid, Jolie's artful, gorgeously photographed study could be a silent-era epic, for it's the faces that tell this story, which, although set in a distant past, echoes what's happening today in Myanmar.
With The Lego Ninjago Movie, the third in the series, the novelty is gone. We're now familiar with seeing plastic cube characters animated in all their awkward but effective glory.
The Florida Project, despite its ability to marvel at the natural wonders that offset poverty-stricken circumstances, doesn't sugarcoat harsh realities.

Despite the filmmakers' best intentions, Only the Brave, which is expanded from former Boston Herald reporter Sean Flynn's GQ article, emerges as inert drama as we ever so slowly journey to that awful end.
As pretentious, nearly unwatchable fiascos go, All I See Is You is that rare film that can empty theaters in its first (interminable) half hour.
Filmed in virtually non-stop darkness, this sequel lacks any tension-producing shivers or fright.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: In David Sandberg, cinema has a new titan who demonstrates with Annabelle: Creation, a mastery of classic horror motifs that never insults the viewer.
It's impossible to imagine a better Diana Prince/Wonder Woman than Gal Gadot in Patty Jenkins' lively Wonder Woman.
Bryan Cranston might be among our great actors, but talent is hardly enough to make Wakefield anything other than a 106-minute endurance test with a creep.
Everything, Everything sparkles with its interracial cast, but its focus is not race but relationships.

With extraordinary performances by its two lead actors and a quietly observational tone that tells us so much by saying very little, Loving scores as a mighty, nearly miraculous portrait of a love affair.
Disney's digitally animated Moana, a Polynesian folk musical starring a plucky princess and a thousand-year-old demi-god, is beautiful to behold.
The wise and all-around wonderful Sing is enchanting on every level.
A frenetic and increasingly mindless, all-out action drama.
Keaton makes it easy to understand Kroc's energetic empire builder whose self-created legend was that he, not the McDonalds, "founded" the Golden Arches empire.
This is a by-the-numbers sequel whose human dimension has disappeared amid the frantic, nonstop action and unimaginative plotting.
Fist Fight is a high-concept, intentionally outrageous comedy that somehow works.
As she changes, Deutch lets us see Sam's capacity for self-realization, compassion and common sense. It's all beautifully done with a first-rate musical score.
Watching Danish writer-director Martin Zandvliet's debut feature is unnerving, shocking, depressing and scary.
In a low-life kind of silly way, the real laughs come from oversized personality clashes, hysterically pitched fights and a general awakening between our two misfits that they like each other.
As Power Rangers ends, the feeling is definite: They'll soon be back.
As a personal tale of ordinary people taking extraordinary, life-threatening measures to help strangers, The Zookeeper's Wife astounds.

Queen remains Kidman's show, and if still with a movie star-ish aura, she is a treat. Herzog, however, never attains real complexity or an understanding of Bell's interior life. But damn if the desert doesn't look splendid.
Shot on picturesque locations, admirably well paced and emotionally centered, Tommy's Honour rates as a delightful surprise.
Pandas don't have to do a thing to be utterly adorable.
The Circle is a supposed thriller -- without thrills. It also lacks common sense, commanding performances or surprise.
The way that people are disposable becomes a key issue in a drama that begins with a veneer of civility and rapidly descends into accusations, recriminations, regrets and threats.
The gang is back, ready to rock Las Vegas for a wild wedding weekend in the often hilarious if always cliched sequel Think Like a Man Too.
Pastoral, however, belongs to its two leading women. Connelly shows enormous range... Fanning hauntingly suggests a living ghost, a leper who only occasionally sees sunlight.
Sequelitis means that there's no high-flying good times with How to Train Your Dragon 2.
This moronic, witless, unbearably mirth-free mess finds Wayans endlessly mining ethnic stereotypes then mocking them for supposed humor.
Prince Avalanche has the pristine integrity of a movie that knows exactly what it wants to be -- and doesn't worry whether many or any will be eager to jump aboard.
One might expect Jobs, a biopic of Steve Jobs, to canonize the Apple computer magnate who was only 56 when he died in 2011. But it's a lot more fun than that.
This is a classic study of a lone individual standing up to the irrational forces of a mob.
Neatly balancing murderous mayhem with goofy, sophisticated humor, this twisty, blackly comic crime caper is perfectly tuned by its first-rate cast.
What was in the water when the folks at DreamWorks Animation decided to make a 3-D digital feature about a snail who wants to race in the Indy 500?
Dolan's latest feature, the French language Laurence Anyways, proves this is a filmmaker able to breathe cinematic invention and beauty into every frame.
The 3-D digitally animated Epic is bursting at the seams, much like the lush forest where it's set.

Unabashedly an upbeat, snazzily shot infomercial that accentuates and overdoes the positives of this well-scrubbed quintet, Us still manages to capture the lads' refreshing ability to remain basically who they were while coping with life-altering changes.
The songs and music numbers are what make this "Showman" soar.
Much of the appeal of Paddington 2 is the way it combines classic British nostalgia with fast-forward contemporary filmmaking.
Cage easily channels a very unhappy husband and a father's inarticulate rage while Blair's homicidal transformation is unnerving.
Absolutely nutty, buoyed by a wonderfully warped sense of humor and a more-than-game cast that's equal to the film's rapid-fire dialogue and pace, Game Night easily rates as a stunning surprise.

movie_review_blurb: A farewell has never been so silly, sweetly disarming and serious fun as Pitch Perfect 3.

Unfortunately, this is a wasted opportunity.

Tyler Perry's The Single Moms Club is a lackluster empowerment fantasy that veers between dull and embarrassing.
What becomes a legend most? In Elaine Stritch's case, it's this riveting, unvarnished documentary portrait of the lioness in winter.

The romantic notion that there exists one very special person... one you'll want to be with for the rest of your life, is at the heart and soul of Scott Spencer's novel Endless Love, which now arrives in its second, superior incarnation on the big screen.

Anyone who might want characters and not cliches, compelling dialogue and an intriguing scenario, look elsewhere.

Free Birds, an animated buddy comedy that evokes the daffiness of classic Chuck Jones cartoons, is no turkey.

For a courtroom thriller about a seemingly open and shut case, Denial manages to be suspenseful, informative and surprisingly relevant.
