A first-rate Italian puzzler that demands that re-viewers keep mum about its twisty plot.

movie_review_blurb: A lamentable sequel to the surprise 2014 hit.

Criminal is a thriller that offers a familiar relentless high-octane chase through scenic London with a decidedly unfamiliar sci-fi premise. So despite familiar tropes, Criminal manages to seem fresh.

movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: LIFE is fairly low-key, yet it breathes with an honesty and an astuteness.

A beautiful, realistic, heartfelt comedy/drama, with a trio of standout performances.

Wry situations and inventive acting, all caught clearly on camera, and shaped into a satisfying whole.
"White Bird in a Blizzard" is a film that doesn't quite know what it wants to be.

If the story is simple, Chazelle spins off on it, the way jazz players reinterpret old standards. His camera comes in close on instruments, fingers, blisters. Shots are cut together in clear but furious flurries.
A serious, interesting film about a very simple concept: The Truth. And how very complicated that can sometimes become.
More than two hours of sharp dialogue and great acting, if not particularly inventive plotting.
This is Bill Murray's movie, and he dominates (and redeems) every scene he's in.

A daring, startling piece of work. And not only for what Inarritu manages to show. But for what Keaton is courageous enough to reveal.

A not-terrific, not-terrible romantic comedy that owes most of its charm to its two stars.

movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Think you've got a hard-knock life? Try sitting through the new "Annie."
The story goes nowhere slowly and sometimes inexplicably.

movie_review_blurb: A mish-mash - part half-committed melodrama, part half-thought-out political provocation.
Welcome back, Chris Rock.

movie_title: Magician: The Astonishing Life and Work of Orson Welles (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Moore has been a fine actress for a long time and "Still Alice" gives her a remarkable role, and the space to truly live it.

Although the supernatural seems the likeliest answer, it's not the only one, and audiences can read the film either way.

The majority of it isn't just dumb and dumber, or even crude and cruder. At nearly two hours, it's just dull - and duller.

A strange, and beautiful movie, full of odd touches - a knife fight in the middle of a desolate wasteland, a gravestone made from a bed's headboard, a piece of embroidery that stands in for a much-missed keyboard - that haunt after the film's done.
If it were any cheesier, they could pour it on macaroni.
Stewart can never quite answer the question: Why this man's story, of all the ones that should be told? And why now, five years later?
It's not a pretty portrait of the artist. But it is a real one.
I think I smiled, twice.
As a horror movie ... the film's only flaw may be that that's how it reductively sees itself - as just a horror movie.
Solid and dependable, "Forsaken" shouldn't be forgotten. But I wish so much of it didn't feel half-remembered.

"Score" does leave you with a real respect for these people, and their tireless search for ways to turn emotion into sound. An honest appreciation for their literally invisible work. And a determination, I hope, to go out and buy some of it ...
There's something real and touching here. In Everett's thwarted struggles with his own, clumsy emotions. In Maudie's determination to find beauty in absolutely everything.
A movie that's meant to fill this summer's smart-low-budget-thriller slot. Except it's not very smart and it's not very thrilling.
There are some good ideas here. But in the end "Rough Night" feels more like a rough draft - and proves only that rowdy girl comedies can be just as unfunny as rowdy boy comedies.

All of this is great fun.

No wonder the Martians never came. There's no intelligent life here.
A safely predictable, predictably safe movie about characters who never risk or question anything, and filmmakers who think poop jokes are the height of wit.

movie_review_blurb: This isn't "just" a film about special needs. It's about special kids - and the very special adults who advocate for them.
Tlthough the spirit here is willing, I'm sorry. This film is just weak.

"Okja" is definitely a treat for fans of Bong's work, for admirers of carefully crafted cinema and for anyone with deeply held concerns about genetically modified organisms, factory farms or animal welfare.

movie_review_blurb: The adults' acting is crude and clownish. The kid actors are insufferable. The gags are largely slapstick, with the three major joke groups - pee, poop and puke - all over-represented.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This isn't one of Linklater's storytelling experiments. This is a hang-out movie and - what's more - a deeply heartfelt, American one.

This isn't a picture, it's a pose, in a constant competition with itself to drop another literary reference ... But all it can do, like some over-eager freshman, is trot out a quote -- it doesn't understand what they really stood for.
movie_title: The Only Living Boy in New York (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A small, gentle charmer about what life's like for a teenager who knows she's far more interesting than the town she lives in.
"The Killing of a Sacred Deer" takes strange and unexpected turns along the way, and some of them are brutal, and a few of them are shocking. But that surprise is a good deal of its power.

movie_review_blurb: It goes so overboard on humanizing Bauman, it actually diminishes him. With such a barely-there hero, we start looking around for other people to become interested in.

movie_review_blurb: The new version of King's classic demonic clown story delivers two of the author's signature pleasures -- an emotional re-creation of those beleaguered years of childhood, when it was us-against-the-adults, and a truly visceral sense of horror.

movie_review_blurb: If you enjoy cinematic outrageousness for its own sake, you may have a good time with Tomie: Unlimited; unfortunately, the film's real strength is buried beneath the special effects.
Viewers eager to enjoy terrors dressed in the accoutrements of Gothic horror may have a good time, though slow pacing and a misguided ending undermine the effectiveness.
Godzilla roars back to life in this new Toho Production, but the filmmakers' attempts to teach the old monster some new tricks only partially succeed.
This emphatically grim art house horror film offers hypnotic visuals but lacks a clear vision of its central character.
The killer donuts take second stage to the unfunny comedy routines of the human characters, which run on so long it's as if the film is daring its audience to get fed up and walk out.

Although there is an admirable attempt to stay true to the higher aspirations of the high-class source material, the new effort is undermined by the need to fashion itself as a crowd-pleasing blockbuster, loaded with exciting special effects.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This early example of a Japanese kaidan (ghost story) with a contemporary setting begins strong but gradually devolves into stupidity, as the scenario figuratively rips itself to shreds with a series of increasingly ridiculous plot twists.
This is one trip down memory lane that few viewers wanted to take, and it is easy to see why: Hot Tub Time Machine is an unwieldy welding-together of sentimental soul-searching and gross out humor.
This profound subversion of our critical and aesthetic assumptions confronts us - like a logical paradox that seems both true and false - with a film that seems both awful and entertaining.
movie_title: Incubo sulla città contaminata (Nightmare City) (Invasion by the Atomic Zombies) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: The financial failure of EDGE OF TOMORROW represents the greatest inverse relationship between quality and ticket sales since TWILIGHT sent breathless teen girls storming into theatres.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Though purists may disagree, Abrams' two Star Trek features rank atop their predecessors, eclipsing ... all but the best of the classic Star Trek films.
...the most beautiful boring movie ever made.

If you have never heard of KING OF THE LOST WORLD, you're lucky - or at least you were, until you started reading this review.
Jaden Smith (who was actually good in THE KARATE KID) winds up looking like a nervous child who, forced to play baseball by his father, strikes out with the bases loaded.
It's the kind of film you enjoy late at night, especially after a few drinks, but you don't really respect it in the morning.
movie_title: La noche de Walpurgis (The Werewolf Versus the Vampire Woman) (1971)

movie_review_blurb: By reconfiguring its old formula, Blumhouse Productions has crafted its best film in years, erasing memories of the terminally declining PARANORMAL ACTIVITY sequels and spin-offs.

If you think that being trapped with a bunch of guys telling dick jokes would the equivalent of Hell on Earth - well, according to THIS IS THE END, you are more right than you think.
Consistently intense but inconsistently satisfying ... in its attempt to pack relentlessly downbeat horror into 20-minute packages.
HATCHET III is almost as much gleefully gory fun as the original - a comedy-horror hybrid that elicits screams of laughter and disgust in equal measure...
The familiar zombie routine has never been realized on such an epic scale, but that is the film's only claim to novelty.
It's a great message for children and a poignant reminder for adults: everyone has something to offer; the "cool" kids aren't always cool; and sometimes the underdog has his day.

To watch this film is to gain a new level of identification with HAL 9000: as MORTAL INSTRUMENTS unspools before your eyes, you can feel your mind going...going...gone - until you find yourself humming a verse of "Daisy Bell."

...almost a textbook case study in the pitfalls of remakes.
At least the Thor-Loki narrative thread is worth unwinding. Too bad it's twisted up with all the overblown blockbuster nonsense.

Like watching someone else play a bad videogame.
...the film should be retitled "Dario Argento's Whatever Popped into My Head."

Makes TWILIGHT look good - something I never thought I would say about any movie ever - now please excuse me while I go wash my mouth out with soap.

The most astoundingly okay movie so far this year - which is apparently all it takes to earn high praise these days.

a director, Raimi's strength lies in his manic inventiveness %u2013 which is somewhat in abeyance here, as he tries injecting some traditional plot elements into the old formula.

The camera languishes on sequences like Nacho rubbing cow manure into Esqueleto's face. Jokes like these are nacho good, nacho funny.

Our caped hero does not turn the world backwards to relive time, but much of director Bryan Singer's film is lifted from the 1978 Richard Donner version.
The pace is grueling...as the many sword fighting sequences clang on and on. Even battling gigantic tentacles becomes a yawner after the 45th pirate is squeezed.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The script does not wear so well, dragging along for stretches. Reeves, in his usual sullen delivery way, does not help take up the slack.
All 'Lady in the Water' lacks is a narrator ending the tale with 'and they lived happily ever after.' This is a Shyamalan flick?
So well animated, voiced, written, and directed, it defines itself as one of the best animated flicks this summer, rightfully standing beside 'Monster House' and 'Cars.'
Top praise should go to Stone. After the overblown failure 'Alexander,' he made a wise decision to shoot an up close and personal script. Less proves definitely more.
The whole of the movie is rough edged cruel. Main characters, including Ricky, are ignoble back stabbers.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Produced by Mark Ciardi ['The Rookie,' 'Miracles'], the fact-based 'Invincible' goes for touchdown. It is a formula movie that works.
Coming near the close of a summer full of movie superheroes and remakes, 'The Illusionist' is a film buff's treat. Here is an atmospheric, period tale of magic and murder.
Not only is 'M:i:III' a massive adrenaline rush in terms of almost non-stop action sequences, it is better than its predecessors.
Sure comedy isn't pretty all the time, but in 'The Cable Guy,' comedy is actually ugly. (published 6-14-96)
It is wall-crawling hands down the most adrenaline pumping super hero flick ever.
It is the structure of the film, including the smooth-subtle pans, turning present to past and back to present, that really awe. (published 7-19-96)
Like the finest of Vermeer's paintings, the film's richly textured elements blend perfectly, unforgettably framed.
Despite a fairly upbeat ending, the ugly images dominate the film with the time/reality plot a bloody nose afterthought.
He (Peter Jackson) has succeeded in topping the series for the grandest of finales.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Judd, Jackson and Garcia's work is pedestrian at best. But they did accept this script.
Amir Mokri's purposely frantic (ie: jerky) camera work during action scenes irritates, but still 'Taking Lives' is a marginally diverting thriller.
Do fans care this high dollar eye candy is much ado about really nothing?
As it is, 'Down With Love' seems forced, with the principals looking like youngsters dressing up and over-acting to impersonate grown-ups.
Old fashioned spirit and resolve work well in a movie like 'Evelyn.'
Lost we become in story telling that emphasizes cuts and coincidences, leaving serious characterization gaps.
In boldface fact, 'Die Another Day' is the best Bond in years, and arguably ranks with the vintage Sean Connery set. Any Connery/Bond fan knows that is high-spy praise.
Cage is absolutely terrific down to his eye twitches and neck jerks.
To be fair, Rodriguez's wicked dialogue does elicit some laughs amongst the on-screen carnage.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Nolte's hard lived, leather-lined face looks like a Muncie road map, and fits robber Bob to each crease.
Jammed with double and triple-crosses that make Doug Jung's confusing screenplay secondary to the film's overall look.
A vastly entertaining and noble motion picture. Spending two hours and 20 minutes with Aubrey and crew is high honor.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The overall look is purposely grim and downbeat.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: My only reservation about Caine is his less than credible Texas accent, especially since his brother's is so pronounced.
The immense sets look matte-drawn, reminiscent of the decades-old 'This Island Earth.'
A superbly done roller coaster of a sci-fi/fantasy spectacle.
Marion Cotillard is fantastic. It is the best sync singing, including body language, since Larry Parks in 'The Jolson Story.'
Just when the Hollywood western genre seemed long ago ridden off into the sunset, here thunders back Open Range with double barrels ablaze.
Emotional gut punches are plentiful in director Peter Berg's stunning 'Friday Night Lights.'
Perlman has not only the towering body, sculpted face, and commanding voice for such a role, he exudes a very humane heart.
The longest two hours, 10 minutes I have spent in a theater for some time.
A curious mix of thug violence, romance, and whimsy.
Feel your jaw drop when first viewing the arrival of the thousand Greek ships, a visual masterpiece.
If you were raised on action-packed computer games, this movie is from Sega heaven.
A marginally diverting, fun way to spend a couple of hours, and you even get to hear De Niro and Crystal duet on tunes from 'West Side Story.'
Mark Steven Johnson has wisely paced his film with elaborately choreographed fight sequences and ingratiating dialogue.
It is unrelentingly gritty and tense.
My guess is Shelton and fellow writer Robert Souza borrowed an idea from TV's improvisational 'Whose Line Is It Anyway?'
The terrific horse racing sequences, exciting as they are, complement the base story of human dignity and perseverance.
A remarkable picture peppered with stream-of-movie-consciousness, 1930's media imagery.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: I cannot recall seeing a tank being lobbed at a copter with such finesse.
Mel Gibson, the Lord love him--and I believe He does, has succeeded in producing the first major motion picture ever that is both spiritually and historically challenging.
The most spectacular and intriguing sci-fi action film since the 'Star Wars' trilogy. (published 7-6-96)
Endless sequences of posing and posturing by Beckinsale and fellow fangsters.
Pacino's puppet-stringing of his recruit is reminiscent of Peter O'Toole's manipulative character in 1980's 'The Stunt Man.'
Expect top notch work by Cruise, Crowe and Co.
Director Peter Jackson's awesome three hour film, seeming like half the time, is the handsomest fantasy film ever made. (Published 12-22-01)
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Even without a whit of singing, it is the 'Wizard of Oz' of our time. (Published 12-22-01)
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Burton has crafted a sweet yet bizarre film seeming at times like 'The Twilight Zone' in Oz.
Zellweger's performance is major reason to catch this movie.
Who would think a fight over real estate would be so fascinating, so gut wrenching to watch?
The performances are a bit too underplayed to suit me, but the melancholy film is both funny and fascinating.
Period dress, set design, manners and acting are fine--as is Mike Newell's direction. If only the script was less predictable.
Lesser known Price yarn has its moments.
This could jump start movie musicals.
The final act's battle scene is the most spectacular medieval type ever filmed. (Pubished 1-3-03)
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: 'Nemesis'? Try 'NUMBesis,' and fight nodding off during the first half.
Chan's daredevil persona creates a fun but never graphically violent action movie. [published 7-26-96]
Try not to double or triple-up laughing. (published 7-19-96)
A provocative film with Oscar caliber performances. (published 7-19-96)
A crowd pleaser of enormous star magnitude.
But is this 'Alamo' the definitive version? No, this is no History Channel presentation.
Thornton's ultra low key performance is a plus, as is the effectively moody, black and white cinematography.
A fascinating, unprecedented spoof of Hitler, one of the few before WWII that dared to take him on.
Just don't think too much between the super battles. This is, after all, very comic book.
Back is Chris Columbus, whose direction this time around has a purposely darker, more ominous look.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Using the real-life Rodney King mess as a backdrop is pretty tawdry exploitation.
Then there is 'Gods and Generals,' cut from the same production cloth as 'Gettysburg' but a film of very loose ends.
A multi-million dollar fiasco.
Three quarters of a century later, viewing 'The Jazz Singer' is perhaps a historical curiosity to many. It is an insult to overly sensitive others.
If something isn't done soon, the earth as we know it (love that cliché) will destroy itself. Who do you call? Core busters!
Satisfying explanations of the whys, whats, and whos are missing. Yet this 'X-Files' type thriller has its moments.
Penn and Robbins, especially, are absolutely riveting in this haunting tale of lives lost.
The film's action is limited to repeatedly ransacking Cusack's apartment, and the plot is rife with Big-Brother-is-watching paranoia.
How I wanted to flee the dreadful 'Village' after its first 20 minutes. What happened? It's the story. It's the direction. It's Shyamalan.
A handsome musical about the most ambiguous of American composers.
Using 9/11 and its aftermath, in fact, is pretty risky business for these sophomoric South Park guys.
A Cassavetes must-have, must-see
The f-word laces Billy Bob's every comment, including those directed at children. Shock humor abounds, if that is your cup of body waste.
Don't even look for Clarence the Angel in this slow paced, but effective story.
The childish fun and wonder of the early Potter movies has turned into high school fear and loathing. ...A downer of a wiz kid flick.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Adrienne Shelly has borrowed from her Jenna and taken familiar sitcom ingredients to fashion her own special dessert treat.
Hard to believe, but director Paul Greengrass has made this installment more nail bitingly frantic than ever.
Director-screenwriter Neill Blomkamp, who imprinted the movie history map with his incredibly original 'District 9,' does not equal that triumph. But portions of 'Elysium' come near.

Both (Daniels) and Strong have compressed an engrossing saga covering the Civil Rights Movement, five presidents, a family's generational growth, and a love story into 132 minutes. It had to be a daunting task, but it works

Alfonso Cuarón and his son, Jonás, have penned a fantastic yet credible story of courage, friendship, and survival. Even the title, 'Gravity,' is appropriate in its dual simplicity. (This) is a perfect movie. Seeing it in IMAX-3D is perfection plus.
Each part is plum and comedically necessary. Who would have even thought of casting Tilda Swinton or Ralph Fiennes in a wild comedy? Voilà, they seem perfectly cast.

As good as this 'Transformers' looks, and the visuals are the only reason to see this spectacle, the flawless effects become overbearing after nearly three hours. (I was checking my watch after 90 minutes.) Enough is too much.
'Tammy,' tell me true, why couldn't you have been funnier?

Marvel has the most tortured, flawed superheroes in the comic book universe. Proof positive is substantiated throughout 'The Wolverine,' arguably the best of the shiv-wristed franchise. It is also the most grueling to watch.

What a terrific film, what a technical achievement. If you were impressed three years ago with the special effects in 'Rise of the Planet of the Apes,' and surely you were, prepare to be blown away with this sequel.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Brosnan is a nitty, gritty, Bondish (due to his handsomeness) secret agent with absolutely no penchant for tongue-in-cheek joking, drinking non-stirred booze, or loyalty to the Queen.
...A funny, bittersweet dramedy that connects, in large part due to a superb cast.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Honestly, it is reminiscent of Bruce Banner becoming enraged and turning into The Hulk. Maybe the movie going public will be caught up in all the histrionics. I found it hilariously hokey.
What a great ensemble cast led by the terrific Duvall, arguably the best motion picture actor of our time, who anchors the film.
'St. Vincent' is owned by its star, Bill Murray, from start to finish and extending into the closing crawl.
Most of all, 'Birdman' is a directorial triumph for Alejandro González Iñárritu, who also helped write the screenplay. (This is) a serious movie fan's movie.
Formula or not, 'Guardians of the Galaxy' maintains its fresh appeal from opening to end credits. The film greatly benefits from Chris Pratt's loopy, devil-may-care persona.
...Just as charming, hilarious, clever, and well paced as its predecessor.
Lone Ranger creators George W. Trendle and Fran Striker are surely doing pinwheels in their respective graves. (This new take) is an odd mix of parody, homage, and re-imagining of the legend.
The f-bomb isn't just used, it is part of McCarthy's character's breathing process. Frankly, after the 38th f-you, it had gone beyond boring.
I did see and greatly enjoy the previous 'Bournes,' but was dizzied at what the heck was going on in this new take. No doubt this is the end of the franchise.
The plaudits have to go to Ben Affleck, whose producing/directing/acting trifecta makes 'Argo' one of the top films of the year, and a natural for the Oscar.
This is the kind of film requiring vigilant attention. Do not leave to get snacks. You will be 'Cloud Atlas' lost forever. ...A complex and must see film.
No doubt whatsoever that Denzel Washington will be Oscar nominated, and likely win, for 'Flight.' His performance is a stunner.
The franchise has refashioned itself by never once forgetting its glorious history, including a certain 'Goldfinger' car.
Figuratively, at its visual core, 'Lincoln' is a collection of Mathew Brady photos come to life. Daniel Day-Lewis dominates. His Oscar worthy performance encompasses greatness...(He) IS Lincoln.
Despite the Ed Gein and love story MacGuffins, 'Hitchcock' makes for a 'good evening.'
While 'Quartet' seems to be part of a double feature with 'The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel,' it does lack 'Exotic's' breadth of characterizations and humor.

It is not (Bruce Willis') fault he has grown more than a tad too old to play John McClane (for the 5th time since 1988), but he can be blamed for signing on to such a script-shallow, decibel-deafening blast-fest.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: What a stunner it is. Presumptuously speaking, this new take (a prequel) is/will be a modern classic.
There is a great deal more than magic and laughs...it also says a hatful of bunnies about audiences and the pervasive, decadent state of entertainment in our society.
It looks good, particularly on an IMAX screen, but the flick is ultimately style over substance. Involving it is not.
Prepare to be hoodwinked, thanks to screenwriters Drew Pearce and Shane Black. Black also directs this terrific 'Iron Man' installment, which both exhilarates and exhausts.

It is all about style: ultra colorful, superb costuming, knock-out set design, and all in 3-D. That last ingredient pops the imagery past one's eyes and deep into the brain cells. Way past my comfort zone.
(Pitt's) character could use some Kevin McCarthy/'Invasion of the Body Snatchers' frantic demeanor.
Hollywoodized to the extent of depicting President Lyndon Johnson as an obstructionist to the African-American cause. Nonetheless, 'Selma' is compelling cinema.
The second half of the movie becomes a loud, f-bombing cliché of excessive violence.
As refreshing as it is not to see a comic book, slam-banger movie this close to summer releases, the talky 'True Story' could use some movement. Adapting it as a stage play seems more plausible.
Fellow enthusiasts, prepare for a towering T-rex, calculating raptors, and much more. 'Jurassic World' is just what the pterodactyl ordered.
The joyful absurdities and frightful images peppering the self-described 'Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them' are reason enough to see this fun flick.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Stylistic touches and new characters make 'Rogue One' seem fresh, which also invigorates the ongoing franchise.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Combining these two blade runners, working side by side, is a recipe for stunts, special effects, and big box office.
Stereotypical in many ways, 'Kong: Skull Island' is great fun to watch, thanks to a literate, savvy script, fine acting, and visuals that should please the most discriminating monster movie fan.
Emotionally wrenching in many ways, 'The Zookeeper's Wife' succeeds as a fact-based a story of love and perseverance.

This second volume is pretty terrific, a must-see. It suffers a bit from being a sequel in that characters are already firmly defined. (The revelation of their personas was a plus in the previous film.)
This one is the best Spider-Man movie ever, and among the best of any in the history of superhero films.
Important to the film's success is Hans Zimmer's unique score, which becomes a living entity unto itself due to pulsating sounds.
Two factors elevating 'Only the Brave' above the norm are the film's location photography and realistic forest fire sequences.
Compelling? Well, so-so. A unique take on the familiar Charles Dickens tale, 'A Christmas Carol'? Definitely.
Though contrived, 'Wonder Wheel' has stunning color and Kate Winslet as pluses.
Director/screenwriter Rian Johnson has truly delivered the galaxy goods on this event-the second installment of the sequel trilogy.

The cinematic takeaway here is a combination of the factual story, the superb supporting cast (Sarah Paulsen, Bob Odenkirk, Carrie Coon, and Tracy Letts among them), and the film's powerhouse leads, Streep and Hanks.
I had hoped for so much more than what was delivered. The loyal fan base will no doubt think otherwise.
Rhythm, raucous behavior, and racism. What else could one desire from a great musical?
Besides being overlong and having a slapdash ending, 'Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children' is a sensory treat.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Once Batman finally gets back to action, with the audience's dander by that time primed to the max, the film explodes in scene after dazzling scene of air to street attacks and counter attacks.
It is the totally engrossing in-flight sequence that dominates 'Sully.' Prepare your adrenaline.
'Florence Foster Jenkins' is undoubtedly the best movie of 2016 so far, and seems out of place in-as usual-a summer of comic book superheroes.
'Ant-Man' will appeal mostly to ant-people. Translated: children. Factor in fans of Paul Rudd and Marvel superheroes, and you could have a box office community picnic.
Calling this (lackluster) movie 'The Man from U.N.C.L.E.' is misleading. Naming it 'The Future Men from U.N.C.L.E.' is probably too cumbersome, but truthful.
Depp's superb work here is a major turnaround in a career fallen to hats and Halloween costumes.
What superb, must-see storytelling 'Bridge of Spies' certainly is.
Central to the story's theme are love, family and homesickness, ingredients perfectly blended and served by director John Crowley. What a truly lovely film.
'Youth' is a handsomely photographed, well acted movie. It is also distant and uninvolving.
Don't expect a passionate love story or even Leonardo batting a passing eye at some lady of the trail. This is a man's man movie.
Its bizarreness will grab from the get-go. Ready yourself for filmed eccentricity, ladies and gentlemen.
The Coens have laced 'Hail, Caesar!' with enough visuals and double entendres that beg for multiple viewings to appreciate them all.
After 2-1/2 hours of sitting through relentless CGI violent visuals and deafening sound effects, I was exhausted.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The story has never been more captivating.
It all makes for a fantasy-fun, if not deafening, two hours and 24 minutes.
As director Steven Spielberg's second fantasy-adventure film, the other being 1991's mediocre 'Hook,' 'The BFG' turns out to be more satisfying but no classic.
In this 49th official Tarzan feature, Alexander Skarsgård ranks a tad above average....which is better than the overall film.
There are enough plot variations and new inclusions to satisfy diehard fans of the original franchise.

'Ben-Hur' looks less like a true movie spectacle, and more like the lackluster 'Christian produced' message movies released over the past decade. Like them, the acting, dialogue, cinematography and score are pedestrian at best.

The trick with 'The Avengers' is to satisfy each superhero's fan base while simultaneously divvying out each hero's scenes in equal portions. Director-screenwriter Joss Whedon has pulled it off with muscle flexing aplomb.
When 'Wonder Woman' is good, it is compellingly fun. But when the Amazonian warrior is shown for the 37th time in mid-air, slo-mo battle pose, it is a yawner.
An imitation Three Stooges flick cannot possibly get any funnier than 'The Three Stooges: The Movie.' I laughed, and laughed...to my surprise.
Where is Meryl Streep? After all, 'The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor' seems to have everything else in its mix, including a three-headed dragon (and) Abominable SnowMEN.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Of all the depictions, Brolin, Cromwell, Jones and Wright come off best without being impressionist comic characters. Best of all is Dreyfuss' Cheney. The sneer, the shifty eyes, and the demeanor are dead on.
This is Jolie's dazzling show, cementing her acting credentials.
[As the] central character, senior citizen and anti-social Walt Kowalski, Eastwood gets to literally snarl dozens of times at life's tics and impositions... ...A beautifully realized film.
One of the '50s icons of sci-fi, featuring a giant tarantula on the rampage.
Expect Disney violence, which means greatly curbed, implied destruction laced with explosions. And a lot of running to and fro. This IS a chase film.
A stunning film laced with absorbing performances, jarring special effects, and atmospheric set design. It has been a long time since a film has evoked as many creepy, spine deep tingles as this one.
Fun, silly werewolf teen comedy featuring Jason Bateman. This is the sequel to Teen Wolf, in case you couldn't tell.
...Elicits laughs, adventure, and refreshing, positive energy in a way series creator Gene Roddenberry intended.
The pathetic, witless state of modern film comedy and mass appeal. Even at this level, 'Land of the Lost' bores.
This is not a terrible movie, just disappointing when considering all the talent firing and dodging lead.

A film phenomenon of our time. Like the Star Wars series, the financial and social impact of the Potter series translates to motion picture history and, eventually, legend. Savor this satisfying episode of its ongoing, broomstick ride.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Channeling Julia Child had to be a challenge for Meryl Streep, and I do not mean just getting that distinctive voice down. Streep not only nails the voice, but the body language as well. ...And amazingly, she embodies the great chef's spirit.

If sensitive, intelligent, and cat food craving creatures whose heads look like transplants from the 'Star Wars' cantina scene is by itself not enough to pique your interest to see 'District 9,' then wherefore art thou?
...The more knowledgeable you are about WWII history and 20th Century pop culture, the more you will appreciate this Tarantino absurdity. What a wildly violent and memorable absurdity it is.
A triumph in comic book movies...the best Batman movie ever made. But it is Ledger's demeanor--his body language, eye contact, and delivery--that gets under one's skin.

A beautiful tip-off to the film's truth versus reality element is Whitacre's subtle yanking back his toupee (we kind of suspected he was wearing such) while talking to his FBI pals. Damon pulls the scene off, and his hair back, superbly.

A mishmash...looking more like a Roger Moore Bond parody. There are numerous airplane stunt sequences, explosions and gunfights...(that) fatally bleed the character-driven humor of the original series.

Skulls and cliffhanging aside, 'Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull' is a nostalgic reunion for fans. Harrison Ford, with his quirky (and often funny) delivery...has copyrighted this great, heroic character as his alone.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The violence is too much for young children, and the witches are too corny for older viewers.
At last a proactive campaign of awareness and action to defeat bullying is afoot. This documentary has already been lauded as a step toward that goal.
(Regarding)...the relationship between woman and bee...a tender moment of their holding hands (yes, one is a bee hand) while on the terrace is sort of cute, sort of creepy.
Johnny Depp's dynamic performance in the title role is Oscar worthy, and arguably the greatest of his career.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Boomers and older will love it. Others should too.... The plus is it's played out by two terrific actors of our time.
If you cannot stand even 10-15 seconds of painfully jumpy, sideways cinematography, try to fathom 'Cloverfield's' 75 minutes of eye strain.
'Spiderwick's' biggest shocks are due to big names cast in off beat roles...the real eyebrow raiser is seeing Nick Nolte as the evil ogre Mulgarath.
Style overwhelms substance. By the seventh rewind, the audience has grown understandably weary.

'What makes us different makes us beautiful,' touts the film's promo blurb. Good thought, but do any of the characters in 'Penelope' ever believe it? For sure this is a different film, but beautifully executed it is not.
CGI effects are letter perfect believable. The opening mastodon hunt/stampede is as good as effects seen in the recent 'King Kong,' greatly enhancing the film.
By film's conclusion, Drillbit is a mock hero at best, and the few bits of comedy have been overshadowed by viciousness.
Pacing is brisk, the laughs frequent. With an ending corny and Capra-esque, 'Run, Fat Boy, Run' charms right to the finish line.
It is about as close as we will ever get to, say, Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell--in rapid fire wordplay. And the words, by Brantley and Reilly, connect fast and witty.
Pacino's frenzy, some nice Seattle location scenery, and an over-the-top ending right out of 'Batman' do not a fine crime film make.

Robert Downey Jr. nails Iron Man. More apropros, change nails to welds. For it is Downey who most significantly raises the quality bar of 'Iron Man' to the classic level of fellow comic book heroes Superman, Batman and Spider-Man. Welcome, new franchise.

...Adolescent heaven personified with endless, wallopin' fights between WWF-looking steroidians, highlighting a mindless production akin to a widescreen video game. In the oft pounded word of The Hulk himself, 'Grrrrr!'
To be honest, I had to drag myself to Zombieland. And, horrors upon hilarity, I laughed throughout it. Chalk it up to the comedy's rapid pacing, graphics, makeup, actors, and clever writing.
'I Am Legend' is essentially a Will Smith one-man show, and he succeeds marvelously.
Most of us know the beginning, middle, and uplifting end. However, the hook this time is a trifecta: 3-D, digital imagery, and Jim Carrey. That hook makes this 'Christmas Carol' worth seeing.
What should have been, could have been. It sure isn't this Green Slacker.
'Unknown' is a nail-biter, an edge-of-seater, and a fast couple of hours. It is just as well that its action moves faster than logic.
Maybe this flick could actually spawn a movie franchise. At the very least, it could work on TV. The gimmickry is in place, reminiscent of 'Burke's Law' and the chauffeur driven Rolls.

...An unconventional think piece, impressively helmed by Duncan Jones. Intellectual sci-fi fans will love it. The 'Transformers' and 'Battle: Los Angeles' visualists will get headaches from thinking too much.
...Above average movie eye candy. Branagh's direction as well as the writing, which includes an abundance of intelligent dialogue sequences (for a comic book), are a plus--as is the acting overall.

The story is reminiscent of 'Courage of Lassie' (1946) since it involves a beloved pet, of sorts, that is thrust into a world war, and whose survival, let alone return to its home base, is fraught with impossibility upon impossibility.
Sure, the revisionist history, plot device is troublesome, but the film's digital effects provide enough spectacular action and levitation eye candy to soothe any blue Beast.
Once again, the Judd Apatow-influenced school of witless comedy reinforces that we should bust a gut laughing at virtually the lowest of low humor. This is funny? No.
(Director David) Yates and screenwriter Steve Kloves have lovingly transported (Rowling's) vision to the most satisfying finale, truly grand, in film history.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: (The leads) have the necessary chemistry to carry 'Cowboys & Aliens' for its rip-roaring two hours. True, Daniel Craig handles all the rough and tough physicality, while the elder Harrison Ford is, appropriately, much more reserved.

After all the 'Transformers' exposure over the last few years, who would have guessed more battling bots would hook our interest? Maybe it is because 'Real Steel's' bots need humans to think for them.

The production overall is breezy and fun, with a nonstop pace after the first half hour. That is when the action really kicks in. The on location filming, particularly Trump Tower and the Macy's Thanksgiving Parade, is superb.
The screenplay itself is problematic, but Streep dazzles.
Director David Fincher has crafted a disturbing dazzler of a thriller, embellished by sharp acting.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the gore, which is marginally justified to drive the revenge aspect, the film is worth seeing for the clever plot turn finale as well as above average performances by leads Jamie Foxx and Gerard Butler.
Ballet is an art which explores love and death through the symbolism of music and dance. Mix in a ballerina with extreme self esteem issues, and you get a fascinating, edgy film.
Spectacular and increasingly brooding as ever...the most foreboding and shocking of them all.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Stars Jeff Bridges and Garrett Hedlund play second or third fiddle to the glitz, so place your movie ticket bet on vibrant reds and blues that reach out of the screen to be the main attraction here. It's all in the eye candy.
...A fascinating, absorbing film well worth friending.

movie_review_blurb: In this 90-minute movie, which runs twice the length of one of the Ab Fab episodes airing stateside since the mid-Nineties, this deliciously bad behavior is diminished by a silly plot.

A testament to the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things unseen.
Storks flutters like a bird with a broken wing -- it never quite gets off the ground.
The script is replete with filler inserted in the name of "real life": bad jokes and silly riddles, spontaneous songs, and improvised scenes in which conversations go around in circles.

Viggo Mortensen may be the most taciturn actor in American movies today. His weatherworn, handsome face (with a cleft chin to rival Kirk Douglas) communicates character with only the slightest of movement.
Galifianakis' cluelessness can tickle, but he's having a progressively difficult time making things feel fresh.
The movie never allows [Garner] to truly plumb the depth of her character's despair, which would have made the uplift of its message all the more effective.
By the end, Triple 9 is anything but by the numbers, a frustrating head-scratcher sabotaged by its narrative ambition. It's too bad things wind up that way, because the film has promise.
The Vatican Tapes ends with the prospect of a round-two showdown between the Church and Lucifer Unbound in a sequel. Let's pray otherwise. Quoth the raven: Nevermore.
The badly miscast Delevingne communicates nothing to suggest the sway she holds over her lovesick admirer. She's an enigmatic blank page, a paper actress in a paper movie.

What's ultimately endearing about Shaun the Sheep Movie is its message of loyalty and devotion. The resourcefulness and tenacity with which Shaun searches for the man he once took for granted is genuinely touching.
At its narrative apex, Prince veers toward expected tragedy and then unexpectedly crumbles, both stylistically and thematically.
Predictable but never coy about it, After Words speaks to the fateful connection that sometimes occurs between two people under the most improbable circumstances.

Using a ghostly digital rendition of the actor's face on a computer screen to embody his words, the filmmakers make Brando eerily come alive at times to tell his story. Wow. It's nothing short of transcendent.
Despite its questionable title (to whom are the "we" and "your" referring?), the film isn't very approachable. It keeps its distance in the emotional depiction of its relationships.

Stumbles down the runway like an overdressed supermodel with two left feet.

movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's meant to be thrilling fun, but it never takes off in the way imagined. There's no merriment in the .357-caliber chaos, no mirth in the staccato of bullets.

movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Rough Night briefly gallops when these girls-gone-wild party, but once things take that unfortunate turn, the movie goes flat-footed: Logic dissipates and transitions stumble.
Elliott carries The Hero with what appears to be minimal effort, but rest assured, there's a deceptive weight to his resigned character.
Remember the visceral excitement you felt the first time you saw De Palma's Carrie, Scorsese's Raging Bull or Tarantino's Pulp Fiction...? Baby Driver induces the same reaction.
Wish Upon is yet another high-concept, low-budget (here: $12 million) enterprise that aims to make a fast buck with minimal effort.

In the end, it's the vision (literally) of an Americanized Gallic filmmaker that makes Valerian worth a look in a season traditionally chock-full of predictable, big-budget franchise flicks. Just turn off your brain, sit back, and let your eyeballs feast.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's an intriguing story to be told here, but there's a better way to tell it. To borrow from the Bard, the spots in Lady Macbeth simply won't wash away.
There's seldom a dull moment when this funny and bright woman is onscreen. In a nod to another Nineties memory, there's something about Jenny.
Those who like things sentimental and sweet - and there's nothing wrong with that - will find comfort in the notion of leaving the past behind to allow the future to go forward.

Bristling with unapologetic righteousness, the ragged documentary Whose Streets? takes no prisoners in its raw depiction of events transpiring in the predominantly African-American community of Ferguson, Mo., about three years ago.
It's like watching a pharmaceutical commercial showing you how wonderful things will be once you convince your doctor to write that cure-all prescription for you.
Like its predecessor, everything about the stylized Kingsman: The Golden Circle teeters just a little over the top.

Paris Can Wait may be a film à clef of sorts -- there's a hint of the autobiographical in it, the suggestion of something experienced -- but even that angle doesn't make the movie terribly appetizing. What it needs is a little salt.
The message feels programmed like some LGBTQ version of a Hallmark card. Sometimes capital letters are needed to get the attention of those persons who most need to hear what needs to be said.
One can only hope Perry will move on to another holiday and perhaps take the effort to reconnect with the crazy old-lady persona that has served him so well. Until then: Oh hail, no.
movie_title: Tyler Perry's Boo 2! A Madea Halloween (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While some of the sociological theorizing voiced by a variety of talking heads here may prompt some eye-rolling, the frame-by-frame dissection of the sequence by fanboy and fangirl filmmakers in awe of its artistry is exhilarating.
If only all of our third acts turned out that way.
No wonder the movie feels something like a retread: It gets you there, but the ride is neither nowhere as smooth, nor nearly as compelling
Most of them look as if they're simply going through the motions: a head-bob here, a hip-thrust there.

There's a nagging feeling we should expect something more from this guy. To borrow the most quotable line of dialogue from The Room (bellowed at the top of the lungs): "YOU ARE TEARING ME APART, FRANCO!"

As is the case with most of Allen's films in the last 25 years or so, the script plays like a first draft, with the characters spouting stilted dialogue you'd never use in conversation, much less ever say out loud.
A nagging question persists throughout Darkest Hour: Is Oldman's compulsively meticulous turn here anything more than a brilliant impersonation?

This isn't a movie musical. It's a Las Vegas revue featuring songs aiming for high rotation on a Top 40 radio station, one that will doubtlessly enthrall those moviegoers who mistake spectacle for quality.
It's a heart-pumping 15-minute or so sequence that proves that the old man's still got it, but whether it's worth the wait will depend on your level of patience.

The movie attempts to satirically explore the single-ladies world of bad dates, bad boyfriends, and bad bosses in the age of the #MeToo zeitgeist, but it does little more than nibble on the ubiquitous sexism that women experience.
Without preaching from the pulpit, A Fantastic Woman powerfully communicates the hostility and hatred that persons such as Marina encounter simply due to their otherness.
Barracuda may not have the sharp teeth of the Hollywood nail-biters that have swum before in familiar waters. But if you're attuned to its slow-burn charm, it still offers some bite.

The actors (both professional and nonprofessional) perform each scene - each shot, for that matter - as if it had no relationship at all to the rest of film, with the emphasis more on energy levels rather than credible characterizations.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Snatched fails to tap into the full potential of either of these funny ladies by shoehorning them into this unbecoming genre flick. It's not worth paying the ransom for this one.
Why it's taken this superb movie two years to cross the ocean is a mystery. See Truman with a good friend. You'll be closer for it.
A sumptuous tapestry of color, shadow, and light.
Truly, madly, deeply: There's magic in this Moonlight.
A Man Called Ove deftly incorporates the seminal moments of its titular character's past in a series of flashbacks that inform, rather than intrude upon, the present.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Loving (a title that works on more than one level) unhurriedly recounts this husband and wife's near decade-long ordeal in a manner commiserate with their quiet and unwavering commitment to each other.

The film buzzes with hand-drawn creativity that's precious in both the pop-cultural and material senses.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's arguable that Nyoni is stretching a thin premise, but this film is one of the obvious breakouts of the year: exactly the kind of young work-brash, committed, and narratively unpredictable-that film festivals are supposed to champion.
Our Brand is Crisis would have an uphill battle on its hands even if it were a masterpiece, which it most certainly is not.

A queasy demise is the best-case scenario on the other side of a one-night stand in Harrison Atkins' Lace Crater, a s-s-s-s-s-s-spooky and inventive indie debut that's best seen, if possible, in a packed theatre.
There is no such thing as a minor Terence Davies.

While a number of Ospina's filmmaking decisions are kooky as all get out, highbrow formal considerations take a backseat to the urgency, the personality, and the sheer richness of the filmmaker's excavations.
movie_title: It All Started at the End (Todo comenzó por el fin) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: If I Am Not Your Negro lacks subtlety as an objet d'art, then, all I can say is America continues to live in hostile times.

Daughters damns precedent altogether, sidestepping the broad strokes of African-American history familiar from so many textbook historical dramas set during the era of antebellum slavery or the '60s Civil Rights Movement.
But the din that erupts from the logjam-creative, psychic, historical, national-is nothing if not honest.
movie_title: In the Last Days of the City (Akher ayam el madina) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: It's the multitude of miniature narratives that gives Pedro Costa's film its abiding, silent outrage.

When the film's whirligig plotline goes off-rail in the heady final act, Oscar and Gloria's origin story bends over backward to justify a magical-realist conceit that was more fun without explanation.
An expensively mounted treatise on important issues that's terrified to dig in obsessively, yet so ramrod-stiff with indignation that it never comes anywhere near compelling entertainment.
To Keira Knightley's credit, she's all too willing to undercut her pretty-girl reputation by looking and acting a fool for Lynn Shelton's camera.
It's hard to tell if the film is hampered or helped by the performances of its three stars, because it's so amateurishly written and directed that their participation beggars belief.
The film places its characters in a reflexive historical continuum that dooms them to be mere demonstrative types from start to finish.
It shrugs off the bigger questions about Iranian politics its first half appears to raise, falling back instead on a gestalt of the eternal, Kafkaesque regime, wherever the viewer may find it.

The film is more interested in performance and symbolism than in the meaning of its characters' words or their substitutive gestures.
Georgian filmmaker Salome Alexi's superb Line of Credit delicately skewers its characters' expectations for the post-Soviet good life.
It lays bare that the franchise's most radical asset is also its most conservative: an overriding emphasis on, above all else, the on-screen family.
Given its played-out subject matter and hoary coming-to-terms narrative arc, one's ability to enjoy the film hangs on a tolerance for the ever-popular on-screen man-child.
As characters endlessly digress on the differences between rom-coms and real life, the film evinces a schizophrenic relationship with its own inside-baseball cynicism.
The film feels utterly infatuated by the cop/crook dividing line long-since drawn, if not flogged, by Michael Mann.
This is the kind of filmmaking that gets touted as "workmanlike" when it's really straight-laced to the point of tepidness.
A grab bag of visual punchlines and topical references capped with interchangeable music tracks.
It's as unsparing a sketch of twentysomething life in New York City as American independent cinema has yet offered.
What intrigues, if in a lurid sort of way, is the film's fudging of projected viewer desires with its characters'.

movie_review_blurb: Mystery Men is like its hapless heroes. It's a wannabe that has the best intentions -- including a pronounced anti-gun stance -- but none of the knack it takes to save the day, or itself.
For all its wry humor, it concludes as a heart-piercing affirmation of life and love in the face of death.
As it rambles on, it makes less and less of the material, rather than more.
It's a movie that shows us that the silence between two people can be more dramatic than 100 pages of dialogue.
Its weary clichés and flat comic bits are apparently supposed to be fresh and insightful.

movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's all perfectly pleasant, but the movie lacks an urgent dramatic pulse, or a clear sense of whose story it's supposed to be, or even, from scene to scene, whether it's meant to be a comedy, drama or thriller.
A muted but engrossing look at marriage at a crossroads.
A wrenching feel-bad movie graced by a luminous central performance.
Has its moments, but never takes wing.
Plug in. Again. But be prepared for some glitches in the software.
A small-scale domestic drama with large-scale feeling.
The next best thing to riding a sub to the bottom of the North Atlantic and prowling around the sunken ocean liner.
A grimly glam superhero tale that doesn't quite dare to hit the heights.
What sounds like a stunt, or a genre-mashup oddity like Bugsy Malone, proves to be a sharp, tongue-in-cheek exercise, balancing deadpan menace with well-timed comedy.
The movie has a tactile reality. You can almost smell it.
A thing of lean, cool beauty, the movie's a killer showcase for Foxx and Cruise.
It may feel like assembly-line work. But during a holiday movie season crammed with celluloid equivalents of filet mignon, sometimes it's good to chomp down on a decent burger.
Finally, a movie that can vie with Gigli as the worst feature of the new millennium.
A few good performances can't carry a sluggishly written and directed movie that you may want to rename Find Me an Exit.
Flawed but sincere -- the sort of thoughtful, adult movie that rarely appears in the summer.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A mockumentary often as unnerving as it is amusing, CSA: The Confederate States of America kicks off with a simple premise: What if the South had won 'the War of Northern Aggression'?
movie_title: CSA: The Confederate States of America (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Block Party is an easygoing, loose-limbed, big-lunged celebration of, well, celebration.
A blunt, awkward, wannabe Important Movie, Freedomland bludgeons its good ideas into a pulp of overacting, overdirection and black-and-white characterizations in a story meant to be shaded in gray.
Despite a meandering tone, Loggerheads is consistently watchable thanks to committed actors playing recognizable, decent folks just trying to do the right thing -- or rectify mistakes of the past.
Like minimalist composer Steve Reich's prickly, tense music on the soundtrack, the movie itself is too often too intellectual, experimental and abstract.
The movie is driven by the characters' passionate, despairing arguments about the fine line between victimization and violence. But Paradise Now also has, at times, an almost surreal visual flair.
Hoffman goes beyond impersonation to something close to possession.
A model of clean, lean storytelling.

The movie's most compelling element of all is Moreau, wandering the nighttime streets trying to find her lover. It's as if she's blown from one cafe to the next on a blended wind of passion, dread and the lonely trumpet wail.
movie_title: Elevator to the Gallows (Ascenseur pour l'échafaud) (1958)

movie_review_blurb: The actors are so committed to Potter's vision, they persuade you to go along with them.
Think of it as a visual tone poem about longing and loss, a journey through a vale of luminously beautiful tears.
A cool, sometimes chilly dissection of one couple's relationship.
Shot in long, single takes, the movie willfully tests your patience. You wish it would hurry up. Yet when it ends, it haunts you for a few days. (Well, me anyway.)
It's less a whodunnit than a whocares.
Stiles nails her feminazi, bound-for-Sarah Lawrence shtick, but just as easily melts into giggles or pulls off a slapstick drunk scene.
Makes sex seem the least exciting thing in the world. And that's a dirty shame, indeed.
Suffers from narrative shapelessness. It's hard to tell what message Miller is trying to convey.
movie_title: The Ballad of Jack and Rose (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There are two crucial bits of miscasting, one bad, one good, both distracting.
It's about the gradual wakening into awareness, the graduation from carefree youth to responsible adulthood.
What holds Vera Drake together is Vera herself -- a completely absorbing performance from Staunton.
Solemnly questioning issues of science and metaphysics, it creates a spell that's a unique blend of the ominous and the sensual.
The movie seems determined to be an instant Christmas classic, but its idea of seasonal awe comes straight off a factory conveyor belt.
Has such an engaging, offbeat first half that it's all the more frustrating when it gets lost inside its own convolutions and delayed revelations.
Penhall's screenplay captures the emotional isolation that grips people touched by cataclysm.
It's an overly calculated, schematic graph of a script that eliminates the things we go to the movies to experience: interesting characters, a story we can relate to, an emotional release.
The film's first half is hypnotically watchable.
Bardem's Ramón is such a vital life force, it's all the more bittersweet to watch him fight to leave a world that would be much emptier and sadder without him in it.
movie_title: The Sea Inside (Mar Adentro) (The Sea Within) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: By the time two newlywed couples lumber toward their honeymoons atop bejeweled elephants, the movie's frothy excess and good humor can make you say 'I do,' too.
Too littered with loose ends and 'huh?' moments to work as the edgy sci-fi thriller-romance it wants to be.
Sensory overload is the order of the day, Pacific Rim packing a punch with its bold and bright colour palette, sheer size and mega volume.
A perfect excuse for high levels of hysteria, mayhem, profanity.
A polite, if insubstantial, film-watching experience.
For a gore-free film, there are plenty of scares.
Manages to disappoint as the pair sleepwalk through the film, seemingly unaware of how abjectly unfunny it is.
Misses the chance to either match the first film's lofty levels of humour or make something truly different.
Side-splittingly hilarious, The World's End deftly balances its character work with lashings of comedy and impressive action sequences.
A simultaneous celebration and criticism of youth.
Impressive, superior drama.
Still proves as thrilling as ever.
Content to pitch most of its plot twists and gags squarely at kids.
With more romantic mushiness than the brain-chomping kind.
There's plenty to enjoy if you can look past the unconvincing emotional connections.
Lacks the laughs to hold up the appeal of a dumb comedy.
This Is 40 sees Apatow mistaking his personal life as the perfect fodder for another dramedy that stretches beyond a comfortable running time.
The result is a safe, pleasantly entertaining mainstream flick.
Give Courtney the lead role in a spin-off and call it a good day to wrap up.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: No shortage of large scale action on offer both on land and in space.
Shane Salerno's doco is at times also over-wrought, but luckily his subject is so damn intriguing that he carries Salinger through its most heavy-handed moments.
Avoids exposing the harsh truth that watching CGI creatures beat each other up has limited entertainment value.
It's hard to shake the sense of déjà vu as the film's narrative follows the trajectory of The Hunger Games a little too closely...
Makes The Fifth Element look like 2001 by comparison.
Densely crammed, unmistakeably excessive Quentin Tarantino dialogue, Django Unchained is his most exciting, accessible and satisfying film for ages.
An exciting thrill-ride that strikes a brilliant balance between jaw-dropping space scenes, anarchic wit and bountiful belly laughs.
If you're not looking for something that puts politics to the sword, but merely uses it to provide a backdrop for some gently prodding humour,The French Minister will provide a chuckle or two.
One of the best big budget films of the year.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Lord and Miller continue to mine a similar vein of absurdist gags, boosting the laughs-per-minute ratio of its predecessor.
We're here for the scares and chills, and on this front the film does enough in building atmosphere and providing the requisite frights to prove watchable.
Sight gags, slapstick and puns abound as you'd expect, with James Bobin again keeping the Muppets moving at a brisk pace, at least most of the time.
Incorporating props, visual effects, lasers and pyro in eye-popping fashion, it eventually starts to seem like an enormous 3D version of a backdrop from Guitar Hero.
It's satisfying to see this level of craftsmanship applied to a film that is often so silly it's a pure delight to watch.
More grounded than most high concept comedy.
For the first time with Her, the relationships Jonze brings to the big screen blossom into something bigger than the story and setting around them.
Ay-yi-yi, Frankenstein.
Better than it almost has any real right to be, José Padilha's RoboCop reboot is an example to Hollywood as to how they should be done.
I'd suggest taking off your Ron-tinted glasses and accepting that the first film isn't flawless, and that this isn't likely to top it. From there, proceed to laugh your ass off.
This efficient adaptation proves extremely watchable, and still packs an emotional punch.
Co-writer Armando Iannucci repeats what he pulled off with In The Loop by helping to pen a film that'll appeal to fans and newcomers alike...
Slow-burning adult drama full of chuckles derived from well-written characters and top-notch acting...
The result is a crime saga with the frequently jaw-dropping fight scenes you'd expect.
I liked it - but I can see why some won't.
Casey Affleck delivers a chilling performance as a sociopathic deputy sheriff whose charming veneer shatters as we're introduced to his taste for violence of both the straight-up and sexual kinds.
A crowd-pleaser, and one that is better than it really has any right to be.
Street racing is dialed down in favour of Ocean's Eleven-style heist plotting and favela gunplay straight out of Call Of Duty: Modern Warfare 2.
Problem is, the film's premise only stands up for about a few minutes. That's why it was written as a short story.
It's safe and boring
Morning Glory is as insubstantial as the telly it tries to make fun of.
Hampered by its lack of narrative tension or palpable sense of romance.
A pretty standard thriller framework, but one that Corbijn and Clooney infuse with mood and atmosphere, eliciting satisfying results.
An often-tense affair that comes with just the right amount of cynicism, a great cast, and one that treats the audience with a modicum of intelligence.
Cred points are on offer from the film's observational/improvisational style that bros Duplass bring along with them, but they've neglected the most important part - making the film interesting.
A surprisingly effective follow-up that replicates the creeping dread of the first film and deftly builds on the original storyline.
The balance of action and humour is off here and by dialing down the moments of ridiculousness from his other films with Ferrell, McKay has made them all the more glaringly odd.
Self-indulgent? Definitely. Funny? Mostly. Real? It actually doesn't matter.
"[Caine] elevates this grim vigilante-fest from pretty darn good to essential viewing."
A giant bland-fest, unleashing a misfiring charm offensive in place of strong characterisation or a story that has a destination in mind.
Haley just ain't no Englund, no matter how much he tries.
McKay does a spectacular job of nailing the booming voice, quivering jowls, quick-tempered impatience and larger-than-life presence of Welles.
A giant win for audiences and the degree to which filmmakers can respect their intelligence.
Linklater casts a spell that defies you to not be moved, and captures the incredible complexity, richness and emotion of every one of our unique lives in the process.
Engagingly funny.
An enormous share of the credit can be taken by Weta Digital and their brilliant CGI ape creations, which come across as living breathing entities with actual personalities.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The dude is so wooden it's like watching Pinocchio with abs.
Timberlake's charisma can't carry this but it's hard to think of anyone who could.
Hysteria goes through the motions without eliciting much of a reaction despite its seemingly racy subject matter.
A mix of pining, familial farce and sweet summer love story.
The Dark Knight Rises wraps in satisfying fashion, even if it may take a little while to fully grab you.
This functions as a much better-than-average blockbuster, and features some great uses of 3D...
The gang of walking, talking, mammalian chums prove as reliably consistent as ever.
Does its best to follow rom-com convention, but without a spark between the leads, a captivating narrative or decent dollop of humour, fails to do the minimum required...
Lives up to its immense potential.
Has no aspirations to be anything other than a blockbuster and on that front it fares okay.
A disappointing addition to the franchise.
This is the best action film in years, one that doesn't muck around in terms of getting things cracking and barely lets up for its running time.
Like Clooney's straightforward and unflashy directorial style, The Ides of March proves to be an effective drama.
Ends up being an unfulfilling blend of gritty realism and over-the-top kinetic editing.
Clint Eastwood's direction lacks focus, most notably in the film's pacing which makes J. Edgar's two-hour-plus running time feel even longer than it is,
This sequel underachieves when you look at what the contributors should collectively be capable of.
Albert Nobbs ends up being little more than a play on screen.
Pitched as a beautiful movie about the end of the world, Melancholia succeeds.
A hodge-podge of nonsense that is just really there to stitch together cool fight scenes and sets.
Contagion is a reminder that we're hardly in as much control of the globe as we think.
Worth a watch just for Williams and the charming tale it tells.
The leap from TV to feature film comes with risks, and again they're not negotiated entirely successfully.
One of the most exhilarating experiences I've had in the cinema in recent memory.
Predestination is more a movie to be regarded than swept up in.
Mostly feelgood tale that's an even more absurd Anvil: The Story of Anvil - but with muscles. And arguably even more compelling bandmates...
Violent fun, punctuated by laugh out loud moments and unexpectedly strong drama.
Doctor Strange boasts the most mind-bending visual effects I've ever seen...
A reminder of why [Oasis] got so much bloody attention in the first place.
You'll be beside yourself with a mix of laughter and incredulity.
Jennifer Kent's debut is an assured chiller that successfully piles on the dread, thanks to great casting and the creepy-as-all-hell character of the title.
Yes, Hollywood seems to be searching for a new Harry Potter franchise...
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A rare delight in how it respects the intelligence of its audience while still offering up lump-in-the-throat emotional beats in service of a welcomely straightforward story.
Sadly, that Felicity Jones isn't a standout as Rogue One's lead speaks to how more effort seems to have been spent on fan service than character development...
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Bolstered by news and home movie footage, you get a sense of how out-of-control the Beatles' touring life was...
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Can't rise above feeling like a current affairs profile piece with great production values and access.
Generally successful at earning audience laughs as it negotiates the terrain of being an averagely ok comedy you're likely to have forgotten before leaving the carpark.
While Greengrass can't resist shaking the camera too much, he's staged some impressive, tense, set-pieces that demand to be seen on the big screen.
The BFG turns out a winner, blending Dahl's big imagination with a surprisingly simple tale at its core that'll defy you to not be won over.
Stillman, Beckinsale, and Austen really share the honours here, though, in this witty, watchable, film.
Lacking in spectacle overall, light on adventure, and weakly written, it's hard to see how we're supposed to consider this legendary viewing.
So (barely) pubescent.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: You're not likely to get drug jokes, slapstick, a dildo-loving toddler and positive gender attitudes in any other above-average comedy sequel...
Simultaneously smart and populist viewing, and a great example of the genre.
Audiences will enthuse, chests will swell, and critics will struggle to avoid phrases like crowd-pleasing and heart-warming. Oh, bother.
Overlong, overly familiar in places and achingly, misguidedly, earnest in others...
Veering from the outrageous, hilarious, moments you'd expect to genuine bouts of melancholy, T2 is a bloody good film in its own right.
A great one-off idea brilliantly executed.
Even if you know what's coming in I, Tonya, this energetic biopic on disgraced Olympian figure skater Tonya Harding still packs surprises.
Should satisfy franchise fans, if not doing much more...
A watchable, if not enthralling, account of important events, and some notions that are perhaps more important today than they even were forty-something years ago.

The Disaster Artist proves to be a hilarious and heartfelt tale of ambition, friendship, and the imponderable mind of creative force Tommy Wiseau, played here in astonishingly believable fashion by director James Franco.
Brimming with humour and heart, innocent without being naive, and celebrating the joy of creativity...
Light on thrills, chemistry, or frights, Flatliners squanders a fun concept...
Easy-going in mood and pacing, Kedi patiently follows a variety of felines through their routines, seemingly living very charmed lives in a city that prides itself on taking care of its cats.
Berg shows respect for the Tsarnaevs' victims, while demonstrating his knack for the chaos of urban carnage and combat.
It may stumble but never entirely loses its footing.
'It' quickly proves unafraid of inflicting gore on innocent kids and boasts a freaking terrifying Pennywise thanks to Bill Skarsgård...
Reduced to a generic cartoon team-up mystic dimension-hopping action movie that barely functions...
Disappointingly, Valerian falls into the trap of constantly trying to dazzle with CGI spectacle, the bombardment of information quickly becoming a mind-numbing chore to look at in 3D.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A refreshingly entertaining film with a hell of a lot of heart.
From the get-go Dunkirk is a relentlessly tense affair...
McLaren stands as more a celebration than sombre eulogy ... and should hold differing types of appeal to various generations.
Audiences would be missing out on something really special here if they overlook the emotional punch Colossal packs out...
Only has surface-level entertainment to offer. It's some surface to behold though...
Considering how generic this slice of vaguely xenophobic counter-terror wish-fulfillment is, it comes as a surprise how bloody American Assassin turns out to be.
Content to wrap up in a politically-neutral and inoffensively tidy fashion that doesn't offend our intelligence.
You'd be correct to go into this film with low expectations. They'll eventually be met...
A hilarious, heartwarming tale that harnesses script, direction and performances and takes plenty of creative risks on its way to delivering movie magic.
[Paul] Dano is utterly fantastic, disappearing into the role...
An inessential sequel that's viscerally, if not emotionally or intellectually, stimulating.
A modern action classic that's not beholden to contemporary or past stylistic trends...
A welcome return of the Avengers amusing team dynamic and essentially asking "what more could you want?"
You're left wondering if there is such a thing as too much.
Leaves a gap that should be filled with gags.
Fails to ensnare its audience thanks to fatiguingly frequent "ah, bet you didn't see that coming" narrative twists.
Never predictable in when it will stun the senses or bore you into submission.
Yes, there are a few too many gags about his advancing years, but [Arnie's] return to being the Terminator is a welcome sight.
One of its many interesting facets is how unlike the unpredictable doco model it turns out to be while still proving utterly engrossing from start to finish.
A fitting send off - with the right number of endings to boot.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Katniss has little to do but react to the actions of others, though she does get to blow stuff up with her bow and enjoy a literal save the cat moment.
How could reteaming Jennifer Lawrence and Bradley Cooper go wrong? In a word - Serena.
Never has a nearly-three-hour blockbuster enthralled me in the way that Interstellar did.
Offers proof that a well-crafted, fight-filled revenge story is the type of pic least reliant on the English language to impress, which this does in spades.
A superior war film that doesn't shirk from sudden, shocking violence but still doesn't overplay its hand when it comes to man's inhumanity to man.
Pleasingly, the two Roberts (Downey Jr. and Duvall) who top the cast list and square off as father and son bring their acting A games...
Sherpa has little desire in hammering any particular message home, beyond offering a window into a seldom-seen culture.
Somehow more inspiring than disappointing, this account of Alejandro Jodorowsky's doomed effort to bring Dune to the big screen still manages to be a testament to artistic insanity and tenacity.
The pairing of Brand and Winterbottom also improves on Michael Moore-esque public stunts, since Brand is equally whip-smart, but eminently more likeable...
The robot Chappie is brought to life awesomely by actor Sharlto Copley and the boffins at WETA, and much of your tolerance for the film will hinge on whether you find Die Antwoord endearing or not.
The results are mixed, and that's being charitable.
Doesn't work as either something fresh, a modern womanifesto or laugh-filled effort.
This superior thriller arrives at a time when Hollywood mostly seems to have forgotten how to make 'em.
Successfully conveys appropriate levels of mania, panic and hilarity while maintaining a moral standpoint missing from other Wall Street tales.
It's amalgam of old and new, a thrill ride that satisfies in its own right as well as in assuaging the fears of fans.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Extended flat periods, and the sense of deja vu pervading its weaker moments.
For a film to render [Murray's] presence grating is a rare thing indeed, but that's what ends up happening here...
Its throwback elements offer more in the way of irritating limitations than timelessness.
[Indulges] the senses with its gore, set design and costuming, and drawing on the skills of its cast...
By taking chances... even Pan's failures help to distinguish it from typical Hollywood kids cash-in fare.
Serves up the scariest, most watchable film about real estate since Beetlejuice.
[A] somewhat puzzling, if ever-watchable, experience.
A better sequel than expected, even if its mid-series stakes never truly seem serious.
Clement is better-suited as a foil to Conchord-like absurdity, where it works as a droll counterweight.
Like most of the musical culture it idolises, it is sub-par.
